fields.headline: Preston crash back to earth
fields.standfirst: Preston North End 1 - 2 Barnsley
fields.trailText: Preston North End 1 - 2 Barnsley
fields.body:
Dave Bassett, the former Wimbledon manager, knows a thing or two about upsetting the apple cart. Although his Barnsley team have yet to develop a penchant for wild antics on or off the pitch, they have eagerly adopted Wimbledon's taste for springing surprises.

Without an away win in the First Division all season, only Barnsley's most passionate supporters would have backed them to beat Preston who, until last night, boasted an unbeaten home record. But goals by Bruce Dyer and Mike Sheron, along with an inspired display by the goalkeeper Kevin Miller, ensured that the home fans' memories of Tuesday's excellent 1-0 victory over Fulham were quickly erased.

It is unlikely, however, that Preston's long-suffering supporters will have been shocked by last night's letdown. While expectations were high, the club has experienced enough turbulence to dampen any extravagant ambitions.

Thirty years have passed since they had previously hosted Barnsley in a league game. On that occasion they won 3-1, but instead of heralding a return to former glories they quickly found themselves on a downward spiral which eventually saw them floundering in the old Fourth Division.

From that point on Deepdale crumbled; the lush grass pitch was replaced by a synthetic surface and John Beck brought his reviled long-ball game to a club famed for Tom Finney's dribbling skills. But the appointment of David Moyes as manager 2 years ago prompted something of a rebirth and now, following their win at Fulham, Preston find themselves genuine contenders for a place in the Premiership next season.

Last night's events did little for their cause as Barnsley, despite an indifferent start to the season, made the early running. Matty Appleby shot over the top on 12 minutes when David Lucas' punch failed to clear the area, only moments after a cross by Appleby had gone to waste when Graham Alexander cleared the ball after watching it trickle across the six-yard box.

Preston rallied briefly but Jon Macken and Erik Meijer were both foiled by Miller, and it was left to Dyer to break the deadlock. A long ball by the captain Steve Chettle found Lucas stranded, and Dyer was on hand to lob the ball over his head and into the empty net.

Sheron came on at half-time and doubled Barnsley's lead with a classic chest-trap and volley. Preston fought like madmen to close the gap, but by the time Macken waltzed through the Barnsley defence in the 86th minute it was too late. Now they know how Fulham felt.

webTitle: From blue to red without tears

fields.headline: From blue to red without tears
fields.standfirst: With his first Merseyside derby in a red shirt looming, Nicky Barmby may draw some reassurance from the last man to make the same journey across Stanley Park. Mind you, that was 41 years ago
fields.trailText: With his first Merseyside derby in a red shirt looming, Nicky Barmby may draw some reassurance from the last man to make the same journey across Stanley Park. Mind you, that was 41 years ago.
fields.body:
When Everton met Liverpool at Wembley for the 1984 Charity Shield in only the clubs' second meeting at Wembley, Bill Kenwright invited Dave Hickson and his wife Pat along to the match.

Hickson is the boyhood hero of Kenwright - the Everton fan who did a Victor Kiam and bought the club he loves - and, almost uniquely, a former No9 for both clubs. "The build-up to that game was amazing," Hickson recalls. "As we walked down Wembley Way the fans were all singing and shouting to us - both sets of supporters, Everton and Liverpool. I just felt so proud."

Should such an occasion arise again, however, it is a fair bet that Nick Barmby would neither be invited nor would he contemplate walking to the stadium following his £6m move to Liverpool last summer, when he announced he wanted to go to Anfield after returning from Euro 2000 as an Everton player.

Two weeks later he signed on the dotted line to become the first player to make that particular move since Hickson himself in November 1959, when he cost Liverpool £12,000.

Tomorrow Barmby will come face to face with his old team-mates for the first time and while it will not be as acrimonious as last week's return of Real's Luis Figo to Barcelona, Liverpool's No20 is unlikely to be taking corners at the Anfield Road End. "The supporters may give Nicky a bad time and he will be nervous, but he's the kind of lad who can handle it," Hickson says.

For Hickson it was not such a big issue, even though he was and is an Everton legend after scoring 95 league goals in 225 games, though the fact that Liverpool were in the old Second Division when he became the final buy of Phil Taylor, the man who soon gave way for Bill Shankly, undoubtedly helped.

Hickson, having moved to Aston Villa for £17,500 in 1955 and a few months later on to Huddersfield, where Denis Law was his inside-forward and the future Liverpool manager was the coach, did not want to leave the city of Liverpool again after Everton had repatriated him in 1957.

"I was left out at Everton, I think for disciplinary reasons, but I was playing all right," Hickson says. "Then Liverpool came in and it seemed as though Everton would let me go. I got one or two abusive letters from Liverpool supporters after I signed, saying that I was trying to take over from Billy [Liddell]. But that was untrue, he was one of my idols, too."

If there were any lingering doubts, however, Hickson soon silenced them. "I scored two on my debut and we beat Villa 2-1. A young lad of 16 or 17 ran on to the pitch and said to me 'you're one of us now'. I've met him since and we had a laugh about it, but I thought 'I will never be one of them'. But I gave 100% everywhere I played and if you do that in this city they love you."

Hickson scored 37 goals in 60 league games for Liverpool and, though it helped them to two third-place finishes, only the top two went up to the First Division. He did face Everton in a floodlit game at Anfield as well as a Liverpool Senior Cup tie at Goodison, but he was established in the team by then and recalls no particular angst.

Indeed for a man who later went on to complete the unique feat of signing for a third Merseyside club, Tranmere, he played in very few derbies, though he was on the pitch in Everton's 4-0 home defeat in the 1955 FA Cup and played both games in the Floodlit Challenge tournament of 1957, arranged to open the respective clubs' lights and which Everton won 4-3 on aggregate. "The atmosphere was brilliant," he says. "I don't think there's anything like playing at 3 o'clock on a Saturday, but this was something new."

The lights will be back on tomorrow - the clocks go back tonight - but Hickson, 71 on Monday, will not be there, though he gets to Everton's home games in his role as a match-day host and PR officer for the club.

In that time he has also struck up a rapport with many of the players, not least the current No9. "Kevin [Campbell] is a great friend who really wants to do well," he says, "and I like David Weir who, though he plays for Scotland, is very underrated. And there's Gazza who's reformed, lost a stone and is enjoying his football again.

"They've only beaten us only once recently [3-2 in 1998] but Danny [Cadamarteri] was pulled back a few times. We've got the Indian sign on them and I don't think we'll get beat."

fields.headline: Graham holds on to dream
fields.standfirst: Tottenham fans still have not warmed to their manager. Roy Collins hears his side of the story
fields.trailText: Tottenham fans still have not warmed to their manager. Roy Collins hears his side of the story.
fields.body:
Apart from the odd groan, George Graham's second anniversary as Tottenham manager passed quietly this month, though from the moment he nosed his car through the White Hart Lane gates, he knew to expect more brickbats than bouquets.

Any billets-doux would, in any case, most likely have borne an N5 postmark, where he is still remembered fondly by Arsenal fans and where the Gunners' soaring success continues to underscore the distance, at least in footballing miles, between the two north London clubs.

Graham understands that a certain section of the Tottenham crowd, who again chanted for his dismissal last weekend, will never accept him because of his Arsenal past. But though he boasts broad shoulders beneath the trademark designer raglan overcoat, he betrays frustration that fans cannot appreciate that a manager's work is, like an iceberg's mass, four-fifths below the surface.

He says: "When I arrived here, the place was in a mess, just like Leeds was. And a manager's first task is to do what I call the dirty work, making unpopular decisions and getting rid of people. Things had drifted so far here that 50% of the players needed to go. It's impossible to get 50% of players in and 50% out in two years but I've got rid of most of them.

"Also, players were swaggering off the training pitch because they had avoided relegation. Swaggering! I couldn't believe it. I told them straight off that there'd be no more swaggering and now we've got a proper direction at the training ground, as I hope we have at the club."

Although he admits that he had hoped, by this time, to have travelled a little farther down the road to Damascus, or any Champions League destination, he believes Tottenham fans who cannot see the progress lack a grasp of reality.

The faded prints of the 1960-61 Double heroes which adorn the walls of Spurs Lodge, Tottenham's training complex, including one outside Graham's office, suggest that the club, like the fans, lives in sepia-toned nostalgia. But the terrace chant that most angers Graham is the one about fans wanting their old Tottenham back.

"I don't know what that means", he says. "Tottenham are no longer one of the top five clubs yet they are supposed to have been playing this wonderful football over the years. And where did it lead to? A cup here and there? If the club is as big as everyone likes to believe, they should have been challenging for the championship. The funny thing is that while I am a villain, Bobby Robson is a messiah at Newcastle - and he has only two points more than us."

Graham talks of the dirty work Alex Ferguson had to perform at Old Trafford, destroying the influence of the Manchester mafia and assorted hangers-on before he was able to start building a successful team. And he dismisses as an urban myth the story that Ferguson came within finger-slicing distance of the axe, insisting that the board knew what he was doing and were always going to stick by him.

The White Hart Lane detractors claim that, far from giving them their Tottenham back, Graham is trying to fob them off with a second-hand version of the old Arsenal, playing boring, long-ball football. And while Arsenal have been among the biggest spenders in the Premiership of late, Graham and chairman Alan Sugar are seen as men vying for the affections of the chancellor Gordon Brown's much vaunted love, Prudence.

Graham answers that by pointing to the £11m spent on Sergei Rebrov. And he says that only the most desperate clubs would spend huge sums before the uncertainty about the future of transfer fees is resolved.

He claims that success can no longer be gained quickly because players are much harder to acquire. He can no longer steal players from the lower leagues, as he did at Arsenal when scouting lacked today's computer-aided sophistication, any more than Arsène Wenger can smuggle in any more unknown young French stars.

He says: "We have got some terrific quality of players here but I need six more. To bring those in, I either have to gamble on players no one else spots at low prices, spend £60m or £70m for ready-made ones, which I haven't got, or bring on some kids. The last one is the route I prefer, domestic players who have a certain affection for the club and I already have a couple of promising ones in Alton Thelwell and Ledley King."

What is threatening to give supporters a collective thrombosis is that their most famous homegrown product, Sol Campbell, already has his head halfway over the garden wall and the fear is that he will drop over the other side when his contract expires at the end of the season.

If he does, Graham will be blamed for not selling him for £20m in the summer. But he says: "There is a great myth about that. If selling him had been on the cards, it would have made sense and I think it would have been done. But Sol decided last season that he was going to see his contract out, no matter who came in for him and he won't discuss it with me or the club. He won't even listen to an offer from us until his contract has expired."

Graham believes Sugar will honour his own contract, regardless of the flak he receives. He says: "We are like Newcastle and Everton, big clubs who have lost their way. But the great thing about football is that you must never lose the dream that if you get things right and build properly, you can recover and go on to great things again. Leeds were on their knees five years ago but look at them now."

Spurs fans may not appreciate the irony. But having been condemned as hopeless romantics by outsiders, they are now accused by Graham of not believing more strongly in their dreams.

webTitle: Football at war over transfer changes

fields.headline: Football at war over transfer changes
fields.standfirst: The European transfer task force has run aground after discussions in Zurich descended, all too predictably, into bickering
fields.trailText: The European transfer task force has run aground after discussions in Zurich descended, all too predictably, into bickering .
fields.byline: Matthew Joseph  in Zurich and  Russell Thomas
fields.body:
Sepp Blatter's much-vaunted "football family" was at war last night after Fifa's president accused Gordon Taylor, chairman of the European players' union, of "decapitating" the task force charged with finding an alternative to the game's transfer system. Taylor retorted that the task force had a "hidden agenda".

So at the end of an acrimonious and confusing day - after two years of talking - football found itself in disarray only four days before the deadline set by the European commission to issue concrete proposals over the issue threatening to destabilise the game and bring chaos.

Blatter and Taylor exchanged angry words at a press conference which had been called to show unanimity between all parties before Tuesday's meeting with the commission in Brussels.

The players' union, Fifpro, had earlier boycotted the final session of talks dealing with the commission's legal concerns over the current transfer system because Taylor believed the players' concerns were not being addressed. Instead he sent alternative proposals to the meeting, only for them to be completely ignored.

Later Taylor made an impromptu appearance at Fifa's headquarters here, with Blatter publicly demanding that the chief executive of England's Professional Footballers' Association explain why he had not turned up at the meeting.

As other task force members looked on with a mixture of support and embarrassment, Taylor launched into a lengthy monologue in defence of his players' interests.

Clearly not liking what he was hearing, Blatter interrupted, shouting for Taylor to "answer the question". Finally Blatter stopped Taylor completing what he had been asked to do.

Taylor said: "We have attended at least a dozen meetings, all of which have ignored the main problem. The proposals the task force is putting forward are ambiguous and look as though they have been drafted with the hidden agenda of maintaining the status quo." He said the union would now give the commission its own proposals.

Blatter admitted there were fundamental disagreements between the task force and players' representatives but conceded "we know we cannot have these new regulations in place without the players."

Earlier he outlined several key areas of consensus, notably banning international transfers for players under 18 and agreeing on the principle of compensation for players under 23.

The sticking point remains what to do about players over 23 switching clubs at will while still under contract.

The plan in the case of a player moving from one country to another is for an independent tribunal to determine compensation with 12 specific criteria for resolving broken contracts.

For a player moving within the same country, national law will take precedence. But this raises the question of how to reconcile the different labour laws of the European Union's 15 states.

The task force chairman Per Omdal said proposals included the protection of young players, the introduction of two annual transfer windows and an acceptance that clubs could no longer hold the registration of players against their will. But he left several complex questions unanswered and said: "It is no secret that duration of contract has been one of the most difficult subjects under discussion."

Taylor is convinced the task force's recommendations will fall flat. He wants compensation based entirely on salary and remaining length of contract, and accused Fifa and Uefa, the European game's body, of trying to retain much of the system which has been deemed illegal by Brussels.

"We tried to reach agreement but will now instead be giving our own set of proposals to the commission because I'd be astounded if what is on the table is accepted. It simply doesn't give the commission the clarity they are looking for."

The prime minister Tony Blair lambasted the commission yesterday for its plan to scrap transfer fees, describing the change as "wrong" and calling for a "commonsense" rethink. Speaking in Spain, he said many small clubs, which rely on transfer money, would be forced to close. Blair was backed by his Spanish counterpart Jose Maria Aznar .

Uefa-Fifa proposals

1 Abolition of international transfers for players under 18.

2 Compensation for clubs developing players under the age of 23.

3 A 12-point set of criteria for compensating clubs for broken contract by players over 23

4 Minimum three year contract periods

Players' objections

1 Compensation for players over 23 to be based on salary and length of contract

2 Maximum length of contract to be two years

webTitle: How the understanding understudy has grown up

fields.headline: How the understanding understudy has grown up
fields.standfirst: After Rivaldo bring on Stan Collymore. It's all in the line of fire, Paul Robinson tells Dominic Fifield
fields.trailText: After Rivaldo bring on Stan Collymore. It's all in the line of fire, Paul Robinson tells Dominic Fifield.
fields.body:
Paul Robinson can pinpoint exactly when he succumbed to momentary self-doubt. It was at 7.40pm on Tuesday at Elland Road, to a cacophony of frenzied chants and blaring fanfares, as the visiting Barcelona players moved down the line shaking hands with their opponents. In a split second of blind panic, the Leeds goalkeeper shuddered in disbelief.

"He came up and shook my hand before moving on to the next man," says Robinson. "I just thought to myself 'That was Rivaldo. He's the World Footballer of the Year. What the hell am I doing here?'"

Robinson could be forgiven his brief flurry of nerves. After all, the latest bright young thing to spring into the limelight in West Yorkshire was a veteran of just five first-team appearances when he stumbled off the bench to replace the injured Nigel Martyn against Charlton a fortnight ago. Since then he has kept a Champions League clean sheet in Istanbul, spared Leeds a hammering at Old Trafford and so nearly knocked Rivaldo off his perch.

With his manager David O'Leary's words no doubt still ringing in his ears - "Paul will go on to play for England" - the 21-year-old will open negotiations tomorrow with the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale over a new five-year contract, with wages to match. Then comes the small matter of attempting to ruin Stan Collymore's big day at Valley Parade. All in all, it has been a whirlwind two weeks.

"It's slowly sinking in," he says. "I'm just trying to do my job and fill a hole. Nigel was running around the pitch this morning and that's good news for the club." He pauses before adding with a smile: "But I think he'll be a few weeks away yet."

Robinson is clearly relishing his chance to impress. Bolstered by some fine displays for the England under-21s, he made a mockery of his tender age by shutting out Besiktas on Leeds's emotional return to Turkey. At Old Trafford last week it was his acrobatics that kept heads up and the score down, while against Barcelona on Tuesday Robinson's virtuoso display pushed the Catalans to the brink of elimination from the Champions League.

Rivaldo, his reputation long forgotten, was thwarted with a quartet of stunning saves; Alfonso sunk to his knees in frustration after seeing his point-blank header clawed away. Then, four minutes into injury-time, Gerard struck a post and up popped the Brazilian to condemn Robinson to another nail-biting European night at the San Siro in 10 days.

"When you're in a game like that with that kind of atmosphere you just don't have time to think 'Jesus, that's Rivaldo charging towards me'," he says.

"You just have to save the thing that's flying at you. That's what I did. It was a pleasing performance, but after the game it felt like a defeat. I honestly believed that it was going to be our night. But we're still in it and are more than capable of doing well in Milan. They are already through and the San Siro will be incredible."

Regardless of how he performs on such a lofty stage, Robinson is aware that once the England No2 has regained his fitness he will return to his former role of understanding understudy. He remains philosophical over playing second fiddle to a goalkeeper of Martyn's ability - and fitness.

"When you have been sat on the bench for so long you do start wondering if your chance will ever come," he says. "You get nervous contemplating whether you'll get on or not. And then your chance comes along and there are doubts. You have to be strong-minded.

"Last year was frustrating. I was down quite a few times and my girlfriend Rebecca took the brunt of it. She had to put up with most of my moods.

"There were chances to move on but the gaffer told me he didn't want me to go out on loan and I wanted to stay. I've been here since I was 14 and I love this club.

"Nigel is a brilliant keeper who has proved himself at all levels. I've got to try and follow him. When he comes back in I'll happily sit back on the bench and start to learn again."

For his part, Martyn has urged Peter Taylor, who tried to sign Robinson for Leicester last month, to promote the 21-year-old to the full England squad to travel to Turin next month.

"The experience would not do him any harm," says Martyn. "I would rate Paul as the best young keeper in the country, although he does need to be playing reg ularly. His performance against Barcelona kept us in the Champions League."

But the youngster concedes: "That would be a very big step to make at the moment. I've only played two or three games. Let's not get carried away.

"At the moment I don't think that's an option. Nigel and I are close friends and I'd better slip him a fiver for saying that."

Instead, Robinson's immediate sights are set on local rivals Bradford City, struggling at the foot of the table with only four goals.

However, City sport a new-look front line of Collymore and Benito Carbone, who have explosive, if unpredictable potential.

"There are stars in every Premiership team these days and we'll be treating it just as if we were playing the likes of Barcelona," he adds.

"Given that I haven't played that many games, it is literally just as big for me.

"I know Stan has scored a few on his various debuts over the years, so it would be nice to shut him out," says Robinson.

"I just don't want all this to end."

webTitle: Zidane left red-faced with five-game ban

fields.headline: Zidane left red-faced with five-game ban
fields.trailText: Zinedine Zidane has been banned for five European matches for butting an opponent during Juventus's defeat by Hamburg on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Zinedine Zidane has been banned for five European matches for butting an opponent during Juventus's defeat by Hamburg on Tuesday.

The France midfielder received his second red card of the competition for slamming his forehead into the face of the defender Jochen Kientz. Zidane will miss the final first-phase match at Panathinaikos and two-thirds of the next group stage if Juventus qualify.

Rangers have been told by the Spanish referee Antonio Lopez Nieto that their appeal against his dismissal of Arthur Numan for two bookable offences during Wednesday's Champions League tie at Sturm Graz will fail.

Rangers will appeal to Uefa over the first caution for re- entering play without permission because television evidence appears to show Nieto waving for Numan to come on. But Nieto said: "Uefa contacted me on Thursday as I was returning from Austria and I told them my version of events. They seemed to accept what I said, that I didn't wave him on but was saying for him to wait. I cannot see how the decision will be changed."

Investigators have searched the home and offices of the former Bayer Leverkusen coach Christoph Daum after his positive drugs test.

"We are investigating him on suspicion of possessing cocaine," said Erich Jung, the chief state prosecutor in the western town of Koblenz. Jung added that investigators had seized written papers and computer data from Daum's office and other items from his home.

webTitle: Oldest club enjoys new lease of life

fields.headline: Oldest club enjoys new lease of life
fields.standfirst: Today's FA Cup fourth qualifying round could see non-league Sheffield add a new chapter to their history, the longest, if not the most illustrious, the game has
fields.trailText: Today's FA Cup fourth qualifying round could see non-league Sheffield add a new chapter to their history, the longest, if not the most illustrious, the game has.
fields.body:
In studying the history of Sheffield, the world's oldest football club of any code, you can skip over most of the 1900s. This century, though, already looks more promising.

Sheffield, who play in the Northern Counties East League, began this season with 10 successive wins. They have already won five FA Cup matches this season, which is more than they won in the first 53 years of the last century. And if they can win again today at Bramall Lane against Northwich Victoria, the oldest club in the Conference, they will be in the first round of the Cup for the first time since the qualifying competition was introduced in 1888.

"Success has bred success," says their joint team manager John Pearson, the former Leeds and Sheffield Wednesday striker. "And it's a good habit to have."

Sheffield held their 143rd anniversary dinner this week, a celebration that should have caused a little queasiness in Australia. Sheffield were founded on October 24 1857, at a meeting in a Heeley greenhouse called by two army officers stationed at Hillsborough barracks. The Melbourne Football Club, which Professor Geoffrey Blainey and others have claimed as the world's oldest, was set up the following year. "Are you going to give him the bad news or am I?" says Sheffield's chairman Richard Tims.

Sheffield teams played to rules very similar to Melbourne's, but various accommodations were reached with the Football Association. The Sheffield club first appeared in the Cup in its third edition, in October 1873, when they drew 0-0 with Shropshire Wanderers. Northwich, founded the following year, debuted in 1883 with a 1-0 win over Druids.

These clubs are so old they were playing before there were referees, leagues or crossbars. Between them they have reached the Cup quarter-finals on four occasions - all before professionalism was legalised.

Sheffield won the Amateur Cup in 1904, beating Ealing Association 3-1 at Valley Parade. They reached the FA Vase final in 1977, losing out to Billericay. In between there were some fallow years, including a run of 24 Cup defeats in 25 ties and humiliations at the hands of Brodsworth Main Colliery (9-0), Atlas and Norfolk Works (6-0) and Treeton Reading Room (4-1).

When Pearson took over, he and the club were close to despair. He was injured and unable to find a club that would employ him. Sheffield were bottom of the table and playing at Owlerton stadium on a pitch so tight that players were forced to back up on the dog track to take corners. It was January and they had only six points. Relegation was escaped on the last day of the season.

Next month, if the new stand and floodlights can be completed, they will move out of the Don Valley stadium to the Coach and Horses in Dronfield, a pub with an attached ground in a town of about 27,000 south of the city and, indeed, south of the county, in Derbyshire. Tims and his fellow directors have put up the money to buy the ground and the pub.

"The idea is to capture 27,000 people," Tims says. "It's back to grassroots football: a pie, a pint and a game and all back home in time for tea."

Sheffield's public may be ready for a success story. Matters have been going so poorly with those upstarts at Wednesday (founded 1867) and United (1889) that some may have begun to doubt the wisdom of the Sheffield association throwing in its lot with the FA in 1878.

Anyone who doubts that a game with marks, infinitely high goals and no offside rule could prosper into this century has not been paying attention. The Australian Football League boasts an average crowd of 34,000, which is rather more than will attend any of today's Cup games.

Melbourne are thriving too. They lost in the AFL grand final this year, in front of 100,000 at the MCG. Sheffield may have to wait a while before they can match that, but in one respect they will always be one better.

webTitle: Actually I'm free on Saturday afternoons, Mr Crozier

fields.headline: Actually I'm free on Saturday afternoons, Mr Crozier
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: Ron's doing his bit for Queen and country.
fields.body:
'! #%**@**! blindin' lad! ... #%**@**! top!" ... Ho ho! ... in my continuing search for England's "missing link" ... I've collared Peter Reid! in the player's lounge at Villa Park after last week's miserable goalless draw ... to ask his views on the "Mackems" hairless hotshot Kevin Phillips! ... "Has he the potential to 'do it' at the top level? ..." "!#%**@**! Right lad!" ... Ho ho, the seasoned scouser may be a little bit "salty" for some tastes but he gets results! ... Villa 0 Sunderland 0!

... But managing a team's not all about, er, effing ... blinding and flinging, er ... fookin' tea cups! ... And as for the England job? ... Well, although I haven't been approached by the FA ... I'm very flattered nonetheless! ... but don't forget the other names in the frame!

Last week it was all "Robson! ... no experience! ... Robson! ... vast experience!" ... Now it's "Taylor! ... er ... Turnip Taylor? ... too much experience!" Oh! ... Peter Taylor! ... Cloughie's Taylor? ... No! ... another Taylor ... what? ... bloody hell! ...

Ah yes! ... Star player of Malcolm Allison's Palace team of the 70s! ... broke Chelsea hearts on Valentine's Day ... '76 wasn't it ... punk rock not yet in its pomp! ... but furious pogo-ing to Knees up Mother Brown at the Bridge ... safety-pins and rivers of "gob" rolling turgidly down the King's Road! ... marvellous!

Er ... yes! ... that Peter Taylor ... isn't it? ... Just one game to bring a bit of temporary respect back to the England team ... or will we once again be the laughing stocks of international football? ... Ho ho... "Mr Grimsdale ... Mr Grimsdale" isn't it? ... marvellous! ... "Trouble in Store" ... isn't it? ... most likely! ... But Peter's famous Norman Wisdom impersonations do help to build team spirit and relieve the tension ... and show me an England team that hasn't had its fair share of clowns over the years!

And a sense of humour is always a big hit with the ladies as well ... I can tell you! ... Ho ho, I remember a night on the town back in the 70s with Big Ron Atkinson and Jim Smith after a charity performance of Hair ... and in those days people in the football world did have hair! ... ho ho ... not Bald Eagle, mind!

Down to the Purple Pussycat ... footloose and fancy-free! ... thanks to that tabloid photo-shoot of me doing The Hustle with Clodagh Rodgers ... And a bit of a slow night ... when in strolls Malcolm Allison! ... trademark cigar ... big fedora ... and a dolly-bird on each arm! ... a couple of go-go dancers from the show!

Big Mal's "givin' it all that", as Tel would say ... rest of us can't get a word in edgeways ... "When's a biscuit tin like a fountain?" ... "Hee hee, stop it ... stop it!" ... "When it's a square tin!" ... "Ah ha ha... oh Mal! ... you're priceless!"

... But all that bubbly ... hmm? ... even Big Mal's got to slope off for a leak eventually ... Bingo! ... and I've steamed in with my impersonation of Freddie "Parrot-Face" Davies ... "Thrrrp ..." the girls lapping it up! ... "Thentimental thongth ... thentimental mel..." When blow me! ... Bald Eagle's trying to trump me by doing his Max Wall! ... very poor! ... looks like I've cracked it but ...

"Eeeeeeeeeeeeeeh!" ... It's Big Ron Atkinson ... hauling his sheepskin coat behind him on a bit of string! ... "Schnorbitz! ... Heel boy!" ... "Eeeeeeeeeeeeeeh!" ... and Big Ron's "bang-on Bernie Winters" has bagged him the crumpet!

Sections of the press have been questioning my ability to juggle the job of England coach with my shelf-stacking duties at Quik-Save ... it's only Saturday mornings, Mr Crozier! ... I'm free in the afternoon! ... As for "too old!" ... I have the energy of someone a tenth my age! ... ask Mrs Manager!

... Monday! ... down to Southampton, Man City ... bloody awful! ... But Glenn's raising spirits at the Dell! ... working his magic! ... he'll soon have the perennial Premiership strugglers ... er ... struggling on an annual basis!

I spent most of the second half struggling to stay awake! ... drifting in and out of a strange reverie ... Did I really hear the Tannoy announce, "Man of the match ... Marian Pahars!" ... What? ... a woman? ... But throughout the evening ... that strange recurring dream ... check my Top Tip!

And no ... I haven't heard from the FA ... though obviously I'm honoured ... Meantime ... over the next 11 weeks ... let me reveal Ron's England Dream Team! ... I'm building from the back!

A lack of width? ... hmm? ... not in Ron's squad! No1 ... Goalie! ... Neville Southall! ... Back between the sticks for Bradford City last season? ... there's one in the eye for the young'uns! The big man may have packed on the pounds a bit but he can still lumber across the six-yard line and bundle the ball away ... hmm? ... Marvellous!

Yes ... Big Nev ... a credit to his profession! ... used to be a bin-man you know! ... What? ... a Taff? ... er ... how about Big Jack as assistant manager then?

Just time for a quick peek at the European scene? ... Mighty Juventus ... down to nine men ... turned over by lowly Hamburg! ... Well you don't negotiate the choppy waters of the group stage without the captain at the helm! ... Zidane? ... Zidane you're rockin' the boat! ... Ho ho! ... one to relish for the Hamburgers!

Ron Manager was talking to Eileen Drewery over a bottle of snake-oil at Southampton's "palace in the sky". © Paul Whitehouse and Jim Reilly 2000

webTitle: Camara focuses on life away from Liverpool

fields.headline: Camara focuses on life away from Liverpool
fields.standfirst: Guinean striker asks to be placed on the transfer list after failing to start a first team game at Anfield this season
fields.trailText: Guinean striker asks to be placed on the transfer list after failing to start a first team game at Anfield this season.
fields.body:
Titi Camara yesterday conceded that his brief and turbulent Liverpool career was all but over by asking to be placed on the transfer list.

The 27-year-old Guinea international striker has finally tired of playing in the reserves and is likely to be sold to the highest bidder.

The final straw for Camara came on Thursday night when the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier chose not to introduce him as a second-half substitute in the Uefa Cup tie against Slovan Liberec.

Although Camara spent more than 15 minutes warming up on the touchline - receiving rapturous applause in the process - Houllier opted to introduce two midfielders, Nick Barmby and Gary McAllister, to a team struggling to find a goal.

Liverpool paid the French club Marseille more than £2.5m for Camara 18 months ago but, despite scoring 10 goals in 37 appearances, he has not featured in a senior fixture this season.

Everton's Abel Xavier is wanted by Benfica, one of his former clubs. Although Walter Smith would sanction the sale of the Portugal defender, it is thought unlikely that the cash-strapped Lisbon club would be able to meet an asking price of about £3m.

The Football Association last night denied reports that it had approached Lazio's coach Sven-Goran Eriksson about taking the England job.

Eriksson's assistant Tord Grip told a Swedish newspaper that the 52-year-old had been contacted "to ask if he is interested" and that Eriksson was "very flattered to receive this offer". But an FA spokes-man said: "Adam Crozier [the chief executive] will be the only one making an approach and he has made no such approach to Sven-Goran Eriksson or the other two candidates."

Colin Todd's proposed move to become Derby County's assistant manager took another twist when Swindon said he was still their manager and asked him to take a few days' leave "to allow the matter to resolve itself". The Second Division side have refused an offer of compensation.

webTitle: English success in Europe can be dangerous

fields.headline: English success in Europe can be dangerous
fields.standfirst: In terms of distracting competitors from their domestic chores, a European League is here in all but name. David Lacey assesses the damage so far
fields.trailText: In terms of distracting competitors from their domestic chores, a European League is here in all but name.
fields.body:
The Premiership may be a fortnight away from discovering what it is really like to be competing for attention with a European league. Already there have been plenty of hints but when the draw for the second group phase of the Champions League is made on Friday week reality may dawn.

This is because there is a distinct possibility that Arsenal, Manchester United and Leeds could all be going into a draw which will involve them in regular European activity until mid-March and maybe beyond.

Arsenal are already through and Leeds need just a point in the San Siro against Milan, who have also qualified, to join them. United have to beat Dynamo Kiev, who cannot qualify, at Old Trafford to progress.

For the Premiership the prospect of increasingly playing second fiddle to English interests in the Champions League is not a happy one. Already the domestic championship is starting to look like a straight fight between United and Arsenal, who both have shown that they can rest important players for Europe and still win routine domestic games.

The match at Old Trafford last Saturday morning could be the regular shape of things to come. Both United and Leeds faced crucial Champions League matches 72 hours later with the result that a fixture which is normally one of the showpieces of the Premiership's season was well populated with spear-carriers.

Sir Alex Ferguson left Ryan Giggs and Andy Cole on the bench and brought on David Beckham only after Roy Keane had been injured. David O'Leary counted Ian Harte, Olivier Dacourt, Eirik Bakke and Danny Mills among his many casualties but all played against Barcelona on Tuesday night.

Given the fact that each club reaching the next round of the Champions League stands to gain an extra £8m it is difficult to argue with such priorities. At the same time the Premiership's status as the most intensely competitive, though not the most technically accomplished, league in the world will be called into question if it continues to be won by teams who increasingly reserve their fuller strengths for a more rewarding competition.

Should Uefa ever bend to the will of its major clubs and, by implication, the leading television companies and accept the formation of a TV-oriented European league it will be a bad day for the Premiership and its equivalents in Italy, Spain, France, Germany and so on.

For as Joan Gaspart, the president of Barcelona, said before this week's game at Elland Road: "Leeds against Barcelona is very important but I'm not sure it's more important than Leeds against Liverpool, Leeds against Manchester United or Leeds against Arsenal."

Last Saturday night the scenes at the Nou Camp proved Gaspart's point when Barcelona beat Real Madrid against a background of passion whose temperature soared way beyond the norm for the average Champions League game. Not only was this a renewal of hostilities between Catalonia and the Spanish capitalists but Luis Figo, a Portuguese mercenary recently in the pay of Barca, had the temerity to turn up wearing the opposition's colours.

Nick Barmby, who recently forsook Everton for Liverpool, is unlikely to be quite so fiercely reviled by his erstwhile fans at tomorrow's Merseyside derby. But the game will generate more heat than Thursday's tepid Uefa Cup encounter between Liverpool and Slovan Liberec, who for all the Kop knew, were a team of Czech pianists with a penchant for candelabra.

The G15 lobby group, which includes Arsenal, United and Liverpool, as well as the leading clubs of Spain, Italy, Germany, France, Holland and Belgium, appear as hellbent as ever on getting a fully fledged European league up and running within the next five years.

Running parallel to this is the idea of an Atlantic league involving teams from Scotland, Holland, Belgium and Portugal - Rangers, Celtic, Ajax, PSV Eindhoven, Anderlecht, Benfica, Sporting etc - who feel they need more competition than they are getting at home.

So one way or the other it looks as if Uefa is fighting a rearguard action in keeping the Champions League the way it is, having already acceded to club pressure first in abandoning the two-leg knockout system which served the European Cup well enough for more than 35 years and then adding an extra round of group matches before the quarter-final stage.

Even now the clubs are not satisfied. For many the financial ideal would be a league purpose-built to provide the most attractive package for television and guaranteed security for its members, ie no relegation.

A closed European shop is surely the last thing the game needs. There must always be an element of chance.

When United play Kiev part of the nation will be agog to see if their manager's ill-judged decision to rotate his team against PSV in Eindhoven returns to haunt him. Another part will be backing Leeds in Milan while a third will be impatient to learn of Arsenal's opponents in the next round.

Take away this sort of interest and a European league sounds about as compelling a spectacle as meeting of finance ministers in Brussels. Even Tottenham on a bad day would be more entertaining than that.

webTitle: England looks to a reluctant Svengali

fields.headline: England looks to a reluctant Svengali
fields.standfirst: Jim White has cautionary words for Sven-Goran Eriksson's. But if the views of the Lazio coach's fellow Scandanavians are anything to go by, he needn't bother
fields.trailText: "If Sven-Goran Eriksson can be persuaded to forsake Rome for a job currently about as attractive as the chairmanship of Railtrack, it will be some coup."
fields.body:
And then there were two. Now that Arsène Wenger has decided he wants to stay on with a team containing players who can actually trap a ball, the FA's shortlist for a new England manager is reduced to Sven-Goran Eriksson and Roy Hodgson. In reality, since Hodgson's most recent experience in England hardly qualifies him for the "sustained success" proviso in that Anyone But Terry job description the FA concocted, that means just one. Sven: if you want the job, it's yours.

The big question is: why would he want it? If Adam Crozier and a container load of cash do persuade Eriksson to forsake Rome for a job currently about as attractive as the chairmanship of Railtrack, it will be some coup. It would also be the single most significant thing Crozier could do in his position as FA chief executive.

The Lazio coach appears to have everything required for the job: experience, skill, steely nerve, a track record of success in the most competitive league in the world. Plus considerable charm. In 1999, I was among a group of British reporters sent to Rome to cover Juventus's last domestic game before their Champions League semi- final against Manchester United. Eriksson, as coach of Juve's opponents, was peripheral to our story.

However, after the game he was more than willing to chat for some time with the visitors, in a way you can't quite imagine some of our leading managers doing with a bunch of foreign journalists. His analysis of Juve and United was not only spot on, it was delivered in the Scandinavian's standard-issue perfect English. There was a slight grin playing on his lips throughout the conversation, which some took for arrogance. But I reckoned it was a wry amusement at the ridiculousness of offering his thoughts on two teams that were not his own for a gaggle of quote-hungry hacks from newspapers he would never read.

If he has a sense of humour, Eriksson will need it should he become England manager. Not least back home. Because among Scandinavian coaches these days, English football is reckoned something of a joke. True, there are 40,000 paid-up members of the Liverpool supporters club in the greater Stavanger region. True, at St James' Park on match days the air hums with the sound of Danish Newcastle fans on away days from Copenhagen. And yes, we all know the much exchanged pub statistic that claims there are more replica United jerseys sold in Bergen than in Manchester.

The Premiership may still hold a romantic pull for supporter and talent alike, but few involved in the game in Scandinavia are under any illusions about standards of coaching over here and the consequent level of technique among English players. The Rosenborg manager Nils Eggen, who sold Steffen Iversen to Tottenham, for instance, is scathing.

"We train twice a day, unlike in England," he says. "We don't have young men with £2m in their back pockets, watching bad movies in the afternoon. Iversen hasn't raised his game one bit since leaving Norway - the Premier League is the worst in the class."

Rune Bratseth, Eggen's assistant, is equally scathing. "There is not much to learn from England," he says. "They're interested in what we're doing, but we're not much interested in what they're doing."

Such feeling is typical: there are not many of Eriksson's contemporaries who regard being invited to coach the England national team as reaching the pinnacle of the profession. Which is why, if Crozier were able to land his man, it would send out such an important message.

It would tell the world - and, just as importantly, the home market - that the English game is no longer afraid of good coaching, that it had cast aside the fashion for employing star players with no qualifications, that it appreciates there is more to preparing a football team than quoting Henry V or proving that you are still the best at keepy-uppy on the training pitch.

In a sense, the appointment of Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren to a French-style collegiate coaching system has already signalled an intent by the FA. Both men are characterised not by an illustrious playing career or the ability to spin a soundbite, but by a studious interest in all aspects of training and preparation. If Eriksson takes the job and if he is prepared to work with the newly appointed Englishmen rather than bringing in his own staff (two very big ifs), then the FA will have built a structure of genuine promise out of a complete shambles in less than a month. The FA and the speedy and successful resolution of a mess: surely it can't happen.

fields.headline: England dismantled by Afridi
fields.standfirst: A taste of things to come as Hussain's men are spun to heavy defeat
fields.trailText:
England 211 for 9 in 50 overs
Pakistan 212 for 2 in 44.2 overs
Pakistan win by eight wickets
fields.body:
England suffered more than a heavy one-day defeat here yesterday; the players also found themselves gawping at a trailer for a particularly nasty horror film. The Test series to come will be much like this.

Quality spin bowling on responsive pitches against vulnerable batting will win the Tests for Pakistan. That, at least, is what they say and it is difficult not to nod in solemn agreement. On Monday in Rawalpindi they will play the decider to this one-day series but already the drums beat for more earnest battles.

The sight of fresh troops in the hotel lobby is a reassuring one. But Michael Atherton, arguably, does not play spin as well as he once did and Michael Vaughan is still a tyro, albeit a very impressive one.

Remarkably, no fast bowler took a wicket yesterday. Pakistan's twirly men scarcely need sympathetic surfaces. Saqlain Mushtaq is no ordinary off-spinner and Mushtaq Ahmed has rediscovered the fizzing leg-break to keep his googly company. Yesterday we had Shahid Afridi bowling fast leg-breaks too. He is a poor man's Anil Kumble, but a plutocrat's Kumble with the bat.

Between them these three had figures of eight for 108 from 30 overs. With occasional bursts of pace, and with Wasim Akram in the vanguard, they were able to restrict England to a miserable 211 for nine. Pakistan knocked them off with some disdain, winning with eight wickets and 5.4 overs to spare. England's psychological ascendancy in this country has been short-lived.

Moin Khan, the home captain, said afterwards: "Spin could be our trump card in the Tests. England were a bit exposed and they crumbled under the pressure."

Nasser Hussain shrugged: "We're a bit spoiled in England, where the ball doesn't turn," said the visiting captain. "But you are going to come unstuck against spin in Asia now and again. We were 40 runs short from being able to put them under pressure.

"We knew when we came out here we would be playing on turning wickets. It's not the end of the world but we've got to learn quickly and the only way to do that is getting some time in the nets, practise and practise hard.

"I don't particularly blame the boys because they don't see an awful lot of spin apart from seeing Saqlain and Mushtaq at various times in the season."

While Pakistan can take much credit from this victory, England should nevertheless shoulder some blame for defeat because even against high quality bowling they batted poorly and thought ineptly.

Hussain, at three, slows the whole innings down. Given a decent start, worth 66 in 13 overs between Marcus Trescothick and Alec Stewart, there was a strong case for the promotion of Graeme Hick. And Andrew Flintoff should have come in before Graham Thorpe. When he did arrive he faced only 22 out of 55 balls delivered while he was there, scoring an anti-climatic 17.

The thinking is intransigent. Captain and coach underline the importance of each player knowing his place and his role, but this is almost the antithesis of the good one-day player, who should be versatile in his skills and flexible in his mind.

In Karachi they played brilliantly to defy their suspect tactics. Yesterday England scored a respectable 95 from their first 20 overs. But after 30 overs they had moved to only 125. There was an urgent need for greater impetus. But what we got was Hussain and Thorpe batting together.

Thorpe, busily acquisitive, is the ideal foil for a heavy hitter. But he should not bat with Hussain, who should open or not play at all. These two batted between the 29th and 39th overs and added 49 when they needed something more than a run a ball. Hussain batted for 28 overs and 89 deliveries for his 54. When Wasim dropped him twice, a difficult chance at 45 and a dolly at 52, one wondered whether he had done so deliberately.

England had been put in and their start mirrored their two weeks in Pakistan. Trescothick, who hit a six and five fours in his 74-ball 65, was all cool assurance while Stewart still fumbled for his touch.

When Mushtaq came on to bowl the 13th over he had Stewart stumped first ball. Trescothick was second out at 116, caught at midwicket, the first of Afridi's five victims.

Hick's dismissal, at 122, was a soft affair. He hesitated as he and Hussain ran a quick single and was so short of his ground he did not bother to run his bat in. He would have survived if he had because the throw missed and the batsman was only inches away from running over the line.

There would be no recovery. Hussain, Thorpe and Flintoff quarried their singles from the tight attack until they perished and again, worryingly, there was no depth charge from Craig White or Mark Ealham.

Pakistan's response became increasingly difficult to discern through the smog and dust and flies. At the end of the match, with the smoke from the riotous fireworks, visibility was about zero.

Afridi, who had come into the side with Azhar Mahmood, at the expense of Imran Nazir and Waqar Younis, secured his man-of-the-match car with a dashing 61. Twice in an over he slogged Ashley Giles to cow corner for six. Ashley, oh Ashley, he was gone with the wind.

The Warwickshire left-armer recovered to dismiss both openers and produce reasonable figures in view of his attacking fields. But Salim Elahi and Yousuf Youhana sauntered over the line with a stifled yawn.

Nasser Hussain shrugged: "We're a bit spoiled in England, where the ball doesn't turn," said the visiting captain. "But you are going to come unstuck against spin in Asia now and again. We were 40 runs short from being able to put them under pressure. "We knew when we came out here we would be playing on turning wickets. It's not the end of the world but we've got to learn quickly and the only way to do that is getting some time in the nets, practise and practise hard. "I don't particularly blame the boys because they don't see an awful lot of spin apart from seeing Saqlain and Mushtaq at various times in the season." While Pakistan can take much credit from this victory, England should nevertheless shoulder some blame for defeat because even against high quality bowling they batted poorly and thought ineptly. Hussain, at three, slows the whole innings down. Given a decent start, worth 66 in 13 overs between Marcus Trescothick and Alec Stewart, there was a strong case for the promotion of Graeme Hick. And Andrew Flintoff should have come in before Graham Thorpe. When he did arrive he faced only 22 out of 55 balls delivered while he was there, scoring an anti-climatic 17. The thinking is intransigent. Captain and coach underline the importance of each player knowing his place and his role, but this is almost the antithesis of the good one-day player, who should be versatile in his skills and flexible in his mind. In Karachi they played brilliantly to defy their suspect tactics. Yesterday England scored a respectable 95 from their first 20 overs. But after 30 overs they had moved to only 125. There was an urgent need for greater impetus. But what we got was Hussain and Thorpe batting together. Thorpe, busily acquisitive, is the ideal foil for a heavy hitter. But he should not bat with Hussain, who should open or not play at all. These two batted between the 29th and 39th overs and added 49 when they needed something more than a run a ball. Hussain batted for 28 overs and 89 deliveries for his 54. When Wasim dropped him twice, a difficult chance at 45 and a dolly at 52, one wondered whether he had done so deliberately. England had been put in and their start mirrored their two weeks in Pakistan. Trescothick, who hit a six and five fours in his 74-ball 65, was all cool assurance while Stewart still fumbled for his touch. When Mushtaq came on to bowl the 13th over he had Stewart stumped first ball. Trescothick was second out at 116, caught at midwicket, the first of Afridi's five victims. Hick's dismissal, at 122, was a soft affair. He hesitated as he and Hussain ran a quick single and was so short of his ground he did not bother to run his bat in. He would have survived if he had because the throw missed and the batsman was only inches away from running over the line. There would be no recovery. Hussain, Thorpe and Flintoff quarried their singles from the tight attack until they perished and again, worryingly, there was no depth charge from Craig White or Mark Ealham. Pakistan's response became increasingly difficult to discern through the smog and dust and flies. At the end of the match, with the smoke from the riotous fireworks, visibility was about zero. Afridi, who had come into the side with Azhar Mahmood, at the expense of Imran Nazir and Waqar Younis, secured his man-of-the-match car with a dashing 61. Twice in an over he slogged Ashley Giles to cow corner for six. Ashley, oh Ashley, he was gone with the wind. The Warwickshire left-armer recovered to dismiss both openers and produce reasonable figures in view of his attacking fields. But Salim Elahi and Yousuf Youhana sauntered over the line with a stifled yawn.

webTitle: Fans for wins sounds like a fair exchange

fields.headline: Fans for wins sounds like a fair exchange
fields.standfirst: Barmy army or (preferably) no Barmy Army, it's results that count for England
fields.trailText: Although they quickly reverted to type yesterday, England seemed to be a changed team when they beat Pakistan in the first one-day international on Tuesday, writes Jim White
fields.body:
Although they quickly reverted to type yesterday, England seemed to be a changed team when they beat Pakistan in the first one-day international on Tuesday.

First there was the batting: four successive names on the England scorecard making more than 50 in the same innings is not something many of us can recall having seen since cricketers wore white trousers.

Then there was the spirited all-round approach to the game, which suggest a foreign coach doesn't seem to be doing England's cricketers any harm. Not forgetting the diplomatic skills: Nasser Hussain, casting aside the apparent contractual obligation among England captains to turn graceless the moment they step on foreign soil, even refrained from the invitation to criticise local umpires.

But the biggest visible change has been in the crowd. For the past 10 years at least, England tourists have enjoyed a huge travelling support. In Australia, South Africa and the West Indies (particularly Barbados) thousands have turned out, taking an almost perverse pride in being there no matter how poor the side they are supporting.

From my experience of the roving throng it divides roughly in two. There are the nerds with scorebooks and carrier bags, shuffling from tour buses, shielded by voluminous hats and several layers of sun block strong enough to protect from nuclear fall-out.

And there are the beer monsters, the barmy army, legless and lairy. Shirt-free and flabby-bellied, by the end of a day's session, their exposed acreage of flesh is so raw a passing dermatologist would conclude there must have been some hideous accident involving paint stripper.

But in Pakistan both types seem to be entirely absent. Instead of every England boundary being greeted as if it signalled the return of the messiah, Andrew Flintoff's mighty thwacks were played out to hollow silence in stands packed with locals. It seems the nerds haven't come because of the lack of a tourist infrastructure and the beer monsters are absent because of, well, a lack of beer.

For years, England winter tours have been about great support, terrible results. So far this time it has been terrible support, better results. Now, which would you prefer?

fields.headline: After BSE: future safety issues
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the BSE crisis
After BSE: a crisis for science
After BSE: other scare stories
fields.trailText: Xenotransplantation
fields.body:
Xenotransplantation

Using organs from specially bred animals - probably pigs - for transplant into humans, to overcome the shortage of donors. At the moment, it is scientifically impractical. The fear is that diseases currently confined to pigs could find a new host in human beings.

GM animals

GM plants are already here. The next wave is GM animals. First up for the supermarket shelf - GM salmon, genetically modified to grow four times as fast as their traditionally bred cousins. Fear one: that they could escape and breed with wild fish, corrupting the wild gene pool and even wiping out the original species. Fear two: that genetic modification could accidentally make them toxic.

Germ line engineering

Currently outlawed, this involves genetically altering human beings. In the related technique of gene therapy, "good" genes are introduced into the bodies of sufferers from genetic diseases. But this only affects the person treated. Germ-line engineering means treating a patient's reproductive cells so that they pass on genetic modifications to their children. Proponents say this could wipe out inherited diseases. Opposition is mainly on ethical grounds.

Legalising cannabis

Part of any legalising argument will be over how safe it is - how its smoke and addictive qualities compare to cigarettes, how its effects on the brain compare to alcohol, and whether it could lead a user to other more harmful drugs.

Nanotechnology

The engineering of the very small. Within our lifetimes we may see the creation of tiny, molecule-sized machines capable of reproducing themselves from readily available raw materials - that is, atoms. Some foresee a danger of this process getting out of control, with the world being smothered in "grey goo".

webTitle: Dorrell says he regrets giving 'no risk' advice

fields.headline: Dorrell says he regrets giving 'no risk' advice
fields.standfirst: Tory minister admits exaggerating Whitehall guidance
fields.trailText: October 28 2000: Stephen Dorrell, the health secretary when human vulnerability to the BSE crisis was finally confirmed in 1996, yesterday became the first Conservative minister to express regret for mistaken assurances he had given.
fields.body:
Stephen Dorrell, the health secretary when human vulnerability to the BSE crisis was finally confirmed in 1996, yesterday became the first Conservative minister to express regret for mistaken assurances he had given.

Months before the link between BSE and human vCJD was admitted, when ministers were still trying to sustain confidence in the beef industry, Mr Dorrell had said there was 'no conceivable risk" from eating British beef.

Yesterday he said: 'The question about conceivable risk was that it was my phrase. I have responsibility for that and I regret having made that statement. But the broader scientific advice coming to the government at that time was advice made in good faith by the relevant advisory body."

As the contrite Mr Dorrell surfaced on Radio 4's Today programme, ministers signalled their determination to use Lord Phillips's report on the BSE crisis to create a far more open climate for 'mature debate" on policy options and scientific advice in Whitehall .

But their aims are doomed to disappoint freedom of information campaigners as not going far enough in giving electors the full picture.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has asked for the names of officials involved in the policy-making. But he regards institutional failures as being more important than the 'blame game" mistakes of individuals. His priority in the months ahead is to replace the old paternalism, which allowed officials to decide what should be put in the public domain, with a system which gives voters and the media the facts and lets them make their own assessments of the risk.

Mr Brown is afraid that Lord Phillips's relatively gentle censure of ministers and officials who made bad judgments on BSE/ vCJD will allow 'a sigh of relief to go through Whitehall and prevent progress being as fast as it should be".

Had scientific advice flowing in to ministerial offices been available earlier, it is argued, many more people would have stopped eating beef to be on the safe side.

However, the government was given a boost from an unlikely source yesterday.

In one of the Anglo-French beef war's rare gestures of conciliation, the authoritative daily Le Monde heaped praise on the Phillips report, saying it represented a level of government transparency and accountability all but inconceivable in France.

'What a lesson in democracy Britain has given the rest of Europe, and particularly France,' the paper said in an editorial headlined the British Example. 'It should be hailed as a model for an investigation by a state that has committed errors and recognises it - without trying to wriggle out of its responsibilities.'

Such a report, accusing government officials of misleading the public for years, would be a long time coming in France, Le Monde said.

fields.headline: Hallé/Elder
fields.standfirst:
Hallé/Elder
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
*****
fields.trailText:
Hallé/Elder

Bridgewater Hall, Manchester

*****
fields.body:
Manchester's orchestras can seem like its football teams, with the BBC Philharmonic ready to challenge any in the world at the moment and the Hallé occasionally liable to dip well below the premier league. And the tenure of conductors, as of managers, can end in tears for reasons that seem incomprehensible to outsiders.

A new conductor is usually warmly welcomed but Mark Elder's first concert as music director of the Hallé was an occasion of overwhelming enthusiasm. The audience was ecstatic; more importantly, the orchestra played with a verve and skill that conveyed absolute commitment.

Elder is, of course, well known to Manchester audiences and particularly to the Hallé, but the concert was a statement that they appreciate his deeply thoughtful brand of musicianship.

Elder opened in the grandest possible style, with Janacek's mighty Sinfonietta. The glorious fanfares of the nine trumpets in the back row glowed with tangible optimism, and the rest of the orchestra responded to Elder's lead with a marvellously idiomatic performance of its angular lines and unusual textures. However, the true revelation of the concert - and reason for unbounded confidence in the future - was Elgar's First Symphony. Elder was plainly concerned to eliminate any thought of this being a piece of imperialistic bombast; but then so are most conductors. What was exciting was what he put in its place. With the most careful balancing of the textures he drew out details of the orchestration that can scarcely ever have been heard.

Elder found in the score passages of an almost Mahlerian sinuosity, something that cannot be done without the most fastidious preparation of players who are on top form and able to respond to the slightest gesture.

He controlled and modulated the pace in a way that created a dramatic reading of quite unusual power. This was a revelatory performance. And it was music-making of a kind that can put the Hallé firmly into the premier league. The future looks good.

webTitle: Smart money sees a future for sterling

fields.headline: Smart money sees a future for sterling
fields.standfirst: Last week we put the case for saying 'yes' to the euro. Here Mark Atkinson looks at Britain's position and finds 'no' the only option - for now
fields.trailText: Last week we put the case for saying 'yes' to the euro. Here Mark Atkinson looks at Britain's position and finds 'no' the only option - for now.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has two things weighing on his mind. First, how to win the next election. Second, what to do about the euro. The second is likely to prove more difficult than the first. While William Hague remains Tory leader a second term is assured, albeit with a smaller majority.

But putting a foot wrong on the question of euro membership could easily cost the Prime Minister his job.

It's not only in the financial markets that the euro is despised. Opinion poll after opinion poll has shown that the British public is deeply suspicious of ditching the pound for Europe's single currency. Yet the government has pledged that it is in favour, in principle, of joining EMU when the economic conditions are right and has promised to assess the situation early in the next parliament. Given the public mood, it's not hard to guess the outcome of that examination.

The key issue for Britain is whether it stands to gain more than it loses. For the time being, at least, the answer is an economic no-brainer. We should stay out.

The continental European economy was once a haven of stability and prosperity, controlled by the mighty Bundesbank. Britain was the home of boom/bust economics, where politicians set interest rates not to control inflation, but to win elections. Handing control of monetary policy to the Bundesbank, symbol of post-war German economic success, was seen as the ideal solution to the British disease.

Now the situation is very different. Since being granted its independence by Gordon Brown in May 1997, the monetary policy committee (MCP) has steered the economy with great skill. It has largely got things right.

EMU membership would involve a loss of fiscal sovereignty. Under the so-called stability pact, countries inside the eurozone have to keep their budget deficits and debt-to-GDP ratios within certain limits.

Britain's public finances are so healthy that it easily qualifies for membership. But in harsher times, when the government needs to increase spending to offset the impact of an economic downturn, the loss of flexibility implied by the stability pact will be sorely missed.

The volatility of sterling outside EMU remains a problem - just ask the hundreds of UK manufacturers who have had to lay off staff due to the impact of the pound's strength on foreign sales. EMU membership would reduce the scope for adverse exchange rate shocks. But again, there would be a price in term of a loss of flexibility. Exchange rates are often subject to the whims of dealers, but they also rise and fall for good reason - to damp down a boom or prevent deep recessions. There is more to be lost than gained in terms of macroeconomic stability from joining EMU.

If anyone doubts that they should take a close look at the current economic situation. With unemployment poised to fall below one million by Christmas and inflation the lowest in the EU, the British economy continues to perform well. Leaving aside all these arguments against EMU membership, there would undoubtedly be a heavy price to be paid for joining in the next few years. While on some measures the UK economy is closely converged with euroland, on others it is far apart. Interest rates and the pound are way out of kilter with euroland. Euroland interest rates at 4.75% remain well below Britain's 6%.

If the government were to advocate entry into EMU today, cheaper money would provide a massive boost to demand and probably result in the economy overheating. Boom/bust all over again. The only way of offsetting the expansionary effect of looser monetary policy would be to tighten fiscal policy, leaving overall demand and inflationary pressures unchanged.

But fiscal policy has already been loosened substantially to make up for Mr Brown's spending freeze in the first two years of his Chancellorship. He is sitting on a huge budget surplus Does anyone think he is going to advocate a hugely unpopular fiscal tightening ahead of an election, when he could use some of the money to cut taxes and cement Labour's electoral success?

Any further loosening of fiscal policy makes joining EMU harder than ever. But Mr Brown knows this and evidently doesn't care. If the economics argue against entry now, the politics are less clear-cut. Mr Blair is worried that failure to become a full member will mean Britain being marginalised.

However, on balance it will probably be the right decision to take. In the end politics and economics are inseparable, and, as Britain's experience in the ERM shows, it pays to put economics first. Ask John Major.

 Mark Atkinson is economics correspondent of the Guardian.

webTitle: Back to basics grows on the high street

fields.headline: Back to basics grows on the high street
fields.standfirst: Two more banks have launched accounts aimed at those previously without access to financial services. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: Two more banks have launched accounts aimed at those previously without access to financial services. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
Barclays and Lloyds TSB this week became the latest high street banks to launch basic accounts aimed at the 2m-3m people who don't have access to financial services because of their poor credit rating or where they live.

The moves form part of the government's drive to address financial exclusion, a problem that has been exacerbated by bank branch closure programmes which have left many deprived communities high and dry.

Basic bank accounts are fee-free and provide day-to-day banking services but don't allow customers to go into debt - overdrafts are not allowed. You can set up direct debits and standing orders, and a card is provided for cash machines. Some go further and offer a debit-type card allowing you to buy goods in shops provided you have the funds. The accounts can usually be opened regardless of your credit rating, though people who have been declared bankrupt will in many cases still be blacklisted.

This week's announcements by Barclays and Lloyds TSB come hot on the heels of NatWest, which launched its own basic bank account three weeks ago. Meanwhile, the Co-operative Bank and Yorkshire Bank are set to unveil their accounts next week.

It's no coincidence that all these institutions are suddenly rushing out products aimed at low earners, those with bad credit ratings and others the banks have traditionally shown little interest in - the Treasury ordered the major banks to offer these accounts. In fact, Barclays, Lloyds et al are actually behind schedule - they were supposed to have the accounts in place by the start of this month, but the Treasury says it is not going to pick a fight with them over the fact that they are a few weeks late.

As many as 3m-plus people are without basic banking facilities, a statistic of particular concern to the government because of its plans to channel benefit payments directly into bank accounts by 2003. Also, consumer groups point out that, without a bank account, people are deprived of the ability to pay utility bills by direct debit, which can reduce the amount you pay.

Other banks offering basic bank accounts include Bank of Scotland, Royal Bank of Scotland, Halifax, Abbey National and Woolwich.

Some of the accounts are very basic indeed, allowing you to do little more than pay your wages, pension or other regular income in, set up direct debits and withdraw money from cash machines. However, some banks, including NatWest, Abbey National, Bank of Scotland and Woolwich, will let people have a Solo or Electron card, allowing them to pay for goods and services without the risk of going overdrawn - the transaction has to be authorised in the shop.

Many of the accounts provide a £10 overdraft buffer zone so even if you have only got a pound or two left in your account, you can withdraw it from a cash machine. Other than that, though, there is no credit facility, thereby preventing people from getting into debt.

You will still need to provide some form of identifica tion when opening an account, but several of the banks have relaxed their rules on this. In addition to a passport or driving licence, pension books, recognised ID cards with photo and signature, and the new-style orange disabled drivers passes with photos are all now accepted by Lloyds TSB, for example.

The banks will make little, if any, money from the basic accounts, as customers won't be paying overdraft charges and many of them will probably not be depositing large sums, and as a result some commentators reckon there is little incentive for the banks to promote the accounts. However, the government says it will be watching them closely to make sure they tell people about them. "We expect the accounts to be actively promoted," says the Treasury.

Some banks are being pro-active and are spreading the word about the new accounts. fields.headline: Manet: Les Natures Mortes
fields.standfirst:
Manet's fruit and veg fancies
Musée d'Orsay, Paris
*****
fields.trailText:
Manet's fruit and veg fancies
Musée d'Orsay, Paris
*****
fields.body:
Contemporary critics loved to suggest that everything Manet painted was a still life - not just fruit and flowers, but his suspiciously inert humans. And one can see their point. His men and women are not so much people as near-death experiences, seemingly poised to tumble from the canvas into chalky dust before us. In Olympia, for example, the bored ivory nude lounges on a bed, her courtesan's constipated gaze challenging ours. Any animation comes from the looming servant; the only vigorous colours from the bouquet that he is bearing.

In Le Déjeuner sur l'Herbe, a basket of fruit and bread spills itself winningly across the grass near the naked model's bottom. It looks filled with life next to the decadent, would-be arcadian poses of the arty threesome behind.

The savage critical reaction to the latter painting in 1863 drove Manet to paint a series of still lives of flowers - and to concentrate increasingly on human-free canvases until the end of his life.

Mid-19th century Paris was in thrall to citron mania, and Manet documented this fad. As a result, next to each sober-suited stiff with a beard is a tonally refreshing burst of lemon. Forty eight of his paintings - one fifth of Manet's entire output - dispensed with humans altogether. There are some wonders here - a halved salmon with an unspeakably dirty pink gash; strawberries in fanciful scarlet; a brioche burnt yet beckoning.

But it is Manet's sublime depictions of asparagus that crown the show. At the time, though, they seemed too prosaic, and were satirised by Proust. In A La Recherche du Temps Perdu, an artist paints vegetables - to a Proustian toff's disbelief: "Three hundred francs for a bunch of asparagus!"

In fact, Manet received 1,000FF for his Bunch of Asparagus, 200 more than he had demanded. We see both canvases in this show and they are compellingly vile - the bunch white and obscenely purple-tipped, the single one green and disgustingly lively. They recall the tree roots that brought the hero of Sartre's La Nausée to the point of throwing up. A great exhibition.

Until January 7. Details: 00331 40494814.
