fields.headline: CBSO/Sakari Oramo
fields.standfirst:
CBSO/Sakari Oramo
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.trailText:
CBSO/Sakari Oramo

Symphony Hall, Birmingham

****
fields.body:
The City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra and its high-octane music director, Sakari Oramo, are swirling to the end of a brief retrospective of 20th-century English music. "Swirling" is the operative word, for Oramo has chosen to close his final concerts with John Foulds's Three Mantras, a hair-raising piece of exotica, to put it mildly.

Foulds, who died in 1939, was a Mancunian maverick, known in his day for incidental music and salon pieces. Towards the end of his not so long life, he was drawn to oriental philosophy and eventually went AWOL in India, having produced a series of colossal east-west fusion scores, most of which have never been published, some of which are presumed lost. Three Mantras, first performed in 1997, is all that is left of an opera called Avatara. Since it runs for half an hour and formed the prelude, one wonders just how long Foulds intended the opera to be.

He owes his rediscovery, one suspects, to the New Age movement, though if anyone imagines Three Mantras is inherently pacific, they are in for a shock. This is, first and foremost, music of violent flux and ceaseless change, aspiring to portray endless cycles of destruction and reconstruction.

It is the music, in short, of Shiva's eternal dance within the cosmic wheel. Raw, unruly string phrases lacerate the air, answered by savage trumpets. Pounding ostinati build relentlessly and Indian ragas are imploded into western passacaglias. Even when the pace subsides in the glittering, beatific central section, Foulds keeps the uneasy tension going by means of protracted chromatic dissonances.

He has been seen by some as a musical law unto himself, a kind of English Ives - though that isn't strictly true. In idiom, he's a post-Wagnerian tonal extremist. There are echoes of Holst and resonances of Mahler - both of whom were also influenced by eastern philosophy. For Oramo - the wild boy of the podium - Three Mantras is a gift. The CBSO play it with sinewy, extravagant vehemence.

Elsewhere, Oramo's choice of repertory is more conventional, - though his approach is radical. There is no attempt at nostalgia or parochial insularity. Oramo hurls English music kicking and screaming into the European mainstream. He turns Elgar's Cockaigne into a tone poem of spine-tingling Straussian zap, in which, for once, there is not a shred of imperial pomp.

Vaughan Williams's Toward the Unknown Region is similarly shown as owing a debt to Brahms before the composer's own voice finally makes its distinct appearance. Britten's Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings asserts a universality of emotion and experience, and Oramo is sensitive to its every flicker of mood. His tenor is Mark Padmore - lithe and elegant, if straining in places - and there are moments of unsteadiness in Radovan Vlatkovic's horn-playing. Oramo sometimes sacrifices finesse to intensity but is unfailingly exciting, and both orchestra and audience clearly adore him.

webTitle: Is the gold card standard high enough for travellers?

fields.headline: Is the gold card standard high enough for travellers?
fields.standfirst: Most gold credit and debit cards include free travel insurance. Kate Harvey wonders if the cover offered is good enough
fields.trailText: Most gold credit and debit cards include free travel insurance. Kate Harvey wonders if the cover offered is good enough.
fields.body:
Can you rely on a gold credit and debit cards for travel insurance? Is it fully comprehensive and how much does it cost? This week Jobs & Money researched travel insurance on the gold cards offered by the big four banks.

Most gold cards are not free and their travel insurance cover is often worse than that offered by insurance companies.

Journeywise, for instance, charges £54 for an annual multi-trip policy for an individual. This includes cover for up to a total of 60 days spent on trips in a year and 10 days of winter sports cover, whereas gold cards generally only offer 31 days' cover.

Journeywise also gives additional "sending you home in an emergency" cover, which the cards do not offer. The gold cards differ in detail, however, so here is a guide. All costs are per person.

Barclays Premier Card

This has an annual fee of £80. The travel insurance is activated only when the card pays for the holiday.

This covers 90 days' holiday including winter sports. The policy gives £1m emergency medical treatment and £1m personal liability. And £25,000 travel accident cover will apply for the journey. If the holiday departure is delayed by four hours or more, benefit is £20 an hour up to 12 hours and cancellation benefit is up to £4,000. Delayed baggage is covered at £25 for each hour up to a maximum of 12 hours. Barclays will pay out up to £1,500 for lost or stolen baggage and will cover up to £500 cash.

HSBC Platinum Card

Travel insurance on the platinum card is an optional extra; £40 on top of the £30 yearly fee, and the card must be used to pay towards the trip. The policy covers 31 days' holiday a year, in Europe and worldwide and includes 17 days of winter sports. The insurance includes £25,000 travel accident, £10m medical emergency, £2m for personal liability and for personal baggage the limit is £2,000 and £500 for money. There is also cover for holiday cancellation at £7,500, missed departure at £500 and travel delay at £300.

LloydsTSB Gold

This is good value as both the card and some travel cover are free.

The policy is valid for up to 31 days on any single trip worldwide but does not include winter sports cover, which costs £50 extra. The medical emergency policy pays up to £5m.

Personal liability cover goes up to £2m. There is insurance of up to £1,500 for personal baggage if it is damaged or stolen. The holder needs to purchase tickets with the gold card to obtain the travel accident policy at £100,000, which covers the journey.

NatWest Advantage Gold

Worldwide travel insurance is at no extra cost, provided the card is used to book part of the holiday, such as tickets. The maximum period of any holiday within the year is 31 days. Winter sports are extra; seven days will cost £42.39.

The policy covers personal accident up to £25,000 and medical emergency expenses up to £1m, increased to £2m when in the US. Personal liability is up to £2m. Personal belongings are covered up to £1,500 and money at £500 but £250 for cash. Delayed baggage on outward journeys is up to £100 after 4 hours and an extra £400 after 48 hours' waiting. It also covers travel delay up to £250 and cancellation up to £3,000.

webTitle: Hi-tech stocks look brighter as sanity returns

fields.headline: Hi-tech stocks look brighter as sanity returns
fields.standfirst: Investors who piled into technology took losses but prospects are improving, says Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Investors who piled into technology took losses but prospects are improving, says Tony Levene.
fields.body:
Technology funds were the big "must haves" in the last individual savings account selling season. Now many investors are doubting that particular piece of financial adviser wisdom. Many bought at the top of the boom: some have lost up to 60% of their money.

Now, however, the funds could be due for a comeback. Basing their marketing appeal on stratospheric past performance figures, discount brokers sold the specialist unit trusts by the million. But the mid-March madness in technology markets, both in the US and Britain, coincided with the Isa sales high point. Since then, the UK-based FTSE Techmark 100 index of medium and smaller-sized technology companies has fallen by 40% - and the US Nasdaq by around a third.

Aberdeen Technology and Henderson Global Technology, the two biggest technology funds and both heavily sold last spring, have fallen 27% and 13% respectively since their peak. SG Asset Management's smaller fund has also given many Isa investors a torrid time.

It is not just small investors who have been caught out. The largely institutional shareholder list of Aberdeen European Technology and Income split level investment trust have seen their money drain away. This trust raised £200m in January, matching it with a further £200m loan from Bank of Scotland. But now it is raising a further £45m to prevent lenders calling in their money. The capital growth shares have crashed from 15p to under 5p, while the income shares have collapsed from 85p to 52p.

Matters have not been helped by the gearing, which magnifies problems, and the fund's reliance on junk bonds to produce a high income. Framlington's highly hyped NetNet fund rocketed from 50p at launch in May 1999 to £1.51 in March 2000. Now it is trading at 66p. As Framlington delicately puts it: "Some investors are nursing a reduction in the value of their investment."

But now technology funds are attempting a comeback. The £1.5bn Aberdeen Technology and the equally sized Henderson are striking out in new directions.

And two new unit trusts aimed at tracking technology indexes are launched this weekend with offerings from both Legal & General and Close Brothers. SG is offering a mix'n'match Eurotech Isa with 50% going into the technology trust and half directed to European Growth.

Henderson's fund hit question marks after the resignation of the two main fund managers, Brian Ashford-Russell and Tim Woolley, quitting to set up their own operation. But while ratings agency Standard & Poors expects new fund manager Nitin Mehta to be as successful, doubts remain.

Mr Mehta has no doubts. "This fund has been around for 10 years. We did dip in March but we are ahead over the past six months," he says. His first-division performance has been based on switching heavily into what he expects to be the next big trends. More than 70% of the trust is US shares.

Around a third of the fund is in "enterprise software" - shares such as BEA Systems and SBL Systems. These US companies make their profits from the links between a firm's in-house system and the internet.

A second 30% slice is in "next generation networks" - companies such as Nortel Networks, Juniper and Ciena.

"These firms sell technology which effectively makes phone wires fatter so more information can be squeezed through at faster speed. We are in a hyper-demand phase for these products," he says.

The flipside is what is left out or downsized. "We have little in computer hardware stocks such as Dell, Compaq, in semi-conductors such as Intel or Texas Instruments, or in Microsoft which has become too mature for us - and has problems shipping Windows 2000," Mr Mehta adds.

At Aberdeen, fund manager Ben Rogoff puts faith in DWDM, dense wave division multiplexing, which can increase phone line capacity by 192 times. "You've got to look for the next system bottleneck and find firms with a solution. Phone companies then have no option but to buy this kit. Internet security is also a big theme," he says.

Active fund managers believe that tracking a market where product lives can be as little as six to nine months means ending up with technological dinosaurs.

Legal & General stayed out of technology last spring because L&G strategist David Rough "doubted prospects in the midst of dot.com madness". Now prices have fallen to "more sensible levels".

"Our technology index fund offers lower risk, lower charges and global diversification," says L&G's Michael Hayden. The fund tracks the FTSE World Index technology section which is published daily.

And Close Brothers, which already has an index fund based on Techmark, is launching a European technology tracker based on the FTSE eTX 50.

"This fund avoids huge holdings in Microsoft and Intel - this way you can profit from targeting specialist stocks in the tier beneath established global giants without worrying about fund manager bias. And you could gain further if the euro is near its bottom," says Close's Marc Gordon.

"You've got to look for the next system bottleneck and find firms with a solution. Phone companies then have no option but to buy this kit. Internet security is also a big theme," he says. Active fund managers believe that tracking a market where product lives can be as little as six to nine months means ending up with technological dinosaurs. Legal & General stayed out of technology last spring because L&G strategist David Rough "doubted prospects in the midst of dot.com madness". Now prices have fallen to "more sensible levels". "Our technology index fund offers lower risk, lower charges and global diversification," says L&G's Michael Hayden. The fund tracks the FTSE World Index technology section which is published daily. And Close Brothers, which already has an index fund based on Techmark, is launching a European technology tracker based on the FTSE eTX 50. "This fund avoids huge holdings in Microsoft and Intel - this way you can profit from targeting specialist stocks in the tier beneath established global giants without worrying about fund manager bias. And you could gain further if the euro is near its bottom," says Close's Marc Gordon.

webTitle: Banking: It's time to seek a better partner

fields.headline: It's time to seek a better partner
fields.standfirst: Millions of us get a poor deal on our current accounts but the battle to persuade us to switch has now started in earnest. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: Millions of us get a poor deal on our current accounts but the battle to persuade us to switch has now started in earnest. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
Every which way they turn the traditional high street banks are seeing rivals such as the new wave of internet banks and retailers attempting to muscle in on their territory.

Marks & Spencer is just one of many players giving them a run for their money - earlier this month it revealed it is opening bank branch-style financial centres in 30 of its stores over the next 18 months where people will be able to talk to specially trained staff about products such as personal loans and cash Isas.

However, the real battleground in the coming months will be centred around current accounts. The "Big Four" banks, Barclays, Lloyds TSB, NatWest and HSBC, have a staggering 30m current accounts between them, yet are paying most of these people a rate of interest of just 0.1% and are charging them authorised overdraft rates of around 17%-18%.

In the past few months we have started to see the first serious attempts by rivals to end this domination of the market, with a number of the new internet banks launching current accounts paying savings-style rates of interest.

And former building society the Halifax this month really ratcheted up the pressure with the launch of what it claims is "the most competitive current account on the high street", paying 4% interest and with an authorised overdraft rate of only 10%.

The new account will be available from January and you'll have to have at least £1,000 going into the account every month to obtain these rates.

It will be interesting to see if the Halifax's clout can overcome the legendary apathy that exists among the UK public when it comes to changing banks. It's always been said that you're more likely to change your spouse than your bank account.

Most people regard switching their bank as a time- consuming process and fraught with danger - specifically, people worry that someone will bungle the moving over of their direct debits and other payments. In August, Jobs & Money told how Jonathan Morrell found himself embroiled in a tortuous saga when he switched his account from Halifax to Smile.

Earlier this month we appealed for people to tell us their account-switching experiences. Here, David Bull and Leslie Connor relate how it was for them. While Mr Connor says he believes the difficulties are often overstated, Mr Bull says his changeover was far from hassle-free.

The banks and building societies have been told that they must make it easier for people to move their accounts, and to this end more than a dozen institutions are taking part in what is called the "current account transfer scheme" which started last autumn.

This supposedly enables payments to be moved seamlessly from a customer's old account to the new one, with the new bank undertaking most or all of the work.

The new bank contacts the old bank, receives the list of payments, then contacts the companies who take money from your account and instructs them to amend the existing direct debit instructions to include the new bank details.

The new bank is also able to set up the new standing order instructions and then confirm to the customer that the payment instructions have been transferred.

The banks and building societies taking part in the pilot scheme are: Barclays, Abbey National, Co-operative Bank (including Smile), Halifax (including Intelligent Finance), Virgin One, Woolwich, Nationwide, Royal Bank of Scotland, the National Australia Bank Group (includes Clydesdale Bank, Yorkshire Bank and Northern Bank), Bank of Scotland and Ulster Bank.

So what are some of the best current account rates available now?

As you might expect, the best rates are on the net - the Halifax's Intelligent Finance (www.if.com) is paying 5% while Cahoot (www.cahoot.com - part of the Abbey National group) is offering between 5% and 7.1%, though to get the latter rate you have to have £5,000-plus in your account and have to go without a cheque book.

The Co-op Bank's Smile (www.smile.co.uk) is paying 4.75%, while First-e (www.first-e.com - a subsidiary of French bank Banque d'Escompte) is offering 4.88%.

Getting away from the internet, there are only pretty thin pickings to be found - Nationwide's FlexAccount pays from 1.45%, while the Woolwich's Open Plan account pays 2%.

I switched and it was fine...

Father-of-three Leslie Connor moved his current account from Barclays to Nationwide as part of a thorough makeover of his finances that saw him switching utility companies and signing up with a cheaper home and contents insurance provider.

He had been with Barclays for more than 10 years but decided to move to Nationwide because of its no-fee overdraft facility (Barclays imposes a £5 a month usage fee for authorised overdrafts).

"My account is relatively simple - just 12 direct debits and a debit card," he says. "So I contacted all the direct debit companies by post about a month before switching and asked for new mandate forms. The companies took up to two weeks to reply. In retrospect I think it's easier just to phone them."

Mr Connor, 43, of Aintree, Liverpool, filled in the forms, giving the respective companies about three weeks to make the change. Then he closed his Barclays account.

"Only one insurance debit failed to transfer - they sent me a letter asking if I wanted to end the policy. After a quick phone call they agreed to take two months' premiums from the new account the following month.

"My experience was relatively painless and I'm saving money, but some people may regard the amount saved as insignificant and not worth the effort. I also believe the difficulties are overstated. Even when things go astray, it just takes a phone call and an extra payment the following month to sort things out - it's no big deal," says Mr Connor, a technician at Liverpool University.

I switched and ran into problems

David Bull moved his current account from NatWest to internet bank Smile last December. Aside from the decent interest rate - 4.75% - he was attracted by the fact that Smile is part of the Co-operative Bank, which is renowned for its ethical stance.

He is happy with Smile's offering but says of the switch: "It was a bit of a hassle." As with other customers, it was moving the direct debits that caused the problems, says Mr Bull, 49, who lives near Oxford and is executive director of the UK branch of Unicef.

Smile promises to write to all the firms that take money from your account by direct debit to give them the new account details and set a date for the switch to take place.

"In theory, you can leave it all to the new bank and need take no further action yourself. In practice, however, I received a succession of letters from my direct debit payees saying they had tried to draw from the old bank and been refused, and asking me to fill in a new form. I worried that doing this would duplicate the messages from Smile and I could end up paying twice."

Mr Bull phoned all the companies and explained that Smile was making all the arrangements and that he would not be returning their forms. He then called Smile and asked them to follow up with each company to sort out any problems.

"In some cases, these problems included threats to withdraw insurance cover unless cash payments were made." This was eventually sorted out, but he adds: "Having started the process in early December, it was the second week of February before everything was completely resolved and all the direct debits were up to date.

"It actually took a lot of my time to ensure all my payees were kept informed and that cover was retained. However, Smile's customer service personnel did eventually manage to get everything straightened out."

He says it was worth the hassle - during 1999 he received a total of £10.66 interest on his NatWest account, while this year to date he has received interest totalling £113.87.

His advice includes: don't try to change over Christmas or other holiday periods and keep meticulous records.

webTitle: Finding your ideal home is easier online

fields.headline: Finding your ideal home is easier online
fields.standfirst: Recent months have seen a proliferation of property sales websites, explains Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: Recent months have seen a proliferation of property sales websites, explains Richard Colbey.
fields.body:
Adding "co.uk" on to "estateagent", "homepages" "rightmove", "propertyproperty" "08004homes" gives access to large numbers of properties across the country.

For people who know exactly where they want to live the sites are of limited use. Even the most comprehensive will not be able to compete with a local newspaper.

But where they really come into their own is when someone wants to find out about house prices in a certain area whether with a view to choosing somewhere to live or buying a property to let. Those who are simply curious about property prices will also enjoy using these sites.

By far the best-designed site for researching prices is home.co.uk. It has nearly 200,000 property particulars, the majority being with estate agents, although private sellers can advertise their homes free.

While the information one can glean from this site will not be as accurate as the major house price indexes prepared by the Nationwide and Halifax, these only divide the country up into regions such as East Anglia and the south-west.

Prospective buyers can specify a type and size of property, an area of up to 80 miles across and a specific price range. Asking it to find a home for less than £50,000 within a 15-mile radius of London EC1 is an easy way to find out where the cheapest homes are in the capital. This somewhat scotches the popular wisdom that an income of £30,000 is necessary to get a foot on London's property ladder.

There are 21 homes avail able for under £46,000, which should be within the range of anyone earning £15,000 and having a small amount of savings. The cheapest are one-bedroom flats in Dagenham and Shooters Hill for £39,995.

At the other end of the scale one can find the most expensive properties by seeking those over £5m. Top is a 12-bedroom mansion with an acre of grounds near Holland Park at £15m. Prices fall to £21,400 in Basildon, followed by only slightly more expensive places in Maidstone, Sheerness and Rochester.

Birmingham is not always cheaper than the home counties, with prices starting at £22,500 for a one-bedroom flat in the Quinton area. The most expensive house within 20 miles of that city's centre is £900,000 for a six-bedroom house in Edgbaston.

Those desperate for a cheap property will find several in Sheffield, Newcastle and Liverpool for under £10,000.

Someone with a very specific area in mind can glean a good deal of information from the site that would have taken ages to obtain by identifying and ringing local agents. For instance, within ten miles of the Scottish border town of Newton St Boswells, there are 21 properties available from a £36,500 two-bedroom apartment to a detached country house for £285,000.

Some areas are not so well catered for though. Within the same distance of Haverfordwest in Pembrokeshire there were only four properties. That though is the exception and for the vast majority of the country home.co.uk has the potential to be used for relatively serious research.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Australian giant to enter UK mortgage fray

fields.headline: Australian giant to enter UK mortgage fray
fields.trailText: Australia's biggest financial services company is making a bid to capture a sizeable share of the British mortgage market in a move that further ups the ante in the cut throat battle for home loan customers.
fields.body:
Australia's biggest financial services company is making a bid to capture a sizeable share of the British mortgage market in a move that further ups the ante in the cut throat battle for home loan customers.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which boasts that 50% of the country's population has a relationship with it, launches in Britain next month with a range of Australian-style flexible mortgages. It has adopted the brand NewWorld and will sell its products via the internet, over the phone and later, through mortgage brokers.

The launch will be backed by a multi-million pound advertising campaign to laud the benefits of flexible mortgages.

Commonwealth Bank is setting its standard variable rate at 6.99% - compared with the typical British rate of 7.74% - and will be hoping to replicate the success it has had in Australia, where it has a 25% share of the mortgage market.

From November 30 it will be offering 11 products, including discounted, fixed, capped and buy-to-let deals. But, surprisingly, it will not provide so-called all-in-one mortgages combining a home loan and current account of the type pioneered in this country by Richard Branson's Virgin One and First Active.

All-in-one mortgages, hugely popular in Australia, allow people to offset money in their current account against their home loan, thereby reducing their interest payments.

But Adrian Cosenza, head of European banking for Commonwealth Bank, said: "We think it is a step too far right now for the UK consumer. Our research is suggesting they are finding that approach too complicated".

Instead the bank will focus on flexible mortgage features, such as the ability to make overpayments, daily rather than yearly interest calculation and "innovative Australian benefits" such as weekly payment options.

The Commonwealth Bank's arrival comes weeks after HSBC shook up the £115bn market by cutting its mortgage rate by almost one percentage point and the Halifax's new telephone bank Intelligent Finance announced competitive rates on home loans.

Citing intense competition, Moody's, the ratings agency, said it was changing its outlook on Halifax's debt rating from stable to negative.

webTitle: Property: Slowdown will mean a steadier market

fields.headline: Slowdown will mean a steadier market
fields.standfirst: Uncertainty still haunts Britain's homebuyers - but some predict stability, says Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: Uncertainty still haunts Britain's homebuyers - but some predict stability, says Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
With the housing market on a knife-edge, few forecasters are willing to project where prices will be next month let alone next year. So it's refreshing that one leading forecaster has stuck its neck out and predicted prices for the next three years.

Ernst & Young ITEM Club, an independent economic forecasting group, says it expects house price growth to fall to 7.3% in 2001 from this year's hectic 12.2% level and moderate further to 5.4% in 2002 and 4.9% in 2003.

ITEM looks at the market through an economist's rather than an estate agent's eyes. It says the recent slowdown, particularly in London and the south-east, is attributable to a slowdown in real incomes. "The easing in the market partly reflects a correction from the excesses of the previous year or so. It also reflects the impact of higher interest rates and the abolition of mortgage tax relief. Household real disposable income growth slowed from 3.5% in 1999 to only 1% in the year to quarter two 2000, and the Treasury model suggests that house prices are very elastic with respect to incomes."

ITEM's forecasts for 2001- 2003 are based on a belief that the economy will slow down next year as financial pressure on companies intensifies and consumers feel the effect of a weakening labour market and rising tax payments.

It expects economic growth of 2.6% next year (after 3.1% in 2000), followed by a further slowing to 2.1% in 2002. The trend in house prices will inevitably follow the same route, it says. "The housing market and the high street are bound to follow, even with short-term interest rates falling back to 5.5%."

Another factor pushing down price rises is the falling number of first-time buyers. "Demographic factors are also turning negative, with the numbers of first-time buyers beginning to decline. Many of these will have large student debts to pay off before they can think of taking on a mortgage," it says.

So is this a bad time to buy? The good news from ITEM is that it believes that the factors that made the property market in Britain so boom-and-bust are in decline. "We are not expecting a 90s Major-style collapse, just a cooling off after the heady pace of last year. Since there has been no boom, there is no need for a bust."

So forecasters do not believe that the housing market has overshot, as it did in the late 80s. "Our analysis suggests that this time house prices have simply adjusted back up into line with earnings, and have not overshot. Similarly, turnover has moved back to the long-term trend line."

Some forecasters have argued that Britain is a "mature" market, where the level of home ownership has reached a ceiling and demand will remain flat. But ITEM cautions against this, pointing to studies in the USA which show that, even in a very mature market, economic buoyancy can result in the home ownership ceiling breaking into new levels.

Its forecasts assume that interest rates will remain relatively low, which enables homeowners to support much larger mortgages. "The secular fall in interest rates allows a fixed monthly mortgage budget to finance a much bigger mortgage than it did. So families have been able to increase their mortgage relative to their income."

ITEM's optimism about the end of the boom-bust cycle also leads it to wider conclusions about the euro. It says that the moderating of the cycle removes one of the chief obstacles to euro membership.

Eurosceptics have argued that because so many Britons are on variable rate mortgages the impact of interest rate changes is far bigger in the UK than in Europe, and we need domestic control over rates.

But ITEM says: "The British people are adjusting to the new low inflation environment and becoming more continental in this respect." So when you next go househunting and arranging your mortgage you are making your own private contribution to the euro debate.

"The secular fall in interest rates allows a fixed monthly mortgage budget to finance a much bigger mortgage than it did. So families have been able to increase their mortgage relative to their income." ITEM's optimism about the end of the boom-bust cycle also leads it to wider conclusions about the euro. It says that the moderating of the cycle removes one of the chief obstacles to euro membership. Eurosceptics have argued that because so many Britons are on variable rate mortgages the impact of interest rate changes is far bigger in the UK than in Europe, and we need domestic control over rates. But ITEM says: "The British people are adjusting to the new low inflation environment and becoming more continental in this respect." So when you next go househunting and arranging your mortgage you are making your own private contribution to the euro debate.

fields.headline: God Only Knows
fields.standfirst:
God Only Knows
Richmond Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
God Only Knows

Richmond Theatre, London

***
fields.body:
Unless a miracle happens, this Hugh Whitemore play, which stars Derek Jacobi, closes tonight in Richmond without moving into the West End.

It is no masterpiece but it is more thought-provoking than the gilded pap you currently find in Shaftesbury Avenue and, besides, boasts a stellar performance from Jacobi. He plays a fugitive employee of the Vatican, Humphrey Biddulph, who bursts into a Tuscan holiday home occupied by two English couples. It turns out that a shady Italian dealer has given him sight of a document which suggests that Jesus Christ was simply an itinerant Jewish healer and that the Resurrection was a carefully arranged fabrication. Having shown the item rashly to a member of the Holy Office, the harrassed Humph has been banged up in a clinic from which he has made his escape. Fearing for his life, he turns for help to these sceptical Chiantishire couples.

You can easily pick holes in Whitemore's premise. The modern Vatican, you feel, would have more sophisticated ways of dealing with a subversive document than murdering or incarcerating its promoters. And while Whitemore says that he set out to create a role for Jacobi, he signally forgot to write one for anyone else: for much of the first act the holidaymakers simply sit around listening to the fugitive's story.

But a debate begins in the second act and at least Whitemore raises questions of which the modern stage generally fights shy. What, he asks, is the value of faith? Is religion the enemy of reason? Are believers just looking for a happy ending to life's disordered narrative?

The debate may be one-sided and lacking in theological intricacy but in the dumbed-down climate of commercial drama it is none the less refreshing. And Jacobi, having played a fantasy pope in Hadrian VII, gets the chance to don the mantle of a ferocious anti-papist.

Prowling round the stage in pyjamas and carpet slippers, he exudes a remarkable combination of vulnerability and rational passion. He apologises at one point for holding his hosts to ransom; yet when he inveighs against Vatican wealth, unscientific credulity or the easy invocation of religion at moments of crisis, he does so with paradoxically righteous anger. Above all, he uses his classical training to highlight the key words in a sentence: acting, I am increasingly convinced, is partly a matter of hitting the right inflexions.

It is a pity that Whitemore doesn't give him a strong opponent. But, in Anthony Page's well-paced production, David Yelland neatly embodies smug English orthodoxy, and Francesca Hunt the stirrings of moral guilt.

It also seems a comment on our times that the West End can find room for prancing penises and minor Coward but not for an enjoyable moral thriller featuring a knockdown performance from one of this country's finest actors.

Ends tonight. Box office: 020-8940 0088.

fields.headline: Orbital
fields.standfirst:
Orbital
Hammersmith Palais, London
****
fields.trailText:
Orbital

Hammersmith Palais, London

****
fields.body:
When Orbital released Chime in March 1990, the Hartnoll brothers, Phil and Paul, created the ultimate, insistent statement in an era of bedroom technology. At that time, the concept of live electronic dance was treated with derision. Through a decade of crossover hits, international tours and festivals, it has become an institution, with Orbital arguably at the helm. This relatively intimate one-off UK show was essentially a reminder of the fact.

Orbital entered to Walter Carlos's synthesised theme to A Clockwork Orange. Behind their databanks, wearing their trademark headlights, the duo still looked otherworldly - although the effect was marred when they cheerfully addressed the crowd in unmistakably human voices: "Thank you! Hellooo!"

Much of the audience appeared to have grown up with the band: twentysomethings and older, dancing fervently, cans of lager or mobile phones in hand.

Listening to Orbital's music while static is almost unbearable: the rhythms urge your limbs into activity, and when they unleashed the early-1990s favourite The Earth Is Burning, masses of hands were thrust into the sticky air. Live, each musical component became something to savour: a track stripped down to a yearning vocal sample or tremulous bassline. Surreal visuals and mock-consumer slogans (another Orbital speciality) accentuated the hypnotic effect, as their styles skittered from angular funk to orchestral pomp, with pop references; they mischeviously cross-bred Belinda Carlisle and Bon Jovi, and the hybrid sounded fantastic.

Dance music tends to date easily, but Orbital remain arrestingly fresh, whether it's the bizarrely beautiful, oscillating melodies of Spare Parts Express (from 1999's The Middle of Nowhere album), or 1996's haunting The Box. At this concert, they also previewed breakbeat-fuelled new material to enthusiastic response (Orbital's sixth album is due early next year). But the classics reigned supreme, with an encore of three certain crowd-pleasers: the cataclysmic onslaught of Satan, their pumped-up cover of the Doctor Who theme and Chime. The latter, a genuine anthem, swept through the crowd like a wave of elation.

Orbital play the Point, Dublin, tonight as part of a Cream night. Box office: 00353 18366777.

fields.headline: CGU cuts income for investors
fields.standfirst: Britain's largest corporate bond fund is to reduce payouts by a fifth, and admits eating into its capital. Phillip Inman reports
fields.trailText: Britain's largest corporate bond fund is to reduce payouts by a fifth, and admits eating into its capital. Phillip Inman reports.
fields.body:
Investors in Britain's largest corporate bond fund - the CGU monthly income plus - were told this week that their income payout had been cut by a fifth after a slump in performance.

About 160,000 investors in the flagship unit trust have already seen a fall this year in the capital value of their fund, reflected in the unit price. Now they have been told the income they receive will fall from 7.8% to 6.3%.

The change will take effect for direct holders from November 27 and from December 7 for people holding units inside an individual savings account (Isa) or personal equity plan (Pep).

Norwich Union, the fund manager, said it had suffered poor returns from preference shares. It has since sold most of its preference shares, which now account for 14% of the fund compared with 50% three years ago.

The switch into low-risk corporate bonds has failed to reverse the fund's fortunes, however. The company said the current outlook for bonds could not sustain high income levels. It claims the decision to cut income will make the fund more stable and put it on course for future growth. The company adds that the annual management charge has been reduced from 1.25% to 1% to compensate investors.

But it admitted it had been dipping into the fund's capital to maintain income payouts, leading investor groups and financial advisers to accuse the company of duping people to invest when it knew yields would need to be cut. The unit price on the CGU monthly income plus has declined by 18% since March 1999. Eighteen months ago the price was 66.6p. Now it stands at 54.7p. The decline in the fund's value can partly be blamed on the policy of taking some capital to meet the demand for income rather than using it for investment.

Norwich Union denied it had concealed the fund's poor performance in the last 18 months and the fund's manager Mark Gull said there was no reason to apologise to recent investors.

"Obviously no one is happy with an underperforming fund, but the capital has performed well over the longer term and we are confident it will in the future."

Age Concern Financial Partnership, the financial services arm of the pensioner charity, has heavily promoted the fund over the last three years to pensioners who want a steady income from an Isa.

Peter Gatenby, the partnership's managing director, says the cut in income was "very disappointing" and he is now examining whether to withdraw the product from its list.

"If they have been eating into the the capital to pay the income it is a very unorthodox way of financing the fund and had we known that we would never have recommended it."

Some financial advisers urge investors to sit tight. Justin Modray at Chase De Vere argues paying the costs of selling and the 4%-5% fee to buy into another fund mitigated against plans to shift funds.

But Brian Dennehy of financial adviser Dennehy, Weller & Co says Norwich Union has breached trust built up with investors. He said an alternative is the Aberdeen fixed interest fund, which has more than £1bn of assets and a current income of 8.4%.

webTitle: Subsidence: Don't let it all fall apart

fields.headline: Don't let it all fall apart
fields.standfirst: Subsidence need no longer strike dread into homeowners' hearts, says Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: Subsidence need no longer strike dread into homeowners' hearts, says Elizabeth Langton.
fields.body:
When cracks appear in the side of a house, or a gap opens up between the skirting boards and the floor, homeowners immediately fear the worst. Nothing fills householders with dread like the prospect of subsidence.

There are currently an average of 40,000 subsidence insurance claims made each year. This month the Association of British Insurers warned that subsidence cases could rise following climatic change.

As a nation we give an enthusiastic welcome to warm weather. Blistering summers, however infrequent, tend to stay in the memory long after the tans have faded. But some homeowners are left with unwelcome reminders in the form of a damaged home. Claims for damage caused by subsidence increase after hot spells.

Panic-stricken homeowners turn to their insurance company for help in making their home sound again. But diagnosing subsidence can be tricky. Structural damage can have many causes, including poor design, lack of maintenance and timber rot. Insurance wrangles involving subsidence frequently come before the Insurance Ombudsman Bureau (IOB).

Its spokeswoman Bridget Philbey says the arguments are often "over whether or not subsidence really is the root cause of the problem".

"When cracks appear in someone's house they can be due to frost, damaged bricks or even follow the installation of PVC windows. Homeowners see cracks appearing around the lintels and think they've got subsidence," she adds.

It's not surprising that insurers investigate subsidence claims carefully. Once, homeowners repaired cracks resulting from subsidence and heave as routine maintenance, says Brian Clancy, chairman of the Association of Consulting Engineers.

In 1971 the introduction of insurance cover for subsidence led to homeowners submitting claims for even minor damage resulting from ground movement. Over the last 30 years the claim bill has shot up. Last year insurers paid out on £364m in claims.

Mr Clancy is a subsidence missionary and his doctrine the prevention of unnecessary, expensive, dirty and disruptive patching up of homes. He is also chairman of an Institution of Structural Engineers task group set up to write the industry bible on the subject, Subsidence in Low-Rise Buildings, published earlier this month.

Thirty years ago the most common way of dealing with the problem was underpinning, an expensive practice that involves inserting extra concrete foundations under the property. By today's standards "that's like going to the doctor with a sore foot and the doctor's response being to remove the leg at the knee," says Mr Clancy.

Nowadays, underpinning should be the remedy of last resort. The buzzword is now management and prevention, he says.

Mr Clancy explains: "The majority of subsidence claims are for properties sitting on clay soil - areas like London and south Manchester." It is well known that trees growing in clay soil near homes can cause structural damage in particular conditions, he adds.

"Research has revealed that 80% of subsidence claims are for property on clay soil. And 80% of these claims are caused by trees or large bushes. In total this means that 65% of all subsidence claims involve trees growing on clay.

"If we find out how to deal with trees on clay soil then we're close to understanding how to prevent and react to the majority of subsidence claims."

Taking an axe to suburbia's trees is not the answer, he warns. Neither is widespread and indiscriminate pruning "Valuers say trees usually add value to a property, somewhere between 10-20%. So give or take a little, a green environment adds 10-15% to the value of a property," says Mr Clancy.

"Lenders who insist on trees being taken down automatically could be cutting the value of the homes by as much as £40,000." Also, many troublesome trees belong to neighbouring properties. "And neighbours don't like being told to take their trees down and may resist it."

Instead, homeowners and insurers need to manage trees that are causing damage. Mr Clancy explains: "A tree near your house may have been growing very happily for 40 years before it starts to cause problems. The tree needs to be taken back in its degree of maturity to the state it was in when it was 30 years old and not causing the property any damage."

Many trees can be managed by careful pruning but when subsidence is involved it is not a job for the enthusiastic amateur. Insurers can employ the expertise of an arboriculturalist, who makes calculations involving the leaf canopy and roots,

Once a building has suffered subsidence it is, in the eyes of some, permanently blighted. Buyers may find they have problems finding a company willing to insure a home that has been affected in the past, says Robert Hooker of the Subsidence Claims Advisory Bureau.

The business (which is not funded by the insurance industry) was set up in 1992 to arrange insurance for householders refused cover because of past subsidence.

"We've convinced certain underwriters to insure these properties as long as we give the building a clean bill of health," he says. The Bureau will also come to the aid of homeowners pursuing an insurance claim. For £250 plus VAT Mr Hooker and his staff will assess properties to find out whether subsidence is the problem.

"We'll send a suitably qualified person who will produce a visual inspection report based on what we see. We give them advice about whether or not they should take it any further," he says.

With increasing numbers of homes likely to be affected by subsidence Mr Clancy says it is unreasonable for lenders or insurers to refuse to mortgage or insure a property suffering subsidence in the past. In turn, homeowners must take care of their large trees and shrubs.

 Subsidence Claims Advisory Bureau produces a leaflet called Trees Subsidence and Your House; send an SAE to Charter House, 43 Saint Leonards Road, Bexhill-on-sea, East Sussex TN40 1JA. Subsidence of Low-Rise Buildings, (second edition) A Guide for Professionals and Property Owners, price £40 plus p&p from the Institution of Structural Engineers. 020-72354535.

fields.headline: Spurs struggle to keep Sol
fields.trailText: Name your price, Campbell is told
fields.body:
Tottenham Hotspur are willing to make Sol Campbell one of the Premier League's highest-paid players but fear it may still not be enough to prevent him leaving at the end of this season under the Bosman ruling.

The club are talking to the England defender "at every opportunity" and have effectively told him to name his price in their efforts to keep him at White Hart Lane.

"If Sol leaves here it won't be because we haven't offered him enough," John Sedgwick, the club's finance director, said yesterday. "We will do everything in our power to keep him at the club as he is Mr Tottenham Hotspur, but we have got to accept he might decide to go. He might be motivated by a new challenge."

Tottenham are also considering taking the Football Association to court as their chairman Alan Sugar continues his fight to have a £150,000 fine wiped out. The London club were hit with the punishment after a mass on-field brawl during a game at Leeds last season. "We don't accept the fine and are looking at ways to challenge it," Sedgwick said. "That could include a civil action."

The FA rejected a Spurs appeal in the summer but, after Tottenham Hotspur plc announced a slight fall in their annual pre-tax profits, the club revealed they were now considering civil action.

Yesterday's announcements followed the news that Spurs spent three times more money buying players than selling them last year.

During a poor season, which saw early exits from the Uefa, FA and Worthington Cup competitions, along with a mid-table finish, the club spent £23.4m on new recruits, including £11m for the Ukrainian international striker Sergei Rebrov and £5m on Ben Thatcher. But only £7m was recouped by player sales, including £3m from David Ginola's transfer to Aston Villa, while the wages bill soared 21% to £26.2m.

Fifa took a step closer to resolving the transfer debacle yesterday with the announcement that they have drawn up a list of proposed changes to the current system. After an exhaustive two-month cycle of discussions and negotiations, the six-man transfer task force will present its conclusions to the Fifa president Sepp Blatter tomorrow before they are handed on to the European Commission in Brussels next week.

The Scottish Premier League has backed Arthur Numan's efforts to overturn his Champions League red card. The Dutchman is set to miss the crucial showdown against Monaco at Ibrox in a fortnight after being dismissed at Sturm Graz on Wednesday night.

Numan was incensed by his first yellow card. Antonio Lopez booked him for re- entering the field of play late in a 2-0 defeat though he had appeared to wave the player back on to the field. Television appeared to support the Dutch international's claims.

"If I have to go to Switzerland and speak I will," Numan said. "If the referee is honest he will look at what he has done and change his mind. It will be terrible if I miss the Monaco game because of this."

The Scottish Premier League has backed Arthur Numan's efforts to overturn his Champions League red card. The Dutchman is set to miss the crucial showdown against Monaco at Ibrox in a fortnight after being dismissed at Sturm Graz on Wednesday night. Numan was incensed by his first yellow card. fields.headline: Hussain warns against overreaction
fields.trailText: England go into today's second one-day international against Pakistan with a warning to control their emotions and avoid specific criticisms of umpiring decisions.
fields.body:
England go into today's second one-day international against Pakistan with a warning to control their emotions and avoid specific criticisms of umpiring decisions.

With sensitivities already running high on their first visit here since Mike Gatting's infamous confrontation with Shakoor Rana 13 years ago, England are keen to appear diplomatic despite their displeasure at Alec Stewart's dismissal in Karachi. He was given out caught behind off the first ball he faced by the Pakistani umpire Riazuddin.

Although Nasser Hussain criticised the decision yesterday, he insisted that they had no objection to Riazuddin standing in the opening Test at Lahore on November 15. "Al got a bad one the other night. We've all had bad ones. We've got to work hard to live with it through the rest of our careers, not just this tour," he said.

"In general, apart from that one decision, I thought the umpires were very good the other night and handled the pressure as well as anyone. We didn't have any problems apart from that one ball.

"If it happened in England or anywhere else it wouldn't be a story. But here we're still talking about it three days later because it's Pakistan."

England, heroically, won that match with five wickets and 16 balls to spare despite chasing a target of 305, but Hussain warned: "We know that they're going to come at us and we've got to expect the worst. That way, if it happens, we won't overreact to it, just as we should not overreact when we win well as we did.

"They will start again as favourites. They have a phenomenal side and they're playing at home. They will probably post another big score so we will have to keep our work rate up." In particular, Hussain is looking for an improvement from his bowlers at the start of the innings.

Today's game has been brought forward two hours because of the dew problem and will now start at 8am British time.

Hussain, who will play today after testing his injured left ankle during practice, added: "Barry Jarman [the match referee] woke me up at eight this morning to tell me about the heavy dew. It's always nice to hear from Barry at 8am. The other night we changed the ball three or four times. This is something you want to avoid doing too often because you get used to the pace and feel of a particular ball."

England (from): *Hussain, Trescothick, Stewart, Hick, Thorpe, Flintoff, White, Ealham, Giles, Caddick, Gough, Alleyne, Solanki.

Pakistan (from): Saeed Anwar, Salim Elahi, Inzamam-ul-Haq, Yousuf Youhana, Shahid Afridi, *Moin Khan, Abdur Razzaq, Azhar Mahmood, Wasim Akram, Saqlain Mushtaq, Mushtaq Ahmed, Waqar Younis.

Umpires: Nazir Junior & Aleem Dar.

webTitle: Bradford stake their survival on Collymore

fields.headline: Bradford stake their survival on Collymore
fields.trailText: Bantams admit to 'enormous gamble' in securing Stan's signature.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore's increasingly slapstick career took another twist yesterday as he spurned a late offer to remain at Leicester and joined Bradford City on a free transfer.

The struggling Yorkshire club have taken over the striker's £13,000-a-week contract in much the same way that Leicester assumed his registration from Aston Villa in February. Bradford have an option to extend the deal for another year when it expires next summer.

"It is an enormous gamble," admitted the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond. "But we have scored four goals in 10 Premiership games, are 19th in the table and want to give our supporters something to cheer about."

Collymore, who is running up a huge tab in the last-chance saloon, should make his Bradford debut against Leeds on Sunday in a game the Bantams' manager Chris Hutchings may have to win to keep his job. His unlikely saviour was spared an official unveiling before the press, which would doubtless have seen him repeat the pledges made when he signed for Leicester in February.

"He had a lot of opportunities to go abroad or play in the First Division," said Richmond. "But the thing that impressed me during the negotiations with Stan and his advisers was that they didn't want to talk about money. They wanted us to take over the existing Leicester contract - not a penny more, not a penny less.

"Look at his track record: he's commanded transfer fees of £8.5m, has always been a prolific goalscorer and was considered, not very long ago, as the best striker in the land. There is no transfer fee involved and we think it's a gamble well worth taking."

The Leicester manager Peter Taylor, who inherited Collymore from Martin O'Neill and might be forgiven for wanting to wash his hands of the striker, was nevertheless disappointed to see the 29-year-old leave Filbert Street. "I'm a forgiving sort and I gave him another chance on Wednesday," he said.

"But there were rules with that chance. I talked to Stan on the phone and we were both very honest with each other. In the end, and after a lot of thought, Stan and his advisers decided to accept the Bradford offer and I think in the long-term it's best for Leicester City. "I'm not too sure it would have worked out for him here. But it's particularly frustrating for me because, as a team, we have not scored enough goals and I'm letting a good striker go."

The stand-in national coach is the latest manager to find Collymore unfathomable, although the striker may find empathy easier to come by at Valley Parade. His new strike partner, Benito Carbone, left Aston Villa under a cloud in the summer. Richmond must now hope his enigmatic strikeforce remains focused on keeping City in the Premiership.

"We're going to hear a lot about the dressing-room spirit and what effect this will have on it," said Richmond. "But that spirit has only brought us four goals in 10 games so far."

Collymore's brief spell with Leicester serves as a microcosm of a turbulent career that has seen him leave Crystal Palace, Nottingham Forest, Liverpool and Villa in acrimonious circumstances. He started only seven games for the Foxes, but still managed five goals, including a hat-trick on his home debut against Sunderland. A broken leg at Derby curtailed last season, although an incident with a fire extinguisher had already prompted O'Neill to warn him about his conduct.

Collymore found himself on the bench this season under Taylor, who criticised his attitude and accused him of being overweight. Negotiations over an extension to his contract were cut short and he was transfer-listed last month.

Just for good measure, the former England striker was involved in a dressing-room spat with his team-mate Trevor Benjamin at a reserve game 10 days ago and has been training with the youth team.

webTitle: Weary Wasim in state of denial

fields.headline: Weary Wasim in state of denial
fields.standfirst: Pakistan great regrets his good name has been sullied forever
fields.trailText: Pakistan great regrets his good name has been sullied forever.
fields.body:
Denial, as President Clinton observed, is much more than a river in Egypt. And he should know. It is also the word that leaps to mind when one speaks to Wasim Akram, one of the most fabulous cricketers the ancient game has produced.

Not even his great fellow countrymen Imran Khan and Fazal Mahmood had such natural bowling talent as this; Wasim is the only bowler to have taken over 400 wickets both in Test matches and one-day internationals and he may yet end his career as the most successful performer in both the short and long game.

But in cricket these days seeing is not always believing. This is a tainted champion, because repeated allegations and innuendos have stained his reputation and now, tragically, they may be remembered long after his mesmeric deeds with the ball, and occasionally the bat, have been forgotten.

He got a bigger cheer than any other Pakistan player when he came in to bat against England in Karachi on Tuesday evening. But when I mentioned his name to the hotel concierge he turned down his lower lip and thumbs and said: "He guilty. Very guilty. Everyone knows. He did bad things." It is a common reaction.

Pakistan's own investigation into match-rigging last summer failed to clear its biggest name. It looked into allegations that Wasim had paid Ata-ur-Rehman to bowl badly in the fifth one-day international against New Zealand in Christchurch in 1993-94 and feigned injury to bowl badly himself. It was also alleged that he unnecessarily withdrew from the World Cup quarter-final against India in Bangalore in 1996, a decision "fatal to the outcome of the game", tampered with the batting order in the Independence Cup in Lahore and in the Singer Champions Trophy in Sharjah to lower the scores, both in 1997-98, and told Aaqib Javed he would not play for Pakistan again while he was captain after the player refused to accept a payment involving money and a car.

Though it was not on the charge list, many people in England were bemused by the Wasim-led Pakistan's defeat by Bangladesh by 62 runs in last year's World Cup. Without taking anything away from Bangladesh, Pakistan's approach was very odd indeed.

Though he was not found guilty of any specific charge, the report concluded: "This commission feels that all is not well here and Wasim Akram is not above board . . . he cannot be said to be above suspicion." It added that he should be fined £3,750, kept under watch, have his finances investigated and be removed from the captaincy as he is "too sullied to hold that office".

Wasim's public attitude, however, is that he is a hurt and helpless victim of a cynical world. And he is still angry with Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, who says he should not play in the coming Test series against England until he proves his innocence.

"It's none of his business," he says. "But it hurt. I lived in England and have been helping England whenever I could for the past 12 years, working with youngsters and trying to do my best when I play. So when the boss of English cricket says this, of course I'm going to be disappointed. Who gives him advice? Our board never commented at what Chris Lewis had to say. It's not our business.

"I'm diabetic now," he says with a forlorn shrug. "Because of all this pressure I have to take three jabs a day. It's been like this for four years now. It has been caused by all this.

"If I did anything I would have been gone by now. Like people have gone. There are jealousy factors. There are no facts, just ideas. 'OK, he must have done this,' people say. Have you got proof? People have made accusations and people have believed them.

"That's what it is, they all think. But now I'm not captain there's no pressure. They say only a captain can be involved in match-fixing. But I wanted to give up the captaincy. I wasn't enjoying it."

He has refused to pay the fine and has lodged an appeal with the Pakistan Cricket Board. "It is not the money," he says. "It is a matter of principle. And after everything I've done in the past 18 months, working hard and doing well, things are going in my favour now. But this thing will be with me all my life, which is something I will always regret."

Wasim, at 34, is certainly playing as well as ever. He has been man of the match in three of Pakistan's past four Test matches, in which he has averaged 62 with the bat and 17 with the ball.

When it comes to cricket Wasim believes England have no chance. "They will suffer because apart from not coming to Pakistan they have not been to India or Sri Lanka very much in recent years. They are not good at playing spin. Saqlain Mushtaq will be the match-winner against them."

Somehow, though, it is impossible to talk only cricket with Wasim Akram. To speak with him, to watch him cavorting with his young son in the hotel pool and, above all else, to watch him play, is to admire the man. Somehow we all want him to be innocent.

 Shane Warne will be out of action for six weeks , missing the start of Australia's Test series against West Indies, after breaking a finger on his right (bowling) hand, catching Mark Waugh at slip in Melbourne playing for Victoria against New South Wales.

webTitle: Blatter and Taylor in slanging match over plans to scrap transfers

fields.headline: Blatter and Taylor in slanging match over plans to scrap transfers
fields.trailText: Football's response to the European Commission's plan to abolish transfer fees lies in tatters this evening after Fifa president Sepp Blatter and PFA chief executive Gordon Taylor were involved in an extraordinary public slanging match at a Fifa press conference.
fields.body:
Football's response to the European Commission's plan to abolish transfer fees lies in tatters this evening after Fifa president Sepp Blatter and PFA chief executive Gordon Taylor were involved in an extraordinary public slanging match at a Fifa press conference.

Taylor, who is chairman of the European player's union Fifpro, accused Blatter of having a "hidden agenda" and refusing to listen to the concerns of the players. Blatter retorted with angry shouts that Taylor was refusing to answer his questions.

The spat began when Taylor boycotted a morning meeting of the joint Fifa-Uefa Task Force to discuss the EC's proposal, because he felt the concerns of his members were not being addressed. Instead he sent alternative proposals to the meeting, only for them to be completely ignored.

When Taylor found out about this snub, he immediately left his Zurich hotel for Fifa headquarters. As he arrived Blatter was telling a packed press conference of his "disappointment" at FifPro's action and condemning the Englishman for going back on an agreement to attend the meeting.

On seeing Taylor, Blatter angrily demanded to know why he hadn't turn up.

Taylor responded by claiming that the Task Force was merely trying to tinker with the present transfer system rather than attempt to find a plausible alternative. Disliking what he was hearing, Blatter interrupted, shouting for Taylor to "answer the question."

"We have attended at least a dozen meetings, all of which have ignored the main problem," an angry Taylor replied. "The proposals the Task Force is putting forward are ambiguous and look as though they have been drafted with the hidden agenda of maintaining the status quo."

Taylor added that FifPro will present alternative proposals to the EC next week, possibly on the same day Fifa hand over their documents which will be drafted on Monday afternoon.

Later, Blatter sounded more conciliatory, conceding that Fifa's attempts to address the problems within the current system will not meet with EC approval without the backing of the players.

"I would urge them to talk to us," he pleaded. "To meet without them is like having your body decapitated. We know that we cannot have any new regulations adopted without the backing of the players."

The argument between Fifa and Fifpro centres on what should be done about the movement of players over the age of 23 while they are still under contract.

The Fifa Task Force believes that a biannual transfer window should be set up, with each player limited to just one move a season, signing contracts which in an ideal world would tie them in for a minimum of three years.

However, FifPro are at odds with the whole scheme. Taylor believes players should only be forced to sign one or two-year contracts, with compensation being determined by the length still remaining on the deal and the outstanding salary.

But with European Competitions Commissioner Mario Monti appearing to back down from his threat to end the transfer system altogether, the whole situation has become a confusing shambles.

fields.headline: McLeish voted first minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Henry McLeish was formally voted in as Scotland's first minister yesterday as he pledged that he would not bow to influence from London.
fields.body:
Henry McLeish was formally voted in as Scotland's first minister yesterday as he pledged that he would not bow to influence from London.

At the weekend he had been made interim leader of the Scottish Labour party using a controversially scaled-down version of the party's normal electoral procedure.

Accepting his new position, an emotional Mr McLeish said: "It is a very great privilege. Thanks for the honour - and let me say I won't let you down."

The Queen will formally approve the first minister today, before he is sworn in at the court of session in Edinburgh.

Both the Scots Conservative leader, David McLetchie, and the Scottish National party leader, John Swinney, stood against Mr McLeish in yesterday's vote by MSPs, ostensibly in protest at his apparent choice by London and at a subsequent peace offer to liaise with his party by means of his civil servant advisers.

Of 123 MSPs voting yesterday, Mr McLeish received 68 votes, Mr Swinney 33, Mr McLetchie 19, and Dennis Canavan, an independent, three.

webTitle: FA approach Eriksson, claims Lazio assistant

fields.headline: FA approach Eriksson, claims Lazio assistant
fields.trailText: Sven Goran Eriksson has been approached about the vacant England manager's job, according to his assistant at Lazio, Tord Grip.
fields.body:
Sven Goran Eriksson has been approached about the vacant England manager's job, according to his assistant at Lazio, Tord Grip.

Grip told the Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet: "The English have contacted him to ask if he is interested in taking the job but, as far as I know, there are some other people who have also been asked."

But Grip insisted England would have to be patient if they wanted to get Eriksson: "He has said that he is very flattered by receiving this offer. But his contract with Lazio runs until the end of the season so he'll probably not move anywhere before that."

Grip's claims come just a day after Eriksson flatly denied that he had been in contact with the FA.

webTitle: Why Hodgson is the wrong man for England

fields.headline: Why Hodgson is the wrong man for England
fields.trailText: With Arsène Wenger out of the running and Sven Goran Eriksson making noises about staying at Lazio, the popular perception seems to be that Roy Hodgson is favourite for the England job. I have to say that concerns me.
fields.body:
With Arsène Wenger out of the running and Sven Goran Eriksson making noises about staying at Lazio, the popular perception seems to be that Roy Hodgson is favourite for the England job. I have to say that concerns me.

I wouldn't argue that Roy's record with Switzerland was commendable. He took them first to the 1994 World Cup and then to Euro 96. But in terms of profile and expect- ancy, what he dealt with there was not even close to the pressure that would be heaped on him with England. Much of his coaching has been like that.

Although he had a brief spell at Internazionale, where he was working under the cosh, the first real chance he had to manage here - with Blackburn Rovers - could hardly be described as an overwhelming success. If the same run had happened at Manchester United or Arsenal there would have been far more of a to-do made of it.

Roy took over a club with a strong base, had a good start and then went downhill so rapidly that he was sacked after 18 months with Blackburn bottom of the Premiership. When things started to go against him he did not seem able to put his finger on the pulse and stop the rot, even with plenty of money from Jack Walker.

In fact when you look at some of his purchases, such as splashing out £7.25m on Kevin Davies and £4.25m on Nathan Blake, you wonder about his record in terms of selection. And I believe the England job is mainly about selection and strategy.

Roy is highly regarded as a coach and although the England job encompasses an amount of coaching, you are not going to improve the players' technique that much in the few days you have got them. What you've got to do is make sure you have a group of players who can fit into the pattern you lay down.

When you're with a team like Switzerland you haven't got that big a pool to choose from, so the side more or less looks after itself. In England he would have a greater choice and that can create its own problems.

Two lads might be performing as well as each other for their clubs and you have got to know who's going to fit better into the international sphere, particularly with the spotlight England's players are put under.

I don't want to decry Roy because he has worked very hard to get where he is but we are talking about the England national job here. Someone who has been as successful as him in Switzerland is Christian Gross, but would anybody be touting him as Kevin Keegan's successor?

If the FA wants a man with World Cup coaching experience who's possibly available then there's someone up in Newcastle with a better pedigree than Roy Hodgson and that's Jackie Charlton. And he's won a World Cup winner's medal to boot.

I know a poll in the Sun this week showed 52% support for Roy Hodgson, 31% for Wenger and 17% for Eriksson but that was a bit false. What people were saying was that they wanted an Englishman rather than a foreigner. If they had put Roy up with Terry Venables and Bobby Robson he may not have got a vote.

I'm not opposed to bringing someone in from abroad and believe Eriksson has the right mentality and knowledge for the job. But if I were to choose an Englishman I would sooner go for Peter Reid, John Gregory or in particular Bryan Robson now that Venables has apparently been ruled out.

I certainly don't like what the FA has done in appointing Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren. I rate Steve highly and think Peter has the potential to become a top coach, but he's only done a couple of months as a Premiership manager. It's miles too early and I think the pair should be concentrating on their clubs.

In any case it's not right to put Peter in that position. If we go to Italy next month and take a spanking, does that set him back four or five years in people's eyes?

I know he had a fine record with the Under-21s and went down well with the players, but if he had lost four games at that level no one would have taken the blindest bit of notice. It wouldn't even have merited a headline.

The full England team is a different kettle of fish. There will be people waiting for him to fail, and it's put him under added pressure he doesn't need at this stage of his career.

webTitle: Microsoft break-in: conspiracy or human error?

fields.headline: Microsoft break-in: conspiracy or human error?
fields.standfirst: Only the hacker and the software giant know whether the penetration of its systems was a skilled break-in or whether it was simply a mistake, writes computer editor Jack Schofield
fields.trailText: Only the hacker and the software giant know whether the penetration of its systems was a skilled break-in or whether it was simply a mistake, writes computer editor Jack Schofield.
fields.body:
Cock up or conspiracy? Only the hacker and Microsoft know whether the penetration of its computer systems was a skilled break-in using custom code, or whether somebody working for the software giant did something human, and stupid. Microsoft isn't saying.

Chris McNab, a network security analyst at MIS Corporate Defence Solutions in Maidstone, says there are three possible scenarios. The most feasible, in his view, is that the hacker managed to get a Trojan (a rogue program) past Microsoft's defences, using electronic mail. The second possibility is that the hacker exploited a security lapse: perhaps an employee disabled his security software, or not all Microsoft's anti-virus software was kept up to date. The third possibility is that it was "an inside job": a disaffected employee or "summer intern" let the hacker in.

The current speculation is that Microsoft's firewalls - software designed to block intruders - and mailsweepers - software to detect malicious code attached to email messages - were penetrated by a Trojan: a program that presents itself as a useful document, image file, utility or game. When the user runs the attachment, the hidden Trojan code is installed on their computer.

Once installed, the Trojan could then do its work. It could, for example, record log-on names and passwords and email them to an address outside Microsoft. The common Love Letter virus used similar scripting techniques to mail itself to people in its victims' address books.

The hacker could then use the stolen names and passwords to log on to Microsoft's internal network, in effect pretending to be an employee working "off campus". Depending on that user's security level, the hacker might then be able to find and download "source code", the program code used to create popular applications such as Microsoft Office or Windows 2000.

Having the source code is like having a secret recipe for Coca-Cola. Examining the source code would enable hackers and rival software vendors to learn the strengths and weaknesses of Microsoft's programs. They might be able to improve their own software, by making it more compatible with Windows, or exploit any security holes they might find.

According to the conspiracy theory, a skilled hacker created a custom Trojan to evade Microsoft's defences, which would identify and remove any of the ones in common circulation. Examples include QAZ, SubSeven, Netbus and BackOrifice.

But according to the cock up theory, QAZ or a similar Trojan was installed by accident, and a hacker got lucky. Perhaps someone downloaded an infected program from the internet, installed it from a CD-rom, or brought in an infected notebook computer loaded with an out-of-date virus checker.

Such things should not happen, but they do. Philip Ryan, chairman of the Security Forum and an information security specialist with Peapod, says: "I do security audits all the time, and even in companies that you would think would be the most secure, there are always staff using out-of-date security products."

Graham Cluley, senior technology consultant at Sophos Anti-Virus in the UK, says: "All companies are at risk, because firewalls and anti-virus software are not enough. Staff have to realise that they can't download programs from the web, and they can't run programs unless there's a justifiable business reason for running them. It's all about getting users to act sensibly and take responsibility for the data on their disks."
