fields.headline: Voices from beyond
fields.standfirst:
The words themselves were matter-of-fact but the short message desperately scrawled on one side of a sodden piece of paper sent a chill through us all. Like Scott's heroic contemplation of his end, Lieutenant-Captain Dmitri Kolesnikov's missive from the wreck of the Kursk offers us a taste of the terrifying moments before a certain death. Stephen Moss on how dying became a public affair

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The words themselves were matter-of-fact but the short message desperately scrawled on one side of a sodden piece of paper sent a chill through us all. Like Scott's heroic contemplation of his end, Lieutenant-Captain Dmitri Kolesnikov's missive from the wreck of the Kursk offers us a taste of the terrifying moments before a certain death. Stephen Moss on how dying became a public affair
fields.body:
We had more or less forgotten the Kursk, the Russian nuclear submarine that sank with all hands in August. For a week then it had dominated the headlines, the world held spellbound by the idea that men were dying before our very eyes, tapping out desperate messages that could not be answered. The botched rescue attempts ended, the crew were declared dead, interest waned.

What really drove the story off the front pages was the assurance from President Putin that the 118 submariners had died almost instantaneously, drowning as the vessel foundered in the icy waters of the Barents sea. It was a tragedy, but a recognisable one: ships sink, men die. Death is ordinary; it is the process of dying that is not.

But Putin's assurances were misplaced. The discovery yesterday of a note in the pocket of an officer aboard the Kursk suggests that some of the crew did survive for several hours after the vessel sank, perhaps longer. "It is 13.15. All personnel from sections six, seven and eight have moved to section nine," wrote Lieutenant-Captain Dmitri Kolesnikov. "There are 23 of us here. We have made this decision because none of us can escape."

The words are matter of fact, almost banal: no heroics, no hysteria. On one side of the single sheet of paper, he gives a factual account of the sinking; on the other side, increasingly illegibly as the light fades, he bids farewell to his wife, Olga. "I'm writing blind," says Kolesnikov. There are some figures, but it is unclear what they mean. We are reading blind. But we are reading, and the words are riveting because our darkest imaginings back in August were correct: some men survived and were confronted with the imminence and inevitability of their own deaths. Brutus, preferring honour, may have been able to look at death with indifference, but we cannot, not when the veil is lifted as it is here. Now we will remember the Kursk forever.

Death in the past has usually been mediated. We could rarely be witnesses to the last moments of the living. Most last words sound as if someone else minted them later to confirm that a person died as he lived. From George V's "Bugger Bognor" and PT Barnum's "How were the receipts today in Madison Square Garden?" to Thomas à Becket's "I am ready to die for my Lord", we are being assured that the famous died without anxiety, and most of all that they died in character. Dying is made to seem like the logical conclusion to living: a drawing down of the curtain on a play we have understood.

Gladiators, we were told, would salute Caesar before embracing death; churchmen like Becket would willingly go to their rest; fictional heroes such as Sidney Carton would happily sacrifice themselves. Death was not something to be feared. The elaborate statuary of Victorian cemeteries is a celebration of death. By contrast, our dull headstones - their size and shape dictated by stringent regulations to allow for lawnmowers - reflect a desire to forget it. We fear death, but have to confront it as never before. This is the first age in which death is not mediated. The dying can make us feel the reality of their final moments, and we can hear the emptiness of the ocean.

We have had messages from the dying before, but they have usually been heroic narratives which reinforced the notion of a worthy death. One of the most striking is the diary of Captain Scott, who kept a detailed record of his ill-fated mission to the South Pole in 1912."There was a blizzard blowing in the morning when Oates said 'I am just going outside and may be some time' and he stumbled out of the tent. We knew that poor Oates was walking to his death, but though we tried to dissuade him, we knew it was the act of a brave man and an English gentleman."

The idea of a gentleman's death animates both the diary and the letters Scott wrote as he lay dying. To his wife Kathleen, he wrote: "I want you to take the whole thing very sensibly, as I am sure you will. You know I cherish no sentimental rubbish about remarriage. When the right man comes to help you in life you ought to be your happy self again. I wasn't a very good husband, but I hope I shall be a good memory."

Scott's carefully wrought final thoughts are very different from Lieutenant-Captain Kolesnikov's scribbled message. Scott offers us consolation; Kolesnikov none. Scott had reached the conclusion of a struggle in which he had ultimately been defeated; he has much he wishes to say (including instructions on how his son was to be educated). Kolesnikov is passing the time awaiting death, struggling to see in near darkness.

Increasingly we are allowed to witness that final wait: to experience not Scott-like heroism but the banality, pathos or sheer terror of the moment. Technological change has given us unprecedented access to the process of dying. Kolesnikov's final thoughts were, like Scott's, recorded on paper, but we can only read them thanks to modern salvage equipment. Black boxes record the final words of pilots as their planes plunge into the abyss. Mobile phones and satellite technology mean there is now no place on earth where people are out of reach. Internet links and webcams make it possible to share your life with a worldwide audience. Or, if you wish, your death. The dying, by accident or by design, are now public property.

In 1996, Timothy Leary orchestrated his dying in a manner wholly appropriate to the modern age which, in the 60s, he had helped to define. Diagnosed as having terminal cancer, he allowed web users to share his final days via his home page. "Why not? Why not? Why not?" were his final words to the thousands attending the internet vigil.

Leary also committed his final testament to film, in The Enthusiastic Death of Timothy Leary. Again he was being prescient: though we frequently sanitise death and talk about it euphemistically, we are increasingly willing to film it. In 1998, as part of the series The Human Body, the BBC controversially filmed the last eight months of a man dying of inoperable abdominal cancer in what it said was an effort to break down the great taboo.

Leary chose a public death, but he was perhaps bowing to the inevitable. In an age of TV surveillance and mobile communication, few deaths can be private. The photograph of the terrifying final moments of 12-year-old Mohammed al-Durrah, the Palestinian boy shot in Gaza earlier this month, became the defining image of the renewed Israeli-Palestinian conflict. We are inured to photographs of the dead, but we cannot deal with a small child cowering with his father in the dust, about to die. As with Kolesnikov, at once we feel the living presence and mourn its unnecessary passing.

Days later, that conflict threw up another horrific image: the Palestinian luxuriating in the blood of the Israeli soldiers he had helped batter to death. A lynching on prime-time TV. The killings in Ramallah had one other terrible twist, though the details of the story are disputed. When they discovered their husbands had fallen into the hands of Palestinians, the wives of the two soldiers had attempted to reach them on their mobile phones. Hani Avrahami's frantic calls were reportedly met by an unfamiliar voice, who told her: "I have just killed your husband."

Even on top of Everest, it is no longer possible to die privately. In 1996, as New Zealander Rob Hall lay dying of exposure 200 metres from the summit, he used his radio telephone to call his pregnant wife in New Zealand. He told her he was dying and they calmly discussed possible names for their unborn child. If a film-maker were to invent such a scenario, he would be laughed out of Hollywood.

Everything now is recorded, including death. The fact of James Bulger's murder was horrific, but what made it overpowering was that grainy image of a tiny child being led from a shopping centre, hand in hand with his two killers. Again, the agony lies in seeing the moments before the tragedy, when it might have been averted. It is no longer possible to be impassive: we are the impotent observers of a pointless death; we are implicated.

If death isn't seen, it seems, it is heard. This week jurors at Reading crown court were played a recording of a telephone call which six-year-old Zeshan Zaidi made to the emergency services while his father was allegedly stabbing his mother and sister. Shortly after the call was made, Zeshan was murdered. The emotional impact on those who heard the call is unimaginable.

More and more we are used to hearing the final words of the dying, usually pilots struggling to save their aircraft. Their words have to be subjected to close textual analysis. As Egyptair flight 990 began its plunge into Nantucket Sound a year ago, co-pilot Gamil El Batouty could be heard intoning: "I rely on God, I rely on God, I rely on God." Was he inviting the end, or praying to God for help in averting catastrophe?

The plane crash is the modern way of death: slick, detached and public. When the golfer Payne Stewart's Learjet criss-crossed the US last year with Stewart, his three companions and the two pilots dead on board and the plane flying on autopilot, the nation watched on TV. For four hours it flew across the country, with an impromptu escort of airforce fighters, before running out of fuel and spiralling into a field in South Dakota. This time there was no note, no word: a sudden loss of cabin pressure had almost certainly rendered all six unconscious within seconds.

Death, having once been heroic, has become surreal: America's favourite golfer suspended in space in his private plane as his adoring fans prayed for him will suffice as its defining modern image. We no longer look for logic or meaning in death, nor do we have the words to express our emotions. As Ian Hamilton pointed out last year in an essay on black-box recordings, even as the end nears pilots rarely depart from the colourless operational language of flying.

Yet at such moments, as Hamilton recognised, even jargon has immense power. In the face of death, perhaps all are heroes, however unheroic the age. Unlike Scott, Dmitri Kolesnikov was not seeking to die a good death. But in doing his duty and then saying farewell to his wife, he did precisely that.

In 1996, Timothy Leary orchestrated his dying in a manner wholly appropriate to the modern age which, in the 60s, he had helped to define. Diagnosed as having terminal cancer, he allowed web users to share his final days via his home page. "Why not? Why not? Why not?" were his final words to the thousands attending the internet vigil. Leary also committed his final testament to film, in The Enthusiastic Death of Timothy Leary. Again he was being prescient: though we frequently sanitise death and talk about it euphemistically, we are increasingly willing to film it. In 1998, as part of the series The Human Body, the BBC controversially filmed the last eight months of a man dying of inoperable abdominal cancer in what it said was an effort to break down the great taboo. Leary chose a public death, but he was perhaps bowing to the inevitable. In an age of TV surveillance and mobile communication, few deaths can be private. The photograph of the terrifying final moments of 12-year-old Mohammed al-Durrah, the Palestinian boy shot in Gaza earlier this month, became the defining image of the renewed Israeli-Palestinian conflict. We are inured to photographs of the dead, but we cannot deal with a small child cowering with his father in the dust, about to die. As with Kolesnikov, at once we feel the living presence and mourn its unnecessary passing. Days later, that conflict threw up another horrific image: the Palestinian luxuriating in the blood of the Israeli soldiers he had helped batter to death. A lynching on prime-time TV. The killings in Ramallah had one other terrible twist, though the details of the story are disputed. When they discovered their husbands had fallen into the hands of Palestinians, the wives of the two soldiers had attempted to reach them on their mobile phones. Hani Avrahami's frantic calls were reportedly met by an unfamiliar voice, who told her: "I have just killed your husband." Even on top of Everest, it is no longer possible to die privately. In 1996, as New Zealander Rob Hall lay dying of exposure 200 metres from the summit, he used his radio telephone to call his pregnant wife in New Zealand. He told her he was dying and they calmly discussed possible names for their unborn child. If a film-maker were to invent such a scenario, he would be laughed out of Hollywood. Everything now is recorded, including death. The fact of James Bulger's murder was horrific, but what made it overpowering was that grainy image of a tiny child being led from a shopping centre, hand in hand with his two killers. Again, the agony lies in seeing the moments before the tragedy, when it might have been averted. It is no longer possible to be impassive: we are the impotent observers of a pointless death; we are implicated. If death isn't seen, it seems, it is heard. This week jurors at Reading crown court were played a recording of a telephone call which six-year-old Zeshan Zaidi made to the emergency services while his father was allegedly stabbing his mother and sister. Shortly after the call was made, Zeshan was murdered. The emotional impact on those who heard the call is unimaginable. More and more we are used to hearing the final words of the dying, usually pilots struggling to save their aircraft. Their words have to be subjected to close textual analysis. As Egyptair flight 990 began its plunge into Nantucket Sound a year ago, co-pilot Gamil El Batouty could be heard intoning: "I rely on God, I rely on God, I rely on God." Was he inviting the end, or praying to God for help in averting catastrophe? The plane crash is the modern way of death: slick, detached and public. When the golfer Payne Stewart's Learjet criss-crossed the US last year with Stewart, his three companions and the two pilots dead on board and the plane flying on autopilot, the nation watched on TV. For four hours it flew across the country, with an impromptu escort of airforce fighters, before running out of fuel and spiralling into a field in South Dakota. This time there was no note, no word: a sudden loss of cabin pressure had almost certainly rendered all six unconscious within seconds. Death, having once been heroic, has become surreal: America's favourite golfer suspended in space in his private plane as his adoring fans prayed for him will suffice as its defining modern image. We no longer look for logic or meaning in death, nor do we have the words to express our emotions. As Ian Hamilton pointed out last year in an essay on black-box recordings, even as the end nears pilots rarely depart from the colourless operational language of flying. Yet at such moments, as Hamilton recognised, even jargon has immense power. In the face of death, perhaps all are heroes, however unheroic the age. Unlike Scott, Dmitri Kolesnikov was not seeking to die a good death. But in doing his duty and then saying farewell to his wife, he did precisely that.

fields.headline: Airey replaces Elstein at C5
fields.trailText: 5pm update:Channel 5 shareholders' fear of losing Dawn Airey is said to have been a key factor behind chief executive David Elstein's departure, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 director of programmes Dawn Airey is taking over from David Elstein as the broadcaster's chief executive, in a shock move announced on Friday afternoon.

Mr Elstein, who became chief executive seven months before Channel 5 went on air in March 1997, will leave immediately with no other job to go to.

Ms Airey is to remain as director of programmes for the time being. At the same time, Channel 5 director of sales Nick Milligan has been promoted to deputy chief executive.

A key factor in the timing of the decision to replace Mr Elstein is understood to have been Channel 5 shareholders' fear that they might lose Ms Airey.

She is known to have had a number of approaches in the past couple of years, most recently from Granada Media about becoming managing director of its Granada Creative division.

One source close to Channel 5 said: "It was a choice between keeping David and losing Dawn - between the past and the future. The shareholders chose the moment, but David goes with huge gratitude for the job he's done."

But Mr Elstein was also understood not to have seen eye-to-eye with Richard Eyre, director of strategy and content at the RTL Group, which became Channel 5's majority shareholder earlier this year.

RTL owns 65% of Channel 5, after inheriting Pearson TV and CLT-Ufa's stakes in the broadcaster when the two companies merged to create the pan-European giant earlier this year. United News & Media holds the remaining 35% stake.

Mr Elstein, who will be exercising his contractual share options, said: "My contract was geared to optioning my benefits as soon as I had completed four years in charge. I left it to the shareholders to choose the actual moment of exercise and they have acted at a time when the channel needs to take a deep breath, galvanise its forces and move on to stage two of its life."

He added that with "all the senior team in place, there is no need for a handover period and the generosity of my contract terms allows me to consider my next step, free of the day-to-day pressures involved in running Channel 5".

Ms Airey said: "It remains the company's aim to drive share to new levels whilst still maintaining a lean cost base and an inventive approach to programming and scheduling. We want to retain the strategic advantage of being the most cost-effective terrestrial broadcaster in terms of viewing share per pound spent on screen."

Channel 5's audience share is around 6% and advertising revenue has risen by almost 50% since the channel's first full year on air in 1998.

fields.headline: Schools fail ethnic minority pupils
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Read the report in PDF format (Adobe Acrobat Reader needed)
fields.trailText: Black and ethnic minority youngsters are disadvantaged in the classroom by an education system which perpetuates existing inequalities, according to a damning report published by the schools watchdog Ofsted today.
fields.body:
Black and ethnic minority youngsters are disadvantaged in the classroom by an education system which perpetuates existing inequalities, according to a damning report published by the schools watchdog Ofsted today.

Despite the government's commitment to tackling racism, the report says that black children failed to share in the dramatic rise in attainment at GCSE, which took place in the 1990s, to the same degree as their white peers.

The report, Educational Inequality: Mapping Race, Class and Gender, was commissioned by Ofsted from researchers David Gillborn, of the University of London's institute of education, and Professor Heidi Mirza, of Middlesex University.

Overall, the proportion of teenagers in England reaching the government's bench-mark of getting five or more GCSEs at grades A -C, has risen from 32.8% in 1989 to 47.9% in 1999 - almost half as much again over 10 years. But national statistics are not broken down according to ethnic origin by the Department for Education and the researchers had to analyse more limited data provided by the Youth Cohort Study of England and Wales.

Each of the main ethnic groups was found to have achieved higher standards than ever before. But their share in the rise in standards has been unequal across the different groups.

Nationally, African-Caribbean, Pakistani and Bangladeshi pupils are markedly less likely to attain five higher grade GCSEs than their white and Indian peers. And African-Caribbean and Pakistani pupils have drawn least benefit from the rising standards, with the gap between them and their white peers now bigger than a decade ago.

A major obstacle in the research was the failure of local authorities to monitor ethnic pupils' achievement. The researchers used data from 118 local education authorities, submitted to the DfEE in support of their bids for an ethnic minority achievement grant (Emag) to supply teaching for ethnic minority pupils.

But almost a third of the authorities did not record current GCSE attainment by ethnic origin.

Of just six authorities who included baseline assessments by ethnic group, one large inner-city authority showed that African-Caribbean pupils enter compulsory schooling as the highest achieving group but leave as the group least likely to gain five high grade GCSEs.

Data from this authority shows that the relative attainment of African-Caribbean pupils declines at each key stage at school.

The researchers said: "That any ethnic group could enter school 20 percentage points in advance of the average but leave 21 points behind opens up an important area for educational debate on ethnic minority attainment."

Co-author David Gillborn added: "This is a shocking report which underlines the need for some form of national monitoring by the DfEE. Black pupils often enter schools ahead of their white peers.

"It is scandalous that they fall behind and end up in restricted ability groups, being entered for the lower tiers of GCSEs."

The school standards minister, Jacqui Smith, said: "It is good that ethnic minority children are achieving higher standards, but there is varied performance between authorities.

"Clearly more needs to be done, which is why we have shown our commitment to helping schools and authorities further in this important work."

webTitle: Task-force tantrums, managerial mind games, and cockney chat

fields.headline: Task-force tantrums, managerial mind games, and cockney chat
fields.trailText: SEPP AND GORDON'S TRANSFER LOVE-IN
fields.body:
SEPP AND GORDON'S TRANSFER LOVE-IN

Here are three statements you may find interesting. Any proposed reforms to the intended abolition of transfer fees have to be submitted to the European Competitions Commissioner, Mario Monti, next week. As it stands, the world of football has not agreed on any. Instead, they've spent their time accusing each other of getting it wrong. Who would ever have thought it?

Today was supposed to be the day that the Blair-esque Transfer Task Force (comprised of various Uefa bigwigs and, er, Gordon Taylor) finally got its battle plan together. But, mainly thanks to Taylor it has to be said, the group has come to no agreement. The head of the PFA, who doubles as boss of the Europe-wide player's union Fifpro, decided not to attend this morning's TTF plenary meeting because he has spent the past few months arguing with them. So instead he sent a sheet of proposed amendments and hoped they would be discussed.

They weren't, and Gordon got a bit testy. "[The TTF's] proposals are too ambiguous, although they are designed that way because essentially all the leagues and associations want to do is try to maintain things as they are," Gordon told the world in his best conspiratorial tones. "For the meeting not to even discuss our alternatives is very disappointing to say the least. It appears they have a hidden agenda."

Gordon then stormed off and walked in on a press conference being held by Sepp Blatter who - surprise surprise - is head of the TTF. Spotting Gordon out of the corner of his eye, Sepp interrupted his own oration to demand: "Why did you not attend today? Answer the question! You can't just hide behind accusations. When we present our findings to the European Commission in Brussels next Tuesday, we will have to tell them what has happened!"

And on that "nur nur nu-nur nur" note, we'll leave it. After all, the most important people in the game acting like school children at a crucial point in footballing history is only funny for so long.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MIND GAMES

"Just what is going on in Sven Goran Eriksson's brain?" the Fiver has asked itself repeatedly. Unfortunately, a flick through Kelvin Koogan's guide to managerial mind games left us babbling incoherently. And so we turned to the only man that might help - TV's Raj Persaud, the psychiatrist from This Morning who stands in for Esther when she's away. But he was busy, so we're going to have to wade through the conflicting evidence ourselves.

So here goes. Yesterday, Mr Eriksson claimed he was "very satisfied at Lazio" before admitting: "I feel like I could do the England job." Other ambiguities followed, and the only thing the sexy Swede seemed certain about was that no-one - not even Del Boy Crozier - from the FA had spoken to him. "I have not had any formal offer or approach," he insisted. And the Fiver believed him - until we settled down with our favourite Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet, that is. Imagine our shock when we saw an interview with Eriksson's assistant at Lazio, Tord Grip, in which he revealed that sneaky Sven had indeed been approached by England!

"The English have contacted him to ask if he is interested in taking the job," Grip admitted. "He has said that he is very flattered by receiving this offer, but his contract with Lazio runs until the end of the season so he'll probably not move anywhere before that. I don't know how our president would take such a thing." Early this afternoon, Tord found out. "Mr Eriksson is our coach and certainly will not be allowed to leave or have discussions until after his contract expires," Lazio uberlord Sergio Cragnotti thundered. "He has been offered a new contract and it is our hope he stays," he continued, without holding his breath for any final decision.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Every now and then, unfortunately, things happen in the sporting world which degrade the true meaning of sport and effect not only sports people but the community itself. Sporting competitions must always retain their character of healthy and conciliatory entertainment" - Pope John Paul II on Sinisa Mijhalovic and Lazio. Barry Venison better watch out.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

UNHAPPY HAMMERS

Nobody messes EastEnder manager Harry Redknapp abaht. If you step out of line, he'll haul you into his portakabin and dispense some advice into your shell-like before you can say 'six months behind Corrie with unexpected teenage pregnancy storyline'. Why, only this morning, popular local character Paolo Di Canio was summoned into Harry's den for a "chat". And all he had done was tell Italian radio that a move to Lazio would be "like a dream".

"The lads are getting a bit sick of some of Paolo's comments," Redknapp explained today, understandably distressed after hearing Di Canio explain how "immensely happy" he would be if West Ham accepted a £3.75m offer from the Rome club. "He gets frustrated when things aren't going well, steam comes out of his ears and he has moments when he goes over the top," said Redknapp, helpfully demonstrating the steam-coming-out-of-ears thing himself.

But while Harry's analysis of Di Canio is hardly the stuff of shocks, a report in the London Evening Standard which suggests the Hammers are prepared to let him go if Lazio stump up £5m is. The Fiver expected Redknapp to immediately deny any intention to part with the popular ball-volleyin', ref-shovin' genius, but that isn't quite what happened. Ostensibly giving it the 'he's staying here' spiel, a sly Harry simply smiled and said, "We just want him to play football" - without specifying exactly where he wants him to do it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Aston Villa manager John Gregory is lining up a £10m swoop for Tore Andre Flo, according to reports.

Abel Xavier has confirmed he wants a move to Benfica. "I can confirm that I was officially contacted by Mr Alvaro Brago Junior plus some other people from Benfica," he admitted. "They had revealed interest in my work and, of course, I am therefore honoured. Already previous talk had existed but, this time, it was official."

Real Madrid are lining up a move for Barcelona midfielder Xavi, according to Planet Football.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Ronaldo has been summoned to court to explain why he played in the 1998 World Cup final hours after suffering a convulsive fit. Today, Brazilian newspaper Estado de Minas printed details of Nike's contract with the Brazilian Football Confederation which showed that Nike had a say in the selection of "at least eight players" in the squad. Meanwhile, Edmundo has declared he was present when a Nike official told Ronaldo to play in the final, an allegation that Nike deny.

Former Bayer Leverkusen coach Christoph Daum has had his home and office searched as part of an ongoing probe into a circle of suspected cocaine dealers. "We are investigating him on suspicion of possessing cocaine, not for dealing in cocaine," said Erich Jung, the chief state prosecutor of Koblenz.

Eddie Thompson, owner of a chain of grocery stores, has made a formal bid to buy Dundee United.

Colin Todd's proposed move to Derby as Jim Smith's assistant took a new twist today. Swindon claim Todd is still their manager and have asked him to take a few days leave "to allow the matter to resolve itself".

West Bromwich Albion are aiming to raise £1.5m from a share issue to fund a new 8,000-seater stand to replace the existing Rainbow Stand. The club will also look to invest some of the money to improve facilities at their football development centre.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)

Hold on there's no Hold The Back Page this week! What's Friday without Brian Bouffant?

Sky Sports 2: Live First Division Football - Preston v Burnley (7pm)

An evening with Erik Meijer scarcely compensates.

webTitle: Earth will get hotter than expected

fields.headline: Earth will get hotter than expected
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Leading climate scientists now agree that human pollution, mainly from fossil fuels, has added substantially to global warming in the past 50 years and that the Earth is likely to get far hotter than previously predicted, with immense consequences for people and wildlife.
fields.body:
Leading climate scientists now agree that human pollution, mainly from fossil fuels, has added substantially to global warming in the past 50 years and that the Earth is likely to get far hotter than previously predicted, with immense consequences for people and wildlife.

A summary of the 1,000-page final draft of new research by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change - a UN-sponsored group made up of the world's leading atmosphere scientists - has been sent to governments this week. It is expected to add urgency to talks on global climate change in the Hague next month, at which Britain intends to take a lead in urging states to set targets and timetables to cut emissions.

The report suggests that the upper range of warming over the next 100 years could be far higher than estimated in 1995. Its worst-case scenario raises the average global temperature by 6C (11F) above the 1990 level. Average temperatures today are 5C (9F) higher than they were at the end of the last ice age. Five years ago the panel predicted that average temperatures would, at worst, rise by 3C (6.3F)

The leaked document is the first major update of climate prediction since 1995, when the panel concluded that there was "a discernible human influence" on the Earth's climate because of the greenhouse effect - which is caused by the buildup of heat-trapping chemicals in the atmosphere.

The panel has now concluded that the burning of fossil fuels and emission of man-made chemicals has "contributed substantially to the observed warming over the last 50 years". The scientists believe, too, that temperatures could rise far higher and faster than previously predicted if emissions are not curtailed.

The human influence on the Earth's climate has long been debated, but this is the first time such an authoritative group has gone so far.

While there are still uncertainties, scientists say there is an "increasing body of observations that provide a collective picture of a warming world that cannot be solely explained by natural forces. Emissions of greenhouse gases and aerosols due to human activities continue to alter the atmosphere in ways that affect the climate system," the report says.

Many panel members in the US say that the summary represents the closest thing to a consensus possible in science.

They point to the additional data gathered in the past three years, which shows that the world is much warmer than any similar string of years in many centuries; improvements in computer models designed to project future trends; and better understanding of the influence of other emissions, such as particles of sulphates which can cool the Earth by reflecting sunlight back into space.

Speaking in a personal capacity yesterday, one of the British authors of the report, Mike Hume of the University of East Anglia, described the research as "incremental back-up" to what had been suspected for years.

"Our current best insights lead us to see a continuation of global warming and an acceleration of it," he said.

Evidence of increased warming has been found in retreating glaciers, thinning polar sea ice, retreating snow packs, increased precipitation, and the big rise in weather-related natural disasters .

Global warming will deeply affect poor countries, leading to huge numbers of refugees, crop failures, and extreme weather. Most emissions of carbon, the main greenhouse-warming gas, are from rich countries. The US is responsible for 23% of carbon emissions; Britain's 3% is the same as that of Africa.

"More and more people working in atmospheric science or on climate or ecology have had to come to grips with the fact that climate change is affecting what they're looking at," he said.

"It reinforces what we were able to say in 1995," said Tom Wigley, another NCAR climatologist. "It shows the previous projections in 1990 and 1995 were conservative."

Some governments may insist on changing the text before it is published in May.

webTitle: Oct 27: Diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: First with the news
fields.standfirst: It's time to ensure staff are fully briefed before a highly critical, council-commissioned report into children's services hits the press
fields.trailText: Should have been off this week for half term - but had to come in on Monday to spend the day briefing staff and the press about the impending Barratt report.
fields.body:
Should have been off this week for half term - but had to come in on Monday to spend the day briefing staff and the press about the impending Barratt report.

The report will be discussed on October 30 at a special policy committee, alongside the social services inspectorate report about our children's services. The documents will go out on Tuesday, so we want to make sure that staff heard about it all from us before they read about it in the paper. Also wanted to give press briefings to try to ensure some well informed coverage. (I am resolutely optimistic - even in the face of bitter experience.)

Staff briefings go well. Chief executive chairs, executive member for children and health presents, I speak about what we are doing and how we are moving forward, there are questions and the leader of the council winds up. The chair of scrutiny is also on the panel. I think it works, in terms of staff seeing the high level of corporate commitment and concern there is in the organisation. Turnout is a bit low, not least because it's half term.

It is a challenge to keep staff's hearts up while enabling proper, thoughtful reflection on the past and the undoubted failings of the organisation. It is a difficult time and will continue to be until Christmas. These reports will be followed by the joint review and it is hard to deal with a sequence of reports telling you things are bad. I hope we can keep the many good staff and managers we have and continue to attract more over the coming months.

Finish off the day with policy committee where there is long discussion about our family finders services and how the best value review is being implemented. I collapse in bed later and forget until the morning that I am on holiday.

 Lisa Christensen is executive director, social services and health improvement, for the London borough of Lambeth

fields.headline: China to outlaw 'second wives'
fields.standfirst: New freedoms are undermining marriage. So Beijing is trying to legislate against the mistress
fields.trailText: New freedoms are undermining marriage. So Beijing is trying to legislate against the mistress
fields.body:
Legislation to make life tougher for Chinese men with concubines has been tabled this week for debate in parliament in Beijing. The marriage law was last changed in 1980; now sweeping amendments are being considered by the standing committee of the National People's Congress.

The initiative responds to a tide of public opinion against misbehaving husbands, led by the official Women's Federation - a tide swollen by anger at corrupt officials who use their ill-gotten loot to finance a "second wife".

Hong Kong businessmen with mistresses on the mainland are also feeling the pressure: a typical case is that of Lin Guande, who has been sentenced to six months in a Chinese jail.

Lin, like many other Hong Kongers trading in Guangdong province, bordering Hong Kong, found a new Chinese partner, and relations with his wife deteriorated at home.

He and his mistress, Lao Xia, made the mistake of holding a "wedding party" to celebrate their relationship at an expensive restaurant late last year. He has been sentenced to six months for bigamy; his partner has been given a suspended sentence.

The proposed amendments to the marriage law reflect widespread concern at a decline in the institution of marriage.

The Women's Federation in Guangzhou city, the capital of Guangdong province, has even been pressing for extra-marital affairs to be made illegal.

Pressure for the changes, says the China Daily, has been "largely caused by the 'concubine phenomenon' that is sweeping the country, especially in southern provinces, as increasing numbers of men get wealthier".

In the most notorious recent case a senior official sentenced to death for corruption in July, Cheng Kejie, was said to have committed his crimes in collusion with his mistress, Li Ping.

Pictures of the gold, diamond rings and expensive watches the two accumulated were shown in public anti-corruption exhibitions.

A Communist party spokesman said the "temptations of women and money" were to blame for Mr Cheng's fall from his position as top party boss in Guangxi province.

Guilty officials

The pending revision of the law covers not only bigamy - already a criminal offence - but also domestic violence, property rights and the care of children.

Divorce was almost unheard of during the decades of Mao Zedong's leadership, from the 1950s to the 1970s, when social pressure ensured that couples stayed together even when their marriage had broken down.

Though the current statistics are unreliable, one newspaper claimed this week that as many as a million marriages now break down each year.

Another estimate held domestic violence responsible for one in three cases.

Keeping concubines is associated in Chinese minds with the feudal society of the past, when rich men might have half a dozen secondary wives in one household.

The practice was eroded by modern 20th-century thinking, and outlawed by the post-1949 socialist society. Today's "number two women" are installed in separate accommodation, often in a different town from the primary family home.

Chinese experts say that a large number of the men involved are Communist party officials who embezzle public funds to set up a second home. Several recent cases of corruption in high places have featured a mistress, whose role has been painted in lurid colours by the popular press.

A senior official of the the standing committee considering the amendments, Hu Kangsheng, said the rise in adultery had as its driving force "rich and powerful [people] who became subjected to the obsolete and decadent ways of thinking of the feudalist society of the past".

To many younger Chinese the issue is more complex than that. They take a more relaxed view of sexual behaviour, and they may have watched their own parents endure loveless marriages.

Various new definitions of bigamy have been suggested, including cohabitation for more than six months and a partnership which produces children.

The draft law does not contain such rigid stipulations: Mr Hu said this week that the committee would have to consult legal experts and the supreme court first. There are fears that the new emphasis on trying to shore up marriage by legal means as recipe for "social stability" may result in the fettering of individual rights. The new law will stress couples' "mutual responsibility for faithfulness in marriage".

Labour-camp solution

A proposal for a three-year separation period before a couple divorce has been dropped, presumably because it is considered unrealistic.

The debate on marriage in China's new age has been rumbling on for several years, and refuses to go away. Two years ago the Women's Federation in Guangzhou city called for married men who kept mistresses to be sent to labour camps.

Some newspapers at the time voiced opposition, publishing letters from people saying the state should stay out of their private lives.

fields.headline: b is for boxing
fields.standfirst: Why has chic French designer Agnès b teamed up with the sportswear company Everlast?  Simon O'Connell  finds out
fields.trailText: Why has chic French designer Agnès b teamed up with the sportswear company Everlast? Simon O'Connell finds out
fields.body:
I remember staying up late at night to watch Ali fight. It was a pleasure to look at him - the way he danced on his beautiful legs, and that baby face. I loved him so much." Agnès Troublé (the "b" in Agnès b is from Bourgeois, her first husband's surname) is talking about her love of Muhammad Ali, which three decades later has led her to collaborate with Everlast, his kit supplier and one of America's oldest sportswear companies, on a new range of clothing, b Everlast.

At first this seems a highly improbable partnership. Agnès b epitomises French chic and understatement, while Everlast is a rugged sports brand little known outside the often brutal world of boxing. But in fact the synergy is as crystal clear as the gulf between Ali and most of his opponents. Agnès b eschews ostentation in her work, dislikes the fashion world (she always refers to her designs as clothing, never fashion) and has stuck to many of her classic styles since founding the label in 1973. Her famous snap cardigan has remained a staple since 1979. Everlast, meanwhile, continues to produce garments almost identical to those of 50 years ago and studiously avoids designs that flirt with fashionability.

Agnès b has always admired Everlast's classicism and heritage, but was unaware of the mutual respect at Everlast for her designs. "About three years ago, Everlast sent a selection of their classic garments as a present," she explains, "saying they thought the two labels were connected by their simplicity and everlasting designs. I later asked if I could contribute to their designs and we came up with the idea of launching a joint label."

Everlast's heyday corresponds to a golden period in Agnès b's own life - the late 60s and 70s, a time of revolution, rebellion and optimism. "In New York there are still red neon-lit bars with pictures of the great boxers on the walls and all of them wore Everlast. This was an epic time for boxing. There is something very noble about these pictures. They remind me of Paris in 68."

Agnès b is famous for several things: for dressing the stars in both Reservoir Dogs and Pulp Fiction (think Uma Thurman in white blouse and black cigarette pants), for seemingly preferring art and film to fashion, and for being probably the only fashion designer to carry the spirit of the 1968 riots with her to this day. Fleeing from her middle-class background as a youth, Agnès opted for right-on poverty, marches and ferrying wounded demonstrators to hospital in her car. This uncompromising attitude permeates everything she does. She refuses to advertise, which may explain why, despite running a business with a £75m turnover and being revered in France and Japan, she is not as famous as some lesser designers in this country.

Her customers are extremely loyal because her clothes are of a quality and classic design that ensures wardrobe longevity. Everlast, too, provokes fierce loyalty in the boxing world. The company has been based in New York's Bronx since 1910, handing out free sportswear to promising boxers.

"Famous boxers including Ali, Larry Holmes and Evander Holyfield wore Everlast at the height of their careers but no fee was paid. They stayed loyal because they remembered that, when they were poor kids who couldn't afford training gear, Everlast supported them. They wanted to repay that," says Brian Kristofferson, Everlast's head of European distribution. In a world of multi-million-pound kit sponsorship deals, such loyalty seems anachronistic. It is impossible to imagine top sportsmen wearing Nike or Adidas for free today.

A combination of loyalty and moral rectitude has also meant that, until now, Agnès has refused to manufacture anything outside her native France, partly out of patriotism, partly because quality is high in French factories, but mainly because she wants to avoid exploitation of workers in developing countries, which other labels routinely accept. With b Everlast, though, and its sister range b Sport, the policy is changing slightly. "The collection is made in Morocco because we have increasing ties with North Africa in France and because I like it there," she says. "The factory is also socially responsible as decent wages are paid and child labour is not used."

This sort of attention to detail is evident throughout the Agnès b empire, which employs more than 1,200 people worldwide. In addition to 114 boutiques, she has since 1984 run an art gallery in Paris which has showcased cutting-edge artists such as Seydou Keita, Frederic Bruly Bouabre and photographer Martin Parr. Since 1997 she has funded a magazine, published eight times every year, which gives free rein to selected artists to do as they wish; 100,000 copies are distributed free around the world and recent collaborators have included Gilbert and George, writer-director Harmony Korine and Louise Bourgeois. In 1998, Agnès was the first French person to present the Turner prize to the winner.

Then there are the movies. She has produced three films so far (Funny Games, Seul Contre Tous and Peau Neuve) and has now found a novel way to show her collections - by directing a short movie in which actors model the new collection (she never stages catwalk shows). She was also heavily involved in the recent Sarajevo Film Festival and her current collection is entitled J'aime le cinema .

For all this, Agnès has a relaxed, almost haphazard demeanour. One senses that if something needs doing, she simply does it, working instinctively, as artists do. "I have no difficulty focusing on the clothes with all my other interests. I enjoy it and work quickly. Anyway," she adds, "lots of actors and artists like my clothing which is very encouraging."

fields.headline: Greens are the new black
fields.standfirst: Golf is cool, says  Albert Hill... No, really
fields.trailText: Golf is cool, says Albert Hill... No, really
fields.body:
Golf used to be one long fashion comedy act, all diamond jumpers and garish socks, but this winter there are few hipper places to be seen than honing your handicap on the golf course. Ever since fashion central sent out the orders that argyle was in, nouveau riche was chic and gloves were gorgeous, there was only one game to turn to.

There has always been an element of the catwalk about the amble between holes. Golf, don't you know, is the ideal way to close deals, so dressing your best is part of the game. Luxury labels have long been seen on the greens (luxurious not always being stylish) and it was Prada who blew new life into the sartorial side of the game by producing a sleek range of fairway fashion in 98. Now, though, we're more likely to be coveting our competitors' Scotch House cashmere or Burberry pullover.And it's no longer discreet chic that impresses - where else but on the 18th hole would you get away with a pink gingham visor?

webTitle: Melchett to quit as Greenpeace boss

fields.headline: Melchett to quit as Greenpeace boss
fields.standfirst: Special report: the GM debate
fields.trailText: Peter Melchett announced today that he is to resign as executive director of Greenpeace to spend more time on his organic farm.
fields.body:
Peter Melchett announced today that he is to resign as executive director of Greenpeace to spend more time on his organic farm.

The 52-year-old Labour peer - who quit the Lords when the government axed over 600 hereditaries last year - leaves the environmental pressure group at the end of the year, after working with the organisation since 1985.

In a statement, Lord Melchett said that his time with Greenpeace had "been an incredible and wonderful experience.

"I can't imagine anything better, more fun, or more rewarding, but it's time for me to move on and let someone else have a go."

fields.headline: Dramatic weekend for Northern Ireland
fields.standfirst: This weekend's crucial meeting of the Ulster Unionists threatens to tear the delicate fabric of the Good Friday peace accord, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: This weekend's crucial meeting of the Ulster Unionists threatens to tear the delicate fabric of the Good Friday peace accord, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Once again, Northern Ireland first minister David Trimble is struggling to hold his Ulster Unionist party together.

The party's ruling council meets tomorrow to vote on a proposal that it withdraw from the power sharing executive - a move that would inevitably shatter the Good Friday peace accord.

The council's 860 members are being frantically canvassed by both sides in what has become a bitter struggle for power in the higher levels of the embattled party.

One of the ironies of the situation is that the party's grass roots are apparently solidly behind their leader. A poll of Unionist members today produced encouraging results for Trimble: 68% want him to stay as first minister, and nearly 60% say he is the best man to lead the party.

That's more than twice as many as those that support his main tormentor, Jeffrey Donaldson. Donaldson, who will be proposing the withdrawal motion at the crucial weekend meeting, is undismayed by Trimble's exasperated charge that he is undermining the party as well as the peace process. He argues that it is the peace process itself which is destroying Unionism.

Last month, the party was stunned by its loss of the South Antrim parliamentary byelection to Ian Paisley's stridently anti-Good Friday Democratic Unionist Party. The Donaldson faction believes that if the Unionists stay in the power-sharing executive, their remaining support will simply drain away.

Trimble's case is that the party needs to be in power - or at least have a share of it - to influence the course of the broader agreement, which includes the establishment of all-Ireland institutions.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, infuriated many loyalists when he suggested that those cross-border institutions could be strengthened, if devolved government proves unworkable. His notion of Anglo-Irish "joint authority" in Ulster was intended to jolt the Unionists back into line on power sharing.

Instead, it may have strengthened the hand of the hardliners, who want to distance themselves from the peace process by imposing impossibly tough conditions and deadlines.

Top of their wish-list is IRA disarmament, and the scrapping of plans to reform the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Neither of those things is going to happen. If that is the road the Ulster Unionists choose to travel this weekend, they are going to be heading nowhere. But if they leave, they will tear a hideously large gap in the delicate fabric of the peace process.

webTitle: Inept England fail to take off

fields.headline: Inept England fail to take off
fields.standfirst: Click here for the scorecard
fields.trailText: A couple of days ago Duncan Fletcher said that all England's batsmen bar Alec Stewart were still at the learning stage in one-day internationals. At the time it seemed harsh. Today it looked generous, as England mirrored their most recent collapse, against South Africa in Kenya. On both occasions they lost six for 28, though it's arguable which one was the more feeble. After the fireworks in Karachi this was like a weakly fizzing Catherine wheel.
fields.body:
A couple of days ago Duncan Fletcher said that all England's batsmen bar Alec Stewart were still at the learning stage in one-day internationals. At the time it seemed harsh. Today it looked generous, as England mirrored their most recent collapse, against South Africa in Kenya. On both occasions they lost six for 28, though it's arguable which one was the more feeble. After the fireworks in Karachi this was like a weakly fizzing Catherine wheel.

Eight of the nine wickets fell to spin - confirming what every Pakistani has been saying for years about England's ability against the slower stuff. But the award for Witless Dismissal of the Day goes to Graeme Hick. His was a masterclass in how not to take a sharp single: start, stop, wait, dawdle, don't ground bat. It had to be seen to be believed.

The other top-order batsmen were almost as culpable. Take Alec Stewart, who mowed mindlessly at Mushtaq Ahmed's first ball. As an attempt to unsettle Mushy from the start it wasn't without merit, but England were already 66 for 0 after 12 overs - a couple of sighters might have been better.

Then there was Nasser Hussain. He may have reached his second consecutive 50 - the first time he has done this in 49 one-day internationals - but it took him 82 balls and the suspicion remains that when the boundaries dry up, so do his scoring options. His dismissal was reminiscent of the one that cost England the first final of the Carlton & United Series in Australia two winters ago when he danced wildly at Shane Warne. The result - an England collapse - was the same.

Graham Thorpe was bowled by a nothing ball, and the rest played the spinners with a mixture of unrewarded sweep shots, gaping gates and stiff forward prods. Imagine John Bull trying to work out Sinbad the Sailor and his flying carpet and you get the picture.

England's ineptitude against the slow bowlers was such that they managed to score just 99 runs in their last 25 overs. On Tuesday Pakistan managed 106 from their last 10. It was that bad.

It also left the bowlers with far too much to do. Ashley Giles was steady, but one left-arm spinner who doesn't turn it much is no match for Saqlain (mystery offspinner) and the legspinning duo of Mushtaq and Afridi. And the fast bowlers were reminded just how hard it is to contain the batsmen here when the ball isn't swinging. Even so, Gough and Caddick didn't help themselves by overstepping eight times in total. For all England's progress with the ball over the last year, this is one area of their game they're getting worse at.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. Click here to read his regularly updated bulletins on today's game

fields.headline: Irish students star in online Big Brother
fields.trailText: The Irish answer to Big Brother and MTV's Real Life launches today, involving five students based in Dublin. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Irish answer to Big Brother and MTV’s Real Life launches today, involving five students based in Dublin.

Five volunteer Dublin students - three male and two female - were today faced with the unenviable task of being filmed going about their everyday lives in their shared home.

The “reality-based” websoap, called No 54, will be available though the Irish student website, Oxygen.ie, with the cameras being switched on until the new year.

In exchange for being filmed, the students will have rent-free accommodation, but only for the duration of the soap. The websoap has been set up by Oxygen, which picked the five contestants from more than 500 students who responded to an ad.

In all, 20 webcams have been installed to cover all the action in every room, including the bathroom.

Cara Given, Oxygen content manager, explained the idea wasn’t just to be an Irish web version of Big Brother. “The show will feature live bands, DJ sets, stand-up comedy and more. The students will live in the house, be online all the time. And their lives will provide the entertainment for the channel where there are no regular scheduled events. They are stars in the making.”

The students involved include Frieda Gormley, 20, a law student at Trinity College, Dublin; Ross O’Mullane, 22, studying information and communications technology at Trinity; Ewan, a Trinity history and French student; Liam Doyle, 23, studying analytical science at Dublin City University; and Siobhan O’Dowd, 20, a drama student from Belfast.

  • This article was amended on 2 December 2021 to remove some personal information

fields.headline: Women are the victims
fields.trailText: Erin Pizzey (Letters, October 26) challenges Bea Campbell's observations that "men are the problem" (Comment, October 25) for our understanding of violence. I am the author of the snapshot of domestic violence in the UK (the results can be found on: www.domesticviolencedata.org. This study was based on police activity throughout the UK on September 28.
fields.body:
Erin Pizzey (Letters, October 26) challenges Bea Campbell's observations that "men are the problem" (Comment, October 25) for our understanding of violence. I am the author of the snapshot of domestic violence in the UK (the results can be found on: www.domesticviolencedata.org). This study was based on police activity throughout the UK on September 28.

On this day, 81% of those contacting police were women attacked by men, 8% men attacked by women; 4% women attacked by women and 7% men attacked by men. Even "official" statistics show that men as perpetrators overwhelmingly dominate domestic violence. Men even attack other men almost as often as women attack them. For some men, domestic violence surely lurks at home. But to deny the impact of gender in the information we have about domestic violence is surely a mistake.

I suggest that Pizzey begin a campaign to stop pub violence. Here is indeed a very serious issue of men's safety vis-a-vis violence in this country. All our evidence suggests that for men, it is the violence found in pubs and clubs and from disputes and conflicts with friends and neighbours that harm men the most.

To deny the gender of violence is to deny all the evidence we have. Since we are now beginning to understand that social policy and practice should be evidence-based, we should insist that good policy understand the gendered nature of violence.
Prof Betsy Stanko
Director, ESRC Violence Research Programme
University of London
vrp@rhul.ac.uk

I addressed the Conservative party conference on domestic violence. I joined the Women's Choices debate, drawing attention to the fact that in a land of freedom and choice many women have no choice even over what happens to their own bodies being, as they are, victims of abuse in the home. I was stopped many times by delegates of both sexes telling me of daughters and women friends who had been beaten up and even stabbed by boyfriends and husbands, and reminding me that abuse can also take the form of mental and psychological control.

The image of women as disposable objects is a possible contributory factor and well overdue for investigation. The report is a damning indictment of domestic life in 21st-century Britain.
Julia Barnes
Cheltenham, Glos

Erin Pizzey is right: women can be violent too. Research carried out for the Department of Health found that over three-quarters of mothers had smacked their one-year-old babies, and 14% used implements - usually wooden spoons and slippers - to hit their children. Domestic violence against babies and children is routinely minimised. In fact three weeks into the 21st century the government issued a consultation document asking whether physical punishment causing brain damage can ever be defended as "reasonable". Let's hope this shameful document marks a turning point and that the law is soon reformed to give children the same protection from assault as adults.
Carolyne Willow
Children's Rights Alliance for England
cwillow@primex.co.uk

Some men are violent some of the time, and in some circumstances - just as some women are. If we begin to look for the causes of such violence, which might range from social factors such as poverty, crime and social exclusion through to the disinhibiting effects of drugs and alcohol, we might start to find some answers. As it is, all Ms Campbell offers is an appeal for the subspecies of man to stop it.
Stephen Baker
London

fields.headline: Is Israel ready for Wagner?
fields.standfirst:
For many Israelis, he is a hated symbol of anti-semitism, a composer whose music provided the soundtrack to the Holocaust. So the playing of Wagner in Tel Aviv tonight breaks a powerful taboo. Suzanne Goldenberg reports
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: For many Israelis, he is a hated symbol of anti-semitism, a composer whose music provided the soundtrack to the Holocaust. So the playing of Wagner in Tel Aviv tonight breaks a powerful taboo. Suzanne Goldenberg reports
fields.body:
When Gil Shohat, a shaven-headed 27-year-old pianist and composer, heard that his works were to feature on a programme with the composer Richard Wagner, he immediately put in a call to his grandmother. She told him: "Fine, if the music is good, let them play." Shohat needed to hear that; his Polish-born grandmother had lost several close relatives in the Nazi holocaust.

"That was my seal of approval," he says.

It is a blessing that Shohat and the rest of the Israel Symphony Orchestra (ISO) could use tonight when they defy a powerful taboo to perform a short piece by Wagner, who remains for Israelis a symbol of anti-semitism. For an older generation, the composer's music is inextricably linked with Hitler - although the German maestro died 50 years before the Nazis came to power. Hitler adored him and claimed inspiration from a racist essay Wagner wrote that earned him the reputation of the arch anti-semite of the musical world.

On Wednesday, a judge in Tel Aviv threw out a petition from the Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Jerusalem, and other holocaust activists, for a restraining order against the ISO, which is based in the central Israeli town of Rishon LeZion. But that did not end the controversy.

The activists appealed to Israel's supreme court, but yesterday it refused to ban the performance. There are plans to demonstrate outside the concert hall, and to use Wagner to draw attention to some 200 anti-semitic attacks around the world, the fallout from Israeli army's bloody clashes with Palestinian demonstrators.

"On a symbolic level, it would be incredibly ironic to have Wagner played for the first time in Israel while anti-semitic outbreaks are taking place all over the world," says Efraim Zuroff of the Simon Wiesenthal Centre.

When the ISO, the smaller, innovative rival to the more famous Israel Philharmonic, announced earlier this year it was putting Wagner's Siegfried Idyll on the programme for its chamber music series, Shohat and other members of the ensemble braced themselves for the storm that was expected to follow. "Of course, I was worried," he says. "I did not want to hurt anyone. I know that Wagner is a symbol for Holocaust survivors."

There was an initial frisson of anger, and then silence. A single ISO supporter cancelled his subscription and a few musicians refused to take part, but unlike other attempts to stage Wagner in Israel, this time it appeared the show was going to go on.

Even so, the orchestra proceeded with extreme caution. It chose a relatively short piece, and one that is shorn of political content: Siegfried's Idyll was written for the birth of Wagner's son. It also decided to reduce the potential for confrontation by relegating Wagner to its second series, played on Friday at lunchtime, and by limiting its advertising.

The extreme delicacy is testimony to the tremendous power Wagner exercises on the popular imagination. Israel is home to 300,000 survivors of the Nazi Holocaust, and the experience is central to the identity of younger generations.

For one day each year, the country freezes to a halt for the siren, whose wail announces two minutes of official remembrance of the Nazis' victims. Radio and television stations are turned over to the broadcast of documentaries about extermination camps and Nazi atrocities.

And the Holocaust is the backdrop for the epic struggle between those who want Israel to remain a fundamentally Jewish state, and those who map out a "post-Zionist" future where Jews and Arabs live as equals.

But at the same time as the Holocaust has remained a defining part of Israeli identity, the 52 years since the creation of a Jewish state have seen a shucking off of the fears that form an older, European view of the world.

"From the 50s, Israelis, including survivors of the concentration camps, drove Volkswagens which were the spiritual creature of Hitler, and they received compensation from the German government," says Ehud Grosz, director of the ISO. "We had the Pope visit earlier this year, and he expressed some kind of remorse for anti-semitism, and we had the president of Germany address our Israeli parliament in Germany. The memory of the Holocaust doesn't need a ban on Wagner."

That appears to be the prevailing view for musicians and the Israeli cultural elite: the time has come to put Wagner on the programme. In such rarefied circles, it is an accepted fact that no orchestra can aspire to world-class status if it does not play Wagner. The Israel Philharmonic practises his works in secret.

"The debate is: do we or do we not distinguish between the artist and his art?" Grosz says. "I think we do, but with sensitivity, and so we have waited for more than 50 years."

In the early days of the Jewish state, it was impossible to distinguish between the man and the music. Until the 60s, Israel's state-owned radio refused to broadcast Schubert's lieder - unless they were sung in Hebrew. It was only a decade ago that Israeli orchestras began performing Bach's St John's Passion, which is now popular with audiences, who apparently fail to notice the depiction of the Jews rigorously calling for the crucifixion of Jesus. Nowadays, Richard Strauss, who was a member of the Nazi party, is regularly featured on concert programmes, and Wagner's recordings are freely available in music shops.

But is Israel ready for Wagner?

In 1981, when conductor Zubin Mehta tried to slip a Wagner composition into an encore at the Philharmonic, the audience began chanting, "Shame, shame" and an usher leapt on to the stage and rolled up his sleeve to display the blue tattooed number of his concentration camp.

Zuroff would argue the country is not ready even now. "There is a certain arrogance to the stance of the Rishon LeZion orchestra trying to present this as a debate between enlightened people, and irrational people," he says. "It is reprehensible to use supposed cultural values to inflict pain on many Israelis."

But since the late 80s, under the stewardship of music director Avi Hanani, Israel Radio has been gently removing the cultural barriers against composers linked to the Nazi era. In the past decade, they have introduced Israelis to the works of Richard Strauss as well as artists who prospered under the Nazi regime, including Herbert von Karajan and Elizabeth Schwartzkopf. Five years ago, there was a Wagner broadcast, albeit as part of a documentary.

The ISO conducted the first performance of Strauss, and last summer the New Israel Opera staged the first performance of a Strauss opera, Elektra, at the Romanian ampitheatre in Cesarea and received a 15-minute standing ovation.

Hanani's efforts at enlightenment have not gone unopposed. Last month, Israel Radio's board of directors pulled a broadcast of Wagner's Lohengrin, the day before it was to be aired. "They told us: 'You can not allow music to be played on the radio that was broadcast on the way to the crematoria'," Hanani says. Except that, in truth, Wagner wasn't. That infamy goes to works routinely played in Israel such as Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata, and Mozart's Eine Kleine Nachtmusik.

"None of us heard Wagner in the time of the Holocaust. We heard German folksongs from the mouths of German soldiers, when we were marched past cities and villages. For me, the association is not Wagner, it's Lily Marlene," says Raoul Tanenbaum, a journalist who spent two years in Bergen Belsen.

Tanenbaum is not opposed to the concert. "It is better trying to analyse the social function of Wagner than to boycott him, especially for a younger generation. Someone can like Wagner's music, but he has to understand what evil can be done with good music."

Even Zuroff admits that singling out Wagner for a boycott is illogical, but is adamant the sentiments behind the ban are just. "Every society lives by its symbols. For whatever reason, Wagner become the symbol rather than Strauss," he says. "People here have very little time to go into issues. They live by stereotypes and by slogans. I want to validate their feelings."

And so that remains the crux of the controversy. "It is always politics and emotion, rather than actual thinking," says Hanani. "It was dug into the heads of politicians that Wagner was evil, and a Nazi. They might well have chosen the Volkswagen as their emblem of hatred, but they did not. Banning Wagner was much more practical."
