webTitle: Fergie helps WH Smith ward off web loss

fields.headline: Fergie helps WH Smith ward off web loss
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Booming sales of electronic organisers, along with with the success of Sir Alex Ferguson's autobiography, helped the high street chain WH Smith increase its annual pre-tax profits by 5% to £140m.
fields.body:
Booming sales of electronic organisers, along with with the success of Sir Alex Ferguson's autobiography, helped the high street chain WH Smith increase its annual pre-tax profits by 5% to £140m.

The rise came despite trading losses of £7m from the company's internet activities. The performance pleased City analysts, and the shares climbed 21.25p to 390.25p.

WH Smith's chief executive, Richard Handover, said: "We're very pleased with these figures - we've made some good steps forward in difficult conditions for retailers."

The chain's sales of "electronic stationery" leapt 45% to £25m as Britons caught on to a global craze for Palm Pilots, Psions and other handheld computers. Mr Handover said: "It's right up out street - stationery is our calling and people come to us for things in that area."

Another strong performer was Hodder Headline, the group's recently acquired publishing business, where operating profits jumped 40% to £16m. Sir Alex's account of his career in football management topped bestseller lists, along with new novels by Stephen King and Josephine Cox.

There has been strong speculation that WH Smith will build on the Hodder acquisition by buying a US publishing business; Viacom's Simon & Schuster is rumoured to be a possible target.

However, Mr Handover played down talk of a big deal: "We're not in the business of making massive, cash-consuming acquisitions in the States. It would have to be the right deal at the right price."

Analyst Philip Dorgan of stockbroker WestLB Panmure said the figures showed WH Smith was improving: he upgraded his recommendation on the shares from "underperform" to "neutral".

Like for like sales were up 5%, and although Mr Handover said the company's entertainment departments had lost sales during the first half of the year they had picked up in recent months, helped by a shift towards a narrower range of best sellers.

fields.headline: Larsson the great leveller
fields.standfirst:
Bordeaux 1 Dugarry 23
Celtic 1 Larsson 25 pen
fields.trailText: A Henrik Larsson penalty cancelled out a goal by the French international Christophe Dugarry to give Celtic a vital away goal in the first leg of their Uefa Cup second-round tie at the Stade Lescure last night.
fields.body:
A Henrik Larsson penalty cancelled out a goal by the French international Christophe Dugarry to give Celtic a vital away goal in the first leg of their Uefa Cup second-round tie at the Stade Lescure last night.

Having had the better of the opening exchanges, Martin O'Neill's men fell to a sucker punch midway through the first half when François Grenet's corner found Dugarry who rose above everyone to head emphatically home.

Celtic hit back almost immediately, David Sommeil bringing Larsson down in the area and the newly cropped Swede sending Ulrich Ramé the wrong way from the spot.

The Parkhead side could have made a dream start in the very first minute when Bobby Petta's cross was pushed out by Ramé as far as Larsson, but the header went inches over.

Then the visitors had their hearts in their mouths when they survived penalty claims after the Portuguese striker Pauleta went down under a challenge from Johan Mjallby.

Paul Lambert had an effort cleared off the line by Grenet before the goals came, after which Lubo Moravcik lobbed just over the bar and after the break Ramé did well to push a fierce right-foot shot from Didier Agathe past the post.

However his opposite number, Jonathan Gould, almost blew it for Celtic in the 64th minute. Agathe brought down Dugarry just outside the area and Gould fumbled Lilian Laslandes' free-kick, but happily for the Celtic keeper the ball rolled wide of the post.

Celtic: Gould; Boyd, McNamara, Valgaeren, Lambert, Petrov, Agathe, Petta, Moravcik, Mjallby, Larsson.

Referee: TH Ovrebo (Norway).

webTitle: Tarantino hunts Uma for Kill Bill

fields.headline: Tarantino hunts Uma for Kill Bill
fields.trailText: Quentin Tarantino is hoping to persuade Uma Thurman to work with him again on his forthcoming "revenge drama" Kill Bill
fields.body:
Quentin Tarantino is hoping to persuade Uma Thurman to work with him again on his forthcoming film Kill Bill, according to Yahoo! News.

Described as a "revenge drama", the Reservoir Dogs director has written the script as a starring vehicle for Thurman and the actress is looking to clear her schedule so she can work with him again after the huge success of 1994's Pulp Fiction.

Tarantino, along with Roger Avary, won an Oscar for Best Screenplay for the film, which also starred Bruce Willis and was responsible for resurrecting John Travolta's career. Thurman was also nominated for a Best Supporting Actress in her role as the drug-taking gangster's moll.

Tarantino is also rumoured to be developing an epic second world war drama for Miramax and Thurman will next be seen in Merchant-Ivory's adaptation of the Henry James classic The Golden Bowl, released in the UK on November 3.

fields.headline: Heskey shatters Czech stalemate
fields.standfirst:
Liverpool 1 Heskey 88
Slovan Liberec 0
fields.trailText: The only truly contented man inside Anfield last night was the Everton supporter who appeared to have entered what he will regard as the evil empire to complain about the noise.
fields.body:
The only truly contented man inside Anfield last night was the Everton supporter who appeared to have entered what he will regard as the evil empire to complain about the noise.

On Sunday, the blue and red halves of a divided city will collide at the same venue to squabble over local pride and Premiership points. You do suspect that Walter Smith and his boys will be rather looking forward to their day out across Stanley Park.

If Liverpool can make things difficult for themselves then they certainly will. Although they should still scramble through into the Uefa Cup's third round all the applause last night was reserved for the unheralded, unfancied players from the small mining town in the north of the Czech Republic.

Slovan Liberec never once hinted at ambition, rarely crossed the half-way line and placed so many men behind the ball that the evening was almost totally bereft of entertainment.

And yet, they headed home reflecting on arguably the most satisfying result in their distinctly unspectacular history.

"I think that we deserved more than we got," said the Liverpool manager, Gerard Houllier. "It is never easy to play when the other team puts 11 men behind the ball but we knew it was going to be like that."

Liverpool will take some solace from the fact that they did not concede but, in truth, that represented consolation in its hollowest form.

Rarely, if ever, can a leading English club have stepped into the dark recesses of the unknown with such gay abandon, with such confidence. Perhaps that was the problem.

Liberec may currently find themselves in the higher echelons of the Czech Republic's premier League but, as Houllier is fond of pointing out, everything in football is relative.

That's to say that Czech football - certainly in domestic terms - has enjoyed more fruitful periods. To put it politely, Liberec, on their first-ever excursion onto the European stage, are, by general consensus, one of the weakest sides left in the competition.

Not that Houllier is a man to take anything for granted; yesterday was Thursday but he probably checked his diary to confirm.

Liverpool often struggle to impose their will on allegedly inferior opposition but, even so, the countless problems they encountered last night came as a surprise.

If possession and goals were mathematically joined at the hip then the Merseysiders would have been strolling down Easy Street long, long before Liberec began to fully appreciate that it is incumbent upon all teams, however timid, to make some form of worthwhile contribution.

Liberec had still to set foot beyond the half-way line when Robbie Fowler missed the first of half a dozen chances which came his way.

Opportunities make their way towards Fowler like iron-filings to a magnet but after so many injury problems over the past couple of seasons, the young man who has lived up to, rather than lived down, the nick-name, God, is still not match fit; he's gifted but he's struggling.

If he was now fully restored to rude health Fowler would certainly have scored after 13 minutes for having reached a Vladimir Smicer cross from the right, scoring did appear to be an easier option than did missing. But, miss he did, his header from no great distance drifting up and over the crossbar.

With no width to their play and a curious lack of urgency in midfield, Danny Murphy excepted, Liverpool ran around in ever-decreasing circles in search of inspiration, either that or a Czech mistake. In a dull first period, they were to be disappointed on both counts.

The inescapable fact that Fowler was completely out of sorts made the events of the 54th minute all the more curious.

Liverpool's pedestrian, predictable football was carrying them nowhere until Jiri Stajner was adjudged to have pushed Dietmar Hamann as he shaped to shoot. Fowler opted to take the penalty but, having comfortably cleared the crossbar, the ball was still rising when it hit the man in Row Z.

But, as Houllier said afterwards, all's well that ends well and with three minutes remaining Liberec finally succumbed when Emile Heskey drove into the roof of the net after substitute Nick Barmby's shot had been blocked.

Liverpool (4-4-2) Westerveld; Carragher, Henchoz, Babbel, Ziege; Berger, Hamann, Murphy (McAllister, 69min), Smicer (Barmby, 69); Fowler, Heskey.

Slovan Liberec (4-1-3-2) Hauzr; Capek, Johana, Pilny, Lexa; Janu; Kozuch (Bakes, 84), Michalik, Neumann; Lazzaro (Nezmar, 80), Stajner (Jun, 72).

Referee M Busacca (Switzerland).

Opportunities make their way towards Fowler like iron-filings to a magnet but after so many injury problems over the past couple of seasons, the young man who has lived up to, rather than lived down, the nick-name, God, is still not match fit; he's gifted but he's struggling. If he was now fully restored to rude health Fowler would certainly have scored after 13 minutes for having reached a Vladimir Smicer cross from the right, scoring did appear to be an easier option than did missing. But, miss he did, his header from no great distance drifting up and over the crossbar. With no width to their play and a curious lack of urgency in midfield, Danny Murphy excepted, Liverpool ran around in ever-decreasing circles in search of inspiration, either that or a Czech mistake. In a dull first period, they were to be disappointed on both counts. The inescapable fact that Fowler was completely out of sorts made the events of the 54th minute all the more curious. Liverpool's pedestrian, predictable football was carrying them nowhere until Jiri Stajner was adjudged to have pushed Dietmar Hamann as he shaped to shoot. Fowler opted to take the penalty but, having comfortably cleared the crossbar, the ball was still rising when it hit the man in Row Z. But, as Houllier said afterwards, all's well that ends well and with three minutes remaining Liberec finally succumbed when Emile Heskey drove into the roof of the net after substitute Nick Barmby's shot had been blocked. webTitle: Notting Hill script plagiarised, says Blood and Wine writer

fields.headline: Notting Hill script plagiarised, says Blood and Wine writer
fields.trailText: A British scriptwriter is suing the makers of the 1999 hit film Notting Hill for more than £10m, claiming they stole his ideas
fields.body:
A British scriptwriter is suing the makers of the 1999 hit film Notting Hill for more than £10m, claiming they stole his ideas.

Nick Villiers, who co-wrote the Michael Caine-Jack Nicholson film Blood and Wine, claims many of the ideas used in Notting Hill were his, according to today's Daily Express. Villiers believes they were stolen Eric Fellner, co-owner of the company who made Notting Hill, Working Title Films, who was a friend of his at the time.

He claims the notions he shared with Fellner when they were working on a film adaptation of the novel Cheek, turned up in the screenplay for Notting Hill written by Blackadder scriptwriter Richard Curtis.

Fellner who, with his business partner Tim Bevan, has turned Working Title films from a minor British production house into one of Hollywood's biggest players, with screen hits such as Elizabeth and Bean, denies the allegations. A spokesman for Fellner said yesterday: "It sounds totally ridiculous. There was no novel it was based on. Richard Curtis wrote that script entirely from scratch."

Notting Hill, which starred Julia Roberts and Hugh Grant, was the biggest-grossing British film ever at the American box office and helped re-kickstart Roberts's career after a series of flops.

webTitle: Restaurants: Soho Thai, London W1 and Thanks For Franks, London W1

fields.headline: Soho Thai, London W1 and Thanks For Franks, London W1
fields.trailText: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Telephone: 020 7287 2000

Address: Soho Thai, 27-28 St Anne's Court, London W1.

Although not, as the name suggests, the only Thai restaurant in Soho, this is rumoured to be one of the best. Formica tables and a laminated menu belie a splendid selection of Thai cuisine. Starters range from £3.50 to £7.95 and include the usual fishcake, soup and dumpling squad. Main courses are an assembly of pan-fried dishes, curries, noodle dishes such as pad Thai, all priced between £4.25 and £14.95. There's an impressive vegetarian stretch too, including a scrumptious pad woon sen for £5.25. The decor's not stunning, and it's a bit cramped, but the service is chipper.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Telephone: 020-7494 2434

Address: Thanks For Franks, 26, Foubert's Place, London W1.

Thanks indeedy, for Franks is a jolly place with tasty morsels galore, keeping Soho's baggy-trousered brigade fed and watered six days a week. You can sit inside - a bit squashed - or outside if the weather is kind. Or, of course, you can take away. A full breakfast, just £3.25, includes bacon, sausage, egg, toast, chips and a nice cup of tea. Lunchtime brings a choice of hot dishes such as shepherd's pie and moussaka and a quite possibly endless range of sandwich combinations. A rosemary bap with roast chicken, mayo, parmesan and lettuce is yours for a mere £2.50.

On the menu

Made mustard

As opposed to unmade mustard?
No. As opposed to mustard powder, a substance peculiar to this country, devised by Jeremiah Colman.

And made mustard?
Refers to pungent emulsion favoured by the French, Germans, Americans and Japanese.

But isn't made mustard made with mustard powder.
Indeed it is, except for Dijon, which is made with crushed mustard seed.

Anything else I should know?
There's Savora, an English-made mustard developed at the turn of the century, which, apparently is very popular in South America. Then there are..

Enough, enough.

Just out

El Rey Caranero Superior Chocolate

Form:
Slim, 80g bars of Apamate Dark Chocolate; Caoba Milk Chocolate; and Icoa White Chocolate.

Flavour:
Apamate: balanced sweetness/acidity; long dry, dense chocolate finish. Caoba: rich; sweetish; velvety; seductive Icoa: well, it's better than Milky Bar. Just.

Verdict:
Venezuela's gift to choccie lovers. Made only from Caranero Superior cocoa beans, and superior they are too. Not outrageously or searingly chocolatey. Relies more on sublety and texture for effect. Apamate is a stunner, Caoba a vamp. Pass on Icoa.

Price:
£1.30 per 80g bar at Waitrose.

Food on the net

www.souprecipe.com

Weary of dining on lettuce leaves and vinaigrette? Fear not for it is now, unarguably, soup weather, and this here chirpy little site is fully equipped for the frozen-toed, blender-wielding population. You can wade through categories such as slow-cook, noodle, stews and gumbos, rifle through the alphabetical index, search for the Thai broth of your dreams, safe in the knowledge that there are hints galore if things go awry.

Pros:
more recipes than you can shake a stick at, including apricot, lentil, BLT, avgolemono, and pizza (it sounds crazy, but it might just work).

Cons:
Excrutiating puns are rife. Witness: "Roux the Day" and "A-Maize-ing Corn Chowder".

webTitle: Sister roles for Zeta Jones and Julia Roberts

fields.headline: Sister roles for Zeta Jones and Julia Roberts
fields.trailText: Catherine Zeta Jones has signed up to star alongside Hollywood's hottest property, Julia Roberts, in a film which will see them playing sisters
fields.body:
Catherine Zeta Jones has signed up to star alongside Hollywood's hottest property, Julia Roberts, in a film which will see them playing sisters.

America's Sweetheart will be Zeta Jones's biggest film to date and she is set to receive a £4m pay packet for the project, according to today's Daily Mirror. She will play a successful film star whose career falls apart after her divorce from her famous husband. Notting Hill star Roberts, recently voted Hollywood's most bankable star, will play the sister who tries to help her pick up the pieces.

The film has been written by Billy Crystal, who will also play a veteran publicist. High Fidelity star John Cusack has signed up to play Zeta Jones's sleazy husband and it is rumoured that the newly freed Robert Downey Jr is also keen to join the cast

A "friend" of Zeta Jones is quoted as saying that: "She is really pleased to get this role. The chance to appear alongside someone as successful as Julia Roberts is just fantastic Once her wedding is over she cannot wait to start filming."

Zeta Jones will marry Michael Douglas next month.

fields.headline: PR Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 27.
fields.trailText: October 27: Procter & Gamble has put its Sunny Delight brand out to pitch after incumbent agency Ketchum Life resigned the account.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble has put its Sunny Delight brand out to pitch after incumbent agency Ketchum Life resigned the account. The decision sparked speculation that Ketchum Life may be about to pick up some business from Britvic Softdrinks, which is reviewing its agency arrangements.

Easygroup boss Stelios Haji-Ioannou has been named communicator of the year at the PR Week Awards. The campaign of the year award went to Shandwick International for its handling of the aborted maiden cruise of P&O's Aurora superliner, which also won the crisis management campaign award.

Woolworths has poached Nicole Lander from Tesco to fill its head of communications post, which has been vacant for eight months.

Microsoft has hired Finsbury International Political Regulatory Advisors, the lobbying arm of Finsbury, to handle a European competition brief.

Chime Communications has launched its first investor relations division.

Coca-Cola has hired Jackie Cooper PR to handle the launch of energy drink Burn.

webTitle: 10 tips for buying and cooking the perfect sausage

fields.headline: 10 tips for buying and cooking the perfect sausage
fields.standfirst: At its best, the British banger is up there with the greatest. At its worst, it is unspeakably awful. So how to find a perfect specimen?  Matthew Fort, a man who knows a thing or two about sausages, offers a few words of advice
fields.trailText: At its best, the British banger is up there with the greatest. At its worst, it is unspeakably awful. So how to find a perfect specimen? Matthew Fort, a man who knows a thing or two about sausages, offers a few words of advice
fields.body:
If there's a dish
    For which I wish
    More frequent than the rest,
    If there's a food
    On which I brood
    When starving or depressed,
    If there's a thing that life can give
    Which makes it worth our while
    to live,
    If there's an end
    On which I'd spend
    My last remaining cash,
    It's a sausage, friend,
    It's a sausage, friend,
    It's a sausage, friend, and mash.
    When love is dead,
    Ambition fled,
    And pleasure, Lad, and Pash,
    You'll still enjoy
    A sausage, boy,
    A sausage, boy, and mash .

So sang the Bard of the Breakfast Table, the Singer of Suppers, AP Herbert, and he's right, of course. The world loves a sausage. The Italians love their salsiccie and salamis, the French their saucisses and cervelas, and the Germans their wurst. Iraqis have their mumbar, the Algerians their merguez, the Poles their beskidzka, the Hungarians their gyulia, the South Africans their boerewors and the Chinese their ap yeung cheung. And we have our banger, chippolata, saveloy, and puddings black and puddings white, all to be celebrated: for next week is Sausage Week.

Sausages are big business. We eat 137,801 tonnes of them each year, at home and away. Consumption outside the home has risen by 26% since 1996. Sausages have become fashionable fare in restaurants. There are even restaurants of standing devoted to them. You will find them among the fancy foods in supermarkets. Nigel and Nigella and Jamie have set out their sausage recipes.

At their best, our sausages are up there with the greatest: bronzed, glistening, plump with promise, a curl of steam rising up from their rounded flanks, sweetly, succulently porky on the tooth, releasing scintillas of leek, sage, chive, mace or nutmeg in a cloud of warm vapour. At their best; that's the trouble.

By a law now so ancient, antiquated and inadequate that it should be challenged in the European court of human rights for revision, a pork sausage in this country needs only to contain 65% meat, of which only 50% - a piffling 32.5% of the whole sausage - has to be lean meat. Let's say your sausage is 12cm long, which is a decent size of a snagger, and about 4cm wide. So 4cm of it will be meat you or I would recognise as being fit to eat, but what about the other 8cm - 67.5% ?

Well, that could be made up of fat, skin, rind, gristle, sinew, rusk, soya, milk protein, salt, pepper and water. Yes, water. Water is cheap, you see. So 10% of the sausage can be rusk, but because cheap rusk swells up with even cheaper water, that could be 20% of your sausage by volume.

Actually, it could be more than that because manufacturers can add phosphates, which increase water retention still further. That's before they start adding the antioxidants to stop fat going rancid; sulphur dioxide to prolong shelf life; dextrose to sweeten whatever tiny lean meat content there may be and to help browning; sodium caseinate to maintain colour and looks; and sodium ascorbate to give it a lovely look. Oh, and herbs and spices, of course.

If this causes you to look at your breakfast staple or dinner delight with new eyes, it could be worse. That meat content could be the MRM - mechanically recovered meat - an industrially produced meat slurry made "fit" for human consumption by the magic of the food technology. Yes, of course it's cheap.

Oh, and if you think that the standards are pretty low for pork sausages, then you should try beef ones. They have to contain only 50% meat.

The trouble is, we're all too ready to tolerate this appalling state of affairs. A few years back we ran the Guardian Great Sausage Quest for The People's Sausage. It was one of the great exercises in consumer democracy. Sausage-lovers nominated their favourite sausage and then came forward to take part in panels which tasted the entrants blind.

In the third and last year that we ran the Quest, panels tasted more than 1,000 sausages at four centres around the country. And, let me tell you, those sausages added up to a truly colossal amount of fat, gristle and unmentionable substances. Although there were truly glorious examples of the sausage maker's art among them, it was remarkable how much unspeakable rubbish had misty-eyed devotees who swore by their qualities.

However, when tasting blind, and when price was not an issue, your average, everyday sausage consumer knew quality when he or she tasted it. Each year the sausages that went through to the final were the best in each area. That is, they had the highest meat content, the best quality meat, natural casings and fresh herbs or spices, and were made by small-scale butchers.

The moral of the story, it seems to me, is only buy your sausages when you can be certain of their provenance, and can go back and complain if they don't cut the mustard. It's true, too, that while sausages are user- friendly and consumer-friendly - and a doddle to cook - they do benefit from a modicum of respect. Never, for example, prick a British sausage. The principle of higher sausage cooking is to do so at a low, even heat. The heat must gradually permeate the filling, causing the fat to leach out through the semi-permeable skin, while keeping in the juices to maintain prime succulence. Too high a heat turns the juices to steam, causes the filling to swell rapidly and so burst the confines of the casing in an unseemly fashion.

There are those who swear by the baking method, and those who even grill them. I will have none of these methods. I fry my sausages long and slow, for about an hour, turning maybe twice. The pan I use is an old friend, a heavy, cast-iron job, which has never seen a bubble of washing up liquid in its long and productive life, only very hot water. It is blackened with heat and age, the layers of grease fused into a natural non-stick surface. And when my chosen sausages have reached the properly bronzed state and the coarse ground meat has reached porky perfection inside the pristine skins, why, then I am ready to feast.

The appeal of sausages stretches across class, creed and age. They are almost the only traditional artisanal butchery product still widely made, with regional differences still built in, as it were. They are a far more potent symbol of our national identity than the miserable pound. They are one of the few institutions in this country worth preserving and worth fighting for. Let us celebrate the sausage.

10 steps to banger heaven

1. Never buy a sausage with less than 75% meat.
2. Preferably buy from a small butcher who knows where his meat comes from.
3. Check how often they are made.
4. Make sure they have natural casings (that is pig or lamb, not plastic).
5. Never eat a freshly made sausage. They need a day or so to settle down.
6. A good sausage should have a soft, plump glean to it. It shouldn't be too wet or dry, tired and sad.
7. Don't hesitate to complain if your sausages aren't up to snuff.
8. Treat them with respect. Sever each link cleanly.
9. Never prick a sausage or tear the skin.
10. Always cook them gently, preferably frying them over a low, even heat.

As the race for the White House hots up, Martin Kettle reports on Al Gore's visit to Little Rock, the scene of an infamous Bill Clinton escapade almost a decade ago.
Special report: US election
fields.trailText: As the race for the White House hots up, Martin Kettle reports on Al Gore's visit to Little Rock, the scene of an infamous Bill Clinton escapade almost a decade ago.
fields.body:
According to its publicity brochure, the Excelsior Hotel in Little Rock is a place "where something important happens every day", and, judging by the attendance, Al Gore's speech there on a hot southern morning this week seemed to live up to the claim.

Gore spoke with authority and passion about the case for a smaller, smarter federal government machine.

No politician in modern US history has a better claim in this field than Gore. He pioneered it. He understands it. He believes in it. And he is interested in it. For Gore, the search for good government is something of a mission.

But Gore's speech at the Excelsior summed up a lot of the Democratic nominee's wider problem as he battles to clamber past George W Bush's narrow but persistent lead in the presidential election.

It was a microcosm of what is going wrong for Gore. He was giving the speech not because he wanted to, but because he had to.

During the three presidential debates, Bush had managed to pin a 'big government' label on Gore.

Like much of what Bush says, it was untrue. But like everything that Bush says, it served a purpose. The label stuck, and Gore's task this week was to shake himself free of it.

As Gore spoke in the Excelsior, one's mind occasionally wandered up a few floors in the same building to something else important that happened in the hotel some nine and a half years ago.

That was the day when a woman called Paula Jones was working on the registration desk at a conference in the Excelsior. Early in the afternoon, she got a message from an Arkansas state trooper that Governor Bill Clinton wanted to talk to her upstairs in his suite.

She went upstairs - and the rest is history. (Though she famously told the governor that afternoon "I'm not that kind of girl", Paula Jones appears in a nude photospread in this month's Penthouse.)

What happened in the hotel on May 8 1991 goes a long way towards explaining one of Gore's other big problems.

In his speech in the Excelsior, Gore twice mentioned that he had been a member of the Clinton-Gore administration.

Presumably this was out of deference to his Arkansas audience, since it was two more mentions of the word "Clinton" than Gore normally makes in his stump speeches. Normally, he's just not that kind of boy.

Gore's patent reluctance to having Clinton join him on the campaign trail has created massive anger in the White House and among Clinton's acolytes.

The issue has been simmering at boiling point for several weeks, and Clinton himself has occasionally shown that he is straining to get out there to drum up the votes.

But Gore is cautious for a reason. His polls tell him that Clinton is a double-edged weapon. People like the policies, but they mostly do not like the man, and Gore knows better than anyone that, if the two of them were to appear together on the stump, Clinton would eclipse him.

Clinton, not Gore, would become the story. That, of course, is precisely what the Republicans want.

It's important to remember that Gore's best phase of the campaign - possibly his only good phase at all - came after the Los Angeles Democratic convention when he strode up to the podium and said "I stand here tonight as my own man."

The weeks that followed were the one period in the election when Gore has enjoyed a clear lead over Bush.

That's not to say that there is no vanity and pride involved for Gore in keeping Clinton at arm's length. There is. But his strategy makes sense for other reasons too.

Next week, Clinton will finally be allowed out on to the campaign trail. He will go to California next Wednesday and will barnstorm through a series of other states in the days between then and election day, November 7.

Other states under consideration by the Democrats include Arkansas, Louisiana, Missouri and Kentucky. But at no point will he stand on the same platform as Gore.

Notice, though, what kind of role Clinton will play. His task will be an attempt to woo middle-of-the-road voters, as many of the Clintonites might like to imagine. Bush has won those voters away now.

Clinton's task will be to mobilise the core Democratic vote, especially the black and ethnic minority votes, and to ensure they do not turn to Ralph Nader.

In the end, for the Democrats, this election is coming down to a desperate attempt to rally the traditional party around Gore.

Unless they succeed, Bush looks increasingly like the winner.

fields.headline: Overexposed...
fields.standfirst: ...over-expensive moisturisers
fields.trailText: ...over-expensive moisturisers
fields.body:
Are a few wrinkles so terrible? Is the appearance of youth now the only appearance to have? Oh, darling, do you even need to ask? Forget about winning five gold medals or running eight miles in five seconds. The real record on everyone's minds is who can make the most expensive moisturiser. So Anita Roddick's minor hissy fit last week over anti-wrinkle cream was actually irrelevant: for the true beauty devotee, never mind the wrinkle cream, pass the £1,000 pot of moisturiser.

Yes, yes, we all know we are in the cult of youth at the moment. A model is mature if she is beyond puberty, the average age of a singer on Top of the Pops is 10. Most disheartening of all, rather than laughing indulgently at these plush pots, far too many of us are tripping over in puddles of our own drool as we clamour after the latest, and most pricey, jar of eternal youth.

These pots of promise reflect, literally, the price you put on yourself. Are you an Oil of Olay fan? You high street cheapskate. Does Crème de la Mer adorn your bathroom sink? You are a glamour puss with oodles of self-respect, or so the beauty industry insinuates.

Queen of the beauty castle is still Crème de la Mer, beloved by beautiful faces such as Jennifer Lopez and Stella McCartney. But if that's not exclusive enough for you, there is Sisleÿa by Sisley, with its extracts of shiitake (aka mushrooms) or Clé de Peau Beauté La Crème, launched this month. If you love your beluga caviar, but can't fit enough of it in your tummy, smear it on your face with La Prairie Skin Caviar Luxe Cream.

You may feel ultra-glam rubbing these concoctions into your valued complexion morning and night, but will you still be able to afford the mirror to watch your- self doing so? Luxurious they may be, overpriced they are for sure.

fields.headline: Mario Badescu skincare
fields.trailText: They may be ridiculously perfect by day but by night the beautiful faces of Beverly Hills go to bed covered with little pink blobs speckled across their valuable complexions. Welcome to the secret world of Mario Badescu skincare...
fields.body:
They may be ridiculously perfect by day but by night the beautiful faces of Beverly Hills go to bed covered with little pink blobs speckled across their valuable complexions. Welcome to the secret world of Mario Badescu skincare, for far too long the privilege of in-the-know Americans, willing to obtain their beauty products by mail order or at the exclusive salon, rather than simply popping into a chemist like the rest of us plebs.

It's certainly got good word of mouth and a clientele list to make the Met Bar green with envy: Donatella Versace, Kate Moss, Jennifer Aniston, Gwyneth Paltrow and, um, Tom Selleck (above) have been spotted in the Mario Badescu salon in mid-town Manhattan. The always plain-speaking Naomi Campbell credits the products with "making my face", no doubt with a little help from Badescu's famous spa, perhaps the gingko-collagen or herbal seaweed treatment.

But forget about the moisturisers, cleansers and the rest of the usual suspects. The real source of this cosmetic line's fame is the Drying Lotion , aka "Pimple Healer" (pictured above, $32, tel 001 212 223 3728 to order). Cowardly celebrity fans, not wishing to admit to less than perfect complexions, remain shtoom about their personal use of the now celebrated little pink bottle, with the one fab exception of Cher, who happily admits to being a big fan of the Pimple Healer Drying Lotion. Good to know that even the queen of supernatural beauty is no stranger to the odd eruption.

God only knows what is in this stuff, but whack a bit on an emerging spot, go to bed and get up with idyllic, blemish-free skin. Sadly, though, even the hyperbolic Badescu salon can't promise you'll awake looking like Gwyneth.

fields.headline: Oversubscribed...
fields.standfirst: ...  animals on clothes
fields.trailText: ... animals on clothes
fields.body:
Fashion folk are not known for their love of animals - live ones, at any rate. But now you can unleash your fashion-conscious inner animal without draping yourself beneath piles of roadkill or wearing tacky animal prints (so very last season, you know). This season, adorn yourself with designs of the animals themselves, rather than depriving them of their skins.

At Moschino, designer Rosella Jardini has gone down the Yellow Brick Road with Toto-like Scottie dogs prancing across jumpers, pencil skirts and knee-length dresses, complementing the "J'adorothy" T-shirts. In the diffusion line, the cartoonish Moschino Cheap and Chic, a veritable cacophony of farm animals - roosters, chickens, sheep - is slapped across the clothes. Meanwhile, Trussardi has gone to the dogs with greyhounds - the label's signature motif - dashing across all manner of garments.

This animal attraction looks set to continue next season as well. Dolce & Gabbana have bejewelled cats on pussy cat vest tops. Vogue's Designer of the Year, Stella McCartney, caused a bit of a ruckus two weeks ago at Paris fashion week with the extravagant horse prints on her clothes for Chloe (see left). Wild horses won't be able to drag us away from them come spring. And let's not forget this year's Trendiest Designer (© every fash mag) Luella, whose label consists, Godfather-style, of a giant horse's head.

Why all the animal magic? One can only presume that designers are at last getting in touch with their inner beasts. I am fashionable, hear me roar. And crow, and neigh, and bark.

fields.headline: BBC awarded interactive honours
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The BBC last night won four awards at the Bafta Interactive Entertainment Awards, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC last night won four awards at the Bafta Interactive Entertainment Awards.

BBC Online won the news category for the third year running, the enhancement of linear media award for its coverage of golf and tennis events, and the factual award for its history site.

BBC Online also won a special overall award.

Channel 4's Homework High website, developed by Glasshead/Cimex, won the online learning award.

Freeserve-owned interactive soap Online Caroline won an award for interactivity.

David Bowie was honoured in absentia with the Berners Lee award for best personal contribution to the UK interactive industry.

Freeserve-owned interactive soap Online Caroline won an award for interactivity. fields.headline: Dickson snubs Crossroads remake
fields.trailText: 8am: Actress and singer Barbara Dickson has turned down the offer of a role in Carlton's ITV remake of Crossroads, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Actress and singer Barbara Dickson has turned down the offer of a role in Carlton's ITV remake of 1970s daytime soap Crossroads.

Carlton director of drama Jonathan Powell confirmed that an approach had been made to Ms Dickson in the early stages of casting the returning soap, but said the actress would not be appearing in the show.

Crossroads is due to return to ITV daytime early next year in what is expected to be an early afternoon slot.

webTitle: StepStone says it is on profit path

fields.headline: StepStone says it is on profit path
fields.trailText: 8am: StepStone.com yesterday admitted it had lost £30m in three months but insisted the foundations were in place to make a profit by 2002. By Rob Griffin.
fields.body:
StepStone.com, the online recruitment firm, yesterday admitted it had lost 43.2m euros (£30m) in three months but insisted the foundations were in place to make a profit by 2002.

Giles Clarke, chief executive of the Norwegian company, blamed the losses on the costs of a rapid expansion that has seen the site introduced to Austria, Finland, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

But he said the company's strong cash position,159m euros at the end of September, and profits generated from the new European operations would help pull it out of the red.

"We made it very clear that this would be the quarter where investment would peak," Mr Clarke said. "As the markets grow in all the countries we see tremendous opportunity for us and are full of optimism about the future."

Mr Clarke said there were no plans to expand into more countries "in the near future".

StepStone, which believes people are now more willing to travel for new jobs, said Germany ranked as its second biggest market, behind Britain.

Last month it announced the purchase of 75% of Job-Today, one of Germany's leading online recruitment companies, and intends to acquire the balance over the coming months.

"It's becoming more and more an international business and people are doing deals across a number of countries," Mr Clarke said. "There's a great mobility across the EU and people are more linguistically gifted than they used to be. The immigration laws have also changed more in the last six months than they have in the last 30 years."

Total sales stood at 17.05m euros for the quarter ended September 30, 2000, an increase of 37% over the previous quarter.

fields.headline: E-market takes to the air
fields.trailText: 8am: Two aviation business-to-business internet exchanges are to merge, bringing together customers and suppliers in an attempt to cut costs. By Mark Milner.
fields.body:
Two aviation business to business internet exchanges are to merge, bringing together customers and suppliers in an attempt to cut costs.

AirNewco, which includes leading British, mainland European and US airlines, is teaming up with MyAircraft, a supplier-based exchange, in a new service that is expected to come into operation in the first quarter of next year.

"The deal is one of the first to bring together buyers and sellers in a major industry as joint owners of a neutral, global e-marketplace," the companies said yesterday. "Up to now aviation's e-business race, as in other sectors, has involved exchanges that are seller driven, buyer driven or independent."

The combined exchange - which has yet to be named - will be open to all industry players and provide an electronic marketplace for fuels, parts, maintenance, airport support services and on-board catering provision.

"These services will enable buyers and sellers to reduce transaction costs, lower inventories and realise significant supply chain savings," the companies said.

AirNewco includes British Airways, Air France, American Airlines, Delta, Continental and United Parcel Services among its members, while MyAircraft is made up of United Technologies, Honeywell, BF Goodrich and i2 Technologies - an internet commerce specialist.

Ownership of the new exchange - which will be independently managed - will be shared among the member companies. According to investment bank Schroders Salomon Smith Barney analyst Nick Cunningham, the new exchange should be stronger than the two businesses operating separately.

webTitle: W&K faces $1m lawsuit in Nike ad wrangle

fields.headline: W&K faces $1m lawsuit in Nike ad wrangle
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Wieden & Kennedy is facing a $1m lawsuit after allegedly using music in a Nike ad without the singer's consent, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Sportswear company Nike and its advertising agency, Wieden & Kennedy, are facing a $1m (£700,000) lawsuit after allegedly using a piece of music in an ad without the author's consent.

The singer, Billy Paul, is suing both companies for using his song, "Me and Mrs Jones", in one of its latest commercials.

He is seeking $1m in lost licensing fees in a suit filed in the federal district court in Los Angeles, after claiming that the company had not sought his permission for its use.

"Me and Mrs Jones" was the number one song on the Billboard Top 40 chart for three weeks in 1972.

A source at Wieden & Kennedy said this morning it sounded like "a very stupid mistake".

webTitle: Boo is reborn in confident fashion

fields.headline: Boo is reborn in confident fashion
fields.trailText: 8am: Kate Buggeln has been selling all her working life. But selling investors and customers on the new-look Boo.com is her biggest challenge yet. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Kate Buggeln has been selling things all her working life. But selling investors and customers on the new look Boo.com, a name associated with the world's highest-profile dot com failure, is her biggest challenge yet.

The 39-year-old American has been charged with the revival task by fashionmall.com, the American fashion internet portal that paid an estimated £250,000 for Boo's brand, logo and the right to use its domain name after the e-tailer went into receivership this year. Ms Buggeln is relaunching Boo as a fashion and lifestyle site on Monday, and believes her team have learnt lessons from the collapse of Boo mark one.

"We want to bring to our customers the best of international style from interesting websites that we have located around the world", said Ms Buggeln, who hopes her 17 years' experience in the retail sector will help revive the site.

A history graduate from Farleigh Dickinson University in New Jersey, Ms Buggeln began her career as an executive trainee at Bloomingdale's department stores. She has also worked with retailers to design and launch brand strategies and business models.

Despite the negative connotations attached to Boo.com - the company began trading in early November last year and went bust in May after investors refused to add to the estimated £80m they had poured into the firm - Ms Buggeln is determined to cash in on the well-known name that Boo established.

"Retaining the name Boo uses this awareness of the name to bring people to our site so they can see how great our product is", Ms Buggeln said.

She admitted to feeling fortunate that the original Boo team spent so much money on marketing. The high level of awareness they created is now helping her cause.

The brand, name and customers the new site targets, as well as the team's sensibility to style - "We have the same sort of irreverent sense of humour as our predecessors" - are, however, where the similarities between the original Boo and the new incarnation end. Ms Buggeln and her team number nine, whereas the original Boo employed between 300 and 400 people.

The new company is also financially secure. Fashionmall.com has about $27m in the bank. It is estimated that will last 10 years based on the current burn rate.

webTitle: Hinduja brothers firm up Express offer

fields.headline: Hinduja brothers firm up Express offer
fields.standfirst: Barclay brothers withdraw Express bid
fields.trailText: 8am: The Hinduja brothers are expected to name their management team to run the Express newspapers in an attempt to demonstrate their offer is serious, writes Jill Treanor.
fields.body:
Brothers Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja are today expected to name the management team they have handpicked to run the Express newspaper group in an attempt to demonstrate they are serious about making a formal £100m offer for the titles.

The move by the London-based brothers, who are planning to make the bid through their Hinduja Group conglomerate, comes after a rival bid by the Barclay twins was withdrawn. The Hinduja's formal bid is expected today, with details of investment bankers acting on their behalf.

Brothers David and Frederick Barclay last month offered Labour peer Lord Hollick between £75m and £100m for the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star stable but the offer was rejected. However, it appears to have prompted a number of other interested parties to contact United News & Media, which owns the titles, with potential offers for the newspapers.

Yesterday the Barclays said they were withdrawing their bid, made through the Press Holdings group which publishes the Scotsman and Sunday Business, after United News refused to disclose full financial information about the newspaper group.

"In the circumstances and in order to prevent further speculation, Press Holdings has no alternative but to withdraw its interest in the Express newspaper group and to consider the matter closed," Andrew Neil, publisher in chief of Press Holdings said last night.

United News, which has faced speculation about the fate of its newspaper interests after its plans to merge with Carlton were thwarted by regulators, refused to comment last night.

However, analysts say recent presentations by United management left them with the impression that the papers will change hands. Another potential bidder for the titles is David Montgomery, the former Mirror Group chief executive who is thought to have secured backing from venture capitalist group 3i.

fields.headline: NTL aim raises taxing question
fields.trailText: Footsie label must come with a price tag.
fields.body:
NTL, the cable company and broadcaster run by the energetic Barclay Knapp, is a British company in all but registration. Just about all of its cables run under our streets, the leaflets offering this or that telephone and digital TV package are stuffed through British front doors. And, until last week, NTL wanted to screen a good portion of the country's Premiership football.

Its headquarters are here and the core of its business message is all about using its experience in the deregulated British telephony market to expand across Europe.

It is no surprise then that Mr Knapp would like to see his firm ranked as a member of the FTSE 100 index. NTL's current market capitalisation of £11bn would, for example, put it way ahead of the premier ITV broadcaster, Granada Media.

The only problem is that NTL is an American company by registration - and a Delaware-registered one at that. It is listed on the Nasdaq exchange. While the London Stock Exchange is happy to see Delaware firms listed on the London market, Footsie status, as decided by the FTSE International constituents committee, is another matter.

To qualify for the top 100, a company has to be British-registered, following London rules on corporate disclosure and the like, and paying British taxes. In past years, the determination of the indices committee to stick with this rule has driven company's such as Ireland's Jefferson Smurfit quite mad.

In NTL's case, Mr Knapp is ruling out a move in registration to the UK because this would trigger all sorts of tax payments not necessary in the temperate fiscal climate of Delaware. But he is sure that Britain's indices committee will see sense and amend their rules. Talks are under way.

This is a tricky one for FTSE International. The London Stock Exchange has come over all international in the wake of its failed merger with Deutsche Börse, and it needs all the help it can get from the indices body as it tries to expand.

For many businesses there is little reason to list in London unless money from big investors follows - something that Footsie inclusion guarantees. Also, taking a firm like NTL away from Nasdaq would amount to a sizeable coup for the LSE, helping to build its fragile confidence.

But changing the index rules is fraught with danger. Opening the door to NTL risks inviting applications from all and sundry, registered in exotic havens that even make the strange eastern state of Delaware seem high-buttoned when it comes to business probity.

More importantly, there is a risk that such a move would be seen as an invitation to current members of the Footsie to move their own tax domicile elsewhere while retaining British blue chip status - costing the chancellor billions in the process.

There are strong arguments for reforming the Footsie and its relatives. It is a good-quality, global brand which should be used to bolster London's position.

But in the case of NTL there is a clear case for telling Mr Knapp that, if he wants to call himself a Footsie chief executive and enjoy the name recognition for his company that goes with top 100 status, the firm should pay the resultant tax bill. After all, businesses owe a duty to the societies into which they sell their products.

Taking exception

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers is really, really determined to avoid any suggestions of political interference in mergers and takeovers.

In yet another announcement about his intention to give John Vickers, the new office of fair trading director general, space to do his job, Mr Byers yesterday said he would only get involved in "exceptional circumstances". By way of example, he suggested these might include mergers which raised issues of national security or where unusual circumstances occur after the director general has offered his "advice".

In fact, Mr Byers is so determined to keep himself at arm's length that as of yesterday he relieved himself of powers to overrule the director general, except, of course, in those indefinable "exceptional circumstances".

New legislation is needed before the changes can take place officially.

Mr Byers is also replacing the current "public interest test" with a pure "competition-based test". He also wants to tighten up the timetable for investigations by the competition authorities.

It might sound technical, but issues of competition affect consumers. Competition, Mr Byers is fond of saying, is an incentive for businesses to be dynamic and innovative and in the process help UK plc prosper.

An excellent goal, no doubt. But just how long it will be before Mr Byers (or his successor) reaches for those "exceptional circumstances" is another matter.

webTitle: Centaur's Brierley to spearhead new launches

fields.headline: Centaur's Brierley to spearhead new launches
fields.trailText: The Lawyer editor-in-chief Sean Brierley has been put in charge of developing new magazine launches for Centaur Communications.. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Sean Brierley, editor-in-chief of The Lawyer, has been put in charge of developing new magazine launches for Centaur Communications, hinting that the company may be moving into consumer publishing for the first time.

His promotion ties in with reports that Centaur is preparing for a £100m flotation.

Mr Brierley, who stood down as editor of the legal trade title earlier in the year to make way for Catrin Griffiths, will head up a new department to develop launches for Centaur.

He told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "We will focus on areas which we have traditionally been involved in, but also some new areas including possibly consumer.

"Although Centaur has a good record in product development, this is the first time we've had a dedicated department for it. New launches have tended to come out of existing ideas, whereas now we want to have a dedicated strategy for new magazines."

Mr Brierley said he would develop new magazines in areas where Centaur has traditionally been strong, including law, marketing, new media and finance, but hinted that there may be scope to move into the consumer arena.

Centaur will focus on launching eight new products, which will include magazines, newsletters, online and exhibition launches.

The company will still be interested in buying new magazines, Mr Brierley said. Last year Centaur bought six Miller Freeman titles from United News & Media for £10m. The company is reported to be heading for a flotation, which is expected to value it at around £100m.

webTitle: How to make sense of the one-day circus

fields.headline: How to make sense of the one-day circus
fields.trailText: The early part of the 2000-01 winter season has been dominated by one-day internationals. Before today, when two more take place, there had been 24 matches in exactly a month, from Harare to Karachi via Nairobi and Sharjah. At six games a week, that's quite a conveyor belt of contests. Which leaves us, well, none the wiser really: just who are the best one-day side in the world?
fields.body:
The early part of the 2000-01 winter season has been dominated by one-day internationals. Before today, when two more take place, there had been 24 matches in exactly a month, from Harare to Karachi via Nairobi and Sharjah. At six games a week, that's quite a conveyor belt of contests. Which leaves us, well, none the wiser really: just who are the best one-day side in the world?

A year ago the indisputable answer would have been Australia, not because they always won, but because they always won when it mattered. In April, however, they lost 2-1 in South Africa, before drawing with them in an indoor three-match series in Melbourne which they should have won. Then they went to Kenya and were whacked around by a 19-year-old Indian called Yuvraj Singh. To rub it in, their star nudger Michael Bevan was deposed as No. 1 batsman in the PricewaterhouseCoopers ratings by another Indian, Sourav Ganguly.

South Africa have a trophy cabinet full of Coca-Cola cups and Akai Singer silverware, but tend to fail when the stakes are higher. Until they shake off their tendency to fall at the final hurdle, they will never be the best.

They too lost to India in the ICC Knockout, but India themselves went down to New Zealand in the final before losing the opening match against Sri Lanka in Sharjah. New Zealand may have triumphed in Kenya, but that came on the back of losing a series in Zimbabwe - the first side to do so since England, four years ago. And they're currently having a hard time of it in South Africa.

Pakistan can be brilliant, but they fell foul of the Kiwis in Kenya and on Tuesday conceded the fourth-highest second-innings total to lose a one-day match ever. That was against England, who looked hard to beat during the summer but flopped spectacularly against South Africa two weeks ago. Sri Lanka had won three out of three in Sharjah, but were a let down against Pakistan in Kenya.

The message, then, is that unless your name is West Indies, Zimbabwe, Bangladesh or Kenya, you can beat anyone else. That's the nature of the one-day beast. But, as we said earlier, it still leaves us none the wiser.

In a sport that strives to make statistical sense of everything, the lack of an objective measure of a side's one-day status - other than a World Cup every four years - is strange. Staging the World Cup every two years is one option, but it doesn't go all the way. The answer has to lie in an ongoing one-day World Championship table. Test cricket already has an unofficial one - courtesy of Wisden - so why not one-day cricket too?

However, under the present system, one-day series between two countries rub shoulders with triangulars, quadrangulars and the four-yearly dodecahedronal. So a one-day table couldn't work in the same way as the Wisden World Championship, in which only the Asian Test Championship has transcended the traditional boundaries of two teams in one country.

One option would be to carry on as you were and simply rank each side according to the percentage of games they win in, say, the calendar year. But the problem with this would be the lack of uniformity: Lots of Zimbabwe's wins come from anonymous three-way tournaments with Kenya and Bangladesh, while Australia barely play either of them. The resulting table could be misleading.

A better method would be to abandon all multi-nation competitions - bar the World Cup and the mini-World Cup - and play all games as Test-style mini-series between two countries. In other words, a replica of the Wisden Test table. Each side would have to play every other home and away in the four-year periods between World Cups. The resulting league table could then be used to determine a seedings system for the World Cup, after which the slate would be wiped clean and the cycle of matches would begin again.

You would lose some of the thrills of the three-way competition - and the marketing men would probably object - but it would be simple to run, easy to follow and would give every one-day series some meaning. It would also mean more cricket in countries like Kenya and Bangladesh, and none in Sharjah, an alleged hotbed of match-fixing.

It might also mean that the debate about the best one-day side in the world could be limited to two or three sides, rather than six or seven. Cricket fans crave order. Why not give it to them?

webTitle: The Middle East: The politics of identity

fields.headline: Middle East: The politics of identity
fields.standfirst: In the Middle East, identity matters. But not everyone is so easily categorised, writes Brian Whitaker in Jerusalem
fields.trailText: In the Middle East, identity matters. But not everyone is so easily categorised, writes Brian Whitaker in Jerusalem.
fields.body:
The other night, in Jewish West Jerusalem, I hailed a taxi.

"Salahiddin Street, please."

"East Jerusalem.You go to Arab area," the driver said.

I wasn't sure if it was a question or an exclamation.

"Yes, East Jerusalem. Is that a problem?"

It seemed not to be, so I got in and noticed a large "No Smoking" sign in Hebrew attached to the dashboard.

Since arriving in Jerusalem, I have begun to look for telltale signs that indicate whether a person is an Arab or an Israeli, mainly to avoid making some gross faux pas in conversation.

Sometimes it's easy. Taxi drivers, for instance, often have a radio or casette playing, in Hebrew or Arabic.

"This area Jewish," the driver said, in a tone that gave no hint of whether he approved or disapproved.

"Those men religious Jews." He pointed to some men in long black coats and wide-brimmed hats.

"Yes, that's obvious," I said. "But what about that man over there?"

"Arab."

"And that one?"

"Jew."

"How can you tell?"

He shrugged. "Live in Jerusalem for one year and you will know."

But what about the driver himself? Despite the Hebrew "No Smoking" sign, his accent sounded Arab, and his car looked more battered than the average Jewish-owned taxi. Yes, he was an Arab.

He put his arm out of the driver's window. "Look, no glass. Somebody threw a stone at the window one day," he said, because he was carrying a Jewish woman as a passenger.

In this conflict, identity matters. Everyone watches everyone else, to check which side they're on. A Jew in an Arab area can be mistaken for a spy. An Arab, working in a Jewish area, is liable to be regarded as an undercover terrorist.

These days, Arab bus drivers who have taken Jewish children to school for years are coming under suspicion and risk losing their jobs.

Palestinians are also taking care to avoid situations where they might be mistaken for Israelis. A Palestinian human rights worker, who drives a car with Israeli number plates, told me he now avoids using it in sensitive areas. If he wants to go to Ramallah, he takes a shared taxi instead.

I arrived in Jerusalem by coach from the Egyptian border. A cardboard sign on the windscreen said "Pullman Tours - Israel". But the word "Israel" had been folded over so as not to be visible from outside. The door of the coach was decorated with stickers in English, Arabic and Hebrew, saying "Peace Now!" I wasn't sure if this reflected the sentiments of the travel company or whether it was just a way of protecting the windows from stones.

The instant way that citizens of Jerusalem categorise each other has something akin to journalism, which prefers simple labels whenever possible.

But not everyone fits quite so easily. Israelis are not necessarily Jewish. Jews do not necessarily practise the Jewish faith. Palestinians may be Muslims or Christians. Yesterday, a woman told me that her grandfather, an old-style socialist, had always insisted on describing himself as a Palestinian Jew.

Walking in Jerusalem's old city, I was surprised to find black soldiers on patrol - in Israeli army uniform. They are, I'm told, mostly of Ethiopian origin, and are generally treated as the lowest form of military life.

So what does it boil down to in the end? Nationality? Race? Religion? The longer I stay in Jerusalem the more I despair of knowing the answer.

fields.headline: EU newcomers eager for enlargement
fields.standfirst: The enlargement of the European Union appears to be a low priority for EU citizens, but it is an anxiously awaited event for the prospective newcomers, writes Ian Black
fields.trailText: The enlargement of the European Union is an anxiously awaited event for the prospective newcomers, writes Ian Black in Brussels.
fields.body:
Gunter Verheugen, the European Union's commissioner for enlargement, was all smiles this week when he visited Warsaw to reassure his worried hosts that things were starting to look up for Poland's historic bid to join the club.

Being "conditionally optimistic" does not suggest wild enthusiasm from one of Brussels' key players. But it was better than the trouble Verheugen caused last month by calling for a referendum in his native Germany to decide whether to allow former communist countries to join the EU at all.

Verheugen's knuckles were rapped for his earlier gaffe and he has since learned to choose his words more carefully. Yet discretion cannot conceal a familiar problem that is casting a shadow over the whole enlargement process: the gap between what the union's elites say and what ordinary people feel.

Nothing underlined this more starkly than new figures from the respected Eurobarometer survey, showing that eastward expansion is a priority for a paltry 27% of EU citizens. In France and Germany, it is only 21%; Britain 26%.

Governments should be horrified at this miserable finding: all 15 member states insist they want to reunify Europe and make amends for the betrayals of Yalta and the long years of Cold War division.

Jacques Chirac, the French president, made that clear in Dresden when he celebrated the 10th anniversary of German unification. Tony Blair devoted much of his recent address in Warsaw to the same issue.

Romano Prodi, president of the European commission and Verheugen's boss, told the European parliament just a few days earlier that the ''ambitious and inspiring'' goal of enlargement was to ''forge the unity of the whole continent of Europe.''

Yet this high-flown rhetoric masks a looming crisis: in leading candidate countries, especially Poland, there is growing nervousness, even anger, at what seems like an ever-slipping timetable for accession.

Officially, the EU says it will be ready to accept newcomers from January 2003. Privately, however, no one in Brussels seriously thinks that any of the first wave will be in before 2005. ''Sometime in the middle of the decade,'' is the off-the-record guess of one senior EU ambassador.

France, running the union's rotating presidency since July, has refused to set a target date, as many had hoped it would, at the Nice summit in December. Britain and Sweden, working in tandem in advance of the Swedish presidency next January, want one.

In Warsaw Blair said so explicitly, naming 2004, when the next European parliament elections are due. Since EU enlargements historically take place at the start of a year, that means newcomers would have to be in by January 2004.

But meanwhile the problems are literally piling up. The biggest is the sheer volume of work that needs to be done to complete accession negotiations - in both Brussels and the national capitals.

Thousands of EU laws have to become part of national legislation. Exacting standards on the single market, financial services and environmental protection need to be put in place.

And perhaps more seriously, candidates are complaining that they are being treated more rigorously than countries like Spain, Greece and Portugal, when they joined. Phrases like ''ever-shifting goalposts,'' or "receding horizons" now echo through the corridors of power in Warsaw, Prague and Budapest.

And although none of them will say this publicly, the first six - Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Estonia, and Cyprus, are not happy that others have been invited in, under the ''regatta'' approach adopted at last December's Helsinki summit.

''Most candidate countries think Helsinki was a high point and that we've gone downhill ever since,'' says one anxious diplomat.

Now the enlargement process also embraces Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Romania and Slovakia. Even Turkey, which no one seriously thinks has a snowball's chance in hell of joining the EU for decades, was upgraded to full candidate for accession.

The result has been an even greater work burden for Eurocrats and an agonisingly slow process on the accession ''chapters'' that have to be closed before a new member can join.

And member states, you often hear commission officials saying, are not prepared to devote the extra resources to help Brussels cope with the burden - or spend the money to sell the idea to their own peoples.

Worries about this are getting louder. Members of the European parliament have expressed concern about the absence of a target date. Officially, parliament wants 2004 to be the goal, and is warning against a new round of institutional reform that could set back the process even further.

But at the same time there are calls for some countries to be denied transition periods - a standard EU device to ease the adoption of difficult measures.

Part of that is a reluctance to hand out the sort of subsidies that farmers, especially in Poland, say are essential. It's a fairly gloomy picture. Verheugen himself has warned that failure would be catastrophic.

So it was easy to sympathise with the frustration of a Polish official, watching wistfully as Germans celebrated the anniversary of the fall of the Berlin wall and the end of communism.

''It was lovely to watch their celebrations,'' she said sadly, ''but hard to reflect that it was us who started it all, with Solidarity, and we are in limbo still, waiting for Europe after all these years.''

fields.headline: Making room for manoeuvre
fields.standfirst:
Instead of floating erratically against the euro, the pound sterling might do better if we returned to a managed exchange rate system

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Instead of floating erratically against the euro, the pound sterling might do better if we returned to a managed exchange rate system
fields.body:
The debate on economic and monetary union is always presented as a choice between two extremes: fixing our exchange rate with Emu countries irrevocably by adopting the euro, or leaving things as they are - with the rate for sterling floating erratically between the UK and our main trading partners. Earlier this week, the euro hit an all-time low against the dollar at 82.30, the first time it has fallen below 83 cents. Against the pound, it fell to 57.86p.

There is another option - a managed exchange rate system which would keep ster ling at a relatively stable and competitive level against the euro, while still allowing room for changes in the euro/ sterling rate when circumstances made it necessary.

Of course, such a proposal invites the retort: what, another European exchange rate mechanism, that was a failure wasn't it? In fact, the ERM was a story of both successes and failures. It ended disastrously for the UK, because we joined at too high an exchange rate. But for most of the participants it provided a period of exchange rate stability culminating in eventual currency union. We need to devise a new ERM which will avoid the mistakes of the past and provide a measure of stability for those EU members who are not in Emu. This is desirable whether or not we eventually wish to join.

The advantage of such an arrangement is that we would not have to subject ourselves to a monetary pol icy determined by the European Central Bank, as we would if we joined Emu. Not only is the ECB free of any democratic political control, but it has already shown a strong deflationary bias, being more concerned about the relatively low rate of inflation in the Emu countries, than the dangerously high level of unemployment.

A new ERM would mean that UK interest rates could not differ widely from Emu levels, but we would still have some room to manoeuvre. In any event it is time we stopped relying solely on interest rates to regulate demand and made more use of budgetary policy. The present approach has left industry at the mercy of fluctuating and uncompetitive exchange rates.

But if we are to create a new ERM, there are a number of key lessons to be learnt from past experience. The first and most vital is that exchange rates must be set at realistic levels in the first place. It is no good setting up any new arrangement unless sterling enters at a competitive level. Given the ECB's concern at the low level of the euro, this could be a good moment to negotiate a deal. Subsequent adjustments in rates should not, as in the past, be left until major changes are needed and the situation has reached crisis proportions. In future rates should be reviewed at regular intervals, and changes made in small, and relatively frequent, steps - rather than in infrequent large jumps.

For example, exchange rates (like interest rates) might be reviewed monthly with a convention that any changes would be made in steps of say, 1%. Such an approach would make it easier to reach agreement and would greatly reduce the potential gains from speculating on changes in rates. In addition past experience shows the need for effective stabilisation arrangements to keep currencies within their stated bands. We should establish a stabilisation fund which would automatically intervene when speculation was threatening to drive currencies out of their bands - rather than relying on ad hoc intervention by the central banks.

Such an arrangement would still leave sterling un stable in terms of the dollar, though with some scope to take changes in the euro/ dollar rate into account when fixing the euro/sterling rate. But the need to seek greater exchange rate stability is a world-wide one. We should be moving towards global management of the rates between the dollar, euro and yen and developing regional currency arrangements based on these leading currencies. Politically, such an agreement covering all the EU members who have not joined Emu would help to narrow the gap between the "ins" and the "outs".

The scheme would be answerable to a committee of ministers and avoid the constitutional fallacy of Emu in putting the key instrument of economic policy into the hands of a central bank entirely free from any democratic control.

It is strange that this option has received so little attention or support, given its potential economic and political attractions which would leave open the option whether or not to join Emu at a later date. Indeed the economic secretary to the Treasury recently went out of her way to insist that "we have absolutely no intention of being in an ERM2 or shadowing the euro or any such arrangements".

Given that the logical out come of further economic integration on the Emu model is some form of European federal government, the ERM-style option would leave those countries who did not wish to join such a federation still closely linked to the inner federal core. Perpetuating the present volatile system of freely floating exchange rates between certain members of the EU will make life increasingly difficult for industry in the countries concerned, and could eventually threaten the break-up of the European Union as we know it. That may be what some elements in the Conservative party would like, but it would reverse one of the greatest achievements in international economic and political cooperation in the post-war world.

 John Grieve Smith wrote the Fabian Society pamphlet Closing the Casino: Reform of the Global Financial System.

Given that the logical out come of further economic integration on the Emu model is some form of European federal government, the ERM-style option would leave those countries who did not wish to join such a federation still closely linked to the inner federal core. Perpetuating the present volatile system of freely floating exchange rates between certain members of the EU will make life increasingly difficult for industry in the countries concerned, and could eventually threaten the break-up of the European Union as we know it. That may be what some elements in the Conservative party would like, but it would reverse one of the greatest achievements in international economic and political cooperation in the post-war world.  John Grieve Smith wrote the Fabian Society pamphlet Closing the Casino: Reform of the Global Financial System. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Europe attempts to talk up euro

fields.headline: Europe attempts to talk up euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: European economic policy makers yesterday launched a charm offensive in a bid to take the pressure of the struggling single currency.
fields.body:
European economic policy makers yesterday launched a charm offensive in a bid to take the pressure of the struggling single currency.

They weighed in as the euro hit a new low of $0.823 - more than four cents below the rate at which the central banks of the Group of Seven countries intervened last month to support the ailing currency. It later rose to about $0.8275.

Euginio Domingo Solans, of the European Central Bank's governing council said Europe's economic performance would eventually be reflected in a stronger euro but warned that intervention could not be ruled out. "The ECB will do all it can to achieve its objective of price stability, without excluding the possibility of intervention," he said.

French finance minister Larent Fabius said the single currency, which has fallen 30% against the dollar, had the capacity to appreciate by at least 20% - though he warned there had to be better economic policy coordination between member governments.

Economic affairs commissioner Pedro Solbes added his voice to the chorus suggesting that the slump in the euro's value only affected those who needed to buy dollars. "A euro is a euro," he said in an interview with a French newspaper. "Your house is worth exactly the same in euros as it was six months ago. Unless you have the intention of selling it and investing in dollars."
