fields.headline: Patten beats drum for euro
fields.standfirst:
Staying outside single currency 'will put Britain in peril'
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Staying outside single currency 'will put Britain in peril'.
fields.byline: Ian Black  and  Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
Britain will come under "very great" pressure to bring its economic and tax policies into line with members of the European single currency, Chris Patten, the European commissioner for external relations, predicted last night.

In a speech about democracy in Europe, the former Conservative party chairman and Hong Kong governor painted a stark picture of the dangers of marginalisation if Tony Blair does not take Britain into euroland.

Speaking in Oxford, Mr Patten gave one of his strongest arguments yet about the logic of scrapping the pound in order to enhance, not destroy, British sovereignty.

In January 2002 euro notes and coins will replace national currencies in 12 of the 15 EU member states, with Britain, Sweden and Denmark all now likely to stay out for the foreseeable future.

"Britain is no longer part of the inner circle of economic policy-making in the EU - the so-called eurogroup," Mr Patten said. "British diplomats hover about outside the eurogroup and pick up what scraps they can about plans for economic and monetary policy but they have no say."

Mr Patten pointed to growing pressure for closer economic coordination in the EU, a key reason for Britain's attempt to prevent the emergence of arrangements for a "two-speed Europe" in the Treaty of Nice in December.

"Britain can resist indefinitely the extension of majority voting to new areas, and thereby maintain her veto on sensitive issues like tax," he said.

"But as greater consensus begins to develop in the eurogroup on economic, monetary and even fiscal issues, I suspect that the economic and competitive pressures upon Britain to come into line, in her own interest, could become very great."

Failure to join euroland could also mean the Group of Seven forum of the big European countries, the US and Japan would give way to a "G3" that would coordinate between those with responsibility for management of the dollar, the euro and the yen.

"Would we still be invited to dine at the high table if we were outside the euro zone?"

Mr Patten backed the idea, put forward by the prime minister in Warsaw this month, for a "statement of principles" or "charter of competences" that would define where the boundaries lie between the nation state and the EU. That would spell out that the EU is now a "mature institution which has achieved the broad balance it seeks between national and European powers".

His comments came as a European commission survey said Britons know less about the EU than any of their continental counterparts.

An alarming 40% admitted that they knew "almost nothing" about the EU, 39% said they knew only "a little", while just 2% were able to boast that they knew "a great deal".

The reason for such ignorance is buried in the same survey which reveals that the British public believes that much of its own press does not give the reader the full and fair story.

Only 2% said UK media coverage of the EU is "very fair" while 27% judged EU reporting as "not very fair" or "not at all fair". Britons rate their press as less objective than 12 of the EU's 15 member states.

Only the Portuguese consider that they are worse served by their media when it comes to the EU.

Some of the report's findings - that public support for Britain's membership of the EU has plunged to its lowest level in 20 years - seeped out in July, but it was only yesterday that the full Eurobarometer report was released. Officials questioned 16,000 Europeans in April and May.

Neil Kinnock, the EC's vice-president, said yesterday: "This survey again underlines the lack of knowledge of the British public about Europe and their desire to know more.

"The most important source of information are newspapers and if several of them go on feeding people with myths it's not difficult to understand the knowledge deficit."

webTitle: Eurosport strikes World Cup sponsorship deal

fields.headline: Eurosport strikes World Cup sponsorship deal
fields.trailText: 8am: Eurosport has signed a sponsorship deal with computer manufacturer AMD for its World Cup programming, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Eurosport has signed a sponsorship deal with the computer processor manufacturer AMD for the broadcaster's package of World Cup programming.

The agreement covers a new magazine programme, One World, One Cup, which features footage from World Cup matches all over the world.

AMD will also sponsor a series of top-level friendly matches in which France will defend its title in the run-up to the next World Cup in 2002. The deal includes sponsorship of all European highlights games.

Dominic Burns, director of sales for Eurosport, said: "With France being the world and European champions, there is immense interest across Europe in seeing how they prepare for the next World Cup.

"AMD is looking to grow its profile in Europe and has selected sport, football and the World Cup qualifying process as the perfect environment in which to reach its target group, build awareness and boost brand values."

webTitle: Rainey Kelly/Y&R to run domestic violence ads

fields.headline: Rainey Kelly/Y&R ads tackle domestic violence
fields.trailText: 8am: An image of a battered woman will form the centrepiece of a campaign for a domestic violence charity launched by Rainey Kelly Campell Roalfe/Y&R.
fields.body:
A harrowing depiction of a battered woman will form the centrepiece of a new campaign for a domestic violence charity being launched by Rainey Kelly Campell Roalfe/Y&R.

The national press and poster campaign for Womankind features the beaten and bloodied face of a victim of domestic violence.

Breaking next week, the campaign aims to tackle violence against women. Over one in four UK women now suffer abuse at the hands of their partners - a rate higher than the US, Canada, Australia and other parts of Europe.

The work features the woman sharing make-up tips on how she covers facial injuries rather than telling anyone about it.

The copy reads, "Makeover tips by Sally Chapman. Florist. For a split lip I put on Vaseline to seal the cut. Next I apply lipstick with a brush as it's less painful. I hide strangle marks to the throat by wearing a scarf or polo neck jumper. I always wear a fringe so I can cover any cuts and bruises on my forehead when my husband kicks me."

The ad will boost support for and awareness of White Ribbon Day (November 25 in the UK) when fundraising events for the charity will take place.

The ad will run in the December issues of Zest, Eve and Cosmopolitan and on 1000 6 sheet poster sites nationally. It was art directed by Jerry Hollens, written by Mike Boles and shot by Nadav Kander. All parties involved in the production and placement of the ad donated their time.

fields.headline: Granada launches north-west talent scheme
fields.trailText: 8am: Granada has pumped £100,000 into a new fund for developing writing talent in the north-west, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Granada has pumped £100,000 into a new fund for developing writing talent in the north-west.

The announcement comes as new head of drama Andy Harries has unveiled three new commissions.

Drama producer Sita Williams has been appointed to oversee the project, which is designed to team up established Granada writers with new writers in a drive to develop new material.

Ms Williams said "There is a strong tradition of writing that has been nurtured at Granada from Paul Abbot to Kay Mellor and we are keen to build on that. We are also looking at providing a window for these scripts by creating a space for regional drama."

Meanwhile, Granada drama Cold Feet has been commissioned for a fourth series, while Fay Ripley, who stars in the series, will star in a three-part series of I Saw You, which piloted earlier this year on ITV.

Granada has also commissioned Jury, a six-part series written by Peter Morgan, which looks at a racially-motivated murder trial through the eyes of the jury.

fields.headline: The best entrepreneurial scene
fields.standfirst: Blair witch 2
fields.trailText: Blair witch 2
fields.body:
After its phenomenal success at the box office, low-budget horror film The Blair Witch Project has become the subject of a media frenzy. One TV report captures the mood.

"And now," declares a newsreader, "Blair Witch fans are not only flocking to the multiplex - they're flocking to the little town of Burkittsville, Maryland."

Cut to the woods around Burkittsville. The local sheriff bawls through a megaphone at a gaggle of black-clad teenagers.

"Get out of the goddamn woods! There is no goddamn Blair Witch!"

Cut to a middle-aged Burkittsville woman standing outside her house.

"Our stickmen sold so well on the internet," she says to camera, "that we started selling them in the front yard of the house. And then, when everybody came by, they wanted to buy rocks. So I went out in the back yard and got rocks out of my rock garden, but I didn't want to get rid of them. So the guy offered me $10, and his wife really wanted 'em, so we got started that way. And then we sold some rocks on the internet, but not as much, cause it costs too much to post a rock."

Cut to Jeff (Jeff Donovan), standing on his porch surrounded by Blair Witch memorabilia: model stickmen, T-shirts, baseball caps.

"You know, there are a lot of nay-sayers who come and... say nay. But then there's a lot of supporters who come to my town and come up to me and they hug me and they say 'Dude! I know it's real.' And they squeeze me and they say 'It's real.' And I hug 'em back and say 'I know it's real too, man.' And we have a bond, we have a connection. And they go 'I know.' And I go 'I know.' And they go 'I know.'"

See also: The Hudsucker Proxy, Citizen Kane, The Man In The White Suit

Don't see also: Knock Off

Pointless trivia: Blair Witch 2 director Joe Berlinger is planning a US remake of The Wicker Man.

fields.headline: Bruckheimer goes to war
fields.standfirst: At $140m, Pearl Harbor had the biggest initial budget ever given to a film. Who would Disney hand that much money to? Step forward Jerry Bruckheimer, the legendary producer who rose to fame with a series of testosterone-fuelled action flicks and a cocaine-snorting, whore-loving business partner: Don Simpson.  John Patterson profiles the man whose film-making by formula set the standard for the Hollywood blockbuster
fields.trailText: At $140m, Pearl Harbor had the biggest initial budget ever given to a film. Who would Disney hand that much money to? Step forward Jerry Bruckheimer, the legendary producer who rose to fame with a series of testosterone-fuelled action flicks and a cocaine-snorting, whore-loving business partner: Don Simpson. John Patterson profiles the man whose film-making by formula set the standard for the Hollywood blockbuster
fields.body:
Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, April 2 2000. A ceremony is being conducted at the war memorial erected to commemorate those who died when Japanese planes bombed the US's main Pacific naval base on December 7 1941 - "a date that will live in infamy", as Franklin D Roosevelt called it in his declaration of war against Japan the following day. Prayers are intoned, the grim events of that Sunday morning are invoked and wreaths are laid on the spot where one of four great battleships was sunk that day, with the death of 2,235 sailors and 68 civilians.

But the gathering is also a kind of blessing for a great endeavour about to be undertaken by some of the ceremony's participants. Hollywood producer Jerry Bruckheimer - the king of breaking glass and gigantic fireballs and a man with an inordinate fondness for retreading old movies and blowing things up - is about to embark on his latest project. In a $140m reprise of From Here To Eternity, Tora! Tora! Tora! and 30 Seconds Over Tokyo, Bruckheimer will get to bomb Pearl Harbor all over again.

Prominent alongside him in the gathering are the movie's stars, Josh Hartnett, Ben Affleck, Cuba Gooding Jr and Kate Beckinsale. Bruckheimer and his alpha-male director Michael Bay stand side by side with the people who have helped make the movie happen: Hawaiian governor Ben Cayetano, the admiral in command of the US Pacific Fleet and, perhaps most importantly, Richard Cook, chairman of the Walt Disney Motion Pictures Group, which has given Pearl Harbor the largest budget ever approved in advance by a Hollywood studio.

The high point of the ceremony comes when a fleet of planes that were all in use 59 years ago flies over the crowd. In the next month of location shooting, the islands of Hawaii and Oahu will be strafed anew by these and other aircraft and the islands' various air and naval bases will once more be littered with corpses, covered in blood and shrouded in smoke. It may only be a movie, but it's a Jerry Bruckheimer movie, which means that, much like December 7 1941, it will be brutal, ugly and loud - just how Jerry likes it.

It has been a good year for Bruckheimer: three hit summer popcorn movies - Gone in 60 Seconds, Coyote Ugly and Remember the Titans - have relined his ample pockets. This follows five years in which he has knocked out one bombastic, testosterone-fuelled mega-hit after another: Bad Boys, Crimson Tide, Con Air, The Rock, Armageddon, Enemy of the State - all of them doing business in the $200m range, and often well above that. Bruckheimer's name and company logo - a point-of-view shot from a car doing 100mph down a lightning-flecked highway at dusk - have become synonymous with masculine aggression, massive explosions, high body counts, sub-Tarantino dialogue and sub-John Woo action spectacle. To those of tender sensibilities he is the devil incarnate, the man who helped destroy the movies, and an architect of our cultural stupidisation; but to those who sit in Hollywood's counting houses he's a man with his finger planted squarely on the moviegoing audience's collective clitoris. He is money.

The last half-decade proves that Bruckheimer has emerged from the shadow of his boorish, bullying, narcotics-fuelled former partner Don Simpson, who taught the cautious, clean-cut Jerry what "infamy" was. An idiot savant whom Hollywood routinely and ridiculously dubbed "a genius", "an intellectual" and "a philosopher", Simpson pioneered the idea that movies should be simple, no matter if that meant they were also simple-minded. He and Bruckheimer earned millions from Flashdance, Top Gun and Beverly Hills Cop. Together they developed a template for movie success that remains the standard operating procedure of producers searching for the lowest common denominator and the highest box-office receipts.

Bruckheimer's post-Simpson movies don't deviate one iota from the formula they established together in the 80s. They usually have their origins in a magazine article - because who reads books in Hollywood? - which is then worked into a script by a number of writers, credited or otherwise, and polished by squadrons of rewrite men like Robert Towne or Scott Rosenberg. They don't build a story into something with bulk and weight; on the contrary, their job is to remove excess distractions until the script achieves Bruckheimer's desired degree of dumbness, a level of simplicity that can be fully summed up in a poster's 10-word tag-line.

Next come the directors, of whom Bruckheimer has a loyal stable. These are usually ants-in-their-pants, edit-like-a-woodpecker-on-amphetamines directors like Tony Scott, Simon West and Michael Bay. They, like Simpson and Bruckheimer, have backgrounds in commercials or music videos, the two kinds of film-making that most resemble finished Bruckheimer products. Most of them are the kind of id-monster overdogs you'd expect to be helming big action flicks like these. Michael Bay keeps a 200lb mastiff near him at all times, and Tony Scott has an unnervingly Simpsonian fondness for big cars, big cigars and big breasts.

The resulting, saturation-marketed movies are derivative in the extreme, and Bruckheimer has even started to cannibalise his own successes. Coyote Ugly, for instance, which was released in the UK last week, has the Flashdance formula: no stars, minimal storyline (hot babe chases big dreams), wall-to-wall MTV hits on the soundtrack, dance routines and an ample display of midriff and cleavage. Gone in 60 Seconds cashed in on the 70s car-chase genre, tapping the audience that flocked to John Frankenheimer's rubber-burning thriller Ronin. It's also a second stab at the speed-freak thrills of Simpson-Bruckheimer's brain-dead racing-car movie Days of Thunder. And Remember the Titans is a return to Dangerous Minds territory; both films feature teachers as heroes, and pupils as infinitely improvable productive citizens.

Pearl Harbor, meanwhile, fits the New York Times's definition of Simpson-Bruckheimer's output as "stitched together, like some cinematic Frankenstein monster, from the body parts of other movies". Among those "other movies" are Bruckheimer's The Rock, Con Air and Armageddon, all of which feature an equivalent number of plane crashes and explosions. As the Los Angeles Times said of The Rock, Bruckheimer's movies, no matter how successful, "epitomise trends in Hollywood film-making that have made many people very rich while impoverishing movie audiences around the world". Are these the movies we deserve, or even desire? How did we come to this?

Pearl Harbor is currently in post-production and is due for US release on memorial day 2001. Bruckheimer describes it as "a sweeping, epic love story" that encompasses both the raid on Pearl Harbor and the Doolittle raid on Tokyo in early 1942. Affleck and Hartnett play marine buddies who both fall for American nurse Kate Beckinsale and both happen to be in Hawaii on December 7. That's about as much plot as Bruckheimer has ever needed to hang a movie on, and both the budget and the presence of the barnstorming Michael Bay would seem to guarantee that considerably more effort and intelligence have been applied to the special effects, big bangs, soundtrack and marketing blitz than to the story itself.

But this time the stakes are rather higher. Bruckheimer, Bay and many crew members have deferred large parts of their salaries, and the producer and director face punitive income reductions should the film exceed Disney's budget. Actors will work for just above scale wages, and Bay won't even get a percentage of the profits. "It's really, really tough," says Bay. "But I knew you only get a chance to do an important movie like this maybe once or twice in your career."

The $140m budget may seem gigantic, but Bay and Bruckheimer originally requested $180m. "We all knew from the very beginning that we were dealing with scary numbers," says Todd Garner, of the Buena Vista Motion Picture Group. Garner and the Disney studio chief persuaded the film-makers to excise certain expensive scenes from the script, including a sequence involving exploding submarines. Shooting took place at Pearl Harbor itself - using thousands of naval men and women as extras - in Corpus Christi in Texas, where the 1941-vintage USS Lexington - doubling as both an American and a Japanese battleship - is now a floating museum, and in the same studio-built Mexican water tank used by James Cameron for Titanic.

To cover his bases, Bruckheimer has elected to avoid the docu-drama approach of previous Pacific-theatre movies like Tora! Tora! Tora! and Midway. "In Tora! you really didn't get to know a lot about the characters. It was just about the attack. It was very well done. Some of the battle sequences were terrific, and we certainly learned a lot from what they did - and what they did wrong. Pearl Harbor is not a documentary in any shape or form. We're trying to do what we did for Titans (which is based on a true story), and that's capture the essence of what happened."

Nonetheless, the spirit of James Jones's novel From Here to Eternity and the film adaptation by Fred Zinneman both seem to hang over the film. One early trailer goes so far as to replicate Eternity's famous love scene in the waves between Burt Lancaster and Deborah Kerr. But just to prove it's a bona fide Bruckheimer movie, the trailer also includes a shot of Ben Affleck in a speeding convertible with Japanese fighters screaming overhead.

The harbour itself no longer exists, so a great deal of money was spent trying to recreate it. "Anything done less than perfectly," says Garner, "would be disrespectful to the Americans who lost their lives there." But the movie will attempt to avoid the kind of Yellow Peril race-baiting that disfigured many previous movies about the Pacific war. "This is not a movie that says one side is good and the other side is bad for staging a sneak attack," says Ben Affleck. "The story does take note of economic factors that may have contributed to the Japanese attacking.

"War is something awful, not something to celebrate. This story is really uncompromising and honest about what the survivors of the Japanese attack went through. I really believe the film will be the definitive piece about the attack."

"High concept" is a misleading but much-used phrase in Hollywood. What it really means is "low-brow" or "lowest common denominator". What it means is a pitch that can be spun out to a studio moneyman in less than 30 seconds, such as "Arnold Schwarzenegger and Danny Devito are... TWINS!" Seven words. Millions of dollars trousered. In this way fortunes are made. The pitch is often cited as the purest distillation of high-concept. It was Don Simpson who invented high-concept. Long may he rot.

Don and Jerry were close, but they were not twins, although they later marketed themselves as if they were. Simpson was the ideas factory, Jerry the man at ground zero, the nuts-and-bolts guy. Jerry was the reserved Midwestern Jew; Alaskan Don the wild'n'crazy guy. Don would refine scripts with writers, often sending script notes that exceeded the length of the scripts themselves. When the script was adjusted, or dumbed down, to Simpson's satisfaction, he would hand over the production reins to Jerry and return to his steel and glass house to resume his bracing regimen of drug-abuse, cosmetic surgery and beating up and urinating on $5,000-a-night prostitutes from the stables of Madam Alex and Heidi Fleiss. It netted $235m domestically and after two sequels the Beverly Hills Cop series made Paramount more than a billion dollars worldwide. Simpson hired writer Chip Proser and showed him a photo which embodied the concept he was after. What you're doing is trying to get inside the heads of these teenyboppers and figure out what they want to see."

Though he never abandoned his old friend, there was no longer anything useful the Alaskan could teach him. Sooner or later, any fool can learn how to make movies stupider than they already are.

Simpson would have shown an amusing, muscular writer like Scott (Con Air) Rosenberg the door. Bruckheimer has the sense to adapt to new trends in dialogue and action signalled by the successes of Tarantino and John Woo.

But finally these movies - with or without Simpson's input - are nearly all designed to make skips full of money in the shortest time possible. To that end they are constructed around big guns, big government, big bangs and big tits, allied to whatever fleeting phenomena Bruckheimer deems worth exploiting. Even Pearl Harbor owes its existence to a recent right-wing nostalgia for the generation that fought the second world war, a nostalgia that fed the John McCain campaign this summer as much as it spelled the success of Saving Private Ryan and anchorman Tom Brokaw's book The Greatest Generation.

We live in an era that combines the fat complacency and political apathy of the Eisenhower 50s with the garish clothes, confusions and doubts of the late 70s. Somehow Jerry Bruckheimer resolves these contradictions and makes money out of them. He is truly the right movie producer for our blighted age.

 Pearl Harbor will be released next year.
fields.bodyText: Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, April 2 2000. A ceremony is being conducted at the war memorial erected to commemorate those who died when Japanese planes bombed the US's main Pacific naval base on December 7 1941 - "a date that will live in infamy", as Franklin D Roosevelt called it in his declaration of war against Japan the following day. But the gathering is also a kind of blessing for a great endeavour about to be undertaken by some of the ceremony's participants. Hollywood producer Jerry Bruckheimer - the king of breaking glass and gigantic fireballs and a man with an inordinate fondness for retreading old movies and blowing things up - is about to embark on his latest project. In a $140m reprise of From Here To Eternity, Tora! Tora! Tora! and 30 Seconds Over Tokyo, Bruckheimer will get to bomb Pearl Harbor all over again. The high point of the ceremony comes when a fleet of planes that were all in use 59 years ago flies over the crowd. webTitle: Afect, Britain's only part-time film school,  is in danger of going under

fields.headline: Show me the money
fields.standfirst: Afect is Britain's only part-time film school - a place with a passion for celluloid where students learn the craft of movie-making on scavenged 16mm equipment. But, as  Steve Rose  reports, this eccentric breeding ground for directors is in danger of going under
fields.trailText: Afect is Britain's only part-time film school - a place with a passion for celluloid where students learn the craft of movie-making on scavenged 16mm equipment. But, as Steve Rose reports, this eccentric breeding ground for directors is in danger of going under
fields.body:
Now that you need no more than a digital video camera and a good idea, it should be easier than ever to become a film-maker; but as any old hand will tell you, there's more to filming than point-and-shoot. "There's a whole generation that knows nothing about film-making beyond pressing a button on a camcorder," says Jeremy Ross, founder and director of the Advancement of Film Education Charitable Trust (Afect).

Afect sees itself as something of a model for film education in this country, although it teeters on the brink of extinction and its scrounged 16mm equipment could be seen as outdated by today's fledgling auteurs. A small, independent school in King's Cross, London, it has become an institution in Britain's film-making community, both for its uniquely populist stance and its sheer tenacity. If you want to know more without giving up your day job, Ross is one of very few people who can help. "I don't know much about the Dogme movement, but that's not the most important thing: the basics of film-making - lighting, editing, composition, etc - are the same whatever format you shoot in."

Afect has survived for the past 15 years on begged favours, appeals, discounts and donations from benefactors such as Sir John Gielgud, Bob Hoskins, Julie Christie and its patron, Mike Leigh. It is also the only facility in the country which caters to students with neither the time nor the money for full-time film school. On top of the cash crises, there are now uncertainties over the leasing of its property and without support from the newly established Film Council, it could disappear.

"We're the scavengers of the film world," says Chris Bullmore, a former film and commercials maker who joined Afect's slim staff last year. "Everything's done on the cheap, but it's a bloody good exercise for the future. A lot of film-making is about discipline, and the less money you have, the more disciplined you are. It's the artist-in-garret syndrome."

As befits a facility whose existence has been spartan at the best of times, the course is oriented firmly towards the practice of making films with limited resources - and essentially that means 16mm film only. For new film-makers, 16mm has considerable advantages over digital, Bullmore explains: "It's much cheaper - especially when you want to hire edit suites and the like - and if something goes wrong with DV equipment, there's nothing you can do. It's all lost, and there's no way you can fix it yourself."

In the Film Council's statement of aims and objectives, unveiled this April, £1m of its £54m expenditure was allocated to training and education. The council is due to begin dishing out its money soon, and Ross's fear is that, as the Film Council's literature states, the distribution of that £1m will be co-ordinated through Skillset, an industry-backed national training body. "You'd think, being the only part-time film school in the country, that our claim would be self-evident, but that remains to be seen," says Ross. "Skillset is OK for certain skills and training, but there's a constant pretence that this is adequate to deal with film-making education generally. It isn't. It will provide some limited technical jobs in the industry but that's not what we're about. We're about making young film-makers.

"Film education has never been adequately supported in this country," he continues. "Go to America and there's a place like this in every state. Or compare it to music-making facilities here. In Britain there are facilities for making quality music but virtually none for film."

A sometime film-maker, sculptor and photographer, Ross founded Afect according to principles formed in his student days at the International Film School with Mike Leigh, among others. "The philosophy was really that this is an incredibly potent medium, and why isn't it speaking to more people?" he recalls. "It was like the printing press when it came out - a way of disseminating information to the people in general, but with film, those wider possibilities were not being explored."

There was much idealistic discussion about opening up film-making and creating alternative routes for film distribution and education, but Ross was one of the few who did something about it. He initiated a film course that was open to anybody, under the auspices of the Inner London Education Authority (Ilea). He started it as a practical course one evening a week in the City of London. The course grew fast and moved venues, but then Ilea was abolished - 15 years ago - just as the course was gathering momentum. Afect decided to continue the project without state support.

With the exception of visiting tutors and lecturers, Ross ran the school virtually single-handed until last year. There are now four permanent staff members (by and large unpaid) and an average intake of 25 students a year. The two-year diploma course costs less than £1,500 a year, compared with a minimum of £3,900 a year at the National Film and Television School, or £4,620 at the London International Film School.

Crucially, teaching takes place in the evenings and at weekends. During the daytime, the studio is hired out in order to bring in extra revenue. Though Afect is not geared towards turning out professional film-makers, the school claims to have a respectable record when it comes to placing graduates within the industry. Katherine Freeman, for example, has had her short films broadcast as part of the BBC's 10x10 programme, and one, finished at Afect, has been purchased by Anglia Television. Mark Sturdy is another, a former banker whose films have been shown at the NFT and who is currently developing scripts commercially.

In many ways, the state of film-making has not panned out the way Ross, Leigh and co hoped in the 70s. There is still no established network of local film-making or film education across the country, and the success or failure of the British film industry under the Film Council will be measured primarily in terms of financial performance rather than benefit to society. The only indication that "taking film to the people" is on the agenda at all is an undefined pledge to "ensure that over time the British film industry reflects the rich cultural diversity of the UK, and offers equality of opportunity and access to individuals whatever their background".

Ross avoids separating the conflicting issues, however, arguing that there should be a net commercial gain from giving more people access to film-making. "What is commercial?" he asks. "It's a question of how you market it. In an age where there's so much flimsy material around without any guts or heart, little films with personal conviction ought to be commercial. fields.bodyText: Now that you need no more than a digital video camera and a good idea, it should be easier than ever to become a film-maker; but as any old hand will tell you, there's more to filming than point-and-shoot. "There's a whole generation that knows nothing about film-making beyond pressing a button on a camcorder," says Jeremy Ross, founder and director of the Advancement of Film Education Charitable Trust (Afect). Afect sees itself as something of a model for film education in this country, although it teeters on the brink of extinction and its scrounged 16mm equipment could be seen as outdated by today's fledgling auteurs. A small, independent school in King's Cross, London, it has become an institution in Britain's film-making community, both for its uniquely populist stance and its sheer tenacity. If you want to know more without giving up your day job, Ross is one of very few people who can help. "I don't know much about the Dogme movement, but that's not the most important thing: the basics of film-making - lighting, editing, composition, etc - are the same whatever format you shoot in." Afect has survived for the past 15 years on begged favours, appeals, discounts and donations from benefactors such as Sir John Gielgud, Bob Hoskins, Julie Christie and its patron, Mike Leigh. It is also the only facility in the country which caters to students with neither the time nor the money for full-time film school. On top of the cash crises, there are now uncertainties over the leasing of its property and without support from the newly established Film Council, it could disappear. "We're the scavengers of the film world," says Chris Bullmore, a former film and commercials maker who joined Afect's slim staff last year. "Everything's done on the cheap, but it's a bloody good exercise for the future. A lot of film-making is about discipline, and the less money you have, the more disciplined you are. It's the artist-in-garret syndrome." As befits a facility whose existence has been spartan at the best of times, the course is oriented firmly towards the practice of making films with limited resources - and essentially that means 16mm film only. For new film-makers, 16mm has considerable advantages over digital, Bullmore explains: "It's much cheaper - especially when you want to hire edit suites and the like - and if something goes wrong with DV equipment, there's nothing you can do. It's all lost, and there's no way you can fix it yourself." In the Film Council's statement of aims and objectives, unveiled this April, £1m of its £54m expenditure was allocated to training and education. The council is due to begin dishing out its money soon, and Ross's fear is that, as the Film Council's literature states, the distribution of that £1m will be co-ordinated through Skillset, an industry-backed national training body. "You'd think, being the only part-time film school in the country, that our claim would be self-evident, but that remains to be seen," says Ross. "Skillset is OK for certain skills and training, but there's a constant pretence that this is adequate to deal with film-making education generally. It isn't. It will provide some limited technical jobs in the industry but that's not what we're about. We're about making young film-makers. "Film education has never been adequately supported in this country," he continues. "Go to America and there's a place like this in every state. Or compare it to music-making facilities here. In Britain there are facilities for making quality music but virtually none for film." A sometime film-maker, sculptor and photographer, Ross founded Afect according to principles formed in his student days at the International Film School with Mike Leigh, among others. "The philosophy was really that this is an incredibly potent medium, and why isn't it speaking to more people?" he recalls. "It was like the printing press when it came out - a way of disseminating information to the people in general, but with film, those wider possibilities were not being explored." There was much idealistic discussion about opening up film-making and creating alternative routes for film distribution and education, but Ross was one of the few who did something about it. He initiated a film course that was open to anybody, under the auspices of the Inner London Education Authority (Ilea). He started it as a practical course one evening a week in the City of London. The course grew fast and moved venues, but then Ilea was abolished - 15 years ago - just as the course was gathering momentum. Afect decided to continue the project without state support. With the exception of visiting tutors and lecturers, Ross ran the school virtually single-handed until last year. There are now four permanent staff members (by and large unpaid) and an average intake of 25 students a year. Mark Sturdy is another, a former banker whose films have been shown at the NFT and who is currently developing scripts commercially. In many ways, the state of film-making has not panned out the way Ross, Leigh and co hoped in the 70s. webTitle: Richard Attenborough on the life and times of Grey Owl

fields.headline: Animal magic
fields.standfirst: Grey Owl was a liar, a lush, a bigamist and an impostor. But he was also one of the world's first environmental activists.  Richard Attenborough on the life and times of the phoney 'Redskin' who inspired his new movie
fields.trailText: Grey Owl was a liar, a lush, a bigamist and an impostor. But he was also one of the world's first environmental activists. Richard Attenborough on the life and times of the phoney 'Redskin' who inspired his new movie
fields.body:
Some nine years ago, trying to pass the time in a doctor's waiting room, my business partner was leafing through a dog-eared copy of Country Life. It contained an article commemorating the 50th anniversary of the death of a man who called himself Grey Owl. The more she read of his extraordinary story, the more she became convinced that here was a terrific subject for a feature film.

Later that same morning I found her in our office, trying to sell the idea. This Grey Owl, she explained, was a man with a cause, an essentially good man with something important to convey, who also happened to be a liar, a lush, a bigamist and one of the world's great impostors. She went on to say that he had been a very successful trapper in Canada, killing hundreds of animals for their pelts, until his love for a local woman, and her love for two orphaned baby beavers, brought about a kind of epiphany. From then on, he crusaded fiercely to save this species from near-extinction and to preserve the Canadian wilderness for posterity.

Grey Owl, who was the most celebrated "Red Indian" of his day, had written a number of best-selling books and in the 30s he came to England to promote them, dressed as a chief in buckskins and a feathered war bonnet. He was invited to Buckingham Palace. He lectured up and down the country. It was then that it all came back to me.

Over half a century earlier, my brother David and I had attended one of Grey Owl's lectures in Leicester, where we lived. We had even claimed afterwards to have shaken the hand of this real "Redskin" and we had asked him for his autograph. I recalled how we had fought for possession of the book containing the author's signature. I also remembered, with renewed chagrin, that it was Dave who won.

Growing keener by the minute on the idea of this film - and knowing that my brother was back from one of his many journeys to hobnob with killer whales or wade through some disgusting pile of bat dung - I picked up the phone. Yes, Dave said, of course he still had the book. And no, he would not hand it over. Defeated yet again in the sibling stakes, I asked where, if anywhere, he thought Grey Owl stood in the canon of conservationists.

The answer was immediate: "He was a major figure, one of the first of his kind. But, sadly, his death in 1938, and the revelations that followed, plus the outbreak of war, meant that all his warnings were ignored. The great tragedy is that if people had acted on what he was saying, the whole ecological movement would have been advanced by at least 30 years." That sealed it. I became determined to make a film about this intriguing character and I eventually cast that wonderful actor Pierce Brosnan in the title role.

But, back then, after I put the phone down, I went on thinking about the evening in 1936 when Dave and I went to Grey Owl's lecture in the De Montfort Hall. It had been a defining moment for both of us, an event which managed perfectly to combine the disparate passions which were to absorb us for the rest of our lives. Dave was 10 and I was 13. For as long as I could remember my brother had this strong affinity with the natural world. His room was always cluttered with snake casts, dead insects and the conglomeration of fossils he insisted on carrying back from our holidays in Wales. He was the quiet, studious one, Dave; the undisputed favourite son of my academic father. I was the noisy elder brother, the show-off with the bad school reports whose theatricality, to my father's disgust, was fostered by our mother, the enthusiastic president of the local amateur drama society.

Not surprisingly, Dave's memories of Grey Owl's lecture are very different to my own. He was bowled over by the man's determination to save the beaver, by his profound knowledge of the flora and fauna of the Canadian wilderness and by his warnings of ecological disaster should the delicate balance between them be destroyed. The idea that mankind was endangering nature by recklessly despoiling and plundering its riches was unheard of at the time, but it is one that has remained part of Dave's own credo to this day.

I, on the other hand, recall almost nothing of what Grey Owl said. The fascination for me lay in his showmanship, in his stage presence, which was phenomenal. The thrilling Indian head-dress, made of rare eagle feathers, made him nearly 8ft tall. His skin was a wonderful bronze colour (I now know he applied a vegetable dye in his dressing room), and, in the days when other races were rarely seen in England, I found him compellingly exotic.

That January evening marked the start of a year which changed our family life for ever. Within months, the civil war in Spain would prompt my mother to march down Granby Street under a red banner in support of the Republicans. In reply, one of Franco's Leicester adherents would lob a brick through our drawing-room window. Undaunted, my mother formed and chaired a local committee to care for evacuated Basque children and, shortly thereafter, one of them caused me to fall in love for the very first time. Her name was Rosa. My father was chairing another local committee which was helping to bring Jewish refugees out of Germany. Again, children were the principal concern, and our house became a staging post for a series of scared youngsters on their way to relatives in the safety of North America. Two little girls, Irene and Helga, would eventually be stranded with us when it was no longer possible for passenger ships to sail the Atlantic. They became our much-loved unofficial adopted sisters and lived within our family until 1946. Both their parents perished in the Holocaust.

Meanwhile, in April 1938, our celebrity lecturer died in far-off Canada. On the following day, a newspaper, aptly named The Worth Bay Nugget, broke the scoop it had courteously been sitting on while he remained alive. Grey Owl, it was revealed, had absolutely no "Red Indian" blood. His real name was Archibald Stansfield Belaney and, far from being nurtured by a Native American tribe, he had been born and brought up by two maiden aunts in Hastings. Soon the English papers ware full of the story of how the whole nation, including King George VI, his queen and the two little princesses, Elizabeth and Margaret Rose, had been duped by this magnificent impostor.

But it was my mother, as usual, who cut to the heart of the matter. I can see her now, thwacking down the issue of the Manchester Guardian containing Grey Owl's revelatory obituary. "His identity doesn't matter a damn," she, who never uttered an oath, said firmly. "The only important thing is what he came to tell us."

 Grey Owl is released next Friday.

fields.headline: In the Mood for Love
fields.standfirst: The latest film to come out of Hong Kong is a perversely exciting tale of adultery and romance - without the standard sexual denouement
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It is a world of crumbling plaster, perspiring wallpaper, of tacky formica restaurant booths, shabby-genteel apartments framed in a shot which can be suddenly bisected by the tatty curtain, flapping in an urban breeze which mirrors the sirocco of suppressed longing. This is the dark and lonely "mood" for love that Wong Kar-wai evokes
fields.body:
If it is possible to find the erotic register of despair, or the romantic dimension of ennui, then Wong Kar-wai certainly achieves it in his new film. This is an exquisitely nuanced account of a married man and his married woman neighbour in the Hong Kong of the early 60s, who discover that their respective spouses are having an affair. For their mutual comfort as fellow sufferers - and also finding in their situation a kind of parodic and perversely exciting intimacy - they embark on an ambiguous affaire de coeur of their own.

It is a secret liaison whose every glance and touch has a silent static crackle of tension: not sexual tension precisely, but the tension of two people who are consciously duplicating the form of their partners' adultery, with all the snatched restaurant meals and meetings in hotel rooms, but forgoing the sexual denouement and refusing to make the four-cornered puzzle snap into place. They have become siblings rather than lovers, a brother and sister orphaned by the absence of trust, and sustained by their own faint odour of incest.

The man is Chow Mo-Wan, a local newspaper editor, played by the estimable Tony Leung, a performer who grows inexorably in depth and acuity. There is something desperately poignant in his gentle, sensitive face, at once lined and boyish. His neighbour is Su Li-Zhen, played by Maggie Cheung, a stunningly beautiful, statuesque screen presence, her hair always worn glamorously up, with discreet droplet earrings, and whose elegant, roof-raisingly sexy form the camera is wont to follow as she sashays along alleys and into corridors.

It's the only overtly salacious thing about a film which effortlessly maintains its own code of formality and propriety. In a film dominated by interiors and cramped apartments, Cheung's face provides a landscape of emotions, showing the camera not merely its luminous beauty, but subtly graduated responses: the flinch at a nosy neighbour's intrusion, the sheen of sweat and unease, the slight puffiness that goes with misery, the ghost of a future middle age of regret. And throughout the film it is Chow and Li-Zhen that we see, but never their counterparts: an affectation, perhaps, but one of whose validity and naturalness Wong Kar-wai effortlessly persuades us.

Hong Kong itself is here a dark and crowded place, steamy and noirish, whose vast sprawl and energy is hinted at in only a few modest sets and locations. It is a place where it seems always to be raining, and from which the two principals are perpetually forced to take good-humoured shelter.

In the Mood for Love is a movie perfumed not merely by the noodles and dumplings that feature so prominently, but by the smell of clothes drying out after being caught in the rain. Cinematographer Christopher Doyle and William Chang, the production designer, have created an almost narcotically tactile world of textures and surfaces, lovingly noticed and brilliantly realised. It is a world of crumbling plaster, perspiring wallpaper, of tacky formica restaurant booths, shabby-genteel apartments framed in a shot which can be suddenly bisected by the tatty curtain, flapping in an urban breeze which mirrors the sirocco of suppressed longing. This is the dark and lonely "mood" for love that Wong Kar-wai evokes.

But it is in this hothouse of emotions that Chow and Li-Zhen's friendship flowers, and Chow discovers in himself the talent that he has yearned for: with Li-Zhen as muse, he starts turning out martial-arts serials. It is a happy invention, as the feeling of pulp fiction, of melodrama and even hysteria beneath the decorum, saturates the film. Emboldened perhaps by this artistic relationship, the couple start to rehearse future, painful scenes together: Li-Zhen confronting her adulterous husband and their own inevitable parting.

Wong Kar-wai locates the poignancy of their love affair in how short-lived it is, and how short all our lives are, and how we behave as if the excitement or the pain of each moment is the precursor to an infinite supply of such moments: the prelude to an open-ended vista, rather than one stage of a finite history. This is partly a humid, faintly Graham Greene-like love story, partly a conundrum about opaque and enigmatic behaviour. But what it mostly is, is a love story for grown-ups, a film that treats the themes of love and betrayal with almost theological seriousness. It is not to be missed.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Galaxy Quest | Scream 3 | The Cider House Rules | Desert Blue
fields.trailText: Galaxy Quest | Scream 3 | The Cider House Rules | Desert Blue
fields.body:
Galaxy Quest
Rental Universal Pictures Cert PG
****

One of the year's cheekiest comedies. A bunch of has-beens from a long-cancelled TV sci-fi series attend a fan convention. The fans, as you'd expect, are largely dressed as extraterrestrial lifeforms. But as the series' hung-over captain, Tim Allen, discovers, some of them are genuine aliens who have seen, from afar, this crew's triumphant progress in "historical documents" on the Galaxy Quest series and want the help of these experienced and battle-hardened travellers. Before you can say "beam me up, Scotty," Allen has boldly and unwittingly gone where he didn't want to and is soon followed there by his fictional "crew".

Conceptually, this is just Three Amigos in space, but unlike the Steve Martin Mexican spoof it doesn't run out of steam and has a sharply knowing script. A lot of the fun is in the casting: the world-weary Tim Allen has never been more likeable; Alan Rickman's innately superior manner and look of deep, withering distaste are put to wonderful use in his role as the series' Spock-like "alien", while the cinema's mighty alien-slayer Sigourney Weaver is cast as a blonde interstellar glamourpuss whose only function is to repeat the captain's orders to the computer. The script enables Rickman, whose dignity is constantly being undermined, to say "I've played Richard the Third. Five curtain calls" to which Allen spits, "Scene-stealing hack!" - a phrase that must surely have been used on occasion by overwhelmed and outshone actors.

What makes Galaxy Quest an unusual comedy is its affection for all its characters. There's a real underlying sympathy for ageing, typecast actors who have to indulge the nerds who believe in the roles they play - not in the actors themselves; for these thespians who pine to use their craft, rather than their spacecraft, again. ("These guys haven't had a real acting job in 20 years," Allen overhears a fan say at the convention.)

But the oddball fans are not viewed with contempt, and one of them eventually gets to help his heroes out of a tight spot. The chief alien is a real personality, too, played with great charm by Enrico Calantoni.

It's never a direct parody but it's near enough to add a layer of extra comedy, even for non-Trekkers. It's the relative subtlety of the comic ideas (compared with formula fare like Spaceballs) that makes this a bit of a treat.

Scream 3
Rental and DVD rental Buena Vista Cert 18
***

Despite the loss of writer Kevin Williamson, this third episode does a reasonable job of keeping things silly but chilly in old Woodsboro. The new writer is Ehren Kruger, who gave Arlington Road its memorable, twisted look. It comes as no surprise that cast members of the movie Stab 3: Return to Woodsboro are dying in unpleasant ways uncannily similar to those in the film, but Kruger pulls off a few new twists in the tale's endless self-referentiality. The most effective of these sees Courteney Cox, returning as Gale Weathers, permanently pestered by Parker Posey, who is playing Gale Weathers in Stab 3 ("What my Gail would do...").

Other laugh-worthy silliness includes actresses playing Cox and Neve Campbell's characters being called Jennifer Jolie and Angelina Tyler and a wandering appearance on a studio tour from Kevin Smith's recurring slob duo, Jay and Silent Bob.

It makes good sense that Campbell's character has become a phone-in agony aunt - who better to advise teens on those little traumas like homicidal maniacs at the senior prom? Of course, part threes are discussed. "They should be the concluding chapter of a trilogy," we are told. Hope so.

The Cider House Rules
Rental and DVD rental Buena Vista Cert 12
***

Another whimsical, sprawling and unpredictable yarn from John Irving, best-known for The World According to Garp. What you can anticipate is controversial subject-matter. Garp brought feminism, transsexuals and a memorably horrible motoring accident to the screen. The Cider House Rules, set in 1943, is a bumpy ride too in plot terms, with abortion and incest featuring prominently.

The story starts in a huge orphanage, where our hero (Tobey Maguire) is "twice adopted, twice returned" and ends up permanent resident and assistant to the head, nicely played by Michael Caine. Caine's cranky but loving patriarch is the most convincing character by a distance, reading the kids gruesome bedtime stories and scaring them with King Kong on film night. It's a shame that much of the film takes place elsewhere and without him. His Maine accent is not too bad, either.

If the orphanage makes you think of Dickens, it's not long before Caine is reading David Copperfield to the kids. Lasse Hallstrom makes the orphanage inmates impossibly well-behaved, and glossy unreality runs throughout a coming- of-age tale that doesn't bear comparison with Hallstrom's autobiographical My Life As a Dog.

Maguire's character is called Homer, but the trials and tribulations of his journey never ring true or provide any great insights. There are incidental pleasures along the way though, including a beautiful New England fall, and Hallstrom keeps you wanting to know what happens next, though the ending is a big let-down.

Desert Blue
Rental Columbia Tristar Cert 15
**

Desert Blue is uncertain in tone and cries out for a trim at two hours plus. Its straight-to-video release two years after it was made is probably down to the increasing celebrity of two of its actresses - Christina Ricci and Kate Hudson.

Ricci is fun as an explosives expert, while Hudson, Goldie Hawn's daughter, is currently wowing the US in Almost Famous. She makes an unconvincing lead as a bratty young TV star who turns nice after meeting local youth Brendan Sexton. The film has no idea how to pull off this transformation. The plot maroons Hudson and her dad, John Heard, in a one-horse town (pop 97) after a possible toxic spill.

I wanted to see a lot more of Heard, as a university professor studying the roadside attraction, Ricci and the scandalously underused Sara Gilbert, who can give Ricci a run for her money for laconic insouciance - and a lot less of Sexton and Hudson's winsome lead duo.

fields.headline: Henry Loyn
fields.standfirst: Master historian who illuminated the social and economic history of the Anglo-Saxon world
fields.trailText: Master historian who illuminated the social and economic history of the Anglo-Saxon world
fields.body:
The interests of the historian Henry Loyn, who has died aged 78, focused on early medieval England and upon Anglo-Saxon society and government in particular; warfare and politics held little attraction for him. He was professor of medieval history at University College, Cardiff, from 1969 to 1977, then at Westfield College, London University, until 1987, and professor emeritus until his death.

He worked, first, on the changing terminology for Anglo-Saxon nobles, showing an impressive ability to read between the lines of Old English and Latin sources. His first book, Anglo-Saxon England And The Norman Conquest (1961, reprinted 1991) provided students with a much-needed survey of early English social and economic history.

In concept, it showed the dominant influence of the great Reading University historian Sir Frank Stenton, but it also displayed Henry's mastery of detail in his search for the middle ground in the great controversies over the scale of the Anglo-Saxon and Scandinavian invasions, and the origins of the manor and feudalism.

The success of this book gave Henry the confidence to reach out to a wider audience. The Norman Conquest, written in good time for the 900th anniversary of the battle of Hastings, went through three editions (1965, 1967 and 1982). His splendid collection of translated sources on The Reign Of Charlemagne (1975), produced jointly with his Cardiff colleague John Perceval, his Vikings In Britain (1977), Governance Of Anglo-Saxon England (1985), and English Church 940-1154 (2000) are all superb undergraduate textbooks.

He also wrote several works for a wider lay audience, some in notable collaboration with the artist Allen Sorrell. Very different skills as an editor and co-ordinator were honed in his facsimile edition of A Wulfstan Manuscript (1971), in the co-edited festschrift for his friend and head of department, Stanley Chrimes (1974), in the Allecto facsimile edition of Domesday Book (1986-9) and in two major encyclopaedic projects (1989, 2001).

Alongside these books, Henry also produced more than 50 substantial articles, notable for their skill in synthesising historical evidence with archaeological, numismatic and legal sources, and surveying hitherto neglected subjects. He also allowed himself occasional ventures into Welsh, and local Glamorgan, topics.

Henry had enjoyed happy schooldays at Cardiff high school - which gave him a lasting accomplishment as a chess player - but his life was changed by the onset of tuberculosis. Excluded from war service on medical grounds, he found himself among the reduced cohort of undergraduates studying at Cardiff, where he gained an English degree, and then, in 1946, a first in history.

Both were fundamental to his intellectual development: he emerged a committed historian, with a deep love of poetry and literature; he stood out among historians for his command of Old English and his supreme ability to write lucid and balanced prose.

In 1946, he was appointed to an assistant lectureship in Cardiff's history department, then under the benign leadership of Professor William Rees. There, he shouldered a formidable teaching load and rose steadily to become professor in 1969.

Henry was to surprise his friends in 1977 by accepting the vacant chair of medieval history at Westfield College. At that time, he was in the midst of an outstandingly successful term as president of the Historical Association (1976-9), but the London base gave him wider opportunities to serve the academic world - including on the British Academy council and project committees, as president of the Society of Medieval Archaeology and as vice-president of both the Royal Historical Society and the Society of Antiquaries.

He was vice-principal at Westfield from 1980 to 1986, and, for the last two of those years, its acting principal. His courteous serenity and willingness to contribute made him welcome as a committee-member, and he was a superb chairman.

He proved a powerful but conciliatory defender of Westfield's independent status within the federal structure of London University. When that battle could not be won, he worked to make a success of the 1989 merger with Queen Mary College without rancour. It is typical of him that, at the height of these responsibilities, in 1986 he found time to lecture to more than 40 audiences across the country in honour of the 800th anniversary of Domesday Book.

A gentle and handsome giant of a man, Henry was much loved by colleagues and pupils alike. His calm and mellifluous voice, his gracious moderation and his enthusiasm for Anglo-Saxon and Norman history helped create a much wider audience for medieval history.

In 1950, he married the love of his life, Patricia "Pat" Haskew, and enjoyed a richly happy home life. In retirement, they returned to Cardiff, this time to Penarth, from where Henry maintained a formidable flow of publications, and put his serene judgment to the service of the local historical societies and his alma mater. He will be remembered as the kindest of facilitators, with a great gift for bringing out the best in all he encountered.

Pat and their three sons survive him.

Henry Royston Loyn, historian, born June 16 1922; died October 9 2000

fields.headline: Vamberto Morais
fields.trailText: Vamberto Morais, who has died of a brain haemorrhage aged 77, was an author and former head of the BBC Brazilian service in London. His work was a beacon to Brazil during its years of military government.
fields.body:
Vamberto Morais, who has died of a brain haemorrhage aged 77, was an author and former head of the BBC Brazilian service in London. His work was a beacon to Brazil during its years of military government.

Morais came from an affluent family of sugarcane mill owners, but rebelled against the poverty and injustice around him. Although a year younger than other students, he finished top of his year at medical school in Recife.

In 1946, as he was about to become head of the psychiatric department at a Recife hospital, he won a British Council scholarship to study at the Maudsley hospital, south London. It was the beginning of a lifelong love affair with England, a country, he said, which gave him a feeling of freedom.

After a year, however, Morais abandoned medicine for ancient history, and, nine years later, returned to Brazil as head of the English literature department at Recife University. But, always a restless person, he soon returned to London to write and broadcast.

In 1961, he was back in Recife, teaching history and writing his first book, A Small History Of Anti-Semitism. After the 1964 military coup, he returned again to London, and, in 1970, became head of the BBC Brazilian service.

Stories about torture, the murder of political prisoners and the violation of human rights were censored in the Brazilian media. The BBC Brazilian service - an impor tant source of news with a wide audience- became a target for the regime, which complained at the coverage of torture accusations. In 1975, a former Brazilain service journalist, Vladimir Herzog, died under torture in an army interrogation centre. Morais's answer, apart from coverage of his death, was to re-run a Bernard Shaw play, in which Herzog played a leading role.

After retirement in 1981, Morais abandoned his earlier anti-clericalism and underwent a religious conversion. He joined ecumenical groups, visited ashrams in India, and practised vegetarianism and yoga. He was an admirer of Brazil's progressive Catholic clergy, who had taken up liberation theology and, under the military, suffered for it.

Morais lived in a semi-detached house in a quiet north London suburb. Inside, however, was another world. He might be standing on his head practising yoga, while his wife Lourdes, a splendid cook, would be preparing Brazilian food and mixing exotic puddings, aided by friends, Brazilian visitors, priests, journalists, spiritualists and monks.

Morais published books on religion and on women's emancipation. He is survived by Lourdes, to whom he was married for 42 years, his daughter Ariadne, and two grandchildren.

Vamberto Lopes de Morais, writer and broadcaster, born September 1 1922; died August 30 2000

fields.headline: Author's 'revenge' on erring husband
fields.trailText: Agatha Christie "carefully orchestrated" her sensational disappearance as if it were a plot for one of her detective novels, the daughter of a lifelong friend said yesterday.
fields.body:
Agatha Christie "carefully orchestrated" her sensational disappearance as if it were a plot for one of her detective novels, the daughter of a lifelong friend said yesterday.

Judith Gardner said the author had planned the episode as an act of revenge against her unfaithful husband, Archie. Her 11-day disappearance in 1926 after an apparent car crash led to government concern and a search by police who believed she had been murdered.

When discovered at a hotel in Yorkshire booked under the name of her husband's mistress, Mrs Christie's excuse was that she had received a blow on the head. "For 24 hours I wandered in a dream, and then found myself in Harrogate as a well-contented and perfectly happy woman who believed she had just come from South Africa."

Mrs Gardner, 84, daughter of Mrs Christie's sister-in-law and friend, Nan Watts, said she had learned the truth as a child in the company of the pair. On the night Mrs Christie disappeared she was secretly hidden by Mrs Watts at her Chelsea home before she kitted her out at the Army and Navy store, gave her money, and put her on a train the following afternoon to Harrogate. "She then just sat there in her hotel room, hiding away," Mrs Gardner said yesterday.

"But she had signed the guests' register in the name Neele - the surname of her husband's lover. It was carefully orchestrated."

Mrs Gardner and her husband, Graham, added: "She wanted Archie back.

"She wanted to give him a shock. If she had had amnesia she would not have signed the register in the other woman's name. She was a highly intelligent woman."

Her disappearance, dramatised in the 1979 film Agatha, with Vanessa Redgrave, misfired because of the scale of press coverage. At one stage police, under pressure from the home secretary, suspected her husband of murdering her.

Mrs Gardner said: "My mother helped her because she was distraught. I think she went to my mother because she had been through a divorce. [Mrs Christie] never did it for the publicity. That was the last thing she would have thought of. She was very upset and shocked - it all went rather wrong."

Subsequently Mrs Christie divorced but she kept her husband's surname, partly because it was her writing name. She married the architect Sir Max Mallowan. But, at her death in 1976 at 86, her first wedding ring and Mr Christie's letters were found in her writing case.

Some of the Gardners' story was discussed in a book and TV programme in 1998, but Mrs Christie's biographer, Janet Morgan, was not convinced by it. The author was "sick and bewildered" before and after her flight, said Dr Morgan.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: • Settlement The US federal trade commission said Microsoft 's interactive television unit WebTV agreed to settle charges filed by the body, which accused the firm of false advertising. The settlement would prevent the company from making "deceptive advertising claims about the performance capabilities of the WebTV system", the FTC said.
fields.body:
 Settlement The US federal trade commission said Microsoft 's interactive television unit WebTV agreed to settle charges filed by the body, which accused the firm of false advertising. The settlement would prevent the company from making "deceptive advertising claims about the performance capabilities of the WebTV system", the FTC said.

 Look ahead The managing director of Sony , Masayoshi Morimoto, said he saw the PlayStation2 console as the firm's "gateway to the future" despite the difficult situation in the division. "I hope everyone sees the game operation from a longer-term viewpoint," he said.

 Deal Investment fund NewMedia Spark said it has invested £1m in an analytical software company, IntelligentApps Holdings. The investment is part of a £1.8m round of funding from NewMedia, and private individuals.

 Tune in Website Meanfiddler.com said that it is to launch a music channel on digital TV under the Mean Fiddler name. It expects revenue from licensing deals, sponsorship, ad and music products sales.

webTitle: Share buyback call rejected by Pilkington

fields.headline: Share buyback call rejected by Pilkington
fields.trailText: Pilkington, Britain's largest glass manufacturer, yesterday rejected a call from one of its largest shareholders for a share buyback to boost its ailing share price.
fields.body:
Pilkington, Britain's largest glass manufacturer, yesterday rejected a call from one of its largest shareholders for a share buyback to boost its ailing share price.

UK Active Value, which owns 5% of the St Helens-based glassmaker, wants the board to use its existing authority to buy back shares to boost investor returns.

The combative investment fund, run by Julian Treger and Brian Myerson, seeks to shake up underperforming businesses.

It has told the Pilkington directors it intends to seek other shareholders' support for a move to buy back shares.

But Pilkington's chairman, Nigel Rudd, said: "It is not our intention to use this authority at the present time but we will always examine any proposal designed to ensure that the share price more accurately reflects the improved position of the business."

Finance director Andrew Robb said that the group, which yesterday announced a 31% rise in first-half earnings, had other investment opportunities. These included the possible purchase of the glass business of Visteon, Ford's components company.

Pilkington is also taking over full ownership of its Polish float glass operation, which it said would add up to £4m in operating profit every year.

On top of that Pilkington's Cebrace, a joint venture with French rival Saint Gobain, is setting up a fourth float glass plant in Brazil due to start operating by the end of 2002.

The increase in profits reported yesterday was helped by improved glass prices and growth in its building and automotive units. Pilkington said it expected further growth in the second half of the year.

Merrill Lynch analyst Mark Hake said in the light of the results he was raising his forecasts for full year pre-tax profits to £225m from a previous estimate of £215m.

The recent decline in Pilkington's share price came after American rival PPG Industries issued a profit warning last month - although some analysts said that PPG's problems had originated in its non-glass operations, and it was therefore an inappropriate comparison for Pilkington.

webTitle: BSE: Denial, failure and the betrayal of the public

fields.headline: Denial, failure and the betrayal of the public
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The government yesterday accepted that successive administrations' failures had contributed to the BSE catastrophe and apologised for the first time to families of those who had died from the horrific, incurable disease that transferred from cattle to humans.
fields.body:
The government yesterday accepted that successive administrations' failures had contributed to the BSE catastrophe and apologised for the first time to families of those who had died from the horrific, incurable disease that transferred from cattle to humans.

As politicians of all sides expressed their sorrow and regret for the "dreadful, scarring experience" endured by the 85 victims of variant CJD, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, announced that talks with families would begin next week on care and compensation packages that will run into millions of pounds.

All measures to protect human health and the extent of scientific knowledge into the killer diseases that ravaged the farming industry and now threaten unknown numbers of the population are to be reviewed following the publication of the long-awaited report into the handling of Britain's most costly peacetime disaster.

The findings and 167 recommendations of Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers, following a two-and-a-half year £27m inquiry, represented an indictment of the Whitehall system under successive Tory governments but his 47 criticisms of 25 individuals were measured and low key. Conservatives last night were privately relieved at Lord Phillips' apparent reluctance to be harder hitting but it was in no one's political interest to say so.

Lord Phillips said nothing could have prevented the BSE epidemic or the infection of consumers because the long, secret incubation periods of the diseases had taken hold before the first cattle were identified as suffering from a brand new killer.

But after praising the efforts of all those trying to fight BSE, he said plaudits must remain muted because policy decisions too often took too long to make and were not implemented, enforced or monitored with sufficient rigour.

Lack of communication, indecision, and the "team failure" to recognise the risk to human health from BSE were among the most serious shortcomings. The attempt to "sedate" the public with reassuring messages helped cause "a public feeling of betrayal" when the probable link to human health was announced in March 1996. One key flaw had been the government's failure to ban mechanically recovered meat from carcasses - used in hamburgers and pies - at the same time as other potentially risky parts of cattle in 1989. This was eventually done in 1995 after years of poor slaughterhouse controls.

The reaction of families was muted but many accepted the Phillips' report was "a thorough job" rather than a whitewash.

Labour ministers attempted, not always successfully, not to make political capital out of the findings, which only covered the BSE crisis until the human link was established, when John Major was still prime minister. Mr Milburn said he had said "sorry to the families for the pain and suffering they have experienced. It is clearly for those who were in the position of power and responsibility at the time to make their own apologies". He was making £1m immediately available to provide better care for vCJD victims and their families while negotiations took place with them and their legal representatives.

Government sources said it was up to families to decide whether they wanted to pursue legal action but suggested agreed compensation arrangements were better than drawn out and uncertain passage through the courts. A trust set up in 1987 to compensate people who were infected by HIV or Aids through blood transfusion had so far paid out £93m to nearly 1,300 victims.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said the Phillips report was being sent to all European partners in the hope they could avoid making similar mistakes to Britain's. A key finding is that BSE has been a "particularly British disaster", with over 170,000 cattle being diagnosed here and fewer than 1,500 abroad, most traceable to the exporting of live animals or infected animal feed.

Earlier Mr Brown told the Commons that the inquiry team had not looked for villains or scapegoats. He insisted Labour had ended the "deregulation culture" of the previous Tory governments.

Mr Major told the Commons that the inquiry report was "impressive and objective". He added: "All of us, as we read it, must accept our own responsibilities for shortcomings that were made and the problems that arose from them." BSE and its transition to vCJD had been a "dreadful , scarring experience".

Tim Yeo, the Tory agriculture spokesman, said he was "truly sorry for what has happened, and I apologise to the families who have suffered bereavement and for those people who are suffering a terrible illness."

Findings of the report

 BSE developed into a disaster because of intensive farming, and the feeding of cow and sheep remains to cows.

 Delays, bureaucracy, lack of rigour by civil servants and poor enforcement undermined policy.

 Reassurance over safety of beef was a mistake which undermined public confidence in government.

 The government did not lie or cover up.

 But it was preoccupied with preventing an alarmist overreaction because it believed the risk to humans was remote.

 BSE-like diseases may yet emerge in other animals.

Recommendations

 Even when risk to humans seems remote, all reasonable precautions must be taken.

 There should be more checks on possible pathways of transmission, and on occupational risks.

 The government must be more open about risk to re-establish public trust.

 Review of secrecy in licensing of medicines.

 More responsibility must be established for coordinating research into new diseases.

 Better training in experts who can track diseases.

 More enforcement checks.

 Scientific committees must not water down assessments of risk to avoid causing alarm.

 Better contingency planning.
