webTitle: Experts finger Bush as the big spender

fields.headline: Experts finger Bush as the big spender
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Casting himself as a leader untainted by political cynicism or partisan hostility, George W Bush made his most personal attack so far on Al Gore yesterday, signalling a rough turn in the presidential election campaign as the two men battle for advantage in what the opinion polls say is going to be the closest White House contest for a generation.
fields.body:
Casting himself as a leader untainted by political cynicism or partisan hostility, George W Bush made his most personal attack so far on Al Gore yesterday, signalling a rough turn in the presidential election campaign as the two men battle for advantage in what the opinion polls say is going to be the closest White House contest for a generation.

Speaking in Pittsburgh, he accused Mr Gore of being "bitter and negative", and depicted himself as the man who could set a new tone of "civility and bipartisanship" in Washington.

As he did so, his taxation and spending plans - the centrepiece of his policy appeal - ran into one of the most influential challenges it has yet faced.

"Bush is very much overspending Gore," the senior pensions expert at the American Academy of Actuaries, Ron Gebhardtsbauer, said after a panel from the academy assessed both candidates' budget plans.

But it was the attack on Mr Gore that captured the headlines rather than the possibility that Mr Bush might himself be indulging in the "fuzzy maths" with which he has taunted his Democratic opponent.

"My opponent's campaign is a fitting close to the Clinton-Gore years," Mr Bush said, as the majority of the national polls continued to show him narrowly ahead of Mr Gore.

"They're going out as they came in. Their guide, the nightly polls; their goal, the morning headlines; their legacy, the fruitless search for a legacy."

Speaking confidently, to the frequent accompaniment of cheers from supporters, he accused Mr Gore of setting a confrontational tone.

"He talked about ripping the lungs out of political adversaries. Part of his campaign headquarters is called, incredibly enough, 'the slaughterhouse', and his staff proudly calls itself a band - and I quote - of 'killers'.

"That's political killers, of course."

Meanwhile the non-partisan group of financial experts from the Academy of Actuaries was delivering its damaging judgment.

Mr Bush's budget plans, the panel found, would force the US back into annual deficits after he leaves office.

His published commitment to cut taxes and switch pension contributions into personal accounts would mean that the government could no longer meet its financial commitments without going into the red from around the year 2015.

The actuaries calculated that Mr Bush's plans would make it all but impossible for the US to eliminate its national debt, a goal to which both main parties have officially subscribed ever since the current account of the federal budget moved into surplus two years ago.

The Bush campaign team says its projections show that it can eliminate the federal debt by 2016.

Mr Gore has promised to achieve this by 2012, a pledge which the actuaries say can be fulfilled, on the basis of their published figures.

"I don't see any way they [the Bush plans] pay off the public debt," Mr Gebhardtsbauer said.

"In 2015, the budget will go negative. There won't be a surplus any more."

The actuaries said they were not taking sides in the election but applying standard evaluation techniques to the plans and rhetoric of the two campaigns.

Mr Gebhardtsbauer said that the only way the Bush campaign could make good its claims would be by double-counting the equity building up in pension accounts.

The actuaries, a professionally conservative group, also said that Mr Gore's budget plan was much more accurate and specific than Mr Bush's. The Bush team has so far produced only broad outlines of its intentions, Mr Gebhardtsbauer said.

A statement from Mr Gore said: "The numbers don't add up." Mr Bush was promising "the same trillion dollars to two different groups of people", he said.

webTitle: Republicans hit by dirty tricks claim

fields.headline: Republicans hit by dirty tricks claim
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Lawyers in Washington are openly hinting at dirty tricks by the George W Bush campaign in one of the most curious mysteries of this year's presidential contest.
fields.body:
Lawyers in Washington are openly hinting at dirty tricks by the George W Bush campaign in one of the most curious mysteries of this year's presidential contest.

Six weeks ago, one of Al Gore's advisers, Tom Downey, received a videotape in the post showing Mr Bush taking part in a rehearsal for the televised presidential debates.

The video, which was shot at Mr Bush's Texas ranch, was confirmed as genuine by the Bush campaign when the incident came to light.

At first, Mr Downey, a former Democratic congressman, assumed the video had been sent by a secret Gore sympathiser in the Bush camp in Austin, Texas. He passed the tape to his lawyer, Marc Miller, who has now complained to the FBI that there could be a more devious motive - an attempt by the Bush to plant the tape itself and suggest that the Gore campaign might be cheating.

In his letter to the FBI director, Louis Freeh, Mr Miller says: "It now appears to be more likely than not that the original transmission of the material to Mr Downey was not in fact a misguided act of a single person acting alone _ but rather the concerted, intentional act by more than one person associated with the Bush campaign."

Sources familiar with the investigation say their suspicions have been aroused by curious circumstantial factors, among them the apparently relaxed view the Bush camp has taken about the possibility of a Gore "mole" in its midst.

Suspicion in the case has centred on Yvette Lozano, an assistant to Mark McKinnon, one of Mr Bush's senior media strategists. Ms Lozano was seen by a closed circuit camera mailing a package from the Texas post office from which Mr Downey received the video. As far as is known, she still remains on Mr McKinnon's payroll.

Both sides in the presidential contest remain on constant alert for possible dirty tricks perpetrated by the other.

Only yesterday, the Bush campaign cried foul when the US National Archives released new White House tapes from the Richard Nixon era, three of which featured conversations involving Mr Bush's father, George Bush Sr, who was then representative to the UN.

fields.headline: AEA loses 30% on profits warning
fields.trailText: AEA Technology lost a third of its stock market value yesterday after the engineering and science company warned that its interim results would be well below expectations.
fields.body:
AEA Technology lost a third of its stock market value yesterday after the engineering and science company warned that its interim results would be well below expectations.

The board said first-half pre-tax profits would be around £3m, against expectations of £9.5m. A stronger performance during the second half would not be enough to prevent full-year profits dropping below last year's £31m.

The group's shares fell 162.5p immediately after the announcement before rallying a little to close 140p down at 346p. About 3m of the shares changed hands. The normal level is about 200,000 a day.

This is not the first time the group has caught the market on the hop. A full-year profit warning in March last year wiped 40% off its share price.

The group, spun off from the Atomic Energy Authority in September 1996, was floated at 280p a share.

The board blamed the latest collapse in profits mainly on a delay in the award of three contracts to its engineering software division. It expects the contracts will come through during the second half. But it said the complexity of the multi-licence and multi-year deals meant the shortfall was unlikely to be made up.

The group said trading in other divisions was faltering. Its battery business had been affected by the delays in the Ministry of Defence's Bowman battlefield radio programme while the performance of its environmental and nuclear technology operations were slightly below forecast.

In addition there would be a £2m restructuring cost as a result of a reshaping the intellectual property rights portfolio of the future technologies division "in preparation for a more creative exploitation of its value".

The division is in effect the group's incubator business. Among its activities is work on lithium ion batteries for applications such as mobile phones.

On the up side, a first half improvement by the group's rail services and products operation, which includes signalling technology, is expected to continue into the second half.

Chairman Sir Anthony Cleaver said: "Since flotation the company's strategy has been to focus the business on those activities which are able to deliver sustained value."

"That approach is beginning to deliver real benefits, for example, where the company has built a new rail business through selected acquisition and by concentrating investment on new products that will achieve significant market penetration and deliver real shareholder value."

However, he said the process of producing a consistent record of growth and a sufficiently strong improvement in the quality of earnings had not been met. The board is to appoint a chief operating officer with marketing and sales experience as a first step towards realising value from group assets and operations. Sir Anthony said there would be other senior appointments.

webTitle: BSE: Muted Tory apology amid reform moves

fields.headline: Muted Tory apology amid reform moves
fields.standfirst:
Labour refuses to highlight blame behind damning facts

Special report: the BSE crisis
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Labour refuses to highlight blame behind damning facts.
fields.body:
Political reform in Whitehall, especially an attempt to lessen secrecy and provide greater rigour in addressing scientific risk, is likely to be one of main beneficial outcomes of the BSE inquiry, although any deep change in such a closed culture will no doubt be slow.

Civil servants are also to be told not to sit on difficult news, but to tell ministers much earlier and to encourage more openness about potential health risks.

Ministers are also advised to keep more scientific expertise in house so they can monitor, understand and act upon recommendations from their expert advisory committees.

The Conservative party was last night hoping that the political fallout from the report would be confined to these largely administrative changes in Whitehall culture.

The shadow agriculture secretary, Tim Yeo, was careful to express the apologies of his party for the health disaster over which the Thatcher and Major governments presided, even if he did not specify for which mistakes he was apologising. But former Tory ministers - many of whom did not bother to attend the Commons statement - were privately relieved that the scale of the attack on individual ministers or Tory ideology was not more forthright.

The Tories were helped yesterday by the agriculture secretary, Nick Brown, who resisted the tempation to make political capital. In the Commons, he simply pointed out that some individuals had been blamed, and some of those who had been blamed had also been praised elsewhere in the report.

Mr Brown even slapped down the Liberal Democrat agriculture spokesman, Nick Breed, for claiming the report had vindicated every criticism of the Tories' handling of the BSE crisis. The Liberal Democrats, fighting the Tories in farming seats, were furious at the Labour restraint.

However, Labour believes there is enough damning material in the 17 volumes of the report for the public not to need to be told by Labour that BSE was a specifically Tory disaster. They privately point out that the report clearly criticises the 1980s bonfire of regulations, Whitehall's denigration of local government responsible for overseeing slaughterhouses and ministers' willingness to protect the interests of the farming industry with a string of overenthusiastic reassurances.

Lord Phillips, who chaired the BSE inquiry, provides much supporting evidence for this analysis. He points out that staffing at the ministry of agriculture fell by 25% between 1979 and 1985. The chief medical officer, Sir Donald Acheson, complained to the inquiry about "the incessant pressure for cuts".

Lord Phillips also quotes a paper from John Major to John Gummer, then minister of agriculture: "As I said in my party conference speech, I am absolutely determined to reduce the burden on business." As a result, the permanent secretary at the Ministry of Agriculture told colleagues in 1993 that "deregulation must be a top priority in the department's work".

Kevin Taylor, an assistant chief vet from 1991, said the deregulation initiative made it "more difficult to introduce new regulations, even when this was essential as a result of investigations".

The report will also give a shot in the arm to the long-delayed freedom of information bill. Lord Phillips states that there "was a clear policy of restricting the disclosure of information about BSE". Similar promises of a more open culture followed the Scott inquiry, but no bill regulating arms exports has yet been published.

He also addresses the difficult relationship between scientific committees and politicians. Such committees, Lord Phillips directs, must "not water down its formulated assessment of risk out of anxiety not to cause public alarm".

The government has taken some sensible steps. It has as a matter of policy published the minutes of many of its scientific committees. In an attempt to restore public trust, it has also given seats to consumer groups.

But the BSE report makes clear that ministers should take more responsibility for making their own decisions rather than effectively asking scientists to make them for them.

However, it is not easy for ministers to second guess the advice of scientists. Nor does any minister want to be responsible for generating unnecessary food scares.

Even though he clears the ministry of leaning towards the agricultural producers, rather than consumers, he recounts the tensions between the two. The first cattle died from BSE in 1985, yet the ministry did not advise the chief medical officer of its concerns until March 1998. Health was not involved in key decisions on compensation for farmers.

Some of these tensions may be resolved by the establishment of the still nascent independent food standards agency. But change in Whitehall is never quick.

webTitle: Single cow may have started epidemic

fields.headline: Single cow may have started epidemic
fields.standfirst:
Sheep scrapie in feed theory is rejected

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Sheep scrapie in feed theory is rejected, says James Meek.
fields.body:
BSE emerged in cattle in south-west England as long ago as the 1970s, and had nothing to do with scrapie in sheep, the Phillips report concludes, finally debunking a cherished theory about the origin of the disease.

The report endorses the theory that BSE and its human equivalent are caused by "prions" - rogue versions of molecules of a chemical that occurs naturally in all animals.

On the scientific response to the growing crisis, civil servants are accused of recruiting expert advisers on the basis of scientists they happened to know, rather than the best people for the job.

The Tory government is accused of failing to give its scientific advisers proper remits, asking scientists what to do instead of seeking advice on which to base decisions, and misrepresenting the scientific advice it was getting to the public.

The first committee of scientists set up to advise the government, under the zoologist Sir Richard Southwood, is accused of being too ignorant of the realities of the meat trade to have made the recommendations it did about how the "remote risk" of BSE infecting humans could be reduced to a minimum.

The scientists are also criticised for allowing themselves to be bullied by civil servants into removing from their early recommendations a mention of the dangers of BSE infecting medicines.

The Phillips report's conclusion that BSE did not result from cattle being fed the remains of sheep with a related brain disease, scrapie, lays to rest a theory that led to serious delays in scientists' appreciation of the dangers to humans.

Like BSE and its human equivalent, CJD, scrapie causes the fatal breakdown of brain tissue, with holes appearing in the brain, giving it a spongy appearance.

Because scrapie had been known in sheep for hundreds of years, without any sign of it being passed to humans, scientists assumed the risk of BSE spreading to people was negligible. Cows had been eating fragments of dead sheep in the form of meat and bone meal (MBM) since the 1920s. In the early years of BSE scientists thought a change in the way MBM was recovered from carcasses had led to scrapie jumping the species barrier into cows, and that the 1980s BSE cases were the first. All these assumptions, the Phillips report says, were wrong, though reasonable at the time.

The first cases of BSE almost certainly occurred in the south-west in the 1970s. They either originated from a single cow where the disease was born from a spontaneous mutation, or were passed into cattle from another species.

With a single cow infected, the disease would gradually have spread, the report says. With the cannabalistic practice of feeding animals MBM from their own species, cow would eat cow would eat cow.

As to what BSE is, the report throws its weight behind the prion theory, which it says "has now won general acceptance" - a statement that will be greeted with dismay in some quarters. Other researchers, such as Edinburgh scrapie expert Alan Dickinson, argue that a particle bigger than a molecule but smaller than a virus, perhaps capable of replicating, is responsible.

fields.headline: Young men, full of remorse
fields.standfirst:
Assessments show dramatic progress after seven years

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Assessments show dramatic progress after seven years
fields.body:
The following is an edited extract of Lord Woolf's recommendations:

This is my decision as to tariffs in the cases of Jon Venables and Robert Thompson. They were ordered to be detained during her majesty's pleasure, after being convicted of murder on November 24 1993. In reaching my decision I have had regard to all the information available to me, and in particular the following considerations:

 The murder took place on February 12 1993. Jon Venables and Robert Thompson were then 10 years of age, having been born, in the case of Jon Venables on August 13 1982 and in the case of Robert Thompson on August 23 1982.The facts of the murder were exceptionally horrific. They were summarised by the trial judge, Morland J. in the following terms when sentencing Jon Venables and Robert Thompson: "The killing of James Bulger was an act of unparalleled evil and barbarity. This child of two was taken from his mother on a journey of over two miles and then was battered to death without mercy and then his body was placed across the railway line so that his body would be run over by a train in an attempt to conceal his murder. In my judgment your conduct was both cunning and very wicked."

Subsequently, in the boys' absence, the judge added: "How it came about that two mentally normal boys aged 10 of average intelligence committed this terrible crime is very hard to comprehend ..."

 The statements which I have received from James Bulger's parents make clear the effects of the murder on them. The mother was 26 at the time. She says, and I accept, "not a day goes by without her thinking of the events of the February 12 1993". Her marriage broke up in the summer of 1994 and she has since remarried. She, however, believes that if James had not been killed, she would in all probability still be married to James's father. Prior to the break-up of her first marriage, she had a further son and since her remarriage she has had two more sons. She is now naturally very concerned for the safety of these children and she says she will not allow them out of her sight.

The impact of James's death has been similarly traumatic for Mr Bulger. I have been provided with a clinical psychological report relating to Mr Bulger. The psychologist was of the opinion that Mr Bulger was suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder as a result of the murder of his son for which he requires treatment. This has adversely affected his ability to obtain employment. Members of his family, his brother and mother, are seriously traumatised. They would, according to the report, also benefit from assessment and treatment.

 Reports on the two boys show clearly that they have made striking progress in the secure units where they have been detained. For example, in a report of February this year a consultant adolescent forensic psychiatrist, accustomed to working with child murderers, says of Jon Venables: "He has made exceptional progress as a child adolescent serving HMP with personal development, acknowledgement of the enormity of his offence, understanding of his actions as a child, and in his "normal" adolescent development in "abnormal circumstances".

A similar report in the case of Robert Thompson, also written in February of this year, states: "Robert has made exceptional progress in his current placement with regard to maturity, education and insight gained in therapy. Robert accepts responsibility for the grave acts he committed in the offence and shows great remorse for the pain and suffering he caused."

 Jon Venables and Robert Thompson have been detained in separate secure units. They are different personalities with different backgrounds. However, the assessment of the respective psychiatrists and the staff of the units at which they are detained are very similar when they describe the way these two young men have responded to their punishment. Significantly, the assessments generally agree that both of these young men are genuinely extremely remorseful about the crime which they committed, and the effect which it must have had on James's family. In addition, neither has shown any aggression or propensity for violence during his detention. They have worked hard in pursuing their education and, given their circumstances, have considerable achievements to their credit. All those who have reported on them regard the risk of their reoffending as being low.

 The progress which they have made does not mean that it is going to be easy for them to be rehabilitated into the community. They are bound to have been affected by having grown up in a secure institution. They have had limited contact with the outside world during the last seven years. It is therefore important that the programme necessary to prepare for their return to the community is commenced as soon as appropriate.

 They are both now 18 years of age. Being 18 they would be due to be transferred to young offenders' institutions. The reports make clear that the transfer would be likely to undo much of the good work to which I have referred. Having been living in an unnaturally protected environment, they are unprepared for the very different circumstances in which they would be detained in a young offenders' institution. They are unlikely to be able to cope, at least at first, with the corrosive atmosphere with which they could be faced if transferred. There is also the danger of their being exposed to drugs.

 Their release will not end their punishment. Having become responsible young men, they will have to live with, and will be marked by, what they did when children of 10. Their crime is not one which is expunged by the Rehabilitation Act 1974. They will be on licence and liable to be recalled to custody for the rest of their lives if they do not comply with the terms of their licence.

 If I had been called on to set their tariff after they had been sentenced, I would probably have selected 10 years as being appropriate, as did Lord Taylor. Today it is clear, as was not clear then, that it is necessary when fixing the tariff to take into account the welfare of the children concerned. In addition, when reviewing a tariff in the case of children I am required to take into account the progress which they have made since they have been in detention. In the case of both these young men the information before me makes it clear that they have done all that is open to them to redeem themselves. While their crime remains horrendous, they are entitled to credit for this. Because of their behaviour they are entitled to a reduction in the tariff to eight years, which happens to be the figure determined by the trial judge.

 An eight-year tariff would expire on February 21 2001. I have already pointed out that it would not be in their or the public's interest for these two young men to be transferred to a young offenders' institution. In all probability, if the tariff period expired today it is likely that it would be after February 2001 before the Parole Board could decide whether they should be released and, if so, for the necessary arrangements to be made to enable this to happen. I therefore set a tariff which will expire today. This will enable the very difficult task of deciding if and how these young men should return to society to begin. I emphasise that the final decision as to whether they should be released and conditions for relief are the responsibility of the board and nothing I have said is to interfere with the board's discretion.

webTitle: Trimble hits back at party critics

fields.headline: Trimble hits back at party critics
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland peace process was facing a grave crisis last night after talks appeared to break down between the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, and hardline opponents in his party.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process was facing a grave crisis last night after talks appeared to break down between the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, and hardline opponents in his party.

With less than 48 hours to go until a crucial meeting of the party council in Belfast tomorrow Mr Trimble accused his critics of "sinking" negotiations over IRA disarmament.

His outburst was prompted by a letter from hardliners, who have called tomorrow's meeting, insisting that Mr Trimble abandon the power-sharing executive by the end of next month if the IRA fails to disarm. Mr Trimble, who is opposed to setting a deadline for IRA disarmament, is likely to face a knife-edge vote at the council meeting.

Victory for his opponents, who secured 47% of the vote at the last meeting in May, would force him to withdraw from the executive, delivering what could be a fatal blow to the peace process.

The IRA offered a lifeline to Mr Trimble by confirming that it has allowed a second inspection of its arms dumps. In a statement the provisionals said the former Finnish president Martti Ahtisari and the former ANC general secretary Cyril Ramaphosa had inspected several dumps.

Tony Blair also intensified his efforts to shore up Mr Trimble's position during a visit to Northern Ireland.

Before talks with leaders of the main pro-agreement parties, Mr Blair said he understood unionist frustration at the slow progress on decommissioning but added: "We have a situation which is by no means perfect in terms of security, but we have paramilitary organisations being brought gradually into the proper democratic process. We would make a big mistake if we gave it all up."

Ministers granted a concession to Mr Trimble when they bowed to his demand that control of policing should be handed to the executive.

Their attempts to win over unionists were in danger of backfiring, however, when Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, issued a blunt warning that the Irish republic's government would play an even greater role in the affairs of Northern Ireland if the executive collapsed.

His remarks angered all shades of unionist opinion, and he was accused of issuing a crude threat. The leading UUP hardliner, Jeffrey Donaldson, accused him of making a "a huge mistake".

The Donaldson camp was increasingly confident last night that supporters of Mr Trimble were moving to its side. The hardliners demonstrated their resolve when they published the letter to every council member calling for Mr Trimble and his two ministers to abandon the executive by November 30 if the IRA failed to hand over or destroy "hundreds of illegal firearms".

Mr Trimble said setting a deadline would play into the hands of the IRA. He described the letter as a "matter of great disappointment".

He had hoped to win round the Donaldson camp by proposing to begin a phased withdrawal from the devolved bodies in the new year if the IRA refused to disarm. No deadline would be set, but Mr Trimble would offer private assurances to the party.

webTitle: Chronology of government action towards BSE

fields.headline: From BSE to CJD and what we were told at the time
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: December 1984 Cow, later identified as first known BSE case, seen by vet.
fields.body:
December 1984 Cow, later identified as first known BSE case, seen by vet.

November 1986 New cattle disease formally identified by scientists working for Ministry of Agriculture.

June 1987 Agriculture ministers told of new disease.

July 1988 Farmers with BSE cases given 50% compensation.

July 1988 Ban on sheep and cattle remains being fed back to cattle or sheep.

November 1989 Ban on cattle offals in human food.

March 1990 First restrictions on cattle exports demanded by Brussels.

February 1990 Full compensation for farmers whose cows have BSE.

May 1990 Chief medical officer, Sir Donald Acheson, reassures public that beef is safe to eat.

May 1990 Minister of Agriculture John Gummer claims beef is "completely safe" and appears on TV encouraging daughter Cordelia, four, to bite into a beefburger.

1990 Government sets up national CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh to monitor CJD cases and investigate possible link with BSE.

March 1993 New chief medical officer, Kenneth Calman, repeats 1990 reassurance as BSE rates start to decline.

July 1993 100,000th confirmed BSE case.

May 1995 Stephen Churchill, 19, dies. First recorded death from vCJD.

November 1995 Government bans mechanically recovered meat, used in pies and hamburgers.

December 1995 "There is no scientific evidence that BSE can be transmitted to humans or that eating beef causes it in humans" - prime minister John Major.

March 8 1996 CJD surveillance unit informs spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee of findings of vCJD.

March 17 1996 Minutes of meeting between the then health secretary Stephen Dorrell and then agriculture minister Douglas Hogg: "Mr Dorrell felt strongly that the government should not accept reponsibility for compensation".

March 20 1996 Government admits probable link between exposure to infected meat and vCJD.

March 20-27 1996 Full beef export ban imposed by EU.

March 29 1996 Cattle over 30 months banned from food.

September 1997 Studies on mice show convincing evidence for link between vCJD and BSE.

December 1997 New Labour government announces BSE inquiry into events up to March 1996 and bans beef-on-the-bone.

August 1999 Export ban lifted.

December 1999 Beef-on-bone ban lifted.

webTitle: Alliance of peers votes down sell-off of air traffic control

fields.headline: Alliance of peers votes down sell-off of air traffic control
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government last night suffered a humiliating defeat over its plan to sell off Britain's air traffic control service, as the Lords voted to delay its sale until after the general election.
fields.body:
The government last night suffered a humiliating defeat over its plan to sell off Britain's air traffic control service, as the Lords voted to delay its sale until after the general election.

Liberal Democrat peers and two rebel Labour peers joined Tory peers to vote, by 112 to 90, for the part-privatisation to be delayed from March until after the election - expected to be in May.

The Department of Transport said afterward that the government would seek to reverse the change in the Commons before returning the legislation to the Lords.

But the department admitted that the £500m sell-off could be sacrificed to ensure that the rest of the delayed transport bill, concerned with control of the railways, could be pushed through.

The government is said to be unconcerned about the relatively small amount that the sell-off would bring the Treasury, but is anxious to increase investment in air traffic control and improve efficiency.

The vote was an unanticipated victory for Tory peers. Afterward they seized on the failure of some 70 Labour peers to turn up to vote, and claimed that the fact that fewer than half of the government's 200 peers had supported it revealed a "stunning lack of confidence" in the policy.

Commenting after the vote, the shadow transport secretary, Bernard Jenkin, referred to a pledge before the 1997 election by Andrew Smith, now treasury minister, and said: "Labour were elected on a policy of 'our air is not for sale'.

"This vote shows that it should never be for sale, and this botched privatisation should be abandoned immediately."

During the Lords debate, Tory transport spokesman Lord Brabazon refused to admit his party would bring in full privatisation - which he had argued for unsuccessfully at an earlier stage.

Instead, he claimed the delay was desirable so that the government could include the measure in its manifesto.

fields.headline: 11 days to go
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.body:
On the stump yesterday

George W Bush

For the second day running Bush campaigned in a swing state with a big Republican name - after John McCain in Florida on Wednesday, it was General Colin Powell in Pennsylvania yesterday. They began in Pittsburgh at a rally at the Soldiers and Sailors Museum before flying to Erie for more of the same. Then Bush was moving on to Toledo,Ohio.

Al Gore

His day started in Bettendorf, Iowa, taping an appearance on the Queen Latifah TV show talking about youth participation in politics with 60 young people. It was Gore's sixth national talk-show date (the others include Oprah Winfrey, and David Letterman).Then he, too, was switching states to cover Madison in Wisconsin.

On the road

Bill Clinton will finally be joining the Gore campaign next Wednesday and Thursday, helping his vice-president in California . But there are no plans for the two to campaign together.

Robert Redford and Melissa Etheridge are among the liberal Democrats drafted to try to persuade leftwing voters in Washington and Oregon not to defect from the Democrats to the Greens' candidate, Ralph Nader.

New endorsements

Gore

Actress Sharon Stone

Bush

Actor Charlton Heston and the National Rifle Association he heads. Last month the NRA contributed $961,826 (£663,000) to the Bush campaign war chest.

fields.headline: Prescott introduces rail recovery plan
fields.standfirst:
Further speed restrictions expected during track inspection as 200 passengers escape injury in another derailment

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Further speed restrictions expected during track inspection as 200 passengers escape injury in another derailment
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday put in place a national recovery plan for the railways to deal with the mounting problems caused by broken rails that are paralysing the network.

The plan will be ready in two weeks, although it will be many months before the network is restored to normal. Railtrack has been given the onerous task of inspecting the poorly maintained rail system, whose deficiencies were exposed by the Hatfield crash.

The announcement came after another derailment, this time at Virginia Water in Surrey, for which Railtrack blamed leaves on the line for having made the train, with 150 to 200 people on board, slide along the line after a trainee driver reported that he had lost control.

Railtrack went on to paint a downbeat picture of the national situation. It warned that the delays could get worse, and estimated that speed restrictions could be imposed on more than 300 sites compared with 206 at present. Managers agreed that the final total could be even higher.

Engineers have found 1,850 cracked rails, a problem which Railtrack has identified only within the past 12 months.

As Railtrack promised to give at least 24 hours' notice of any further line closures, the deputy prime minister said: "The public wants to be satisfied that the rail industry is working together and is doing everything possible to address the safety issues raised by the tragic accident at Hatfield."

Mr Prescott said that the industry had a "robust national track recovery plan" to which Railtrack and the train operators were committed.

It could be used to give passengers the best possible information about future disruption.

He expected that it would take until Wednesday to inspect all the sites where there was known to be "gauge corner cracking" - the cause of the Hatfield crash. There would then be a meeting on Thursday to review progress on the national recovery plan.

Mr Prescott paid tribute to the industry's frontline staff who had worked hard to deal with "horrendous problems" and continued to do so. He agreed that the patience of passengers had been stretched to the limit and would continue to be so.

But the industry had to work together to have a well managed plan for finding faults and repairing them. Advanced notice would minimise disruption and maximise safety.

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, pointed out that the worst case scenario was that 300 sites would have temporary speed restrictions. He said that passengers would continue to face several days of disruption but that the worst should be over by next Wednesday when most inspections will be completed.

Mr Corbett declared: "Our teams on the ground are tired and tempers get frayed, but we have got to bash on and get it sorted. This is the biggest programme of track inspection ever seen."

He said that Clapham junction in south London, one of the busiest places on the network, was earmarked for disruption this weekend as engineers prepared to replace rails.

According to Mr Corbett, the network will be "getting back to stability over the weekend". By Tuesday, Railtrack would know where it was with speed restrictions.

One of the serious passenger problems which the train companies will have to address is refunding passengers for not getting them to their destinations in time. Thousands of people travelling to work have been late, and the shadow strategic rail authority said yesterday that the matter would be dealt with sympathetically.

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow authority, said the emergency summit had agreed on four steps: the identification of problem areas, which should be completed by next week; the development of emergency timetables across the network; the need to return to a normal programme of maintenance; and for the industry to re-examine its structure.

Rail regulator Tom Winsor said he fully backed the steps.

webTitle: Key players in the BSE crisis

fields.headline: Criticised: key players who took leading roles in growing crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText:
Sir Donald Acheson
Chief medical officer 1983-1991
fields.body:
Sir Donald Acheson
Chief medical officer 1983-1991

Told the inquiry that he had never heard of BSE until March 3 1988, 17 months after scientists working for the Ministry of Agriculture first identified the disease. He was worried there might be an unquantifiable risk to human health which prompted his rapid recommendation to set up the Southwood inquiry into the disease.

In 1990, during a TV interview, he said there was "no risk associated with eating British beef". He told the inquiry nearly 10 years later: "The use of such a phrase must have resulted from a slip of the tongue, of which I may well not have been aware at the time." Lord Phillips, in his report, accuses him of giving the public "false reassurance" about the safety of beef.

Sir Kenneth Calman
Chief medical officer, England, 1991-98

He told the inquiry he had given public statements on the safety of beef on the basis that bans on risky offals entering human food and potentially infectious animal feed were effective. That changed in October 1995 when the then chief vet, Keith Meldrum, told him that checks on abattoirs had found spinal cords in some carcasses.

The following month he told Douglas Hogg, minister of agriculture, he could no longer give assurances that banned offals were not entering food. He also revealed that in March 1996, days before the probable link between BSE and the human disease of variant CJD was announced, he had to warn the Ministry of Agriculture not to publish "reassuring messages".

He is criticised in the report for issuing statements in 1993 and 1995 saying that it was safe to eat beef.

Kenneth Clarke
Health secretary 1998-1990

The ebullient minister said he was aware "of territorial rivalry between my medics and Maff", but surprised the committee by suggesting his officials recommended the agriculture ministry should "go it alone" on announcing an offal ban in 1989. The health department was concerned that going beyond scientific advice would upset the "distinguished" Southwood committee.

The report said Mr Clarke should have asked his health officials to consider why, if offal was not safe for babies, it was nevertheless safe for adults. He sometimes appeared frustrated at his treatment at the inquiry, and told the inquiry's counsel, Paul Walker: "I am not convinced you have the faintest understanding of how decision making goes on in government."

John Gummer
Agriculture minister of state 1985-88, minister of agriculture 1989-93

Famously fed his daughter Cordelia a hamburger in May 1990 to demonstrate the safety of beef. Implemented offals ban determined by his predecessor John MacGregor in 1989 but told the inquiry that he understood it was not something that had to be done on human health grounds. He told the inquiry the "almost universal advice" was that the risk to humans was "so remote as for all practical purposes to be ignored".

After taking advice from officials, he decided not to ban mechanically recovered meat used in cheap burgers. It was another five years before it was banned.

The report praised Mr Gummer for introducing more openness into the Ministry of Agriculture, but the publicity stunt was questioned.

Douglas Hogg
Agriculture minister 1995-97

His forlorn appearance topped by distinctive hat provided one of the BSE crisis's most enduring images as the government struggled to contain the damage after admitting a probable link between the cattle epidemic and the emergence of a deadly new human disease.

The report says he did not act quickly enough when confronted with evidence of a link. He is criticised for not involving the Department of Health in discussions about how to deal with the crisis.

In December 1995, he tried to get experts from the government's advisory committee on mad cow disease to back his statements in order to reassure the public about the safety of beef. The report says: "With hindsight, we can see that it was not a desirable exercise."

John MacGregor
Minister of agriculture 1987-89

He learned of the disease from officials in July 1987. He was cautious about a compulsory slaughter and compensation policy on BSE cases because of the cost. Instead he set up an expert working group under Prof Sir Richard Southwood to investigate the outbreak and possible human health risks.

He was responsible in 1989 for the measure that hopefully has saved many human lives - banning high-risk beef offal from human foods. The cabinet had already agreed to ban offals from baby food but Mr MacGregor said he had felt "the only utterly safe thing to do was ban the lot".

Although praised by Lord Phillips for introducing the ban, he is criticised for presenting it in a way that covered up the fact that experts were seriously worried about BSE-infected meat entering the food chain.

Keith Meldrum
Chief vet 1988-1997

The man in charge of animal health for most of the BSE crisis. The report accuses him of not giving proper consideration to the theory that BSE could "jump" species and infect other animals or humans.

He is accused of telling the then agriculture minister, John Gummer, that there was no link between a cat with a BSE-like illness and mad cow disease.

During the inquiry he insisted the Ministry of Agriculture had "attempted as far as we were able to keep the public, scientific community and international authorities informed about all aspects of BSE".

But he said later: "I do not believe it was my responsibility to advise government on the safety of a particular food ... It was not my responsibility to advise the Department of Health on public health issues to do with the safety of a particular product."

Richard Packer
Permanent secretary at the Ministry of Agriculture, 1993-2000

The controversial civil servant is criticised for lack of contingency planning as it became clear BSE probably had spread to humans. The inquiry questioned him at length as to whether his department and the health department should have devoted more time to devising further anti-BSE controls should a link between eating beef and human deaths be established.

He argued that it was difficult to predict dramatic developments and that the Treasury would not have agreed to plans that ran into the billions of pounds the crisis has eventually cost. In addition, such preparation might have been leaked and precipitated "the very event it is designed to set a contingency about".

webTitle: Smacking is not the way to discipline children, says Duke of York

fields.headline: Smacking is not the way to discipline children, says Duke of York
fields.trailText: The Duke of York yesterday said he was beaten once at prep school, and has ruled out smacking his own children.
fields.body:
The Duke of York yesterday said he was beaten once at prep school, and has ruled out smacking his own children.

Prince Andrew said he was disciplined at Heatherdown, near Ascot, Berkshire, but suffered no corporal punishment at Gordonstoun, his senior school near Elgin, nor from the Queen or the Duke of Edinburgh.

The prince, who is championing the Full Stop appeal of the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, replied "Never ever" when asked if his parents had smacked him. "At school I probably got one sanction taken against me, but that was all."

He told GMTV he had not smacked his own children, Princess Beatrice, 12, and Princess Eugenie, 10. "I have a simple philosophy with my children; that is there are a set of boundaries and if they step over those boundaries then you have to find some form of sanction. I'm not entirely certain that smacking is the right one.

"It is not a sanction that I have used on my children, apart from the odd playful 'oi'."

The duke, who is president of the Football Association, has teamed up with soccer stars, including Manchester United's David Beckham and manager Sir Alex Ferguson, and Newcastle United's former England captain Alan Shearer, for a football Full Stop weekend.

webTitle: Judge who scorns prison as easy option

fields.headline: Judge who scorns prison as easy option
fields.standfirst:
Woolf annoyed Tory home secretary

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Woolf annoyed Tory home secretary
fields.body:
Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, speaks from deep knowledge of the penal system when he describes the atmosphere in young offender institutions as "corrosive".

His inquiry into prison riots in 1990 convinced him that former Tory home secretary Michael Howard's dictum that "prison works" was wrong. He often annoyed Mr Howard by criticising his "get tough" penal policy, describing the use of prison as "an easy option which has a miserable record of failure".

In his first major ruling after being appointed master of the rolls in 1996 - he was promoted to lord chief justice this year - he quashed Mr Howard's decision to fix a 15-year tariff for Robert Thompson and Jon Venables.

The home secretary, he declared, had reached his decision to add five years to the 10 recommended by the then lord chief justice, Lord Taylor, in a way that was "perfunctory and falling far below the standards that a court would adopt if contemplating sentencing a child to a period of 15 years detention".

Mr Howard and his colleagues saw Lord Woolf as the worst sort of woolly liberal with dangerous tendencies to appropriate for judges the decision making role that should belong to Parliament. He has described himself as "liberal with a small l", and was one of the first judges to support incorporation of the European convention on human rights into UK law.

He will not be surprised to find opprobrium heaped on him for paving the way for Thompson's and Venables' early release, but will see it as a price worth paying to safeguard their chances of rehabilitation as useful citizens.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Stuart Shields writes: During the Prague Spring of 1968, Eduard Goldstücker (Obituary, October 25) became an MP in the Czech parliament.
fields.body:
Stuart Shields writes: During the Prague Spring of 1968, Eduard Goldstücker (Obituary, October 25) became an MP in the Czech parliament. After the Russians moved in, he took part in a special congress of the Communist party, held secretly in a factory under the noses of the invaders. He was elected to the central committee of what was, in effect, an undercover party.

In later years, he took a somewhat vain pleasure in showing his friends the verbatim transcript of a demand made by the Soviet politburo to Alexander Dubcek and his fellow ministers, who had been taken to Moscow under duress, that he should be removed from any position he held.

After Goldstücker came to England in 1968 - as a refugee for the second time in his life - he would bravely return to Prague for sessions of the parliament, at least until the risk of arrest became too great.

webTitle: New identities will hide old lives

fields.headline: New identities will hide old lives
fields.standfirst:
18-year-olds will be given protection and many years of supervision

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: 18-year-olds will be given protection and many years of supervision
fields.body:
The actual date on which Robert Thompson and Jon Venables will be released is now firmly in the hands of the parole board in the wake of Lord Woolf's controversial ruling.

A special three-person panel, which must include a judge and psychiatrist, will have the difficult task of satisfying themselves that the two 18-year-olds no longer pose a danger to the public and that each has shown appropriate remorse for their killing of James Bulger.

The parole board yesterday began its preparations, including drawing up a dossier on each of the teenagers, for oral hearings to be held in each of the local authority secure units in the north of England where they are being held.

Probation officers will talk to James Bulger's parents and ensure their views are included in each dossier. Each boy will be present at the "informal inquisitorial hearings" which will decide their future.

At the same time, an application will be made by their lawyers next month in the high court before Dame Elizabeth Butler Sloss seeking new injunctions banning the media from disclosing details about them, even though they are now adults.

If Dame Elizabeth decides to grant them this anonymity it will be the first time that child criminals have been given such protection since the case of Mary Bell in 1968.

The right to a private life enshrined in the newly incorporated European convention on human rights is bound to figure strongly in next month's case.

Mary Bell was jailed at the age of 11 for the murder of two young children and served 12 years before her release. She managed to remain out of the public eye until two years ago when a book was published about her life and the Sun newspaper found her. She was subsequently given police protection.

"A key element will be to ensure their safety and protection," said Paul Cavadino of the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders. "Recent experience tells us that if they were to be named and shamed by the media, it would put them, and anyone else who resembles them, at grave risk of vigilante attacks."

As Lord Woolf observed, when he ruled yesterday that their further detention would not serve any constructive purpose, their release will not end their punishment. In fact their release on licence is likely to mean that they will spend years under the supervision of the criminal justice system.

But it will be the question of preserving their anonymity which will prove the most difficult. A new injunction protecting their privacy is likely to mean new names, new birth certificates, new national health service numbers and a new family history which reflects their own lives sufficiently to be convincing. This new identity will apply not only to them but could also apply to members of their immediate family as well.

It is highly unlikely that a positive parole board decision would lead to Thompson and Venables returning to Liverpool. Instead, they will be sent to start new lives in a different part of England.

A unique release and supervision plan will now be prepared to ensure that they can resettle into the outside world. The only people who will know their true identity will be a very tight circle of those directly involved in their continuing therapy and other programmes to ensure they do not offend again.

Those who they go to work with or study with will not know who they are. However, there will be a police surveillance operation for both of them with a panic button in their homes in case a sudden problem arises.

As to their future lives, Thompson is believed to have gained 5 GCSEs and has been studying for A-levels and shown an aptitude for computer studies, art and design, and has considered taking an Open University degree course. Less is known about Venables's educational achievements.

According to Lord Woolf, both have maintained contact with their families, Jon Venables benefiting from the continued interest of his parents and Robert Thompson from the attentions of his mother.

Lord Woolf also pointed out that, apart from their own welfare, there was also a public interest in ensuring that what had been achieved in their upbringing is not wasted.

Society, he said, had invested considerable energy and skilled care in their upbringing. A great deal of money must have been expended upon them. This commitment should be built upon.

But for both of them life outside will mean years of supervision after a very difficult period of reintegration: "It will be like being on a witness protection programme for the rest of their lives," said one criminal justice system source last night.

fields.headline: Mother attacks 'charade'
fields.standfirst:
Murdered boy's father seeks to contest ruling

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Murdered boy's father seeks to contest ruling
fields.body:
The mother of James Bulger said yesterday she felt let down by the legal system after learning of Lord Woolf's decision to allow his killers to be released after almost eight years.

Denise Fergus buried her head in her hands and wept throughout the high court hearing. Afterwards she said she felt disgusted and shocked.

"Thompson and Venables never gave James a chance, but now it is like they are being rewarded for their crime," she said. "So far they have enjoyed an easy life in a children's home. They have got away with murder and the lawyers and judges are bending over backwards to look after their interest. The whole case has turned into a ridiculous legal charade and I am sick of the mess the British legal system has made of it."

James's father, Ralph Bulger, said he was disappointed but not surprised by the ruling. In a statement released through his solicitor, he said he would ask the home secretary, Jack Straw, to set up an appeal process which would allow the decision to be challenged. Mr Bulger's solicitor, Robin Makin, said: "These two boys still haven't apologised to Ralph. If they are truly rehabilitated you would think that would be relatively easy."

Albert Kirby, the senior detective who led the hunt for James Bulger's killers, said he was flabbergasted that Venables and Thompson were being released. "Bearing in mind the premeditation and the severity of what took place, eight years is woefully inadequate," he said. "It is not sending out any sort of lesson to the public that this type of criminal behaviour, irrespective of age, cannot be tolerated."

But John Suffield of Support after Murder and Manslaughter said the killers deserved a second chance because they had grown emotionally. "Anybody who has a child will realise this. They are now men and our criminal justice system has said that these men deserve a second chance.

"I hope they will lead a life which will be of benefit to the community because they have taken so much out of it."

His comments were echoed by Paul Cavadino, director of policy for the National Association for the Care and Rehabilitation of Offenders. "They have served their punishment for a shocking crime and in a civilised society we should be capable of leaving them to build the rest of their lives under careful supervision," he said.

A Home Office statement said the home secretary had continued sympathy for the family of James Bulger.

At the Strand shopping centre in Bootle, where James was abducted by the two boys, shoppers expressed disbelief about the ruling.

Jane Lawrenson said: "They need to be sent to an adult prison for a while to feel what that was like because they will not have experienced much hardship.

"However, I do not believe they should be locked up forever - probably another seven years."

fields.headline: Swindling vicar faces jail again
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: A debt-ridden vicar who served a criminal sentence before being ordained was convicted yesterday of swindling church officials out of thousands of pounds.
fields.body:
A debt-ridden vicar who served a criminal sentence before being ordained was convicted yesterday of swindling church officials out of thousands of pounds.

Trevor Jones, 50, vicar of St Peter and St Mary's church at Stowmarket, Suffolk, had not attempted to hide his past crimes when he applied to become a clergyman, Ipswich crown court was told. Details of Jones's past emerged after he changed his plea three days into his trial and admitted four offences of dishonesty.

The former steeplejack, builder and oil-rig worker wept after being warned by the judge that he could be jailed again when sentenced next month.

Church leaders would not comment when asked to explain why they had allowed Jones, who was ordained eight years ago and had also been a curate in Chelmsford, Essex, to become a vicar.

The Rt Rev Richard Lewis, Bishop of St Edmundsbury and Ipswich, said he was "saddened" and appealed for a "period of reflection".

Jones, a father of three, denied 12 offences when the trial began on Tuesday. Some of the allegations involved deception and theft.

Anthony Bate, prosecuting, told jurors that Jones had persuaded church commissioners to give him three car loans and then spent the money on other things; had stolen more than £1,000 from a church fund for the needy; had forged a solicitor's bill to con the parochial church council treasurer into paying a £1,600 computer rental debt; and had tricked a PCC member into handing over nearly £3,000 to pay off a debt to a building firm.

Mr Bate said Jones's swindling spree had lasted from 1997 to 1999 and involved more than £26,000.

Yesterday, following discussions between lawyers, Jones admitted false accounting and three charges of deception. The sums involved totalled more than £15,000.

Judge John Devaux said Jones had an "extensive criminal record" between 1962 and 1983 and that he had been imprisoned in 1983 for deception.

Ian James, defending, said Jones had never attempted to hide his criminal past and had made a point of it when preaching.

Police sources said later he had been jailed for 18 months in 1983 after being convicted of eight offences of deception and asking for 53 to be taken into consideration.

Jones, who was released on bail, said outside the court: "It is the saddest day of my life." He left to have "a stiff Scotch".

fields.headline: Judge praised for patience
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Profile of Lord Philips, the BSE inquiry's chairman.
fields.body:
Nicholas Phillips has risen rapidly through the ranks of the judiciary since he presided over the Maxwell fraud trial in 1995. He was praised by lawyers in the complex case for his fairness, attention to detail and patience, and was promoted to the court of appeal during the trial.

Those qualities made him an obvious choice in December 1997 to chair what was sure to be a contentious inquiry into the BSE crisis. He was promoted to the House of Lords at the end of 1998.

In the Lords, where he took the title Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers, he was one of seven law lords who ruled by a six-one majority in March last year that the former Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet, could be extradited to face charges of torture in Spain. But most of his time was spent presiding over the BSE inquiry.

Last April he was appointed master of the rolls, the second most senior judge in England and Wales. A caretaker judge took his place until he was free this month to take up the job. He also becomes head of civil justice, taking forward reforms spearheaded by Lord Woolf, now the lord chief justice, to make litigation cheaper, speedier and simpler.

Now 62, he is a moderniser and information technology buff who practised as a shipping lawyer before joining the high court in 1987. Lawyers voted him as among the most popular judges in a survey by Legal Business magazine.

fields.headline: Economy class syndrome denied
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Travellers who spend long hours in the cramped seating conditions of aircraft cabins do not put themselves at increased risk of blood clots in the legs, according to research which claims to have quantified the danger for the first time.
fields.body:
Travellers who spend long hours in the cramped seating conditions of aircraft cabins do not put themselves at increased risk of blood clots in the legs, according to research which claims to have quantified the danger for the first time.

The study in this week's Lancet medical journal appears just days after it was revealed that 28-year-old Emma Christofferson, a sales assistant with Marks & Spencer, collapsed and died from a thrombosis (blood clot) at the end of a 20-hour economy flight home from the Sydney Olympics.

The report was greeted with incredulity by the Aviation Health Institute, an Oxford-based pressure group which has long warned of the dangers of insufficient leg room, particularly on charter flights.

Roderik Kraaijenhagen and colleagues from the University of Amsterdam say their work shows that the risk of what has been called "economy class syndrome" has been poorly quantified and potentially overestimated. Previous studies have been carried out with inappropriate or no controls.

They interviewed 788 patients who consulted doctors. "Our findings suggested that, for all types of transport examined, there was no association between travel and an increased risk of thrombosis," they write.

webTitle: Further blow to the network as leaves derail Surrey train

fields.headline: Further blow to the network as leaves derail Surrey train
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Wet leaves were blamed for a train derailment yesterday which provoked further fears about the safety of the rail network.
fields.body:
Wet leaves were blamed for a train derailment yesterday which provoked further fears about the safety of the rail network.

Four carriages carrying 150 to 200 passengers on the 8.21am South West trains service from Weybridge in Surrey to Staines went through a red light and left the track 100 yards from Virginia Water station, narrowly missing a commuter train travelling to Waterloo from Reading.

The incident occurred on the same stretch of track where a train travelling at 60mph collided last week with a bus stranded on a level crossing at Pooley Green near Egham, Surrey.

The train, which was travelling at 40mph, should have stopped at a red light outside Virginia Water station but overshot to a set of points at a junction which had been set for the train bound for Waterloo.

As the train swerved out of control, signals were changed from green to red to prevent other trains crossing its path.

No one was seriously injured but two passengers were treated for shock in hospital.

Railtrack said last night that early investigations suggest the incident was caused by leaves on the line.

Michael Holden, Railtrack's southern zone director, said that leaves on the track were the equivalent of black ice on the roads.

"The prompt action of the driver and the signalman ensured there was no danger to other trains or passengers," he said.

Passenger Michael Groves, 41, from Weybridge, Surrey, vowed never to use the railways again. "One moment it was like any other morning, the next there was terror. The train buckled and the carriage started to tilt over. People were screaming.

"Some people started to get off but I urged them not to. They could have electrocuted themselves on the rails. Instead we waited for the fire brigade who were very quick and helped us off.

"Everyone was in shock. This was the most terrifying experience of my life. As soon as the paramedics arrived I burst into tears."

Six ambulances were sent to the scene and British transport police and Surrey police launched an incident plan. St Peter's hospital in Chertsey, Surrey, was put on full standby.

fields.headline: Judge ends Bulger killers 'tariff'
fields.standfirst:
Parents angry as ruling paves way for boys' early release

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Parents angry as ruling paves way for boys' early release
fields.body:
The teenagers who killed two-year-old James Bulger when they were boys of 10 are almost certain to go free next year after a decision by Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, that their "tariff" - minimum term - expired yesterday.

Lord Woolf said the atmosphere in young offender institutions, where Robert Thompson and Jon Venables would be expected to go now they have reached 18, was so "corrosive" that to send them there risked undoing successful efforts to rehabilitate them.

The murdered boy's mother, Denise Fergus, was in court at the royal courts of justice in central London to hear Lord Woolf deliver his decision. She sank her head and sobbed.

The ruling paves the way for an application to the parole board, which will take the final decision on when the pair should be released. They are expected to emerge from the separate local authority secure units where they are being held in the north of England to new identities in a new part of the country.

In a high court hearing next month, their lawyers will apply for a permanent injunction banning the media from disclosing information about them. A temporary injunction already in force could be extended under the right to privacy in the European convention on human rights, which became part of English law this month.

The pair abducted the two-year-old from a Merseyside shopping centre in 1993. They battered him to death and left his body on a railway track to make it appear he had been run over by a train.

Lord Woolf said the facts of the murder were "exceptionally horrific". The trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, had described it as "an act of unparalled evil and barbarity".

But "the one overriding mitigating factor" was the boys' age at the time, said Lord Woolf. Had they committed the crime only a few months earlier they would have been below the age of criminal responsibility and could not have been tried and punished by the courts. Reports from psychiatrists and staff at the secure units showed they were both "genuinely extremely remorseful" about their crime and the effect on James Bulger's family.

They had worked hard in pursuing their education, and had considerable achievements to their credit. Neither had shown any propensity to violence during detention, and all who reported on them regarded the risk of reoffending as low.

The trial judge had recommended a tariff of eight years, and the then lord chief justice, Lord Taylor, 10 years. The then home secretary, Michael Howard, fixed the tariff at 15 years, but this was quashed by the House of Lords. Lord Woolf was handed the task of recommending a new tariff after the European court of human rights held that judges, not politicians, should take what was in effect a sentencing decision.

Lord Woolf said: "Because of their behaviour they are entitled to a reduction in the tariff to eight years, which happens to be the figure determined by the trial judge.

"An eight-year tariff would expire on February 21 2001. I have already pointed out that it would not be in their or the public's interest for these two young men to be transferred to a young offender institution.

"In all probability, if the tariff period expired today it is likely that it would be after February 2001 before the parole board could decide whether they should be released and, if so, for the necessary arrangements to be made to enable this to happen."

In a high court hearing next month, their lawyers will apply for a permanent injunction banning the media from disclosing information about them. fields.headline: MI5 report 'mislaid' at Palestinians' trial
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Months before the bombing of the Israeli embassy in London in 1994 MI5 received intelligence of a terrorist organisation asking about the building's "location and defences", it was revealed in the appeal court yesterday.
fields.body:
Months before the bombing of the Israeli embassy in London in 1994 MI5 received intelligence of a terrorist organisation asking about the building's "location and defences", it was revealed in the appeal court yesterday.

According to a hitherto undisclosed MI5 report, the organisation was not connected to Jawad Botmeh and Samar Alami, two Palestinian students convicted for conspiracy to cause explosions in 1996 and jailed for 20 years.

The report, described by Michael Mansfield QC, for the pair, as centrally relevant to the case, was passed to MI6 and to the Metropolitan police special branch but was not disclosed to the trial judge. A summary was disclosed to Mr Mansfield after he challenged attempts by the security and intelligence agencies to keep it secret; the full report is covered by a public interest immunity certificate demanded by the agencies and upheld by the appeal judges.

The summary states: "Some months prior to the bombing of the Israeli embassy on July 26 1994 the security service and the special branch received information from an agent source that a terrorist organisation unconnected to the two appellants was seeking information about the location and defences of the embassy for a possible bombing attack."

The first indication that MI5 had been warned was revealed by the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, charged under the Official Secrets Act in connection with unrelated disclosures. "If it wasn't for Shayler, nothing would have been revealed," said Mr Mansfield.

The summary concluded that "related intelligence received after the bomb attack indicated that the terrorist organisation had not in fact carried out the bombing". This was seized on by Julian Bevan QC, counsel for the crown prosecution service, who described it as a "vital sentence".

However, Mr Mansfield insisted the report would have been crucial to the trial defence since it raised questions that could have been put to MI5 and police witnesses as well as the jury. MI5 told the jury there was an "intelligence vacuum" surrounding the bombing.

The report had not been handed to the trial judge as a result of "human error", the court heard. A reference to the report in a separate MI6 file also was not handed the judge because of "human error". A cross reference to the report in another file was not disclosed because of its "unusual physical position".

Mr Mansfield suggested to Lord Justice Rose, Mr Justice Hooper and Mr Justice Goldring that the files had been hidden deliberately - an "astonishing and incredible failure of the duty of disclosure by those responsible".

Questions remained on Rida Mughrabi, alleged to be the third party behind the bombing, who disappeared, said Mr Mansfield; he referred to claims that the ambassador had spoken of warnings of terrorist threats to Israeli or Jewish property, and said Mossad, the Israeli secret service, could have been agents provocateurs.

Lord Justice Rose said he would not order the disclosure of any more MI5 files. The appeal continues.

fields.headline: 'Corrosive' juvenile centres under threat
fields.standfirst:
Damning indictment of institutions echoes chief inspector's view

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Damning indictment of institutions echoes chief inspector's view
fields.body:
The lord chief justice's devastating comment that the atmosphere inside Britain's young offenders institutions was so corrosive that the two killers of James Bulger would be unable to cope cast a shadow over the future of juvenile prisons last night.

Lord Woolf said he had clear evidence from adolescent forensic psychiatrists that if they were transferred to a young offenders institution now they were 18, it would "be likely to undo much of the striking progress" they have made while held in local authority secure units.

"Having been living in an unnaturally protected environment, they are unprepared to move to a young offenders' institution. They are unlikely to be able to cope, at least at first, with the corrosive atmosphere with which they could be faced if transferred.

"There is also the danger of their being exposed to drugs, of which they are at present free," said Lord Woolf, adding that the welfare of the two boys was one of the factors, albeit not the paramount one, in deciding if they should be released.

Lord Woolf's complaint about juvenile jails echoed the protest made a year ago by the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, when he sparked a public storm by suggesting the two teenagers should be released rather than sent to a young offenders institution. The chief inspector said he would not wish them to go to some of the institutions he had seen.

Now the two teenagers are 18 they would be moving into a young offenders institution under the care of the prison service unless the home secretary took a decision that they should remain in social services care. They would have stayed in the juvenile estate until they were 21, when they would have been moved to an adult prison.

But the lord chief justice's remarks that these institutions would do more harm than good underlines recent judgments of the chief inspector. Last year Sir David described Feltham young offenders institution in west London, the largest in Britain with 745 inmates, as "rotten to the core", with conditions that were so appalling they were unacceptable in a civilised society.

In August, after a deputy governor at Feltham resigned in protest at the Dickensian conditions, the prison service promised to take steps to relieve the overcrowding.

Since April, the national youth justice board has taken ultimate responsibility for those parts of the juvenile jails which hold teenagers aged 15 to 17, although they are still run by the prison service. This has started to drive up standards in some institutions but the prison service remains responsible for the majority of inmates aged 18 to 21.

Lord Woolf and Sir David made much of the progress the two boys have made during their time in separate secure units while in local authority social service care.

"The reports show that the two boys have made striking progress in the secure units where they have been detained. The extent of this progress reflects very great credit on all those who have been responsible for their care. The reports draw a vivid picture of two boys who have significantly improved over the years."

This testimony is in sharp contrast to the record of the young offenders institutions whose long-term future must now be in some doubt. The ruling is likely to bring even greater urgency to government plans to expand the number of much smaller local authority secure units.
