webTitle: 'Culture of secrecy' misled the public about risk of eating beef

fields.headline: 'Culture of secrecy' misled the public about risk of eating beef
fields.standfirst:
Ministers 'did not lie', but embarked on mistaken campaign of reassurance

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Ministers 'did not lie', but embarked on mistaken campaign of reassurance.
fields.body:
The tragic scale of the BSE crisis - "a peculiarly British disaster" - was inevitable whatever action the government took, the Phillips report concludes. It says that it is still not possible to reach a firm estimate about how many people in the future might contract and die from variant CJD. Projections range from small numbers to many millions.

"The full extent and effects of the human disease will not be discernible for many years to come," the report says. Baffling and still unresolved scientific questions have "hampered and bedevilled the whole course of events".

Secrecy

Despite strong criticisms of ministers and civil servants for failing to keep the public fully informed as to possible risks, the report commends the government for taking significant measures to protect human health when the likelihood of transmission to humans was considered remote. Allegations of a cover up cannot be substantiated, but the report says it was not surprising that the public felt it had been deceived. A "culture of secrecy" was identified in the Ministry of Agriculture and there was a "team failure" among officials, who were concerned about the beef export trade, to evaluate food risks. But the report concludes that there is no foundation in the allegation that the ministry put the interests of farmers before consumers.

Scientists generally come out of the report well. They are commended for the quick identification of BSE in 1986 and the "prompt detection" of the variant CJD in humans in 1996. Anyone hoping to find "villains or scapegoats should go away disappointed", Lord Phillips says and adds: "Most of those responsible for responding to the challenge posed by BSE emerge with credit."

The report finds that the BSE epidemic was "a consequence of an intensive farming practice - the recycling of animal protein in ruminant feed. This practice, unchallenged over decades, proved a recipe for disaster".

The inevitability of the disaster was caused by a number of factors: BSE had an incubation period of five years; it tended to strike a single cow in a herd; it had clinical signs similar to those of a number of other diseases; it was impossible to diagnose before clinical signs appeared; and it was transmissible to humans with a much longer incubation period. By the time BSE was identified in 1986, as many as 50,000 cattle were likely to have been infected.

"At the heart of the BSE story lie questions of how to handle hazard - a known hazard to cattle and an unknown hazard to humans. The government took measures to address both hazards. They were sensible measures, but they were not always timely nor adequately implemented and enforced."

The lack of rigour by officials in implementing policy decisions was partly because of the belief of many before 1996 that BSE was not a potential threat to human life. "The possibility of a risk to humans was not communicated to the public or to those whose job it was to implement and enforce the precautionary measures." But the report says: "The government did not lie to the public about BSE. It believed that the risks posed by BSE to humans were remote. The government was preoccupied with preventing an alarmist over-reaction to BSE because they believed that the risk was remote. It is now clear that this campaign of reassurance was a mistake.

"A recurring theme in the BSE story," Lord Phillips says, "has been growing public suspicion and dissatisfaction that important information was not being shared and discussed openly so that people were denied proper choices in matters that deeply affected them and their families." Victims and the families have special needs which should be addressed. "The unusual problems of the diagnosis, treatment and care of the early cases of vCJD meant that for some of the victims and their families the tragic horror of the disease was made the more difficult to bear by lack of appropriate treatment, assistance and support."

The report says individual cattle were probably first infected by BSE in the 1970s. When the first cow death was investigated by the central veterinary laboratory (CVL) in 1985 the disease was not recognised because it was masked by other factors. After BSE was identified in November 1986, gathering of data in the following months was impeded by an embargo in the state veterinary service about making the disease public.

By the end of 1987 the laboratory had concluded that the cause of BSE was the consumption of meat and bone meal made from animal carcases and incorporated in cattle feed. This right conclusion was reached "with commendable speed". But other provisional conclusions by John Wilesmith, head of the CVL epidemiology department, were wrong.

The cause of the disease was not derived from sheep infected with conventional scrapie, the report says for the first time, but by the recycling in cattle feed of cattle remains infected with BSE itself. It possibly originated in a cow or other animal that developed the disease as a consequence of a gene mutation. But the report says that the true origin "will probably never be known with certainty".

The assumption that looser regulation in the rendering process had caused the feed to become infectious - a view held to this day - was also invalid. "Rendering methods have never been capable of completely inactivating" the disease.

Assessing the danger to people was made difficult because of the long incubation period. "Maff officials appreciated from the outset the possibility that BSE might have implications for human health." But they failed to consult with the department of health, and the chief medical officer, Sir Donald Acheson, was only informed in March 1988 after the ministry of agriculture had advised ministers that infected animals should be destroyed.

Sir Donald's advice to set up an expert working party under Sir Richard Southwood, professor of zoology at Oxford University, was of "crucial importance in safeguarding human health". The Southwood report concluded that "it was most unlikely that BSE would have any implications for human health". But Lord Phillips says that it did not, as it should have done, make clear the basis for its assessment of risk. "It did comment that if the assessment was incorrect the implications would be extremely serious. This warning was lost from sight."

Scientists' views began to change slightly in 1990 when it was revealed that a cat had been diagnosed with a "scrapie-like" spongiform encephalopathy, yet their concerns were not made public. Instead the messages given to the public, by officials and ministers, was that beef was safe and that BSE was not transmissible. This impression led to a feeling of betrayal when it was announced in March 1996 that people could catch the disease.

Infection

The first measure to prevent further infection - the banning of cattle remains in cattle feed in July 1988 - had a dramatic effect in reducing to a fraction the escalating rate of infection. But ignorance about the scale of infection and the amount of material needed to transmit the disease led to thousands of animals being infected after the ban. The feed trade was given a period of grace of five weeks to clear their stocks. "Some members of the feed trade, being given an inch, felt free to take a yard and continued to clear stocks after the ban came into force."

More serious was the failure to appreciate that tissue the size of a peppercorn could transmit the disease. Cross-contamination in feedmills led to thousands more cattle being infected. The situation was made worse in 1990 by a ban on certain bovine offal for feed given to pigs and poultry, which was "unenforceable and widely disregarded". The dangers of cross-contamination were not realised until 1994.

The decision to protect humans by the compulsory slaughter and destruction of animals with BSE was based on "commendable advice" from the Southwood working party but the report says it should have been introduced months earlier than August 1988.

However, Southwood is criticised for failing to make plain that there was a risk of transmission in eating animals incubating the disease but not showing signs. It only warned about including ruminant offal and thymus in baby food. Both Maff and the health department missed this shortcoming. It was not until June 1989 that offal was banned in all human food.

Maff officials also failed to give weight to concerns about the mechanical recovery of scraps left attached to the vertebral column for use in human food. Because of a breakdown in communications officials believed that the experts on the new spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee (SEAC) were not concerned about the odd scrap getting through the system and some members on SEAC falsely believed that the spinal cord could be removed in its entirety. This was not remedied until 1995 when the meat hygene service took over enforcement of the regulations.

Another failure was the lack of liaison between the ministry of agriculture and health officials about the dangers of the disease being carried in human medicines. A small number of vaccines were eventually phased out after consideration by the medicines control agency and the veterinary medicines directorate but these organisations "do not appear to have been systematically accountable to anyone". Some human vaccine stocks with bovine content were used until 1992. The report says that no comprehensive consideration was given to other pathways for infection until March 1996.

Lord Phillips praises the prompt detection of vCJD by the CJD surveillance unit in that month. On March 16 SEAC concluded that the likely cause was BSE. However, he says that that conclusion should have become apparent to officials by early February. "There was no interdepartmental discussion or consideration of policy option within either department until the middle of March 1996. This was an inadequate response."

On the lessons to be learned Lord Phillips says the effective control of animal diseases needs a proper surveillance regime and incentives for farmers to report instances to the state veterinary service. Consideration should be given to creating a formal structure within government, embracing both animal and human health officials, to respond to future threats.

Veterinarians should be trained in epidemiology: Mr Wilesmith of the CVL was the only member of staff with a postgraduate degree in the subject.

Alarm

Advisory committees like the Southwood committee "should not water down its assessment of risk out of anxiety not to cause public alarm". Government departments should retain in-house scientific expertise to review their advice.

Rigorous thought must be given to the introduction of precautionary measures and make sure they are enforceable and watertight. This did not happen with the ban on bovine offal, meat and bone meal and mechanically recovered meat.

Officials should draw up contingency plans and not just rely on advice from advisory committees. Those civil servants who attended two meetings of the SEAC in January and February 1996, when it became clear that vCJD would probably be linked to BSE, failed to put senior colleagues on alert.

The lesson from the emergence of vCJD is that precautionary measures should be strictly enforced even if the risk is considered remote. All pathways by which vCJD may be transmitted between humans must be identified. Because bovine material is used in a range of food and non-food purposes, including cosmetics and medicines, a comprehensive review of infection should be undertaken.

The report says no one has demonstrated a link between working on a farm and vCJD. The four farmers with BSE herds who did contract CJD were aged between 54 and 64 and their disease did not have the signs of the new variant.

Lord Phillips makes much of the need for transparency from government. "Our experience has led us to the firm conclusion that a policy of openness is the correct approach. When responding to public or media demand for advice, the government must resist the temptation of attempting to appear to have all the answers in a situation of uncertainty.

"We believe that food scares and vaccine scares thrive on a belief that the government is withholding information. If doubts are openly expressed and publicly explored, the public are capable of responding rationally and are more likely to accept reassurance and advice if and when it comes."

At the end of volume 1 of the 16 volume report Lord Phillips names those people who face criticism.

But he says: "We draw attention to the fact that the areas where we have criticised individuals are relatively few. If those criticised were misguided, they were nonetheless acting in accordance with what they conceived to be the proper performance of their duties".

"Some members of the feed trade, being given an inch, felt free to take a yard and continued to clear stocks after the ban came into force." More serious was the failure to appreciate that tissue the size of a peppercorn could transmit the disease. Cross-contamination in feedmills led to thousands more cattle being infected. The situation was made worse in 1990 by a ban on certain bovine offal for feed given to pigs and poultry, which was "unenforceable and widely disregarded". The dangers of cross-contamination were not realised until 1994. The decision to protect humans by the compulsory slaughter and destruction of animals with BSE was based on "commendable advice" from the Southwood working party but the report says it should have been introduced months earlier than August 1988. However, Southwood is criticised for failing to make plain that there was a risk of transmission in eating animals incubating the disease but not showing signs. It only warned about including ruminant offal and thymus in baby food. Both Maff and the health department missed this shortcoming. It was not until June 1989 that offal was banned in all human food. Maff officials also failed to give weight to concerns about the mechanical recovery of scraps left attached to the vertebral column for use in human food. Because of a breakdown in communications officials believed that the experts on the new spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee (SEAC) were not concerned about the odd scrap getting through the system and some members on SEAC falsely believed that the spinal cord could be removed in its entirety. This was not remedied until 1995 when the meat hygene service took over enforcement of the regulations. Another failure was the lack of liaison between the ministry of agriculture and health officials about the dangers of the disease being carried in human medicines. A small number of vaccines were eventually phased out after consideration by the medicines control agency and the veterinary medicines directorate but these organisations "do not appear to have been systematically accountable to anyone". Some human vaccine stocks with bovine content were used until 1992. The report says that no comprehensive consideration was given to other pathways for infection until March 1996. Lord Phillips praises the prompt detection of vCJD by the CJD surveillance unit in that month. On March 16 SEAC concluded that the likely cause was BSE. However, he says that that conclusion should have become apparent to officials by early February. "There was no interdepartmental discussion or consideration of policy option within either department until the middle of March 1996. This was an inadequate response." On the lessons to be learned Lord Phillips says the effective control of animal diseases needs a proper surveillance regime and incentives for farmers to report instances to the state veterinary service. Consideration should be given to creating a formal structure within government, embracing both animal and human health officials, to respond to future threats. Veterinarians should be trained in epidemiology: Mr Wilesmith of the CVL was the only member of staff with a postgraduate degree in the subject. Alarm Advisory committees like the Southwood committee "should not water down its assessment of risk out of anxiety not to cause public alarm". Government departments should retain in-house scientific expertise to review their advice. Rigorous thought must be given to the introduction of precautionary measures and make sure they are enforceable and watertight. This did not happen with the ban on bovine offal, meat and bone meal and mechanically recovered meat. Officials should draw up contingency plans and not just rely on advice from advisory committees. Those civil servants who attended two meetings of the SEAC in January and February 1996, when it became clear that vCJD would probably be linked to BSE, failed to put senior colleagues on alert. The lesson from the emergence of vCJD is that precautionary measures should be strictly enforced even if the risk is considered remote. All pathways by which vCJD may be transmitted between humans must be identified. Because bovine material is used in a range of food and non-food purposes, including cosmetics and medicines, a comprehensive review of infection should be undertaken. The report says no one has demonstrated a link between working on a farm and vCJD. The four farmers with BSE herds who did contract CJD were aged between 54 and 64 and their disease did not have the signs of the new variant. Lord Phillips makes much of the need for transparency from government. "Our experience has led us to the firm conclusion that a policy of openness is the correct approach. When responding to public or media demand for advice, the government must resist the temptation of attempting to appear to have all the answers in a situation of uncertainty. "We believe that food scares and vaccine scares thrive on a belief that the government is withholding information. If doubts are openly expressed and publicly explored, the public are capable of responding rationally and are more likely to accept reassurance and advice if and when it comes." At the end of volume 1 of the 16 volume report Lord Phillips names those people who face criticism. But he says: "We draw attention to the fact that the areas where we have criticised individuals are relatively few. If those criticised were misguided, they were nonetheless acting in accordance with what they conceived to be the proper performance of their duties".

webTitle: Police in wrangle on DNA samples

fields.headline: Police in wrangle on DNA samples
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Three detective sergeants who refused to give voluntary DNA samples for a national database have been forced to take desk jobs with Gloucestershire police force.
fields.body:
Three detective sergeants who refused to give voluntary DNA samples for a national database have been forced to take desk jobs with Gloucestershire police force.

The officers refused to take the tests for personal reasons, it emerged yesterday. They claim the decision to move them to desk jobs was a breach of their human rights.

Voluntary DNA testing, costing £3m, was introduced in February across every police force to combat complications from contamination of crime scenes by officers' clothing, skin particles and hair.

Gloucestershire police said that 700 officers had taken the mouth swab tests and 30 had refused. Of those, three were moved out of front line duties because they could contaminate crime scenes.

Detective sergeant Rod Dally, chairman of Gloucestershire Police Federation, which is supporting the officers' stance, said the force's decision may be illegal. "The Gloucestershire force has one of the highest figures for obtaining samples from officers - but this is supposed to be totally voluntary," he said.

"Sanctions have been taken against these officers. We have sought legal advice to see if the force's action is legal."

Peter Todd, the assistant chief constable, said: "I have to make sure I protect the force and protect the public against identified risks and this is unfortunately an identified risk which I must protect investigations against."

The Association of Chief Police Officers said the fear of some officers that their DNA profiles would be used for some purpose other than an elimination database was wholly unfounded.

A Home Office spokesman said that after a slow start this year 40,000 officers had provided samples.

The Home Office is confident the 75,000 target will be reached by April.

fields.headline: Good day bad day
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

For the government insider who left their electronic personal organiser crammed with private numbers for Tony Blair and his aides in the back of a London cab. Instead of falling into enemy hands it was recovered safe and sound by a PR executive who twigged the significance of A.Blair, Downing St.

Bad day

Poor old former prime minister John Major whose application to join the MCC committee at Lord's is suffering a stormy ride. Apparently because of his membership of Surrey CC rather than his stewardship of the country.

Film of the day

Well, almost. Annie's Bar alive with rumours that a film producer is trying to secure a rights deal to film the late Alan Clark's diaries. The censor trembles in anticipation.

Today

Commons: Not sitting

Lords: Debate on e-commerce in the EU, opened by Lord Brooke of Alverthorpe (Lab).

Warm homes and energy conservation bill, committee.

Debate on Greater London authority (protected information) order 2000, opened by Baroness Hamwee (Lib Dem).

fields.headline: Shipbuilders rescued
fields.standfirst:
Critics claim £1.25bn order to build 10 military vessels rewards failure

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Critics claim £1.25bn order to build 10 military vessels rewards failure
fields.byline: David Gow, Richard Norton-Taylor  and  Michael White
fields.body:
The government yesterday gave a pre-election boost to stricken British shipbuilding by awarding the bulk of contracts worth £1.25bn for 10 new ships for the armed forces to yards in Belfast, Glasgow and on the Tyne.

The orders will create up to 1,200 jobs and safeguard up to 1,600 more.

After one of the most ferocious lobbying campaigns in years, Geoff Hoon, defence secretary, said Belfast's Harland & Wolff would build two of six roll-on roll-off ferries for the rapid deployment of troops to crisis regions, saving the yard from closure.

Swan Hunter, the Wallsend yard that went into receivership in 1993 and was rescued two years later, is to build its first ships for six years - two amphibious landing vessels - in a £150m contract that should see it take on up to 1,200 staff, many of them former shipbuilders working abroad.

The Govan yard on Clydeside, owned by BAE Systems Marine and facing closure, will build the other two landing ships in a £150m contract which, Mr Hoon said, would secure 1,000 jobs.

Industry and union leaders welcomed the government's decision. But there was bitterness that four of the ro-ro ferries would be built at the Flensburg yard in northern Germany.

"It's unthinkable for the Germans to have their naval ships built in the UK and can you imagine the French, Italians or Spanish doing it?" one senior industry source said. But Mr Hoon said 85% of the £950m ferries contract being awarded under the private finance initiative would go to the UK.

The contract had to be subject to open European tender because of EU regulations, he said, but this brought howls of protest at unfair subsidies for German yards.

Under the PFI system, Glasgow-based Andrew Weir Shipping is to maintain and manage the six ferries for the next 20 years, during which they will be available for commercial work when not in military use. Maersk, the Danish line, had hoped to secure this contract, worth 75% of the total.

The outcome came as a severe disappointment to Maersk and its British partner, Cammell Laird, which until the last minute were front-runners to secure the ferries work .They lost out to the sustained political campaign waged by Northern Ireland politicians, Scottish cabinet ministers including the chancellor and their colleagues in the north-east of England, including Tony Blair, Stephen Byers, Peter Mandelson and Alan Milburn.

Cammell, which employs 1,000 people in Birkenhead and 700 on Tyneside, claimed it had lost because it had an almost full order book for its ship repair business, while failing yards had been rewarded.

But Norman Brownell, commercial director at Swan Hunter, said the once-derelict yards had been transformed since the then THS Fabricators took it over in 1995. "This is only the beginning, a platform for our plans which include securing one of the navy's two new aircraft carriers. Our ambition is to become a world-class shipbuilder again and to show there's still a place for British shipbuilding."

webTitle: 16 days of courtroom drama and 5 hours of deliberation that delivered guilty verdict

fields.headline: 16 days of courtroom drama and 5 hours of deliberation that delivered guilty verdict
fields.standfirst:
Disgust at 'barbarity' of James's killers

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Disgust at 'barbarity' of James's killers
fields.body:
Preston crown court was built to reflect the majesty of the English legal system: its court number one is lofty and square, lit by a skylight decorated with crests of Lancashire boroughs.

Here Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, both aged 11, were tried on November 1 1993 for the murder of James Bulger. During the 16-day trial they were to be known only as Boy A and Boy B.

The packed public gallery fell silent on the first day as the two boys, scrubbed and cleanly dressed, were led to their seats in the brass-railed dock.

Thompson appeared calm and fiddled with buttons on his blazer. Venables seemed more agitated, nervously tearing a paper tissue and whispering to the social worker seated beside him.

As the trial took its course and the jury heard of the horrific battering James received after he was abducted from the Strand shopping centre in Bootle, the boys adjusted to the daily routine. Sometimes they were bored, at other times they wriggled in their seats, gazed around, looked at their shoes, cried.

No one who was there will forget hearing the tapes of the boys' interviews with police. For many, details of James's abduction - his two-mile walk from Bootle to the railway line at Walton where his body was found, his injuries caused by bricks and an iron bar - were too painful to bear.

The jury took five and a half hours to decide the two boys were guilty. Denise Bulger (now Fergus) was kissed by Det Supt Albert Kirby, who had led the investigation.

Jon's mother, Susan, cried and his father, Neil, buried his head in his hands.

Mr Justice Morland described the boys' crime as a cunning and wicked act of "unparalleled barbarity". As they were led from the dock, a member of the Bulger family shouted: "How do you feel now, you little bastards?"

On Radio 4's Thought for the Day, the city's Anglican bishop, David Sheppard, referred to the Christian doctrine of forgiveness: "People confuse forgiveness with condoning. There is no condoning the sheer evil of what [the two convicted boys] have done. But they can be redeemed. We are not consigning them to the dustbin."

webTitle: Farmer's account of the BSE crisis

fields.headline: Day that started downward spiral
fields.standfirst:
Retirement offers no respite for struggling tenants

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Retirement offers no respite for struggling tenants, reports Geoffrey Gibbs.
fields.body:
The day the BSE crisis broke is deeply ingrained in Mike Palmer's memory. As Stephen Dorrell rose in the Commons to deliver his bombshell announcement, 12 bullocks from the family's south Devon farm were on their way to be slaughtered.

The Commons statement had hardly sunk in when the abattoir they were destined for had contacted the lorry driver by mobile phone to tell him not to bother completing the journey. The bullocks were returned live to the farm gate.

Sitting in the kitchen of their rented home at Frogwell farm, Mr Palmer, 60, and his wife, Jeanette, wince as they recall the events of March 1996 and contemplate the slump in fortunes that has left them facing the prospect of having to work on well beyond retirement age for little or no reward.

The Dorrell statement was devastating financially and emotionally. The Palmers had seen the ravages of BSE in cattle at first hand - 14 cases among their dairy herd dating back to 1988 - but they were "absolutely horrified" to hear of the possible effects on human health.

In business terms, says Mr Palmer, pointing to figures from the most recent farm accounts, what Dorrell said caused chaos. "In the ensuing weeks we couldn't sell anything and things have not been the same since. Prices have plummeted and they have stayed down."

The Palmers are tenant dairy farmers, running an 80 strong herd of Friesians on 87 acres of farmland owned by Devon county council at Diptford, near Totnes.

In partnership with their 32 year old son, David, they farm a further 160 acres at Halwell, three miles away, where they keep a herd of 220 beef cattle. Boreston farm, acquired 10 years ago when conditions in the industry were healthier, is, they say grimly, owned by the family and by Barclays bank.

In the year to March 1996 - before the industry was plunged into BSE induced depression - the two farms made a combined profit of almost £20,000. Three years later that had sunk to just £7,666.

With bank charges rising, and beef and milk prices remaining well below 1996 levels, accounts for the year to the end of March 2000 will show a further decline.

The financial slump has forced the Palmers to cut back on outside labour and put investment in machinery on hold as they struggle to meet mortgage payments on the farm at Halwell and pay day to day bills.

On a personal level it has meant they have been unable to take a proper holiday. More worryingly it means they will almost certainly be unable to retire when Mr Palmer turns 65 as they had planned.

Like other tenant farmers their capital is largely tied up in the value of their herd. While house prices have been rising the value of the Palmers' dairy cattle has crashed from around £64,000 in 1996 to around £32,000 today. Leaving Frogwell farm in such circumstances is not an option.

"Normally farmers in our position would be able to raise enough money to buy a house on their retirement by selling off their livestock and their farm machinery. But since BSE I very much doubt that is going to be possible," says Mr Palmer, who is also chairman of the Devon NFU tenant farmers committee.

He is, he is quick to point out, not alone in his predicament. "Many tenant farmers have used their capital to survive and have had to increase their bank overdrafts.

"I know many people who are really worried about the future, some of them farmers who should be retiring this year.

"Some of the younger farmers have been getting out because it is easier for them to find a job elsewhere and I know many tenants who milk morning and evening and do an outside job in between just to survive.

"One just lives in hope that things will turn around. It is all we can do. I've got a pension plan, but we are going to really struggle to retire at 65 now.

"Physically I can't do what I used to do. I would like to take things a little easier and not work such long hours, but that is not an option in the present climate."

Worry is etched on his wife's face as she talks of the struggle to keep their heads above water.

Going through the books and working out whether there is enough to pay the next bill is, she says, deeply depressing.

"It is constantly on your mind that you are working for almost nothing.

"We don't mind hard work, but we are not seeing anything for it. I feel that we have got nothing tangible to look forward to.

"Everything seems up in the air and you can't plan what you would like to do in your retirement. It is as if we are living in limbo because we have no way of knowing what is going to happen ahead."

BSE facts

Confirmed cases 177,314 on 35,098 farms.

Peak year of epidemic 1992, 36,680 cases.

This year 962 cases.

Youngest case In 1992, 20 months.

Oldest case In 1991, 17 years five months.

Number of farms with dairy cows 1980, 63,000; now, 33,400.

Number of farms with beef cows 1980, 81,600; now, 70,000.

Average annual net income from farming in 1999 Dairy farms, £8,000; hill cattle and sheep, £2,500; lowland cattle and sheep, £1,500.

Counting the cost of crisis

£3.4bn
Anti-BSE measures, including ban on use of cattle over 30 months.

£2bn
Lost exports.

£140m
Compensation to farmers for slaugher of BSE-infected cattle, and cattle suspected to be infected.

£90m
Research into BSE and similar animal diseases.

£83m
Blood donation controls.

£30m
Research into vCJD and similar diseases.

£6,000 to £60,000 per victim
Estimated cost of care for vCJD victims.

£27m
Cost of inquiry and legal support for witnesses.

Total: Nearly £6bn

fields.headline: Nortel tremours hit hi-tech indices
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Hi-tech shares in the US took another nosedive yesterday as investors feared further earnings disappointments.
fields.body:
Hi-tech shares in the US took another nosedive yesterday as investors feared further earnings disappointments.

The technology driven Nasdaq composite index fell almost 3%, or 95 points, to 3,133 at one stage yesterday, touching the year low reached only last week. The Dow Jones industrial average remained steady as investors sought the stability of blue chip shares.

Nasdaq's fall knocked European hi-tech shares - on the Paris bourse, Alcatel closed down €3.90 or 5.24% at €70.50; meanwhile in London Bookham Technology ended as the biggest FTSE 100 loser, down 274p to £21.50. The Techmark, the City's index of technology stocks, fell nearly 3% to close 3355.78.

Yesterday's Nasdaq decline follows a fall of almost 6% on Wednesday. The index is down more than 30 % since reaching 5,132 in March, before investors lost faith in almost all internet-related companies.

Larry Wachtel, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said that few hi-tech shares remained unaffected by the crisis in confidence. "You have destroyed all the sacred cows. fields.headline: Sad and painful decline of a daughter
fields.standfirst:
Couple forced to watch helplessly as bright young woman became moody and afraid

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Couple forced to watch helplessly as bright young woman became moody and afraid, reports James Meikle.
fields.body:
Peter and Susan Hodge began to fear the worst as they watched their daughter Alison suffer increasing problems walking, her leg shaking, her balance faltering.

They had seen the television pictures of cows staggering from BSE. "I think I had realised what it was before she even went into hospital. I was not surprised when the doctor told us," says Susan.

In their neat semi in Macclesfield, Cheshire, the Hodges chronicle how Alison displayed other classic symptoms of the human disease linked to eating infected beef - mood swings, aggression, slurred speech, hallucinations, problems swallowing and a gradual inexorable loss of bodily control.

She died in August 1998 at the age of 25, in the bedroom where she had spent much of her youth, the 28th fatality in Britain from variant CJD.

Alison had come home after a short stay in hospital. Her parents, her husband Richard Thorpe, his mother and his aunt watched her desperately cling on to life as they devised a rota to care for her. Peter talks movingly of having to help his adult daughter to the lavatory, clean her or wash her hair and somehow cope with the horrifying aversion to water, an element she had once adored, swimming whenever possible.

"She would just fight us. We woke up in the middle of the night when Richard had taken her to the bathroom and she was punching him in the face. It took three of us to calm her down and get her back into bed."

Within three months, Alison was dead. Richard and her parents had taken the agonising decision not to do anything that would prolong her life. Mr Hodge remembers how a few days before she died, he tried to feed her with some cereal on a spoon. "Suddenly, she stopped swallowing. Fortunately, I had a little syringe so I was able to get a little water and rinsed her mouth out. When Sue came home that night, we tried again. But that was the end of it. She just did not eat any more and drink any more." A couple of days later, she was given sedatives and on August 27 she died.

It was all so different a couple of years earlier. Richard, a joiner, and Alison, who worked for a chain of toiletry stores, married in October 1995. After a childhood and early adulthood in which Alison suffered eczma, asthma, food allergies, migraines and other illnesses, life seemed good. She loved aerobics, working out and skiing. But Alison began getting anxious and Richard noticed she had less time for him. She was losing weight despite eating well and became scared by local youths burning out cars on the waste land behind their new house on the outskirts of an estate. The house was sold and the couple moved in with Alison's parents late in 1997.

Alison's driving became erratic. She was tired and irritable but blamed stress. She persuaded Richard they should go skiing in Italy despite complaining of uncontrollable leg shaking. She fell and suffered a hairline fracture of her right elbow. On her return, she could hardly walk off the plane. One day she collapsed at work. Richard brought her home and she never went back. "She could not even slice bread to make a sandwich," Susan recalls.

By late May, she was in Manchester Royal Infirmary for tests. She was given a walking frame with wheels. She kept falling over. She was told a brain scan was of poor quality because she could not keep still. "She was upset because she was unable to control her movements," says Susan.

In June, Alison was back home after a consultant neurologist and experts at the CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh disagnosed her as a suspect vCJD victim. The Hodges praise the help of their GP, district nurses and a members of local care attendant scheme. But lack of help from the local social services, was, says the family, "appalling".

Cheshire social services department this week said it was concerned that the Hodges felt their response "was less than satisfactory" but pointed out that Alison's was the first case they had ever dealt with. Susan Hodge later helped officers to understand the needs of those caring for later victims.

The local coroner refused an inquest because Alison died of "natural causes" - although the government has now agreed to open one early next month.

The Hodges believe the government and health authorities must give families more support - financial, emotional and practical. Susan, who works in the coffee shop at a local supermarket, Peter, a coach driver, and Richard reduced their working hours and bought expensive equipment to care for Alison.

"I was left very much in the dark as to the benefits to which I was entitled," says Susan. "We still had our household commitments, our mortgage and so on."

Meanwhile, they constantly rake over the past to try to understand why their daughter got the disease. During Alison's early years, they lived in the south-west where BSE was later to become a particular problem. They have often visited Leicestershire, where there has been an apparent cluster of victims. They regularly had roast beef for Sunday lunch, even though Susan gave it up when she sympathised with protesters against live cattle exports, but Alison would rarely eat beefburgers, cheap mince or meat pies.

"I think it is a blow to my pride really," admits Susan, who like other mothers of vCJD patients feels guilty that they may have fed their children contaminated material.

She has also wondered about baby food (though Alison rarely ate it), gelatin of bovine origin around the antibiotic capsules Alison used to take and the appendix operation Alison had in her teens. Experts recognise the possibility that the disease can be spread by contaminated surgical instruments.

Peter now says: "I can never eat beef again. Some people know what Alison died of and say "they do a nice roast beef down here" and I want to punch them on the nose." Others seem almost embarrassed to hear of their daughter's story. "When farmers come on television and say how hard done by they are, the first thing I say is 'tough titty'. I have no sympathy for them."

Deaths 80.

Victims still alive 5.

First known death Stephen Churchill, aged 19, May 1995.

Youngest death 15.

Oldest death 54.

Youngest victim Girl of 14 still alive. Symptoms first evident at 12.

webTitle: Room at the top Elite restaurants join tout scheme

fields.headline: Room at the top Elite restaurants join tout scheme
fields.trailText: The laws of supply and demand have finally caught up with Britain's most fashionable restaurants, where the rule of first come, first served has proved an astonishingly robust survivor.
fields.body:
The laws of supply and demand have finally caught up with Britain's most fashionable restaurants, where the rule of first come, first served has proved an astonishingly robust survivor.

For the first time, some of the elite eating places in the capital (soon to be followed by their equivalents in Leeds and Manchester) have accepted a touting scheme that at peak times adds up to £20 to the bill.

Pioneered in the United States, the scheme guarantees seats at five-star establishments such as Le Gavroche or Aix at the Halcyon in return for a commission to a brokering firm.

"We're basically dinner table touts," said a spokesman for the company, DinnerBroker, "and we're meeting a need - just like touts for Wimbledon or theatre tickets. It's just surprising that it's taken so long to arrive for eating out."

Discreet folded tenners to the maitre d' may be one of the reasons, say caterers, who have been reluctant to shed the mystique of hard-to-book tables by agreeing to an open, pay-for-the privilege system.

The London scheme offers guaranteed bookings at virtually immediate notice between 7-9pm, for a £15 commission for two people or £20 for four. Clients to date have been almost exclusively business people, according to the firm.

"It's a case of having an important contact arriving at Heathrow in the afternoon and wanting the best restaurant for them that evening," said the DinnerBroker spokesman. "We can guarantee room up to the last minute because we make block bookings a month ahead. If we do fall short of customers, the sort of restaurants we're dealing with never have any problem filling tables from their waiting lists."

DinnerBroker's reservations stand until 5pm daily and then revert to the restaurant if they have not been taken.

Forty London restaurants have signed up with DinnerBroker, which splits the commission on a 50-50 basis. The roll-out to regional centres is planned before Christmas.

fields.headline: Credit Suisse joins MSN portal
fields.standfirst:
Europe's 'new affluents' targeted

Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Europe's 'new affluents' targeted
fields.body:
Microsoft is aiming to draw Europe's "new affluents" to its MSN portal through a new partnership announced yesterday with Swiss bank Credit Suisse.

In its first significant signing for its new MoneyCentral personal finance portal, which is to be launched in the UK, France and Germany later this year, Microsoft said Credit Suisse would make its new investment service aimed at Europe's 40m wealthy individuals available on MSN.

As a result of the deal announced yesterday, customers of Credit Suisse can start trading shares and other investment products in a few weeks, while other personal finance products will be added later on.

The move came on the day that a study showed that established firms would dominate the internet economy. GartnerConsulting said that the value of the European internet sector will soar from $53bn (£37bn) to $1.3 trillion in the next four years, with old economy rather than dot.com companies responsible for the bulk of the upturn.

The report, commissioned by networking company Cisco, claimed that up to 95% of dot.coms were expected to fail within two to five years. For most, the costs of setting up a website and distribution system and establishing their brand were crippling.

However, the growth of European e-commerce was not expected to result in a significant increase in overall sales. Nick Smith, vice-president of GartnerConsulting, said: "People are not going to want more lawnmowers just because of the internet."

The Gartner report shows that more money is being spent in Europe on internet infrastructure and applications than on online deals. But while infrastructure spending would grow slowly, the value of e-commerce would soar 123% a year over the next four years.

Over the same period, average transaction values per head of population would jump from $500 to $12,000 in the US from about $300 to $8,000 in the UK, and from $240 to $7,000 for the European Union members as a whole.

 Patrica Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, yesterday said the auction of 42 licences to deliver broadband internet and multimedia services over the airwaves will start on November 10. The government is expecting to raise a minimum of £78.3m from the auction.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Jazz Legends | The Friday Play: Naples 44
fields.body:
Julian Joseph features the deliciously smoky voice of Sarah Vaughan in today's Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3). Vaughan's early singing experience hardly pointed to what lay ahead: she began as a 10-year-old chorister in a New Jersey church. Her break came when Billy Eckstine recruited her to the Earl Hines band. Two years later she'd won her first award, to remain at the top of the tree for the next four decades.

Travel writer Norman Lewis served in southern Italy during the war as a British army intelligence officer. Jonathan Holloway has adapted Lewis's diary of that period as The Friday Play: Naples 44 (9.0pm, Radio 4). It's a moving and often hilarious account of an ever-anarchic society struggling to survive one more trauma. Neapolitans and Brits rub against one another in mutual incomprehension while historic feuds and habits continue in their timeless way. Jeremy Howe's lively production keeps the action humming along.

webTitle: Comment: Secrets of the secret service

fields.headline: Search for the spooks
fields.standfirst:
If whistleblowers such as David Shayler are gagged, there's no chance of uncovering history

Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: If whistleblowers such as David Shayler are gagged, there's no chance of uncovering history
fields.body:
I was looking through the files MI5 kept on my father during the second world war. He spent most of the war in prison, as a former leading fascist who had led a campaign to prevent Britain from going to war with Hitler. The files contained long extracts from his private letters, carefully selected to make his views sound more extreme than they were. There was also a memo from MI5, gloating about having purloined love letters from my mother, and another saying that my father did not seem to know they were opening all his mail.

Just as the story became unbearably tense, up came a blank page. The next file was closed until 2039.

A few files on, another was retained under Section 3(4) of the Public Order Act 1958, which means that it's kept under wraps in the Home Office, on the authority of some functionary who signed himself A Booth. I don't know what is in it, but the files either side of it contain allegations that MI5 spies acted as agents provocateurs, and told lies in order to get people interned. Given how shoddily the spies and the politicians behaved on the evidence they have let me see, I shudder at the horrors they have concealed.

Now we come to more modern times. It transpires that MI5 are attempting to have the impending official secrets trial of their own whistleblowing former officer, David Shayler, conducted in secrecy, if a legal challenge to be mounted by the Guardian should be rebuffed. Mr Shayler is seeking to uncover the true history of an attempt to assassinate Colonel Gadafy of Libya.

In his book about MI6, the sister intelligence agency, Stephen Dorrill writes: "The argument goes that the service must protect its methods and its sources; though names can always be blanked out, and the fact is that secret service methods have hardly changed for 2,000 years." Mr Dorrill is talking here about documents just a decade or two old. The documents I want to see relate to events between 55 and 65 years ago. It would be laughable to argue that letting me see them might jeopardise the safety of an agent.

The historian Professor Colin Holmes is working on a book about William Joyce (Lord Haw Haw), who was hanged for broadcasting for Hitler during the war. We now know that Joyce had worked for MI5 for years, and his handlers tipped him off that he was about to be interned, which triggered his hasty departure for Germany in 1939.

Files being hidden from Professor Holmes include the internment file on John Macnab, Joyce's closest friend, with whom Joyce shared a London flat at the time that he left for Germany. If anyone outside MI5 knew the truth about Joyce's connection with the security services, their role in his treachery, and the nature of the warning and any guarantees he may have received from them, it was Macnab.

Macnab's internment file has been shredded. Perhaps this was an innocent mistake by an ignorant official. Then again, perhaps it wasn't: 415,000 MI5 files have been shredded since the organisation was founded in 1909, more than half of the files it created. And they are shredding them faster than ever. 130,000 files have been shredded in the past two years, according to a recent parliamentary answer from Home Office minister Charles Clarke.

Of course, they claim they don't destroy files with any historical significance. But if they had opened Macnab's internment file instead of shredding it, Professor Holmes would have had to join a long queue of contemporary historians anxious to read it. It is more likely, as another veteran spywatcher, Dr David Turner, puts it, that "the spooks are cramming into the shredder the evidence of their past misdeeds."

Professor Holmes has also been denied access to the MI5 files on Ben Greene, a close relative of novelist Graham Greene and former BBC boss Hugh Carlton Greene. Ben Greene was interned at the start of the war, but they had to let him out when he proved that the evidence of treacherous statements which justified his internment had been invented by an MI5 agent. Crucial files in the Ben Greene affair are retained under Section 3(4).

From the files that are available, I was able to show in my book about my father that during the war, MI5 agents lied in order to get people behind bars; and that Home Secretary Herbert Morrison enjoyed his power to keep people in prison without trial. There's more, though, in the files they won't let us see.

Does it matter? We are only talking here about a few fascists and neo- fascists. But it shows that the spy- masters don't just spy; they play an active part in the events on which they are spying.

We know that in the 1930s, Mosley's fascists were deeply penetrated by the security services. One of the many spies among Mosley's entourage, a former Ulster Unionist MP called WED Allen, recruited my father for Mosley, and subsidised many of Mosley's campaigns. (Allen turns up years later, looking after Kim Philby just before Philby decamped to Moscow.) Another, PG Taylor, provided the evidence on which many of Mosley's former followers went to prison. We know that the spymaster himself, Maxwell Knight, was a fascist sympathiser. One starts to wonder if fascism could ever have flourished without the spies to do the work. Did the state deliberately subsidise British fascism and keep it alive?

In the same period, the Independent Labour party - once a powerful force from the left which threatened to topple governments - was being reduced at breakneck speed to a powerless remnant, partly by infiltration from the Communist party. MI5 had a file on the ILP in the 30s, too. But it is closed until 2020.

Then, if they don't shred it first, perhaps we will find out that the Communist party and the security services collaborated to destroy the most influential and dangerous force on the left.

Or else they didn't. The point is that we don't know. We do know that the security services are as much actors in our history as the politicians and the industrialists. What was their role in the 1926 general strike? In the decline of the trade unions during the 1980s?

We read that Stella Rimington's crucial interventions in the 1985 miners' strike are to be deleted from her forthcoming memoirs. Those of us who were active trade unionists in the 80s know that the spies and agents provocateurs were among us, and we have as much right to know about their role as about Margaret Thatcher's.

We need to see all the files, not just those they think it is good for us to see. Otherwise the spies and the politicians can ensure that contemporary history is the study of those parts of history which they think it right for us to know.

The Rebel Who Lost His Cause by Francis Beckett is published by Alison and Busby; 50 Years of Special Operations by Stephen Dorrill is published by Fourth Estate.

webTitle: German far right party faces ban

fields.headline: German far right party faces ban
fields.trailText: After months of anguished debate the authorities agreed yesterday to seek a ban on the most radical of Germany's rightwing parties.
fields.body:
After months of anguished debate the authorities agreed yesterday to seek a ban on the most radical of Germany's rightwing parties.

At a meeting in Düsseldorf of interior ministers from the 16 regional governments, and a later meeting of state governors in the eastern city of Schwerin, all but two of the states voted to outlaw the National-Democratic Party of Germany (NPD).

The outcome makes it a virtually foregone conclusion that the government will petition the constitutional court to ban the NPD.

In an increasingly tense atmosphere, a senior NPD official in the south-west, Siegfried Stössgen, was recovering yesterday from three gunshot wounds received in an attack on Wednesday. The police would not rule out a political motive.

The federal interior minister, Otto Schily, said an application to ban the NPD would send a "clear signal" to the neo-Nazis.

"A country that had gas chambers for the annihilation of millions of Jews cannot tolerate organised anti-semitism," he said.

The proposed ban is the centrepiece of a government drive against the far-right. It decided to seize the initiative after concluding that racism, particularly in the east, could hinder future economic prosperity and social stability - largely because ministers feel that the country will need millions more immigrants.

There is a deep cross-party reluctance to do anything that would curb the scope of German democracy, however.

The conservative-led Hesse and Saarland states opposed the ban, saying that driving the NPD underground would not solve the problem.

Guido Westerwelle, secretary-general of the Free Democrat party, said pursuing the ban would only "build a stage for their hollow ideology".

A ban would allow officials to confiscate the NPD's property and withdraw federal campaign funds.

Although electorally insignificant, the NPD, formed in 1964, received more than DM1.1m (£325,000) last year.

webTitle: Wives may now get half in 'big money' divorce

fields.headline: Wives may now get half in 'big money' divorce
fields.trailText: Wives of rich husbands will get more money on divorce after a judgment yesterday by five law lords which acknowledges that the family courts have failed to keep pace with the times.
fields.body:
Wives of rich husbands will get more money on divorce after a judgment yesterday by five law lords which acknowledges that the family courts have failed to keep pace with the times.

The judges laid down guidelines that could see wives in "big money" divorce cases successfully laying claim to half the family's joint assets.

Dozens of court cases have been adjourned pending the law lords' judgment. The ruling came at the end of a five-year legal battle costing £840,000 between a divorced couple who farmed together for 33 years, building up assets worth £4.6m when the case first went to court in 1996.

Pamela and Martin White worked two farms near Taunton, Somerset. Mr White held one farm, Rexton, worth £1.78m in his sole name. Between them they owned the other farm, Blagroves, worth £2.66m, and Mrs White had capital worth £193,000.

The high court judge, Mr Justice Holman, gave her an £800,000 lump sum to add to her capital and ordered her to hand over her share of Blagroves farm to Mr White.

The judge said the sum of nearly £1m was enough to buy a house and provide for her living expenses, dismissing her claim that she should have enough to buy her own farm as unreasonable, since it would break up the farming business.

Outraged, Mrs White, 64, took her claim to the court of appeal, where she won £1.5m to add to her £193,000 capital - totalling around two-fifths of the joint assets. The legal costs for both sides had reached £310,000 by that stage.

But both sides appealed to the House of Lords, incurring what Lord Nicholls described as an appalling £530,000 in legal costs, making a grand total of £840,000.

Mr White, 63, argued that Mr Justice Holman was right just to give his former wife enough to live on for life and to buy a house.

Mrs White argued that she should get half the assets. But despite the £530,000 legal bill, the House of Lords left her with exactly what the court of appeal had given her.

The ruling means that judges in future cases where a couple's assets exceed their housing and income needs will start with a "yardstick of equality" instead of looking just at the wife's "reasonable requirements".

Lord Nicholls, whose decision was endorsed by the four other law lords, said a wife would not automatically get half the assets because there were other factors to take into account.

But "as a general guide, equality should be departed from only if, and to the extent that, there is good reason for doing so".

He said the principle would not apply only in cases such as the Whites', where husband and wife had contributed equally to the family income. "There should be no bias in favour of the money-earner and against the homemaker and the child-carer."

Mrs White's solicitor, Ian Airey, said his client, now farming with friends in the west country, was disappointed that the House of Lords had not awarded her one of the two farms.

"While she appreciates that this case is of great importance to all divorcing couples and that many cases have been adjourned to await the judgment in this case, her principal concern has been to obtain a fair division of the matrimonial assets."

webTitle: Gay rights code set to be shelved

fields.headline: Gay rights code set to be shelved
fields.trailText: The government is expected to avoid a pre-election row over gay rights by deferring new measures to outlaw discrimination against homosexuals in the workplace.
fields.body:
The government is expected to avoid a pre-election row over gay rights by deferring new measures to outlaw discrimination against homosexuals in the workplace.

The Department for Education and Employment had been planning an advisory code of practice on discrimination for this autumn. It has been drawn up by the equal opportunities commission, in cooperation with the Confederation of British Industry and gay rights groups, and sent to ministers for publication.

However, an EU directive agreed last week will require the government to introduce laws within three years banning discrimination against gays.

Stonewall, the gay rights campaign group, accepted yesterday that ministers were now likely to shelve the code and wait for the new legislation.

There have also been doubts about whether the code as drafted would be detailed enough to have much impact in the workplace.

Ministers are thought to favour waiting for the tough legislation required by the EU rather than fighting anti-gay rights groups first over a code and then over new laws. As well as deferring the row until after the election, ministers could argue that the legislation was an EU requirement rather than the initiative of a Labour government.

Ministers have already lost a battle to repeal section 28 of the Local Government Act preventing councils from promoting homosexuality. The government was twice defeated by opposition from Tory peers. Similar divisive battles have been fought in Scotland.

Gay groups claim that discrimination against lesbians and homosexual men in the workplace is widespread, but the CBI fears that new laws will create new tensions.

In a TUC survey in April 44% of respondents claimed they suffered discrimination because of their sexuality. The EU directive agreed last week outlaws discrimination on grounds of religion, sexual orientation and disability.

Church groups are worried that the directive will prevent churches from exclusively employing people of their faith for ancillary jobs. It is generally recognised that the directive gives an exemption to church schools so that they can recruit teachers who are of their faith.

webTitle: Blameless life for those in a very British affair

fields.headline: Blameless life for those in a very British affair
fields.trailText: The Commons echoed yesterday with the heartwarming sound of the British establishment forgiving itself. So far 80 people have died from variant CJD, and there may be thousands more to come. But, thank heavens, it's nobody's fault. Or at least nobody we know.
fields.body:
The Commons echoed yesterday with the heartwarming sound of the British establishment forgiving itself. So far 80 people have died from variant CJD, and there may be thousands more to come. But, thank heavens, it's nobody's fault. Or at least nobody we know.

Oh, it turns out that some people made mistakes. The Phillips report lists 23 of them in an appendix, mostly civil servants, doctors and scientists. But by a happy chance, many of these people are also praised in another part of the report. So they're certainly not responsible.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, read out a statement in his usual flat, monotonous voice. He certainly wasn't going to blame the Tories. What could be more inappropriate at such a sad time than to point fingers at the ministers who were in charge during the affair?

As it happens, much of the Phillips report is written in British, that tongue which is tantalisingly close to English but also very different. If you can translate British into English, you can see how tough its judgments really are. The government had taken sensible measures, "but these were not always timely, nor adequately implemented and enforced".

This means in English, "the measures were ignored". Officials "showed a lack of rigour in considering how policy should be turned into practice", which I take to mean "sat on their tushes and did nothing".

But that's the report. MPs were much more kindly. Tim Yeo, the Tory spokesman, made a stirring and heartfelt apology. "I apologise to the families of those who have suffered bereavement, and to those who are still struggling with a terrible illness."

Very apposite, except why was Mr Yeo apologising? And for what? He wasn't there. He isn't even mentioned in the report's index (unlike, say, John Gummer: 27 times, and Stephen Dorrell: seven times.)

I suppose in the same way I could apologise for the Crusades, or slavery, or Jack the Ripper. Very satisfying to the victims, perhaps, if I had had anything to do with it.

John Major (four mentions in the index) rose to exculpate everyone. Many of those in the report's annexe of guilty men (or wholly innocent, devoted public servants, as we now know them to be) were also praised elsewhere.

"There are no scapegoats or villains emerging from this report," he announced. Some mistakes had been made. "They were not due to indolence, but to the overwhelming pressure on a few key officials."

Mr Brown could not have agreed more. If mistakes had been made, they were "as the government struggled to find a proportionate response to the emergent challenges of BSE".

This is British for the English statement "failed pitifully to realise in time how serious the problem was".

The former agriculture minister Douglas Hogg (13 mentions) leapt up to tell us that everyone involved in the scandal was as fragrant as a dew-fresh rosebud.

"In regard to officials," he said, "we believe they gave advice in good faith and to the best of their professional ability."

Only Colin Breed, the Liberal Democrat spokesman, dared to break into the hushed tones of redemption. (And what a fine name he has for someone whose brief includes livestock.)

"It is a sorry saga of complacency in the early years, incompetence when risks were emerging, and complicity when things started to go wrong," he told the House.

There was a massed intake of breath. What? Someone was actually accusing someone of being at fault, suggesting that some blame might be apportioned for the greatest crisis our agriculture industry has ever faced?

Heaven forfend! That's not the way we do things in Britain. Or not in the House of Commons.

So far 80 people have died from variant CJD, and there may be thousands more to come. But, thank heavens, it's nobody's fault. Or at least nobody we know. Oh, it turns out that some people made mistakes. The Phillips report lists 23 of them in an appendix, mostly civil servants, doctors and scientists. But by a happy chance, many of these people are also praised in another part of the report. So they're certainly not responsible. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, read out a statement in his usual flat, monotonous voice. He certainly wasn't going to blame the Tories. What could be more inappropriate at such a sad time than to point fingers at the ministers who were in charge during the affair? As it happens, much of the Phillips report is written in British, that tongue which is tantalisingly close to English but also very different. If you can translate British into English, you can see how tough its judgments really are. The government had taken sensible measures, "but these were not always timely, nor adequately implemented and enforced". This means in English, "the measures were ignored". Officials "showed a lack of rigour in considering how policy should be turned into practice", which I take to mean "sat on their tushes and did nothing". But that's the report. webTitle: End of the road for Go-Peds

fields.headline: End of the road for Go-Peds
fields.standfirst: High court ruling forces scooters off highway
fields.trailText: High court ruling forces scooters off highway.
fields.body:
Go-Peds, the trendy motorised scooters that have achieved cult status were effectively driven off the roads yesterday after the high court ruled they had the same legal status as motor vehicles.

The decision means scooter aficionados will need a driving licence and third party insurance to use them on public highways. But as no insurance company is prepared to cover them for road use because of their inadequate braking system and lack of lights or proper steering, driving them on the public highway is liable to prosecution.

Lord Justice Pill and Mr Justice Bell ruled that a Middlesbrough restaurateur, Michael Saddington, who was arrested in a "Keystone Cops" chase through Harrogate should have been convicted of driving while disqualified.

The judges overruled magistrates who dismissed the charges against Mr Saddington, 38. They allowed an appeal by the chief constable of North Yorkshire against the magistrates' decision.

Lord Justice Pill said he was satisfied that a Go-Ped was a mechanically propelled vehicle and in the eyes of the law was intended for road use. Therefore a driving licence and third party insurance would be needed.

At an earlier hearing he said the public may need protection from the Go-Ped craze because of a loophole in the law which allowed their uncontrolled use. Mr Saddington will not however be punished for his "spur of the moment" act as the judges decided not to remit the case back to the magistrates for sentencing.

Lord Justice Pill added: "The test is not whether a reasonable person would use a Go-Ped on a road which in ordinary circumstances he probably would not because of the dangers involved.

"The test is whether a reasonable person would say that one of its uses would be on the roads. That person must consider whether some general use on the roads must be contemplated and not merely isolated use or use by a man losing his senses." The judge added that, in his opinion, people would be tempted to use Go-Peds on the road. They would ignore manufacturer's warnings not to do so, and the court's opinion that they are not roadworthy.

Mr Saddington's barrister, Richard Reed, said after the case: "The ruling effectively means that Go-Peds are now deemed road vehicles and require insurance if they are used on the roads. But the reality is that no insurance company will ever provide cover, so they can never be legally used on roads." Mr Saddington borrowed the scooter in what he described as a "toys for boys" prank. As he tried out a Go-Ped belonging to one of his restaurant staff, he heard police sirens behind him.

"It was a bit like the Keystone Cops actually. When I heard the sirens I thought 'I wonder where they are going?' expecting them to whoosh straight past. But it turned out they were chasing me," he said outside the high court earlier this month.

Mr Saddington said that after riding the 22.5cc machine, which is not fitted with a speedometer, mirrors or lights but is capable of speeds of up to 20mph, he was convinced they were unsafe for road use.

When he appeared before magistrates he pleaded guilty to failing to stop at traffic lights and failing to stop for the police. He was found guilty of failing to wear protective headgear but cleared of driving a motor vehicle while disqualified. Mr Saddington was fined £275 including costs.

fields.headline: Violence closes peace theatre
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: A British theatre company teaching children from warring ethnic groups in Indonesia how to build friendships through drama cancelled its programme yesterday after at least three people were killed in rioting in West Kalimantan.
fields.body:
A British theatre company teaching children from warring ethnic groups in Indonesia how to build friendships through drama cancelled its programme yesterday after at least three people were killed in rioting in West Kalimantan.

The David Glass Ensemble, from London, had been working with 43 children from the indigenous Malay and Dayak groups and migrant Madurese on a British Council project in Pontianak in West Kalimantan, the Indonesian half of Borneo.

Last night its five members and their two British Council coordinators were preparing to leave the strife-torn city for the capital, Jakarta, as buildings continued to blaze near their hotel and gangs rampaged on the streets.

"There is no way we can continue working here," Jim Hollington of the British Council said. "Not only is the safety and security of the team at risk, but the project is no longer viable, because the children's parents will not let them take part in the workshops and performances."

Jane Arnfield, the company's project leader, said the violence had taken them all by surprise. "We have been here since last week and no one had any inkling that something like this might happen."

Most of the children they were teaching were victims of violence between the Madurese and local tribes, particularly the Malays and Dayaks.

Hundreds died in a major outbreak in the province last year, and 4,000 Madurese refugees from the unrest are still living in squalid camps in Pontianak, which lies on the equator, 470 miles north-east of Jakarta.

The latest trouble began with a minor traffic accident on Wednesday morning. Violence quickly flared after a Madurese bus driver hit a Malay motorcyclist, even though no one was seriously injured.

Police officers, said by witnesses to be extremely trigger happy, were unable to stop gangs of Malay youths rampaging through the city.

A Madurese man was hacked to death after a mob grabbed him from the officers who had arrested him.

webTitle: What the Lynx razor ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Lynx razor ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Lynx razor ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
An Asian guy is standing at his rather tatty bedsit sink in just a pair of purple Y-fronts, shaving. He finishes, gets dressed and - the final touch - puts a match between his lips for that special Saturday Night Fever look. Our hero then jumps on his moped and rides to a nearby disco, where he meets a girl sitting at a table. As he joins her she knowingly blows out a candle in front of her. He then coolly tries to strike the match against his chin to relight it, but he's had such a close shave that it doesn't work. The girl grabs the match, and promptly strikes it under her arm.

The jargon:
This ad marks a long overdue departure from the traditional jet fighter-cum-square-jawed man in bathroom approach favoured by razor manufacturers (er, Gillette, that is). The jokey film promotes "the extension of the Lynx brand into the shaving products market" and adopts the same strategy as the main deodorant's advertising, feeding into its "core seduction promise", says agency BBH.

Personality:
You have to be old enough to be shaving and, obviously, you don't have a beard. Apart from that, you could be any sort of bloke age-wise/income-wise, but the "psychographic", as adfolk say, is that you're young-thinking, irreverent, down to earth and discerning.

Financial status:
The Lynx Triple Blade Razor costs between £4.50 and £5.50. This may sound pricey, but you have to remember this is a "shaving system", not a disposable razor.

Telling lifestyle detail:
Chances are you probably already use Lynx deodorant, given that the commercial is aimed first and foremost at existing Lynx fans.

Other relevant data:
The ad was shot in Turkey by the groovy directing team Traktor, who've also done stylish films for Diesel and MTV. Apparently, it wasn't easy convincing the female model that a shot of her striking a match under her arm would not be professional suicide.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man arrested after shooting
fields.body:
Man arrested after shooting

A man, 19, has been arrested after suffering a gunshot wound during an attempted armed robbery at a bank in Newbridge, South Wales, yesterday. The incident has been referred to the Police Complaints Authority.

Martian landings

A meteorite from Mars which fell into the Antarctic and was found in 1996 to contain what looked like fossil microbes stayed cool enough at 40C to allow the survival of bacteria between planets, according to a new study by US scientists published today in the journal Science.

Murdered wife's £25,000 will

Colin Harrold, 35, of Uffington, Lincolnshire, who was cleared at Northampton crown court earlier this year of killing his wife, Diane, is set to inherit £25,000 as well as sole ownership of the £350,000 luxury home where she was found dead in the swimming pool. A friend admitted the murder.

Art works 'untraceable'

More than 600 works of art in British museums and galleries cannot be proved not to have been looted from Jewish owners. Only two claims had been received after a year's trawl through museum archives.

£1m puzzle solved

An unemployed mathematician has won £1m for solving the Eternity puzzle. Alex Selby, 32, of Cambridge, and fellow mathematician Oliver Riordan, 28, completed the 209-piece patternless jigsaw two years before the game's creator, Christopher Monckton, expected.

Top of the pops plans award

Top of the Pops plans to launch its own pop music awards show in Manchester next year.

TV licence up

Colour TV licences will cost £109 next year, a £5 rise, ministers said yesterday.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Picture of Dorian Gray | Chinatown | The Two Jakes | Jubilee
fields.body:
The Picture of Dorian Gray

(Albert Lewin 1945)

6.55pm, TCM

In the centenary of his death, an atmospheric Hollywood treatment of Oscar Wilde's gothic novel about a young man's pact with the devil in a corrupt Edwardian London. George Sanders sets the tone beautifully with his cynical, sneering Lord Henry Wotton, who unwittingly sets up the deal, and Hurd Hatfield is perfectly smooth as decadent Dorian, remaining the picture of innocence while the portrait in the attic grows older and more evil looking. Elegant, witty and barbed; Oscar would have enjoyed it.

Chinatown

(Roman Polanski, 1974)

8pm, Sky Cinema

Near faultless recreation of film noir, in a dazzling 30s Los Angeles shaded by the themes of evil and corruption that seem to resonate in the Polanski psyche. Jack Nicholson is private eye JJ Gittes, Faye Dunaway (pictured) the femme fatale. Scriptwriter Robert Towne invests Gittes with a Chandleresque nobility, but places him in an even harsher world, cruel as a switchblade.

The Two Jakes

(Jack Nicholson, 1990)

10.20pm, Sky Cinema

And here's Jake again, with Nicholson back as private eye Jake Gittes and directing this belated sequel to Chinatown. It's 1947, 11 years on, but he's still haunted by the events of the earlier film. And now Harvey Keitel's property developer Jake Berman is roping him into the murder of another woman, and Los Angeles is again a cruel place of earth tremors, blood, and relentlessly shifting realities in Robert Towne's labyrinthine script. Meg Tilly and Madeleine Stowe are the dangerous women.

Jubilee

(Derek Jarman, 1978)

12midnight, FilmFour

Despairing view of a punk futureworld as viewed by Queen Elizabeth I (Jenny Runacre), who travels through time to witness the collapse of her nation. A harsh punk score and the likes of Little Nell and Toyah Wilcox set the tone, and it's all meant to reflect the grubby present. The pill is sweetened by a bitter humour.
