fields.headline: Hi-tech jitters hit home
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Bookham Technology was the highest profile victim in a depressing day of trading which saw Wall Street jitters over technology stocks impact hard on this side of the Atlantic.
fields.body:
Bookham Technology was the highest profile victim in a depressing day of trading which saw Wall Street jitters over technology stocks impact hard on this side of the Atlantic.

The company, which makes fibre-optic components, took the mantle of the FTSE 100's biggest loser after shedding 11.3% to £21.50 as traders spent much of the day monitoring events stateside.

Yesterday's slide, which followed a 13% drop on Wednesday, means the company is now way off its £54.37 year high and sliding ever closer to the £16 low.

Hopes of a bounce in New York failed to materialise as the markets closed, with the main index dragged a further 65.5 points lower to 6,302.3.

The Techmark 100 index of technology companies fared worse, sliding 101.9 points to 3,355.78.

Logica was down 154p at £18.66, Sema shed a further 70p to 910p and Misys ended the session 48p lower at 709p.

They were not alone. Baltimore Technologies, the Irish internet security outfit, announced it was teaming up with Motorola, the US communications company, to develop secure solutions for mobile phones and other wireless devices.

But even Baltimore, which has outperformed the UK software sector by about 40% this year, saw its shares initially gain 4% before sliding back 24p to 527p.

AEA Technology, the science and engineering firm, had a dire day after issuing a profits warning due to a delay in the award of contracts. The stock plummeted almost 30% from 482.5p to end the session at 342.5p.

Telecommunications stocks were also out of favour with Cable & Wireless suffering a 6% fall to 897p and British Telecom not far behind as it slipped 16.5p to 737.5p in the wake of this week's advances.

But it was not all bad news. The pharmaceuticals sector, at least, had something to cheer as it contributed 14 points to the FTSE's haul for the day.

Shire Pharmaceuticals, replacing Woolwich following the acquisition of the mortgage bank by Barclays, celebrated its arrival in the FTSE 100 with its shares rising 35p to £13.85.

Glaxo Wellcome was 42p higher at £20.44, while SmithKline Beecham rose 19.5p at 931.5p. AstraZeneca, the Anglo-Swedish drugs group, which announced it was outsourcing its IT infrastructure services to IBM, climbed 46p to £32.16.

Most retailers were also looking healthy with Sainsbury adding 11.5p to 382.5p, Tesco inching up 5.75p to 262.75p and Safeway putting on 5.25p to 285.75p.

There was, however, little joy for beleaguered Marks & Spencer which lost a further 8p, representing just over 4%, to 175p.

The media sector was besieged with worries over advertising and ITV revenues which impacted strongly on the fortunes of Granada Media, which dropped 28p to 368p, and Carlton Communications, which lost 36p, or 6.3%, at 534p.

BSkyB, the satellite broadcaster, bucked the sector trend to enjoy a buoyant time with its stock up 23p to 885p.

Banks had a generally poor day with Barclays going down 24p at £18.80, HSBC slipping 15p to 968p and Lloyds TSB losing 3p to close at 657p.

Elsewhere, shares in Churchill China, the British ceramic products maker, rose 11p to 157.5p after the company said trading was exceeding expectations.

The improvement, it said, came from progress in its "Dining In" division where sales in north America were higher than last year.

Imperial Chemical Industries was another gainer, up 15p at 412p on the strength of positive comment from its broker UBS Warburg.

Away from the turmoil of the main FTSE 100 index, life was fairly tranquil with the FTSE Midcap 250, which crawled 5.3 points higher to end at 6,549.7.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: My broken marriage has left me hating men. How can I move on?
fields.trailText: My broken marriage has left me hating men. How can I move on?
fields.body:
I was 22 when I married an unsupportive person. After five years of emotional turmoil, I ended it. That was five years ago, and I have gone through an immense struggle to get my own flat and stabilise my career.

During this time, I received little emotional support from my family. We now spend happy days together but it has left me bitter and I cannot help feeling let down for having been left to face things alone. Through this, I avoided anyone who tried to get close as I had become a man-hater.

Now I have started enjoying life more, and there are a few guys who would like to be friends. But I cannot respond. I have become extremely reserved and find it hard to converse in a group. I can only talk easily about work. Recently a man whom I like very much has been trying to get close but my silence is scaring him off. I just don't know what to say to him. How can I overcome this bitterness and relate to people again?

Choose to be happy

Here is a tried and tested different perspective - had you looked at your "immense struggle" as a gift or a learning experience you could have chosen (and still can now) to feel proud of yourself: strong, self-empowered and positive. You, however, despite spending "happy days" with your family, have chosen to remain sad and bitter inside - so choosing another path. This is obviously causing you and those trying to get close to you a lot of distress. Perhaps sharing a few lessons that I learned from my saddest experiences might help: I learned to live in the present only, to choose to smile and be happy and positive, no matter what, and, most importantly, that you get out what you put out. Pat yourself on the back for being so strong, be grateful for your family now and for the people around you and forgive yourself and others so that you can, from today, start a new positive life, full of joy and love. You deserve it.
Annie G Watts Surrey

Tell him how you feel

You are not a man-hater; you have just been hurt and are trying to avoid it happening again. As for what you do next, I suggest you talk to the man who is attracted to you and explain your background to him. If he is worth bothering with he will understand. I am a man in a similar position to your friend and am waiting and hoping to get a positive response from a woman I feel very strongly about and with whom I have a good relationship. However, whilst there are encouraging signs, nothing has developed yet. This situation has been going on for some considerable time and is hard for me to conceal. For us men it is a difficult card to play as we are always at risk of accusations of harassment if we are seen to be too persistent for too long. Talk to your man friend and explain how your reticence has developed; you could easily end up making two people very happy.
Name and address withheld

Let him do the talking

When I was about to go on my first date, aged 15, I panicked and cried: "But what will I talk to him about?" I was offered these pearls of wisdom: "Just ask him about himself." Since then I have never, in all these years, been short of conversation.
Polly Walker, Powys

Stop blaming others

Was it really all so terrible? After all, he didn't beat you up and you didn't have kids to complicate leaving him. You at least had the freedom to establish a new life and career without having to take the children's needs and childcare into consideration.

I felt rather irritated by the melodramatic language you use to refer to your past. Self pity seems to be your problem. Maybe this irritated your family too when you expected support from them.

Start taking responsibility for your own role in past events rather than blaming others. You chose to marry and stay with your husband for five years. Instead of feeling bitter towards your family for, as you see it, being unsupportive, try to understand why this happened and learn from it.

You probably need to question your expectations. When my marriage broke up, also after five years, it never occurred to me to ask my family for support as I was an adult at the time. My friends gave me support.

You will not overcome the bitterness until you stop blaming other people. Forgive and forget and look forward to a positive future. I suggest you make some women friends too. Friendships with women are more durable and these would enable you to become less emotionally dependent on your family.
Name and address withheld

It's worth the risk

I think, despite real success in rebuilding your life, your self esteem and self confidence may not have fully recovered. No wonder then that you feel vulnerable, defensive and understandably angry toward those who let you down so badly. However, while these emotions have protected you, giving you time to heal and recover safe within your isolation, you now recognise it is time to move on. The fact that you are beginning to enjoy male company is an indication of this.

Try talking to the man you mention and explain your situation. If he is as nice as you say he will respond with understanding and support. If not, then he isn't the type of man you need right now. You will be a more "whole" person in the long run if you are prepared to take a risk on trusting, loving and being loved again. It will be challenging, probably painful - but ultimately more than worth the gamble.
Name and address withheld

You can love again

I too was married to an "unsupportive person", an alcoholic, for 10 years. I battled on against the odds for so long out of misplaced loyalty. When I finally divorced, most of my family were of little practical help; they preferred to kick my already low self-esteem by pointing out how foolish I had been and what a bastard the ex-husband was. My father wisely pointed me to the future and made me realise that no amount of regret or bitterness could turn back the clock. I was owed money, I had to pay my ex-husband's debts, but thanks to the support of Al-Anon, good friends and a second job, I made it and am now blissfully happily married to a wonderful man.

As for your family - like mine, they probably had no idea how to cope. I largely kept my own council, preferring to confide in friends who had similar experiences, and this paid off. Parents are not there to pick up the pieces of your life if it goes wrong; don't burden them. I too avoided men for six years, afraid of commitment; I did not believe I could be happy again in a relationship. It took a great deal of time and patience and a few shallow, meaningless friendships with men before I realised that I was capable and worthy of a loving marriage. Your biggest problem is self-esteem. There is no magic recipe for regaining it, but don't give up, and try to keep an open mind. Somewhere out there is a man who will make you happy; you just have to find him. I did - so can you.
Name and address withheld

Next week

When I began a relationship with Rob three years ago he had just started attending AA after many years of heavy drinking, which had resulted in the break-up of his marriage. When he and his wife separated, their two teenage sons remained with him. His relationship with the two boys was often difficult but, in spite of his drinking, he always provided for them materially (hot meals, tidy house). However, he is the first to admit he probably provided them with little emotional support over the years. In the last three years, he has remained sober and, through hard work and loyalty to his company, he has been rewarded with promotion and a large increase in salary. You would think this new-found prosperity and atmosphere of calm sobriety would unite the family, but it has only alienated the elder son.

He has moved in with his mother, re-appearing or calling only to make financial demands. It's as if he feels that the only way Rob can make it up to him is to buy him things. Rob is more than willing to spend time with him but this isn't what his son wants. It's obvious the boy has been damaged by Rob's drinking, but surely throwing money at him won't help.How have other readers coped?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
A pack of swans flew overhead as I walked on Longhorsley moor last week. I knew they were whooper swans by the chanting - a soft, melancholy, bugling note, who-who-who, from which their name is derived. Mute swans are largely silent apart from an occasional hiss - the whooper really "whoops". The whooper carries his head upright and has a bright yellow beak with a black tip to it, the mute's neck carriage is more curvaceous and the beak is orange, backed by a dark nasal knob. Mutes are largely residential in habit whilst whooper swans are migrants, nesting in Iceland and the Arctic Circle.

Many whoopers now come to our northern counties in the autumn before moving further south, others stay all winter, and these appear to be on the increase on suitable lakes, pitfalls and around Lindisfarne, our Holy Island. Perhaps this is due to recent mild winters. A third swan to visit our shores is the Bewick. The neck carriage and colour of the beak are similar to the whooper but the bird is half the size. Swans were once highly regarded as table birds, especially at Christmas.

Swans are popular birds with other surface-feeding ducks, because in midwinter they are efficient ice-breakers. Due to their bulk and weight they can often prevent the water freezing, thus cutting off the food supply.

During one fierce winter freeze-up, a pair of whoopers stayed on a local lake all winter and it was fascinating to watch them. Ice encroached from all sides to leave a little pool of open water which became crowded with aquatic birds, and by sheer persistence the pair of whoopers kept the water from icing over completely.

fields.headline: Growing pains
fields.standfirst: When the BBC announced the resurrection of Bill and Ben, The Flowerpot Men earlier this week the nation breathed a collective sigh of nostalgia. But  Stuart Jeffries thinks it will all end in tears
fields.trailText: When the BBC announced the resurrection of Bill and Ben, The Flowerpot Men earlier this week the nation breathed a collective sigh of nostalgia. But Stuart Jeffries thinks it will all end in tears
fields.body:
It was the late 60s in the Black Country. I was a small boy, and my brother Neil was even smaller. We sat at Nanny Lewis's dining table one afternoon each week having lunch. After lamb chops with peas and potatoes, two custard tarts in tinfoil cups would be brought out. We ate them, then I turned one foil cup upside down, looked at Neil, and said "Flobadopalop?" He looked at me and replied "Flobadopalop!"

It was 1.40pm, and time for the weekly ritual of Bill and Ben, The Flowerpot Men. Neil and I watched the programme while my mother and her mother did the dishes in the adjoining kitchen. Even though Bill and Ben appeared as part of the Watch With Mother strand, we often watched without mother.

And that was very appropriate. Just as Bill and Ben only came to life when the Gardener left the potting shed and went for lunch, so Neil and I only played when the authority figures were out of the room.

Bill and Ben would make their appearance each week by rising over huge flowerpots in which, we supposed, they had been hiding while the Gardener pottered nearby. First, up popped Bill. Or maybe it was Ben (they were very nearly identical). Then down he popped. And then up. And then down. Neil and I and the rest of the children in the TV audience would join in, immediately caught up in playing hide and seek with The Flowerpot Men.

But that primal game was tainted for me, since - even though Bill and Ben were playing at hiding from the friendly TV audience - I knew that this was just the simulation of the real hide and seek they played with the Gardener. But why did they need to hide? Why did they have Weed as a look-out while they played? Why did each episode end with them scrambling back into their pots as the Gardener returned filled with chops and tarts? What would the Gardener do if he found these little boys who were mostly made from flowerpots?

I felt sure he would have crushed their faces with his hobnail boots, reduced their blank, painted eyes to blanker dust. He would have snapped off their arms and legs and used their flowerpot torsos for planting geraniums.

Childhood innocence quickly became a fraught affair when we watched Bill and Ben. Games and playing were not things that would be tolerated by thunder-browed adults like the Gardener, and so Bill and Ben had to pretend not to exist rather than be caught playing in pots.

Thirty years after they were last seen on British television, Bill and Ben are going to come out of their pots again in a new 26-part BBC series to be screened next year. However, the strings that used to yank Bill and Ben upright have been dispensed with - the pair are to be recreated using computer animation.

They will have lime green bow ties with matching gloves. The look-out, Weed, who used to say only one word, namely "Wee-eeed!", is to be given an expanded vocabulary, as well as sunglasses and an "earth mother" image. There will be new characters, including a hedgehog, a worm and a tortoise. Jon Thomson, from The Fast Show, will lend his voice to the project and thereby - or so suggests the press release - give the show "a contemporary feel", whatever that means. The aim is that Bill and Ben will compete with the Teletubbies and the Tweenies.

All this is painful to me, because my most tender childhood memories of watching television are bound up with Bill and Ben. With all due respect to the team from Cosgrove Hall films, who have spent a year working on this, I don't want Bill and Ben to be given a computer-aided makeover. I don't want these adults marching down the garden path and trampling the Flowerpot Men into some semblance of modernity.

The last thing I want - and this is apparently what viewers are going to be offered - is a narrator to translate Bill and Ben's "flobadopalop" speech into English. Instead, I need to remember the obviousness of the puppeteer's strings, the crudity of the pair's painted faces, the clumsy flowerpots that were strung together to make up Bill and Ben's arms and legs.

What I want, of course, is to keep those delicious custardy memories from my childhood intact and stop the Flowerpot Men being superseded by improved models that mean nothing to me. I even want to remember the painfully suggestive drama of subterfuge and hiding from the Gardener in order to recall why television viewing was such a rich experience for me in my childhood. Perhaps, you might be saying, I should grow up and forget about Bill and Ben. But there is part of me that never will.

 Stuart Jeffries's book, Mrs Slocombe's Pussy: Growing Up In Front Of The Telly, is published by HarperCollins and will feature on Radio 4's Book Of The Week in December

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
We can all sleep easy in our beds tonight, because The Big Breakfast house is safe. Contrary to scurrilous reports that the show will be axed when mainstay presenter Johnny Vaughan leaves at the end of the year, we can now reveal that Channel 4's early morning wackiness is safe for 2001.

A new executive producer has been drafted in, however, and things will be shaken up in a bid to bolster ratings. Good news is that the dodgy flying chicken titles will change in the new year. Even better news is that the house will stay. Which will please Charlie Parsons and Waheed Alli, founders of Planet 24 (which makes The Big Breakfast). They secured the cutely named Lock-keepers Cottages in London's East End before landing the contract to make the programme eight years ago. And it's a location that clearly inspires affection and a sense of belonging in all who work on the zany two-hour show - not to mention the few hundred thousand viewers who tune in every day (yes, less than when Chris and Gabby were presenting it but, er, that was before digital TV).

Daily visitors to The Big Breakfast house would be forgiven for failing to notice the studio's attractive canal-side setting. They wind through Bow's industrial estate, E3, finding their destination only by virtue of directions from a Boots lorry loader. (Boots shares the business lot, and your man's seen so many lost-looking black Mercs circling the business park - "Looking for The Big Breakfast?" - that he now has the convoluted directions down to a fine art.)

So the waterside studio hasn't had its day yet, and will survive to host another year of hospitality fry-ups in the good old tradition of TV liggery. Vaughan himself will next be seen on the BBC in his own comedy, Orrible. And in case you're panicking that, like the sugar on your Weetabix, you blink and the next week he's gone - don't worry. He's just on holiday.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

(Boots shares the business lot, and your man's seen so many lost-looking black Mercs circling the business park - "Looking for The Big Breakfast?" - that he now has the convoluted directions down to a fine art.) So the waterside studio hasn't had its day yet, and will survive to host another year of hospitality fry-ups in the good old tradition of TV liggery. Vaughan himself will next be seen on the BBC in his own comedy, Orrible. And in case you're panicking that, like the sugar on your Weetabix, you blink and the next week he's gone - don't worry. He's just on holiday.  Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Right place, wrong time
fields.trailText: Buffy The Vampire Slayer | Fat Friends | Horizon: The Lost World
fields.body:
There's little more irritating for the hardened TV viewer than a time differential - or temporal distortion as they might say in Star Trek - between the real world of one's living room and the telly world. It's a sad reminder that most of what transpires on TV is made up, and that, no, you couldn't visit The Bayside Diner in Summer Bay if you went to Australia - because it isn't real. It's irksome enough that it's Christmas in ER when it's August here, but at least it always looks Christmassy in Chicago. That it's Christmas here and nearly Easter in Neighbours and Christmas in Neighbours when it's June here - and Christmas at a different time altogether in Home and Away - is really frustrating. In the future, when technological advances in TV mean you can watch anything that's ever been on at any time, it will be possible to watch Christmas special after Christmas special whenever you fancy. Not only will this advance the postmodernist theory about the end of history, it will cheer Wizzard, who wished it could be Christmas every day.

They don't have Christmas in space, at least not on Star Trek: Voyager. There, they have Prixin instead, which sounds rude but isn't.

All of which leads, like roads to Rome, to Buffy The Vampire Slayer (BBC2). Through no sound judgement on the part of BBC schedulers who have punted Buffy around like a beachball, it reached a Halloween episode just as the real world reaches Halloween. Spooky, but in a good way. Not one of the series' best episodes, its message was too obvious - the only thing to fear is fear itself (that, and Peter Stringfellow) - and its climax a bit of an anti-climax (again, like Peter Stringfellow). There were nice moments, however, especially a forlorn Buffy musing on the life of a pumpkin. "You grow up in the sun, entwined with others but then someone comes along, cuts you open and scoops out your guts." Bless.

And bless Kay Mellor too for Fat Friends (ITV) and its wonderful James Bond titles pastiche with cakes instead of guns. In the world of Julia Fleshman's slimmers, guts and growing up in the sun were also to the fore with Poor Lauren (Jewish Judy Mallett) having an epiphany (and it wasn't even January 6) about her unhappy life since she started dieting, Kelly failing to lose weight with only four weeks to go before her wedding, and Julia's hair looking more like a sedated guinea pig with each passing week. Its overstated moral notwithstanding ("I blame the magazines"), it's witty, moving and sparkly, much like Lauren in her tooth-fairy costume.

Horizon: The Lost World (BBC2) started melodramatically. "Earth has one secret left," it proclaimed. Really? Just one? Not a couple? Not 'What's in the middle of the Amazon?', 'What's at the very bottom of the ocean?' and 'Where do broken hearts go?' And then the one Horizon picked to examine? Talk about building your part up.

Anyway, this small over-egging aside, the secret Horizon had picked was a good 'un - Lake Vostok buried under four kilometres of ice in the middle of Antarctica. It could be 30 million years old and hold the secrets of the origin of life on earth. Whoooo. The best kind of science'n' nature documentary, Horizon charted the existence of Vostok in men and women's minds from the depths of the Cold War when the Russians were boring holes in the ice above it, eating pounds of butter to keep warm (more effective than vodka, apparently) and weren't even convinced it existed, through to the British airborne radar team who confirmed its existence in the 1970s ("It's half the size of Wales!") to the present day and Nasa's involvement in the project.

While the story of the lake is in itself a gripping yarn, the scientists involved in the programme seemed a bit thick. Speculating about the fate of the life with which Vostok once teemed, they took an awful long time to get to the idea that, in the dark and under the enormous pressure, all the plants and animals died, leaving only teeny tiny microbes. And wondering what see-through insects in a Romanian cave fed off, no one suggested unwitting scientists.

But the most icky bit of Horizon was learning that microbes were the magicians of survival. Imagine a whole lake swarming with miniature Paul Daniels (well, more miniature than usual). Maybe we should leave Vostok well alone.

fields.headline: No: 1750
fields.standfirst: Bernard Matthews
fields.trailText: Bernard Matthews
fields.body:
Appearance
Bootiful.

Erm, are you sure?
No, he's not really beautiful. You know: the adverts on telly with the chirpy farmer outside his Norfolk mansion.

Actually I do know what you're on about. I just prefer not to talk about it. It's too painful.
You're right; they were voted amongst the worst adverts of all time in a hall of fame compiled by Campaign magazine.

Any reason he's in the news right now, apart from the fact that Christmas is coming?
Obviously you're not up to speed with the intricacies of the meat market.

Au contraire - I get lucky almost every Saturday night.
Not that kind of meat market. I'm talking business. I'm talking finance. I'm talking the turkey-eat-turkey world of the Stock Exchange.

Why don't you just tell me what's going on?
Sorry. It seems the City doesn't think the company - worth £232m - is as bootiful as he does, and so we're looking at a management buy-out. He plans to buy it back himself, though.

Who's to stop Bernard buying it back again?
Well it seems US giant Sara Lee is considering tabling a rival offer.

Blimey. And hasn't Matthews been in the news for anything else?
Nothing much recently. He's been keeping a fairly low profile at home in his mansion. In the early 80s large numbers of his workforce sued him, claiming they were suffering from plucking elbow.

Poor pluckers
Hmmmm. Anyway, then he found himself back in court when he was prosecuted for illicitly putting turkey slurry into beef, pork and sausage products.

How could they tell the difference?
I'll ignore that. Next in the late 80s, he was fined for discharging excessive waste into Norfolk's rivers. No just the once either - 27 times.

Making them considerably less bootiful than they were before.
Exactly.

Not to be confused with:
Bernard Manning, Stanley Matthews, Meg Mathews.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Fujimori leads 'manhunt'
fields.body:
Fujimori leads 'manhunt'

The beleaguered president of Peru, Alberto Fujimori, returned empty handed from a dramatic manhunt for his feared former intelligence chief yesterday.

But with no arrest order issued for Vladimiro Montesinos, the president's critics said the spectacular chase near Chaclacayo, 22 miles east of Lima, was staged to impress Peruvians who had lost trust in their leader.
AP, Lima

300 questioned on mob attack

Sri Lankan police detained 300 people for questioning yesterday after a Sinhalese mob, estimated at 3,000 people, attacked a rehabilitation centre for former Tamil soldiers, killing 25 of them.

Survivors accused the police of doing little to halt the violence and of taking part in the attack on Wednesday in Bandarawela.
AP, Bandarawela

Estrada fights bribery claims

The Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, promised yesterday to step down if it is proved that he took £5.8m in bribes from illegal gambling, as has been alleged. The vice-president said he should resign now.
Reuters, Manila

webTitle: Take me to court if you dare, Smith tells Mugabe

fields.headline: Take me to court if you dare, Smith tells Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
Former Rhodesian leader delivers defiant riposte to Zimbabwean president's threat to bring him to trial

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Former Rhodesian leader delivers defiant riposte to Zimbabwean president's threat to bring him to trial
fields.body:
Ian Smith, the former Rhodesian white minority leader, challenged President Robert Mugabe yesterday to carry out his threat to put him on trial.

Mr Smith said he would love the opportunity to tell the world that Mr Mugabe was a "gangster" who had plunged Zimbabwe into anarchy.

Reacting to Mr Mugabe's threat on Wednesday to take him to court, Mr Smith said during a visit to London:"I welcome it. I would love that. Let him try it.

"It would give me the chance to tell the world the truth about this gangster. Our country is in total anarchy.

"I will give him the date and time of arrival of my plane so he can meet me at the airport. I go back on Monday week. Mugabe is like a wounded animal in a corner.

"He is unpredictable and dangerous. He is in a state of panic."

Mr Mugabe told supporters of his party, Zanu-PF, on Wednesday that he would revoke Zimbabwe's national racial reconciliation policy, adopted at independence in 1980, because whites, backed by Britain and the US, were trying to destabilise the country.

"Ian Smith and the whites who participated in the massacre and genocide of our people, those who fought against us, we shall try," he told a few hundred supporters in remarks broadcast on state television.

But analysts said the threats against Mr Smith and other whites would not stand up in court because of amnesties granted to both sides after the 1979 political settlement which ended the seven year liberation war.

The offensive against whites has not succeeded in taking the heat off Mr Mugabe, who is facing an investigation by a parliamentary impeachment committee.

An opinion poll found yesterday that 74% of Zimbabweans want him to step down.

Numerous black Zimbabweans rejected his latest move.

"It's sheer madness and shows that Mugabe is trying to grasp at anything to prop up his dictatorial regime," said Wilfred Mhanda, a former liberation war fighter.

"He tried using the land issue but that did not work, so now he is playing his last card - the racist card. But the people won't buy that."

Mr Mhanda, a leader of the Zimbabwe Liberators' Platform, a group of war veterans who oppose Mr Mugabe's rule, and his supporters are distributing red cards proclaiming "Mugabe must GO now!"

They are urging people to hold them up every day at 1pm.

Tendai Biti, an MP for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, said that if Mr Mugabe instituted some kind of war crimes tribunal, it could question the president's own past; "Such an inquiry is a double-edged sword.

"Mr Mugabe has himself been responsible for lots of atrocities, both during the war and since independence."

fields.headline: Suicide bomber raises new fears
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A dangerous new element was added yesterday to the bloody conflict between Israel and the Palestinians, with the first suicide bomb attack for two years.
fields.body:
A dangerous new element was added yesterday to the bloody conflict between Israel and the Palestinians, with the first suicide bomb attack for two years.

One soldier was slightly injured when a young man pedalled up to an Israeli army post in Gaza on a bicycle and blew himself up. The attack also heralded the first planned operation by an Islamic militant group since the violence began four weeks ago.

For the Israeli security forces the bombing is further evidence that the Palestinian Authority will no longer do its bidding in suppressing militants of the Islamic Jihad and Hamas organisations.

Earlier this week, the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, brought both groups into a decision-making council which meets almost daily to co-ordinate operations against Israeli troops and outposts.

Yesterday's attack was an amateur affair. The bomber, identified as Nabil Areer, a school caretaker in his 20s, packed five kilos of explosives on his back and then rode into a wall when he was challenged by a soldier, according to Israel's commander in Gaza, Major-General Yom-Tov Samia.

But Islamic Jihad, which claimed responsibility for the attack near the Gush Katif block of Jewish settlements in Gaza, pledged further attacks. As did Hamas.

Ismail Abu Shanab, a leading Hamas figure in the group's Gaza stronghold, maintained that the attack was fully endorsed by Mr Arafat's Fatah movement. "There is complete agreement. This is the full national unity of the intifada [uprising]. Everyone is with this intifada now," he said.

Such statements are bound to heighten fears among Israelis following the Palestinian Authority's release of dozens of militants from its jails.

Although most of these prisoners were re-arrested later, the Israeli security forces continue to warn that there could be a spate of suicide bombings.

Palestinian sources, however, say that the most skilled operatives from Hamas and Islamic Jihad are dead and that yesterday's bombing may have been a rogue operation. Fatah officials also say that Mr Arafat is dead set against bomb attacks inside Israel for fear of intensifying the conflict.

But after a month of bloodshed, the question remains: how secure is Mr Arafat's hold over his Fatah militiamen? Many now believe that the Palestinian leader is being forced to ride a wave of radicalism to stay in tune with popular sentiment.

Meanwhile yesterday, the Palestinian Legislative Council denounced Washington's role as a broker in the long-running peace process, and said that the Palestinians wanted the United Nations, the European Union, and possibly Russia to play an active role in negotiations.

"The monopoly of America is over now," said Hassan Asfour, a senior Palestinian official. "The American administration killed the peace process by their methods, by their ideas. They can't be fair, and if they can't be fair, they can't be co-sponsors."

webTitle: Pressure forces Cantab chief to quit

fields.headline: Pressure forces Cantab chief to quit
fields.trailText: Troubled biotechnology firm Cantab Pharmaceuticals has parted company with its chief executive, Jurek Sikorski, just a week after the failure of a genital warts vaccine sent its share price plummeting by two thirds.
fields.body:
Troubled biotechnology firm Cantab Pharmaceuticals has parted company with its chief executive, Jurek Sikorski, just a week after the failure of a genital warts vaccine sent its share price plummeting by two thirds.

Mr Sikorski resigned at a board meeting yesterday, following pressure from the company's non-executive directors. Several major shareholders blame Mr Sikorski for the Cambridge-based company's failure to broaden its research pipeline through mergers or acquisitions.

A Cantab spokesman said: "This is a sad day for us in many respects. But looking ahead, it gives us a fresh start and an opportunity to rebuild confidence."

However, Cantab immediately attracted fresh criticism by appointing controversial financier Jeremy Curnock Cook as its executive deputy chairman, with a mandate to look out for deals.

A former manager of Rothschild's International Biotechnology Trust, Mr Curnock Cook became embroiled in a share dealing scandal over the summer. It emerged that he had been awarded share options worth more than $750,000 (£530,000) in several companies in which IBT had invested.

One major investor in Cantab said: "I'm not sure the market will view this as a positive step. Mr Curnock Cook comes with a strange reputation if you look at his history."

Mr Curnock Cook has served as a non-executive director on Cantab's board for 10 years. The company said Nick Hart, its chief operating officer, would become acting chief executive.

The firm has asked Credit Suisse First Boston to conduct a "strategic review", which will examine the option of selling the business. Takeover talks with a rival vaccine specialist, Peptide Therapeutics, collapsed last month.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: SEC launches Amazon inquiry
fields.body:
SEC launches Amazon inquiry

The US Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an "informal" investigation into accounting practices at Amazon.com, the internet bookseller, according to a report last night on the Wall Street Journal's website.

The commission is asking questions about the way in which the company has valued shares from partner companies, often received in return for advertising on its home page. Some equity deals have been with private enterprises which have no public share price.

A spokesman for Amazon.com was reported to have described the inquiry as "normal" and insisted that the firm had stuck to "generally accepted accounting practices".

US debt relief deal comes in

Britain welcomed news yesterday that Bill Clinton has won backing from Congress to pay America's $435m (£303m) contribution towards global debt relief efforts.

Failure by the US to stump up its share of the costs threatened to endanger the flagship plan to relieve the debts of the poorest countries.

"I am relieved and delighted that Congress has at last recognised that debt relief for the poorest countries is essential to tackling poverty," said Clare Short, the international development secretary. "I hope this means Congress will give increasing support to other international development efforts."

Oil predicted at $10 a barrel

The price of oil could crash to $10 a barrel by the end of 2001, former Saudi Arabian oil minister Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani is expected to announce next week.

The price of crude oil has soared in recent weeks amid rising tension in the Middle East and fears about disruption to supplies, breaking the $35 a barrel level. Yesterday Brent crude oil for delivery in December was trading at around £32.10 a barrel.

Yorkshire Bank fined £100,000

Yorkshire Bank has been fined £100,000 by the investment management regulatory organisation for breach of regulatory rules relating to its PEP. Imro also demanded costs of £55,000.

The breaches, which took place between December 1996 and June 1999, concern the bank's failure to complete customer asset reconciliations, failure to keep records and failures in internal organisation and control, Imro said.

MP confirms aid for Nissan

Britain will give Nissan state aid to make its new Micra model in north-east England if the EC gives permission for the help, a minister said yesterday.

Parliamentary undersecretary Alan Johnson said the government had offered Nissan aid in an effort to secure the Micra project for Sunderland, but that it was subject to EC approval. He did not say how much had been offered.

US debt relief deal comes in Britain welcomed news yesterday that Bill Clinton has won backing from Congress to pay America's $435m (£303m) contribution towards global debt relief efforts. Failure by the US to stump up its share of the costs threatened to endanger the flagship plan to relieve the debts of the poorest countries. "I am relieved and delighted that Congress has at last recognised that debt relief for the poorest countries is essential to tackling poverty," said Clare Short, the international development secretary. "I hope this means Congress will give increasing support to other international development efforts." Oil predicted at $10 a barrel The price of oil could crash to $10 a barrel by the end of 2001, former Saudi Arabian oil minister Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani is expected to announce next week. The price of crude oil has soared in recent weeks amid rising tension in the Middle East and fears about disruption to supplies, breaking the $35 a barrel level. Yesterday Brent crude oil for delivery in December was trading at around £32.10 a barrel. Yorkshire Bank fined £100,000 Yorkshire Bank has been fined £100,000 by the investment management regulatory organisation for breach of regulatory rules relating to its PEP. Imro also demanded costs of £55,000. The breaches, which took place between December 1996 and June 1999, concern the bank's failure to complete customer asset reconciliations, failure to keep records and failures in internal organisation and control, Imro said. MP confirms aid for Nissan Britain will give Nissan state aid to make its new Micra model in north-east England if the EC gives permission for the help, a minister said yesterday. Parliamentary undersecretary Alan Johnson said the government had offered Nissan aid in an effort to secure the Micra project for Sunderland, but that it was subject to EC approval. He did not say how much had been offered.

webTitle: Turkey king wrestles with Sara Lee

fields.headline: Turkey king wrestles with Sara Lee
fields.trailText: Bernard Matthews, the 70-year-old Norfolk turkey farmer best known for his catchphrase "bootiful", was at the centre of a multi-million pound takeover battle yesterday after the US company Sara Lee threatened to gobble up his business.
fields.body:
Bernard Matthews, the 70-year-old Norfolk turkey farmer best known for his catchphrase "bootiful", was at the centre of a multi-million pound takeover battle yesterday after the US company Sara Lee threatened to gobble up his business.

In a day of high drama for the processed poultry group, Mr Matthews made a 185p-a-share offer in the morning to take the firm private by buying the 58% stake his family does not already own, valuing the company at £232m.

Just a few hours later Sara Lee waded in, announcing that it was considering a higher bid after failing to secure agreement with Mr Matthews in talks during the summer.

Mr Matthews said he wanted to take the business off the stock market after becoming frustrated with the fickle nature of investors: "They're all going for what they call electronic companies - they're disregarding smaller companies and food businesses."

He was irritated with stock exchange rules, which forced him to make a takeover offer or sell up when the maturation of some share options earlier this year pushed his stake in the business over 29%: "They forced me to sell some of my shares within seven days. That didn't go down well with me."

A former insurance underwriter, Mr Matthews founded the Bernard Matthews turkey business in 1950 by buying 20 birds' eggs and an incubator for just £2.50. He became a household name by appearing on commercials declaring his turkey steaks to be "bootiful, really bootiful".

The Norwich-based company is now Britain's biggest producer of Christmas turkeys. It makes a range of cooked poultry products and has overseas meat ventures in New Zealand and Hungary.

A Sara Lee spokesman said friendly approaches to Mr Matthews in recent months had yielded little success. The US firm has a variety of activities - its products include Pretty Polly tights, Radox, Brylcreem and Douwe Egbert coffee. The group has already taken a bite out of British industry this year by buying Courtaulds Textiles for £150m.

Analyst David Lang of Investec Henderson Crosthwaite said Bernard Matthews was "arguably the best English food company of its size". He said: "I hate to see it go from the stock market. It's a great business but getting people to buy its shares is like pushing water uphill."

Bernard Matthews' shares jumped 29p to 182.5p.

Plucky past

Bernard Matthews slaughters 15m turkeys a year. In the early 1980s, the entire workforce sued Mr Matthews, claiming they were suffering from tennis elbow due to plucking.

In 1988, Bernard Matthews was fined for discharging waste into Norfolk's rivers 27 times. It has also been prosecuted for illicitly putting mechanically recovered turkey slurry into beef, pork and sausage products.

Unions backed a strike ballot last Christmas in which employees fought a pay offer of just 2.3%.

In 1995, it was reported that the firm's Fish Dinosaurs contained just 37% fish.

Mr Matthews is plagued by strangers shouting "bootiful" at him - this has happened as far afield as France.

fields.headline: Intifada 2000 dwarfs the original
fields.standfirst:
Latest carnage takes its cue from 1987, but is many times more alarming

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Latest carnage takes its cue from 1987, but is many times more alarming
fields.body:
The slings and stones may be familiar, but the past four weeks of Palestinian-Israeli violence bear little resemblance to the intifada of 1987 to 1993. They make it look almost gentlemanly.

This time the mood is different, the nature of the conflict different, and the casualties are on a different scale.

"The main thing is the intensity of killing," says Mahmoud Najjar, a Palestinian from Ramallah. "The number of people killed in the first two weeks of this conflict was the same as the number killed in four months during the previous conflict."

Mr Najjar, who was injured in the original intifada, recalls the mass arrests and the bones broken deliberately by Israeli security forces.

"This time they don't want to arrest people, and there is no policy of broken bones," he says. "They aim to kill - 75% of those shot have been hit in the upper body."

The December 1987 uprising started in a small way with a fatal accident in Gaza involving an Israeli fuel truck.

"I don't think there were any plans for the first intifada," says Bassem Eid, a Palestinian human rights worker. "Something just exploded."

Many believe the Palestine Liberation Organisation was taken by surprise by that outburst, though it eventually came to play an important role.

Today's violence, the Israelis insist, is mainly coordinated by the PLO. At the organisational level there may be a lot of truth in this, but the PLO does not orchestrate people's feelings. Everywhere, ordinary Palestinians talk of anger and frustration.

"In the first intifada people still had some expectations about the future. Today they are so frustrated and hopeless," Mr Eid says.

Many agree that the provocative visit by Ariel Sharon, the Likud leader, to the area around al-Aqsa mosque in Jerusalem at the end of September was not the cause, but the trigger of the conflict.

"There was a ticking bomb that Mr Sharon's visit exploded," Mr Eid says. "The bomb was the difficult situation the Palestinians are living under.

"We have seen no fruits from the Oslo agreement which ended the first intifada. There is continuing settlement, confiscation of land, demolition of homes. We are fighting each other for every centimetre."

Although relatively low-level violence continued after the end of the first intifada, last year was the quietest for more than 12 years, with only nine Palestinians and four Israelis killed. But earlier this year violent incidents began to increase: 32 Palestinians and three Israelis had already been killed before Mr Sharon took his infamous walk up the mount.

The growing number of Jewish settlers is an obvious flash point. At the start of the first intifada there were about 73,000 in the West Bank and Gaza. Today there are 202,000.

The other big change is that the Palestinians now have weapons. "The previous intifada had no military component," says Ghassan Khatib, Palestinian director of the Jerusalem Media and Communication Centre. "There wasn't armed action . . . it was sort of peaceful."

In 1987 to 1993 the Palestinians' lack of weapons played well in the media: the David and Goliath image of youths with stones confronting Israel security forces helped to maintain public sympathy abroad for the underdogs. Today, the use of guns on the Palestinian side could damage that image.

Both sides have had seven years to reflect on their tactics in the first intifada. As a result, says Chris Doyle of the Council for the Advancement of Arab-British Understanding, "the Israelis have bunkered down and are not patrolling the streets".

"This gives them a great advantage," he says. "They're choosing the battlegrounds."

Mr Doyle believes we shall not see the street fighting or the attempts to impose laws on Palestinians that characterised the first intifada. Instead, the Israelis will keep out of the Palestinian areas.

"How could they be firing into these cities unless they were 100% sure their troops were not there?"

Meanwhile, satellite television - not widely available during the first intifada - has given many Palestinians encouragement. It has, they say, raised awareness throughout the Arab world.

Whether awareness will be enough is another matter. It has not so far translated into much practical action by Arab leaders, though some argue that it is beginning to have an effect. Syria, for instance, after years of hostility to the PLO, has begun opening its hospitals to wounded Palestinians.

Despite the casualties, and despite the strong cards held by the Israelis, many Palestinians are convinced that the uprising will succeed in shifting Israel's position.

And if it doesn't? "After two or three years another intifada will start again," Mr Najjar says.

webTitle: Two directors quit MG Rover board

fields.headline: Two directors quit MG Rover board
fields.trailText: The simmering conflict at MG Rover burst into the open yesterday when two of the car group's supervisory board directors resigned.
fields.body:
The simmering conflict at MG Rover burst into the open yesterday when two of the car group's supervisory board directors resigned.

Non-executive directors Brian Parker and Terry Whitmore have left the board of Techtronics, the company which acts as a supervisory board for the Midlands car maker.

The two men, together with David Bowes, a member of the MG Rover executive board, have been at the centre of speculation about a rift in the company.

The resignations came only hours before a full board meeting at which at least three of the four non-executive directors had been expected to voice criticism of John Towers, the former Rover chief executive, who heads the new company. Mr Towers led the Phoenix consortium which bought the car company from BMW for a nominal £10 earlier this year.

There had also been reports that supporters of Mr Towers would seek the resignation of the rebel non-executives.

An industry insider described yesterday's resignations as "a coup d'etat by the quiet Mr Towers".

An MG Rover spokeswoman said that Mr Parker, a West Midlands financier, and Mr Whitmore, a director of the Mayflower engineering group, had quit because of the "rumours and speculation" which had been circulating about them.

She said they were busy men who had other calls on their time and added that they were both still committed to MG Rover. Neither man would be paid compensation and there were no immediate plans to replace them, she said.

She pointed out that David Bowes, the managing director of Lola, the racing car firm which is making an MG car for the next Le Mans endurance race, was staying on, even though he had been reported to be planning a rival car making venture with Mayflower.

Mr Towers is reported to have angered some of the non-executive directors by keeping them in the dark about his plans for an alliance with another car manufacturer.

MG Rover is thought to need a partnership with a big car company that could provide it with a platform for some of its planned new models.

Industry sources said that a link with Proton, the Malaysian car firm, was the most likely, even though Proton has said that it is not interested in any equity deal with MG Rover.

Executive directors of MG Rover said last week that the group was discussing possible partnerships in a variety of areas. They added that they had recently been approached by another car maker, but refused to name the company.

Tony Woodley, the T&G union's chief motor industry negotiator, said: "The business plan for MG Rover, drawn up by Mr Towers and his team, is robust and in place.

"The resignations, for whatever reason, will make absolutely no difference. So for the plant, the workers and the unions it is business as usual."

MG Rover is seeking to make about 200,000 cars a year at its Longbridge plant, including the Rover 25, 45 and 75.

It has been losing market share in the UK in recent months, but officials claim that sales are ahead of internal targets.

The company is planning to introduce a range of "sporty saloon" cars under the MG badge, and to build a new MG sports car on the base of the new Le Mans car.

fields.headline: At this price? BG
fields.trailText: Sids who are pondering what to do with shares in BG may have reason to be confused.
fields.body:
Sids who are pondering what to do with shares in BG may have reason to be confused.

The millions who snapped up shares in privatised British Gas have watched the group endure a number of reinventions of late. First, it split off its retail business Centrica, then this week it divorced Transco - renaming it Lattice - from its international gas business, which is retaining the BG name.

This means that the Sids who purchased gas shares at privatisation could now be holding shares in Centrica, Lattice and the remaining BG. Sids may be even more confused by the fact that the BG shares were trading at 400p before the latest split.

Yesterday, interest focused on BG, cited as a target for a number of international gas groups with Shell's name repeatedly in the frame.

Analysts were wary yesterday of dismissing the speculation out of hand. One said: "You just can never say never. BG is actually attractive to oil majors, not just to Shell".

For BG, the bid rumours are good news; the shares powered ahead to 303p at one stage before settling at 293p, up 7p on the day. The bid talk will give a premium to the shares, which the analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson had reckoned should trade at 310p without taking account of a bid.

This level of 310p is based on the Kleinwort analysts' view that BG is itself a substantial business with similar cost structure to the oil majors. They also point out that its targeted growth of 16% would allow it to outpace the oil groups.

Kleinwort says the shares would be priced fairly at just 275p if the group was excluded from a similar rating to the oil groups. For the Sids who find the remaining BG irresistible, buying the shares at this price may be worth considering as a bidder may have to stump up as much as 350p a share to win.

But the risk is that a bidder might fail to show its hand. In which case, the levels at which the stock is trading seem unlikely to rise.

webTitle: Wales pins its latest tourism drive to the Ryder Cup

fields.headline: Wales pins its latest tourism drive to the Ryder Cup
fields.standfirst: A billionaire's dream could attract golf's transatlantic contest - and big economic benefits
fields.trailText: A billionaire's dream could attract golf's transatlantic contest - and big economic benefits
fields.body:
A consortium fronted by former England cricketer Tony Lewis and backed by the Welsh Development Agency will submit a bid tomorrow to the Professional Golfers Association, the sport's governing body, to host the Ryder Cup in Wales in 2009. The tournament between Europe and America takes place once every two years.

If the Welsh bid wins, the consortium believes the publicity and income generated by the appearance of the likes of Tiger Woods, Lee Westwood and Serge Garcia at the lavishly constructed complex would place Wales firmly on the golfing map and give a much-needed economic boost to the principality.

At the centre of the bid is an unusual regeneration project: the Celtic Manor leisure complex. Overlooking the remnants of Wales' industrial heartland at the end of the M4 motorway near Newport, this leisure centre has been built by Terry Matthews, the electronics billionaire. "There is little doubt that hosting the Ryder Cup at Celtic Manor would greatly enhance the profile of Wales internationally and assist in encouraging overseas firms to invest in Wales," said Sir David Rowe Beddoe, chairman of the WDA.

The economic case for staging the tournament is compelling. The last time Europe hosted the Ryder Cup was in 1997 at Valderrama, Spain, and the local impact was significant. According to the PGA, the immediate economic benefit to Spain was £52.2m. Spectators spent £33.5m in the Andalucia region plus £8.5m in other parts of Spain. More than 70% of spectator spend went into the local economy rather than just the event. Around £11m was spent on accommodation and £10m on flights. Asked to rate the importance of the Ryder Cup to the local economy, local businesses awarded it 4.65 out of a possible 5.

The 2005 Ryder Cup is being held in Ireland and the local minister for tourism, sport and recreation believes it will double the number of golf tourists to the country over the next five years. In television terms only football's world cup attracts more viewers, according to the Welsh camp.

Mr Matthews earned his billion working in Canada but is Welsh to the core. He was born on the hills that surround the course and is determined that the world's top players will grace its greens. Celtic Manor has more than 400 hotel bedrooms and extensive conference facilities. More than 40,000 people attended the recent Welsh Open at the course.

The Welsh bid has an unlikely champion in Spain's Seve Ballesteros: "[The Ryder Cup] should move around Europe and go to different countries, and it's never been in Wales, so why not?" Actress Catherine Zeta Jones and rock band Manic Street Preachers have offered to help.

The Wales bid is being advised by World Sport Group, the company that brought the cricket world cup to England. Consultant Mair Stratton says that the potential impact a Ryder Cup in Newport would have on Welsh golf could be the defining factor.

"The right to host the tournament is not just about putting on the best show, it's largely to do with how a Ryder Cup would help development of the sport in the region.We believe we can build a very strong case around the potential benefits for Welsh golf."

However, the Welsh consortium must negotiate some tricky bunkers. Rival bids are being lodged by Scotland, Slaley Hall in Newcastle, a course in Sweden and the PGA's own course at Caldas near Barcelona. The greatest competition is likely to come from a Scotland bid being co-ordinated by Glen Kirton, the man who masterminded the Euro 96 football tournament, and Sweden, which has experienced a surge in interest in the sport.

A decision is expected in January. If the Wales bid wins, they might even hear the roar of the Welsh dragon from the 19th hole at St Andrews.

Actress Catherine Zeta Jones and rock band Manic Street Preachers have offered to help. The Wales bid is being advised by World Sport Group, the company that brought the cricket world cup to England. Consultant Mair Stratton says that the potential impact a Ryder Cup in Newport would have on Welsh golf could be the defining factor. However, the Welsh consortium must negotiate some tricky bunkers. The greatest competition is likely to come from a Scotland bid being co-ordinated by Glen Kirton, the man who masterminded the Euro 96 football tournament, and Sweden, which has experienced a surge in interest in the sport. fields.headline: Invensys quashes talk
fields.trailText: Invensys, the engineering group, yesterday quashed speculation that it was a takeover target but left open the possibility of floating its power systems business.
fields.body:
Invensys, the engineering group, yesterday quashed speculation that it was a takeover target but left open the possibility of floating its power systems business.

Its shares had risen 33p over the past 10 days after reports it had received more than one approach.

Sources were quoted as suggesting advisers close to US engineering firm Tyco International and ABB of Sweden had been looking at Invensys with "more than normal interest".

Yesterday morning the company issued a stock market statement which read: "Invensys notes the speculation in this morning's press and states that it is not currently in discussions with any third party. The company continues to consider options to enhance shareholder value."

But the company, which initially saw its shares sink on the news, recovered on the back of disposal talk to close the session up 1.75p at 162.5p.

webTitle: Switzerland opens up a Pandora's box

fields.headline: Switzerland opens up a Pandora's box
fields.standfirst: Zurich is trying to end banking secrecy. But has the industry come to terms with the clean-up?
fields.trailText: Zurich is trying to end banking secrecy. But has the industry come to terms with the clean-up? asks Peter Capella in Geneva.
fields.body:
Swiss banking has long been tarnished by accusations that it has shielded political corruption, organised crime and fraud in the name of client confidentiality. On Monday UBS and Crédit Suisse will attempt to blow away this image with a voluntary due diligence code that is likely to be tougher than legal standards in most of the countries where the 12 Swiss banks do business.

But it will largely reflect anti-money laundering laws enforced in Switzerland since 1998. "Our banks provide quality service and you must realise that those who assail banking secrecy are not all, by any means, motivated by noble ethical considerations", Kaspar Villiger, the finance minister, said this week.

After their experience under the spotlight in recent years the Swiss are swift to seize on other countries' shortcomings.

Britain and the US fare badly: Swiss magistrates complain about a lack of American cooperation in inquiries into alleged embezzlement of IMF funds for Russia. Tolerance of the Channel Islands' regime is privately regarded as double standards, and while the Swiss claim to have frozen more than £40m of Yugoslav assets under European financial sanctions against Yugoslavia, the EU's record is shrouded in secrecy.

Officials say only one member, Sweden, made an obligatory declaration to the European commission's sanctions office about the amount blocked.

Britain's Treasury says client confidentiality at banks prevents it from publicising the amount; another EU member is said to have invoked banking secrecy. The Swiss take these matters seriously. Banking comprises 15% of Swiss output and employs 200,000. One third of the global private banking market is estimated to be in the control of the Swiss. The anti-sleaze campaign, spearheaded by Mr Villiger, has kept Switzerland off international blacklists of offshore centres.

Anti-bribery agenda

Mark Pieth, head of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's anti-bribery group - who helped draw up the new code - estimates that Swiss police have tackled about 300 high-profile international money laundering cases over the past decade.

Now regulators are looking at other countries. "The obvious profit motive is to get their competitors to do the same thing in the Bahamas," Mr Pieth said. "I have the feeling the big banks are trying to get used to life after banking secrecy."

Discretion was a tradition of Geneva's private banking families in the 19th century, but secrecy was enshrined as a law in Switzerland in 1934 to stop Nazi Germany prying into the accounts of opponents or Jewish business people.

Old fashioned secrecy became untenable from the moment Swiss magistrates started helping their Italian colleagues to chip away at the Mafia's finances in the 1980s. In 1986, the Philippines sought the return of about $660m hoarded by former president Marcos in Swiss accounts - an inquiry which led to the introduction of money laundering laws.

Banks were eventually forced to waive secrecy for the first time in the search for Holocaust assets. They now acknowledge that their early handling of the affair, culminating in a $1.3bn out of court settlement led by Crédit Suisse and UBS in New York this year, was callous.

Since April 1998, banks in Switzerland have been compelled to check the identity of account holders and beneficiaries. Any suspicious transactions or assets must be reported to the authorities and blocked without notifying the account holder.

They are also required to freeze accounts when magistrates ask them to do so in criminal cases, international legal assistance, and a civil proceedings such as those related to divorce, inheritance or bankruptcy. Investigating magistrates have access to details of account transactions under a freezing order. Suspicion can start with a four figure cash deposit or a "politically exposed person".

While the laws are in place, it has been a struggle to make them bite. All six staff of the federal police's two-year-old money laundering authority have resigned in recent months because they feel stifled.

Recent events have not helped. Swiss magistrates froze about $620m of Nigerian assets allegedly embezzled by the late dictator Sani Abacha last year at the Nigerian government's request. After a separate inquiry, the federal banking commission sanctioned or reprimanded 12 banks, including Crédit Suisse and six Swiss subsidiaries of foreign banks, for handling the money despite self-regulation in the 1990s.

Naming and shaming cost

"The naming and shaming used for the first time adds to the cost of acquiring such clients", Niklaus Blattner, head of the Swiss Bankers' Association, admits.

It also highlighted the global nature of money laundering in the era of swift wire transfers and free-flowing capital. Several hundred million dollars flowed between Britain, the US and Switzerland, according to the banking commission. Lawyers acting on behalf of the Nigerian government and a Swiss magistrate have a paper trail that stretches from Brazil to Japan.

"Abacha will be a good learning case for all banks. It's a bit like Three Mile Island - we escaped a major catastrophe and we have to learn from it", Mark Pieth says.

Switzerland's next challenge is EU pressure to get rid of the last bastion of banking secrecy - tax evasion. Mr Villiger is suggesting that his solution, a 35% withholding tax on savings and foreign dividends instead of systematic surveillance, is better and might be considered by EU members themselves. It would also preserve the secrecy law.

Yet ask the finance ministry or a Swiss bank how much secrecy is worth, and they cannot put a figure on it. Mr Blattner says: "I'm sure that with competition increasing, quality and price are important, innovation is certainly influential, but let's say that secrecy is diminishing."

webTitle: Dead sailor sheds light on Kursk tragedy

fields.headline: Dead sailor sheds light on Kursk tragedy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: In pitch-black darkness sometime after the explosions which sent the Kursk to the bottom of the ocean, Lieutenant-Captain Dmitri Kolesnikov realised that he was not going to survive.
fields.body:
In pitch-black darkness sometime after the explosions which sent the Kursk to the bottom of the ocean, Lieutenant-Captain Dmitri Kolesnikov realised that he was not going to survive.

As he waited to die, he wrote a careful account of what had happened in the submarine, apparently for the benefit of naval officials. Then he turned over the piece of paper and composed a goodbye letter to his wife Olga, feeling his way to trace the words across the page in the dark.

This letter, barely legible and soaked through with sea water, was found yesterday in one of the pockets in his uniform, shortly after his corpse was dragged out of the nuclear submarine's ravaged hull.

Most of the information was judged too personal - and possibly too politically sensitive - for public consumption. But the few lines which were released gave a grim insight into how the 118 men in the Kursk died, confirming the worst fears of their relatives that some sailors did survive the initial explosions and were trapped for hours, if not days, inside the submarine.

Until yesterday Russian officials propagated the theory that all the sailors had died in the minutes after the accident. But Kolesnikov's letter reveals that at least 23 men remained alive - some of them making a desperate and hopeless attempt to escape.

The news raised the highly contentious question of whether lives could have been saved if Russia had not initially refused offers of foreign help in the rescue operation.

These men, all based in the five rear compartments of the submarine, broke strict submarine protocol and abandoned their posts soon after disaster struck. They must have realised that their colleagues at the front of the submarine had died immediately in the blast which ripped through the vessel's first three sections on the morning of August 12.

Hoping to save themselves, they defied orders and passed from one section to the next, gathering in the ninth section, in the stern of the submarine, where the only rear escape hatch was located. Kolesnikov, who was 27 when he died, wrote that two or three men were going to try to escape through this hatch. When this failed, they realised that there was no way of getting out and could do nothing but prepare themselves for death.

As the senior officer in the 7th section - commander of the turbine engine room - Kolesnikov took it upon himself to justify the actions of his men, in the only part of his letter that has been made public.

The glowing hands of his luminous wristwatch - a tiny spot of light in the submarine's blackened interior - allowed him to note the precise time of composition.

The chief of staff of the northern fleet, Vice-Admiral Mikhail Motsak, said that the note was written between 1.34pm and 3.15pm on the day of the disaster. Foreign and Russian ships in the area registered two powerful explosions from the accident site at around 11.30am.

"All personnel from sections six, seven and eight have moved to section nine," the note states. "There are 23 of us here. We have made this decision because none of us can escape." Kolesnikov's writing then becomes illegible, apart from the figures 13 and 5, followed by the words - in an apparent reference to the darkness - "I am writing blind".

It was not clear why the men were unable to put on diving costumes and leave through the escape hatch. Some experts suggested that the hatch might have been damaged in the blast.

Igor Spassky, head of the Rubin design bureau, which built the Kursk, said that they should have been able to get out this way, but might have been hampered by injuries.

Nor was it clear when or how the survivors finally died: water may have flooded in during the abortive escape attempt, killing those sailors who had gathered in that section, or they may have died from hypothermia or high pressure, or from the fierce fire which is thought to have swept through the vessel.

Four bodies were found on Wednesday, hours after a Russian military diver began the highly dangerous search inside the submarine. All four have been taken to a mobile forensic science unit at the naval base of Severomorsk, but Kolesnikov is the only sailor to have been named.

The other three corpses are said to have been so badly disfigured that identification is proving difficult.

A naval memorial ceremony will be held at the base next week, before the bodies are flown back to their home towns for individual funerals. Kolesnikov, the son of a submariner, is due to be buried in St Petersburg on Wednesday.

In a brief television interview his widow, so crippled by grief that she could hardly stand, said: "I had a feeling that he was alive and I felt a pain. Now I see that there was a reason for this pain."

Attempts to recover further bodies were postponed yesterday because stormy weather made the operation too dangerous. Further attempts will now focus on the ninth compartment, where most of the 23 men are thought to have died.

Officials did not say whether Kolesnikov's note described in detail how the Kursk went down.

The government has yet to give an official explanation for the disaster, although senior naval officials continue to favour the theory that the accident was caused by a collision with a foreign submarine, rather than by a second world war mine or by an internal malfunction resulting in the blast.

But the limited information which was released proved in itself extremely controversial, highlighting new contradictions in the officials' earlier statements.

Earlier this month the deputy prime minister and head of the commission investigating the disaster Ilya Klebanov said the initial investigations had indicated that the almost all the sailors would have died before the vessel hit the bottom of the Barents Sea.

Kolesnikov's testimony gives new credence to the navy's original reports that sailors could be heard knocking "SOS. Water" distress signals for three days after the disaster.

In the aftermath of the crisis, officials said they had been mistaken and that the noises were probably just rumblings of collapsing machinery and water flooding into the hull.

Relatives of the dead men gathered in the closed naval town of Vidyayevo, where the Kursk was based, said the news confirmed their worst fears.

"It's like having our hearts ripped open again," one woman said.

fields.headline: This judge's humane decision
fields.standfirst:
The treatment of the boys in the Bulger case is a credit to our society

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The treatment of the boys in the Bulger case is a credit to our society
fields.body:
A decision which makes the release of the two boys responsible for the horrific killing of James Bulger more likely was bound to attract the vilification of the still grieving Bulger family and any others who have been in the position of losing a loved in similar circumstances.

The horror of this particular crime seems to have been increased by the fact that the killers themselves were so young and no more than babies in many people's eyes.

And so it must be right that decisions to do with the punishment of these two boys, raising as they do extremes of public emotion, are being taken not by a politician but by a judge, who is capable of taking into account the welfare of the boys as well as the views of the Bulger family.

The lord chief justice yesterday made a characteristically humane decision in the case of the two boys who killed James Bulger, when he decided that the term they must serve for punishment - in other words for deterrence and retribution, known as the "tariff" is eight years and has now expired.

The tariff was previously fixed by the home secretary, and this decision was referred to the court by Jack Straw, the present home secretary, following a ruling of the European court of human rights in Strasbourg that it was a violation of the boys' human rights for the home secretary to intervene in the sentencing process.

These two boys could soon be released and are, in the lord chief justice's view, ready to begin the difficult process of rehabilitation in the wider world. But apparently no matter how much time passes, when one remembers again the facts of the crime, the horror remains undimmed.

In announcing his decision in open court, Lord Woolf remembered the "horrendous" nature of the crime but emphasised that the "one overriding mitigating feature of the offence is the age of the two boys when the crime was committed. However grave their crime, the fact remains that if that crime had been committed a few months earlier, when they were under 10, the boys could not have been tried or punished by the courts".

He had also consulted relatives of James Bulger and considered expert evidence which indicated that the boys "have made striking progress in the secure units where they have been detained...The reports draw a vivid picture of two boys who have significantly improved over the years...Significantly, the assessments generally agree that both of these young men are genuinely extremely remorseful about the crime which they committed and the effect which it must have had on James's family. In addition, neither has shown any aggression or propensity for violence during his period of detention."

The law lords have recognised that there must be a different approach when considering the punishment of a child-offender distinct from that to be applied to an adult. In particular it was stated that any policy which "ignored at any stage the child's development and progress while in custody as a factor relevant to his eventual release date is an unlawful policy".

There is a requirement to keep the protection and welfare of a child under review throughout the period he is in custody. This must surely be the right approach and it is the one which Lord Woolf has adopted.

There can be no case for detaining these boys indefinitely and if as is said they have made significant progress and improvement then the time has come to move the process on.

The final decision regarding release rests with the parole board, who will hear more evidence on the issue of dangerousness and determine a plan for release which will necessarily involve close supervision, monitoring and support.

Lord Woolf's decision is not binding on the parole board and his decision is only the gateway to the long process of rehabilitation; it is certainly not the case that the boys will suddenly be released into the community to fend for themselves or to create havoc.

The reality, as Lord Woolf pointed out, is that their lives will never be "normal" again, and even if released on licence they will forever live under the shadow of being recalled to prison if they do not abide by the terms of their licence.

This case is reminiscent of that of Mary Bell, who killed two children at the age of 11 and was released aged 23. She has apparently made the transition from child-killer to mother. She has by all accounts been successfully rehabilitated. Surely it is a credit to our society and the systems which regulate it that it is possible to bring about such changes, which may enable these boys to lead useful lives.

Aswini Weereratne is a barrister at Doughty Street chambers, specialising in human rights and mental health.
