fields.headline: Profits warning hits AEA shares
fields.standfirst: Nuclear spin-off hurt by contract delays
fields.trailText: Nuclear spin-off hurt by contract delays
fields.body:
AEA Technology lost a third of its stock market value yesterday after the engineering and science company warned that its interim results would be well below expectations.

The board said first-half pre-tax profits would be around £3m, against expectations of £9.5m. A stronger performance during the second half would not be enough to prevent full-year profits dropping below last year's £31m.

The group's shares fell 162.5p immediately after the announcement before rallying a little to close 140p down at 346p. About 3m of the shares changed hands. The normal level is about 200,000 a day.

This is not the first time the group has caught the market on the hop. A full-year profit warning in March last year wiped 40% off its share price.

The group, spun off from the Atomic Energy Authority in September 1996, was floated at 280p a share.

The board blamed the latest collapse in profits mainly on a delay in the award of three contracts to its engineering software division. It expects the contracts will come through during the second half. But it said the complexity of the multi-licence and multi-year deals meant the shortfall was unlikely to be made up.

The group said trading in other divisions was faltering. Its battery business had been affected by the delays in the Ministry of Defence's Bowman battlefield radio programme while the performance of its environmental and nuclear technology operations were slightly below forecast.

In addition there would be a £2m restructuring cost as a result of a reshaping the intellectual property rights portfolio of the future technologies division "in preparation for a more creative exploitation of its value".

The division is in effect the group's incubator business. Among its activities is work on lithium ion batteries for applications such as mobile phones.

On the upside, a first half improvement by the group's rail services and products operation, which includes signalling technology, is expected to continue into the second half.

Sir Tony Cleaver, the chairman, said: "Since flotation the company's strategy has been to focus the business on those activities which are able to deliver sustained value."

The board has decided to appoint a chief operating officer with marketing and sales experience as a first step towards realising value from the group's assets and operations. Sir Anthony said there would be other senior appointments.

webTitle: Leader: BSE report is too weak

fields.headline: Who will carry the can?
fields.standfirst:
The BSE report should have been tougher

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The BSE report should have been tougher.
fields.body:
Is it a Whitehall whitewash? Lord Phillips, the judge who headed the BSE inquiry, denied it yesterday on publication of his 16 volume report on how mad cow disease spread and finally infected humans. Indeed there is a long list of faults, some familiar, some not, set out in the report. There are four pages at the end of volume one in which the criticisms made against specific individuals are brought together and catalogued. Yet, given the scale of the scandal and the length of the £16m inquiry, the judge has pulled his punches.

BSE is an unprecedented bungle which has led to 170,000 cows being infected, 4.7m cows slaughtered, almost £5bn paid out in compensation to farmers and meat renderers, and a thriving high-quality meat export industry destroyed. Most serious of all, we still do not know how many people are infected by vCJD (variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease), the human form of BSE, because of the long incubation period.

Thankfully, experts believe that early estimates which suggested it could be in the hundreds of thousands or even millions now look implausible. So far, there have only been 85 victims of whom 80 are dead. The acting chairman of the government's main advisory committee, Prof Peter Smith, thought yesterday the most likely number would be a few hundred or perhaps several thousands, though he could not rule out tens of thousands.

Those who criticised the European ban on British beef should ask themselves what they would have thought about diseased continental beef being brought into Britain. A key admission in the report is that BSE began in Britain but spread to Europe. The numbers there are still tiny, but like Britain's epidemic, the true effects may not yet be visible. Lord Phillips compared the disease to a chain letter, which can spread far and wide before anyone is aware.

The long list of faults that Lord Phillips documents include the government playing down the links between BSE and vCJD; poor enforcement of the 1989 ban on beef offal (the brain and spinal cord that carry the infection) entering the human food chain; poor communication between the Departments of Health and Agriculture; no contingency planning even years after the final evidence of the link between BSE and vCJD had been established; inappropriate use of scientists; and perhaps most serious of all, delays and denials which led the public to feeling deceived. This last fault will undermine subsequent health prevention programmes for years.

So where have punches been pulled? The report notes that the 1989 Southwood report on BSE, which thought it "unlikely" that BSE would have implications for human health, also added that if the assessment was wrong the implications would be serious. The Southwood reassurance was "repeatedly cited" but the warning was lost from sight.

Who lost it? Clearly the agriculture minister, John Gummer. Worse still, the assurances did not keep up with changing evidence. The public were never told. But who failed to tell them? John Gummer. The former Tory minister is criticised for playing down the risk - but never as severely as he deserves. Similarly, the government's chief vet, who warned in 1987 that "irresponsible and ill-informed publicity" could lead to hysterical demands for draconian action, can count himself lucky to get off so lightly.

The report is not scathing enough about government secrecy - even between departments. The health department was left uninformed at various crucial points. Then when it was shown in 1990 that BSE had jumped to a cat - signalling its capacity to jump species - pet food manufacturers were told ahead of health officials. All of which should make MPs insist that the freedom of information (FOI) bill now before parliament is radically improved. At present factual information to do with health hazards is exempt from access; the findings of safety authorities, like agriculture inspectors, are protected. Parliament must demand greater openness.

Finally, a belated compensation fund for the families of victims has been created. Compared to the £5bn for farmers, this is tiny: a mere £1m. It is scandalous that they have had to wait so long. In the light of the catalogue of failures this report uncovers, the least that parliament should demand is a level of compensation which fully recognises the truly dreadful damage that has been done.

webTitle: Top thinktank calls for increase in interest rates

fields.headline: Top thinktank calls for increase in interest rates
fields.trailText: One of the country's top economic thinktanks has urged the Bank of England to raise interest rates 0.5% to ensure the government hits its inflation target.
fields.body:
One of the country's top economic thinktanks has urged the Bank of England to raise interest rates 0.5% to ensure the government hits its inflation target.

Siding with the hawks in the City, who say rates have further to rise, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said the strength of economic growth, the rise in oil prices and rapidly falling unemployment meant the risks of monetary policy being too loose outweighed the risks of it being too tight.

"In view of this, the MPC should raise rates to 6.5% by the beginning of next year and we have assumed this in our forecast," said the National Institute in its quarterly review published today.

The institute has consistently been one of the most accurate economic forecasters in recent years and its view on rates challenges the assumption priced into financial markets that rates have peaked.

Barring any major policy errors or macroeconomic shocks, the institute said the economy could look forward to at least two more years of strong growth, with output predicted to expand 3.6% next year and 3.1% in 2002.

While the tightness of the labour market meant earnings growth would increase, this would be offset by strong productivity growth of close to 3% in each year.

Backing the analysis of many City economists, the National Institute said buoyant growth ensured there would be a budget surplus of £15bn this year, £10bn more than projected by the chancellor in March.

But that did not justify any relaxation of fiscal policy, which could put further upward pressure on interest rates.

The institute said the strength of the public finances appeared to make more generous state pensions affordable. "However, a proper assessment should take into account the effects of population ageing on a pay-as-you-go pension system."

webTitle: Comment: International failures of Clinton decade

fields.headline: The US and Europe haven't managed our world too well
fields.standfirst:
Failures litter the international scene after the Clinton decade

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Failures litter the international scene after the Clinton decade
fields.body:
When Milosevic fell in the same week that fighting broke out between Israelis and Palestinians, was this merely a matter of the coincidence of bad news and good news that always marks human affairs? What are we to make of this arrival of peace in one place and loss of it in another? The difference between the good and the bad news is not as great as it might seem, and not only because the problems are far from over in the Balkans or because something may be patched up in the Middle East. In the one case, flawed policy just barely achieved a kind of success, and, in the other, flawed policy has led to a tragic failure. The flaws, too, were of a similar order - policy driven by domestic pressures, policy that paid too little attention to the facts on the ground, and policy too wary of difficulties and costs.

A decade that began in an atmosphere of great confidence in many countries and across the political spectrum has ended with a sharp reminder of limits and an unmistakable loss of momentum. Remember that good was supposed to build on good. A peace in one place would lead to a peace in another, a successful intervention in one region could be a model for others elsewhere, and the gradual accretion of new international institutions would eventually change the framework in which all societies made their decisions. The hope was for synergy. Failures certainly littered the decade - the Rwandas and Srebrenicas, the downward plunge of the Russian economy, the Asian economic crash, and all the rest of it - but for those keeping score it was possible to feel that the successes were the precedents rather than the other way round.

The change now may be a diminishing of that sense that a broad improvement is under way. Consider how attitudes to "people power" have shifted. In Serbia and now in the Ivory Coast the removal of a leader who had lost, or never enjoyed, legitimacy may be welcomed - but "people power" is not seen as the magic potion that it once seemed to be. Indeed, in the Philippines, one of people power's most striking successes, we may be coming round for a second dose, and, if so, it will be with a certain weariness.

The sense of foreboding arises at this moment in part because this decade was Bill Clinton's decade and in part because his presidency is finishing with such a defeat in the Middle East. Clinton's departure will mark the end, if not of an era, at least of a time when the United States had extraordinary opportunities which are unlikely to reoccur. Clinton was a world leader in a way in which neither George Bush or Al Gore can be in the future. This was because America had a capital of influence and power when he took over which is now much drawn down. Much of the world was awed, ready to listen, and, up to a point, ready to be persuaded.

But America under Clinton did not use its influence to the full or to the best effect, whether in the Far East, south Asia, Russia, or in the Balkans. Above all, in the Middle East it was by turns serious and timorous in its campaign to isolate and bring down Saddam Hussein and it was slow and often partial in its mediation between Israelis and Palestinians. In the dismal towns of the West Bank and Gaza the bitterness which led to the collapse of the peace process was meanwhile brewing. The daily bombing of Iraq, now an activity entirely divorced from any coherent strategy for dealing with that country, is one index of America's failure. The savage daily encounters between Israeli and Palestinian young men, boys who grew up during these Clinton years, is another. Perhaps American power to change the Middle East was not as great as it seemed. But Clinton was not the man to test it to the limit. His successor will find it hard indeed to mend matters and may not seriously try.

If these were the years in which America failed to live up to its potential, that was also true of Europe, which notoriously mishandled the crisis in former Yugoslavia. But America and Europe together did, in the end, adopt policies which halted the Serbian campaign in Bosnia and later forced a withdrawal from Kosovo, which in turn contributed to Milosevic's fall. A new report by an independent international commission charts how Kosovo was allowed to fester to the point where Serbian suppression of rebellion provoked Nato intervention. It allows that this intervention was "illegal but legitimate". In its broader conclusions, it states in a measured way the need for early engagement in the kind of situations which could produce violations of human rights on a scale that may later give grounds for a humanitarian military intervention. If, as a last resort, such intervention becomes necessary, it proposes "a principled framework" for it, which it would like the United Nations to take up in some way. These are of course sound conclusions, to which a UN secretary general such as Kofi Annan will be sympathetic and some of which he has already anticipated in other reports he has commissioned.

What is striking about the Kosovo report, like those others, for all their criticism of the behaviour of governments and international organisations, is their essential optimism. They look to a managed world, in which most disasters are headed off by preventative action, and others are dealt with, when they have to be, by the judicious use of force. But whether the US after Clinton, or a muddled European Union, uncertain of its own course and far from agreed on external policies, are in a position to learn the lessons laid out is another question. In any case, the potentially grave regional crises which the world could face, such as a further breakdown in the Middle East, a confrontation between nuclear armed India and Pakistan over Kashmir, or a clash between China and Taiwan, are of an order in which humanitarian expeditions are irrelevant. It is only in the context of the containment of these larger conflicts that these lesser, internal problems may be amenable to solution.

One lesson that has been understood is that such quarrels are more obdurate than is sometimes lightly assumed. Europe's less than inspired efforts to deal with its Balkan problem were, with American help, eventually successful, but only just. They absorbed the European Union's energies and distracted it from other tasks. The United States took especial responsibility - to the point of largely excluding other outside powers - for the Middle East and has nevertheless brought it to the present pass. The past 10 years should have been a time when the US and Europe, the two wealthiest and most developed regions, took a strong grip on affairs. Instead they have come perilously close to losing it.

The Kosovo Report, The Independent International Commission on Kosovo, Oxford.

webTitle: Leader: Decision on Bulger's killers right

fields.headline: Not popular, but right
fields.standfirst:
Justice ought to allow for redemption

Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Justice ought to allow for redemption.
fields.body:
The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, must have known that there would be outrage if he cut the 15-year sentence which the Conservative home secretary Michael Howard ordered for the two young men who murdered James Bulger. In the event, he has cut it by even more than some of his liberal colleagues expected, reinstating the eight-year tariff set by the trial judge.

His decision is courageous and right. Mr Howard insisted the release of the two young killers should not be based purely on the risk that they posed, but also on "public acceptability". Stacked in his office then were boxes of vouchers from Sun readers, insisting that the two killers be detained for life. But the reason for having a criminal justice system is to lift sentencing above mob rule. The Howard approach came dangerously close to the traditions of lynch law.

The reason why Lord Woolf was required to set a new tariff yesterday was a ruling in the European court of human rights last year, declaring the sentencing powers of British home secretaries "unlawful" under the European convention. Yesterday's judgment is bound to reopen the attack on the court. But it is not only foreign judges who see it as crucial to take sentencing out of the hands of the politicians: most British policy-making bodies do so too. Two all-party parliamentary committees have backed it, the House of Lords has made unsuccessful attempts to add this change to various criminal justice bills and the British judiciary is united on the principle.

Punishment, Lord Woolf argued in an interview earlier this week, should be a mixture of retribution, deterrence, reparation and rehabilitation. But that last ingredient, he signalled, was perhaps the most important of all: "... above all, you want to try to achieve a sentence which will make the likelihood of that person leading a lawful life in the future greater, not less". These are not normal offenders. They were extremely damaged young people, who under the psychological and social care staff of the secure units have made enormous progress, including acceptance of the enormity of their crime.

The anger of the Bulger family is wholly understandable. When families suffer such a terrible trauma, pumping up retributive instincts helps keep them going. Yet medical studies show that in the long term that reaction is not enough. Hard though it comes, some form of forgiveness is needed for scars to heal.

webTitle: Leader: More flags in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Put out more flags
fields.standfirst:
There are so many royals to celebrate

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: There are so many royals to celebrate.
fields.body:
With the Middle East peace process in ruins, the focus returns this weekend to the process in Northern Ireland. There are two big interrelated issues at stake. One is the future of David Trimble. The other is the number of occasions per year on which the union flag must fly at full mast above official buildings.

The secretary of state, Peter Mandelson, has displeased Sinn Fein by stipulating the figure 17. How entrancing it is to learn that among the 17 occasions for celebration is the birthday of the Countess of Wessex (January 20)! There are few more enchanting figures in public life today than the former Sophie Rhys-Jones and it seems churlish of Sinn Fein to object to hauling up the red, white and blue ensign in her honour.

Indeed, the question is why Mr Mandelson has stopped at 17. There are many young and appealing members of the royal family whose birthdays would - if properly celebrated by flags - surely help unite the troubled people of Northern Ireland. May we start the ball rolling by suggesting that April 6 be henceforth celebrated across the six counties as Lord Freddy Windsor Day?

fields.headline: Onwards and upwards
fields.standfirst:
Prince Charles is prepared to see a Roman Catholic on the throne. And now the Speaker is a Catholic too...

Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: the new Speaker
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Prince Charles is prepared to see a Roman Catholic on the throne. And now the Speaker is a Catholic too...
fields.body:
Michael Martin has become the first Roman Catholic Speaker since the Reformation. Prince Charles wishes to see the Act of Settlement overturned so that our monarch may be Catholic too. What a pity these news stories didn't appear earlier in the month when the "The Future of Multi-ethnic Britain" was published by the Runnymede Trust. They are reminders of the history of a religious minority and it is one that offers relevant lessons to us today.

There was no Norman Tebbit talking about patriotic cricket tests for us Catholics back in the 16th century. We had an Armada test instead. Would you support the Spanish, who were foreign but Catholic, or the queen, who was your head of state, but had a papal fatwa on her head? Some went one way and some the other, as they did for generations after, either plotting against their monarchs or laying down their life for him. Neither behaviour was recognised as unpatriotic by Catholics, but that was the way they were all seen by the Protestant majority.

Protestantism came to define English, and, later, British, patriotism. With religion viewed as the benchmark of what it was to be a loyal subject, Catholics continued to be viewed with mistrust for a very long time after the last English Catholic plot or Highland Scottish rebellion. My English great, great, great-grandfather took a commission in the Austrian army because as a Catholic he was unable to do so here. Following Catholic emancipation, the family produced a fine Victorian general who would have been seen in the rather prominent way that Asian and black Britons are now. For some he would have represented a more interesting and tolerant Britain, while others would have viewed him as vaguely foreign and quite possibly dangerous.

It wasn't until Catholics had died like cattle alongside their Protestant kin in the trenches of the first world war that the slur on their patriotism began to lose its power. It has taken almost another century for it to be forgotten. This is unsurprising when each generation has been taught a history in which the Reformation is seen as a big step in the onwards, upwards direction of the British people.

But I am not against a positive rendition of our past. It is very important that our children grow up with a sense of national pride. I am just glad I was taught a Catholic-coloured view of British history, in which we were noble folk fighting for our beliefs and not fanatical fifth columnists.

My school lessons left me comfortable enough in my skin to judge that our later Catholic monarchs left much to be desired. And while the stories of persecution inspired respect for those who suffered for their faith, I never felt any hatred for the persecutors, who lived in different times with different rules and attitudes - let alone their descendants. After all, there is no persecution now. This experience makes me think that those of us on the bluer end of the political spectrum should be more relaxed about Asian or Afro-Caribbean children having British history presented with an Asian or African slant. That means exorcising a white supremacist view of history, but also its twin, the leftwing song of woe about wicked oppressor and poor suffering oppressed.

Teaching a history in which the British empire is entirely wicked and its dark skinned subjects entirely miserable is not only inaccurate and damaging to the white majority, it could have a very demoralising effect on those it might be intended to support.

I have been struck by the mixed race Britons who are informed on television that their great, great grandparents were slaves. Their distress contrasts sharply with the glee of the TV presenters and their genealogists. People do not want to be descended from victims and the history of our minorities should not be couched simply in terms of victimhood. In the case of the Catholic recusant families, pride has eased their slow entry into establishment.

Now that the Prince of Wales is talking about tearing down the Act of Settlement, can disestablishment of the Church of England be far behind? I hope not, because it would serve only to disestablish faith and that is something no religious minority would want. A letter quoted in the Runnymede report notes how "... secular society tends to push religion ... to the margins of public space ... Islamaphobia and anti-semitism merge with a more widespread rejection of religion which runs through a significant part of 'tolerant' society, including the educated middle class and the progressive media".

Anti-Catholic bigotry today comes from the liberal left and it is interesting that the Runnymede commission member and sociologist, Tariq Modood, far from wishing to boot Anglican bishops out of the House of Lords, would prefer to see other religions similarly represented. However the history of the Catholic minority in Britain indicates that it may be unnecessary for the soul to reside in the spleen. An elected Catholic speaker is worth a hundred Jesuit Lords.

fields.headline: Planning blocks on wind power
fields.trailText: Agents for the Queen are trying to speed up an expansion in wind powered electricity which is being blocked by red tape.
fields.body:
Agents for the Queen are trying to speed up an expansion in wind powered electricity which is being blocked by red tape.

The crown estates are backing moves to end planning obstacles for offshore wind farms, projects which would bring in cash for the Queen as chief owner of British coastal waters and seabed.

Tony Blair this week promised extra cash for renewable energy research, including £25m for capital start-up costs for wind energy. Britain has a target to meet 10% of its energy needs from renewables by 2010, of which over 50% is expected to come from wind farms.

However, offshore wind entrepreneurs say they are being blocked especially in securing planning permission for sites owned by the crown estates. These agents own all British waters up to at least 12 miles from the shore; therefore almost all offshore wind farms will be leased from the Queen.

The crown estates said yesterday it was eager to lease waters to entrepreneurs, but accepted that a planning vacuum was blighting the industry. Frank Parrish, a spokesman, said: "There is an urgent need to simplify the planning procedure. There is no system of planning consent for below water, such as exists on land."

The Department of the Environment was trying to establish a one-stop procedure in cooperation with the crown estates, he said.

Britain's first offshore wind farm, in Blyth, Northumberland, starts generating 4mw of electricity in two weeks' time. David Still, general manager of AMEC Blyth Wind, said it had spent three years in laborious negotiations with planning bodies and the crown estates.

The issue is urgent since generating companies will be obliged from next spring to produce 10% of their electricity from renewable sources.

Mr Still said offshore wind farms needed to cover only 300sq km to meet 3% of the nation's electricity needs. "It's just a little drop in the ocean."

webTitle: Ivory Coast riots claim 10 more lives

fields.headline: Ivory Coast riots claim 10 more lives
fields.trailText: At least another 10 people were added to the Ivory Coast's rising death toll yesterday as anti-junta campaigners turned on each other, having driven the military leader, General Robert Guei, from power by a popular revolt.
fields.body:
At least another 10 people were added to the Ivory Coast's rising death toll yesterday as anti-junta campaigners turned on each other, having driven the military leader, General Robert Guei, from power by a popular revolt.

More than 60 people have been killed in three days of protests, and the defence chief of staff said yesterday that anyone breaking the curfew which will be in force until Monday would be shot on sight.

In the main city Abidjan, three mosques and a church were ransacked and set alight as supporters of the largely Christian Ivorian Popular Front (FPI) fought with their Muslim rivals, the Rally of the Republicans (RDR), to press home their candidates' claims to the presidency.

The electoral commission, which Gen Guei dissolved af ter the results began going against him on Sunday, said yesterday that the FPI leader, Laurent Gbagbo, had won more than 59% of the vote.

Gen Guei won about 32% and the turnout was 37%, the commission said.

But RDR supporters demanded new elections, on the grounds that their leader, the former prime minister Alassane Outtara, was barred by the supreme court from standing.

The latest 10 people killed included a child caught in the crossfire, a policeman, and three RDR activists who were burned alive as the two factions fought with guns and machetes.

Yesterday's violence followed a mob attack by Mr Gbagbo's supporters on Mr. Outtara's home. Mr Outtara later took refuge in the German embassy. Soldiers and armed police attacked both sets of protesters, leading observers to wonder which side, if any, the military was on.

fields.headline: Music hall lament
fields.trailText: It may seem to be a "cheerful old ballad" (Letters, October 24), but the classic version of I'll be Your Sweetheart is almost unbearably poignant. By a female music-hall singer impersonating a young boy, it's a recorded performance to equal Bessie Smith's Nobody Knows You or Schwarzkopf's Brahms Requiem. But who was she? Maybe one of your "older readers" (pace Mr Wilson) knows.

By a female music-hall singer impersonating a young boy, it's a recorded performance to equal Bessie Smith's Nobody Knows You or Schwarzkopf's Brahms Requiem. But who was she? Maybe one of your "older readers" (pace Mr Wilson) knows.
Tony Haynes
London

Re your front-page headline (October 26): "Rail: it's months of chaos". What's new?
Tom Booth
Hampstead Norreys, Berks

Another simple safety tip. How about a person carrying a red flag walking a few feet ahead of every train?
Malcolm Stewart
Edinburgh

How many more people are likely to die on our roads as they avoid the rail chaos?
David Tymm
London

I have been following the paralympics for the last week and I wonder why the ITN news is not covering this at all and why most of the newspapers, except yours, are not doing this either. Is this because people are embarrassed about disability or don't they value people with disabilities? They should be proud of them: we have won 27 gold medals.
Jack Ward-Golden (age 12)
Hayling Island, Hants

The Cooperative Wholesale Society (Letters, October 24) proclaims its ethical investment policy for consumers. Would that we in the Co-op could continue using our stores. Unfortunately the ethical Co-op is closing its main store in Worksop and has now announced its closing of the only substantial shop on our largest estate. Apparently both stores break even, but do not break even enough. So much for consumer choice.
John Mann
Worksop

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • In last week's New Statesman, immigration minister Barbara Roche had another crack at explaining why she is the refugees best friend. Bless her, she will therefore be particularly keen to help Mrs H, a refugee known to the Leytonstone Citizens Advice Bureau who lives on income support.
fields.body:
 In last week's New Statesman, immigration minister Barbara Roche had another crack at explaining why she is the refugees best friend. Bless her, she will therefore be particularly keen to help Mrs H, a refugee known to the Leytonstone Citizens Advice Bureau who lives on income support.

When her mother died here recently, she applied to the DSS for a funeral payment, but was refused under the "immediate family member test" banning payments to anyone with a close family member not on benefit. The intention is to get salaried people to pay, but Mrs H's two sisters, both unemployed asylum seekers, are not on benefits only because they receive degrading local authority vouchers instead of cash. Mrs H had to borrow money and is now in debt. Caring Barbara will want to re-imburse her and to correct this cretinous anomaly at once, and we look forward to having good news early next week.

 Meanwhile, good to see Barbara's colleague Alan Milburn, the health secretary, coping so smoothly with the BSE report press conference. What a busy week it's been, what with the spotlight on domestic violence, at least as arduous a problem for the health service as for the police and social services.

 News in the Sun that the Queen owns and adores a Bigmouth Billy Bass obliges us to boast of being the first to identify the constitutional importance of the crooning rubber fish: a report into Mr Tony's mirthful fascination appeared on July 26. Billy, it seems, is the new "You Don't Have to Be Mad to Work Here ..." sticker - a ready-made sense of humour for people with none of their own. Doubts have been raised about whether it was in fact the Queen, using a pseudonym, who won her Billy Bass in the Diary's Gerald Kaufman competition. If so, Her Majesty ought to be aware that particular gift was a freebie from Harrods.

 After another triumphant day for our fact checkers, two things need clearing up. The genius who gifted the mayoral nomination to Frank Dobson by arranging for the South London Co-op not to ballot members, and is now standing for deputy leader of the London Labour party, is Kathryn Smith, not Catherine Smith. Apologies to the real Catherine for that sloppiness. And Gareth Roberts was the first of many to tell us that Professor Stanley Unwin certainly did appear in a Carry On, as a property developer in Carry On Regardless.

 Speaking of which, 73 emails, letters and faxes with casting suggestions have now arrived - a miraculous reaction for a column very few read, and of which fewer take a blind bit of notice. My favourite so far is Charles Hawtrey for Cherie. As for the person who nominated Desert Orchid for a certain woman minister, this is the Guardian and we don't tolerate gratuitous equism.

 Thanks to Alastair Campbell's crusade against the press's obsession with trivia, a sea-change has taken place in political journalism. Under the entry for February 19 1992 in his new memoirs, Paddy Ashdown writes of a day just long enough after his affair had broken for interest to have dimmed. "Only one question on the Tricia Howard affair," recalls Old Pants of a press conference, "from Alastair Campbell of the Daily Mirror. He asked me a rather rude question (I can't remember what), to which I answered 'No' and moved on."

 An intriguing sign has been spotted on the reverse of "Do not disturb" in Liverpool's Moat House hotel. "Please display outside your room," it counsels, "if you require assistance in the unlikely event of a fire." And quite right. If you can't be bothered to put out the sign, the moment you smell smoke you deserve to fry.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: David Rennie and Sean O'Neill: an apology. In Media Monkey's Diary, page 7, Media, October 23, we referred to the Daily Telegraph's coverage of John Prescott's remarks about the sculptor, Henry Moore (October 17). Contrary to what we stated, Mr Rennie has not disowned the remarks he reported, which the deputy prime minister made in his hearing. Mr Prescott confirmed his comments at a press conference the following day. We further apologise to Mr O'Neill for wrongly suggesting that he was guilty of fabricating the quotes attributed to him and to both journalists for the offence caused.
fields.body:
David Rennie and Sean O'Neill: an apology. In Media Monkey's Diary, page 7, Media, October 23, we referred to the Daily Telegraph's coverage of John Prescott's remarks about the sculptor, Henry Moore (October 17). Contrary to what we stated, Mr Rennie has not disowned the remarks he reported, which the deputy prime minister made in his hearing. Mr Prescott confirmed his comments at a press conference the following day. We further apologise to Mr O'Neill for wrongly suggesting that he was guilty of fabricating the quotes attributed to him and to both journalists for the offence caused.

In a report headed Georgian plane crash kills 82, page 15, October 26, we confused Abkhazia and Adzharia. The plane crashed near Batumi, the capital of the autonomous Georgian region of Adzharia. Batumi is a long way south of Abkhazia, the "breakaway" republic which is no longer ruled by Georgia. The capital of Abkhazia is Sukhum.

The Maternity and Parental Leave Act 1999, referred to in our report, Secretary "sacked for going to ill son", page 8, yesterday, does not exist. We should have referred to the maternity and parental leave (MPL) regulations.

In a report, Exchange presses for end to stamp duty, page 30 (Finance), yesterday, we said stamp duty was 0.25% on each share purchase. We should have said 0.5%.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Letters: Opinion on psychologist's court case

fields.headline: Good to talk
fields.trailText: We are all disturbed by the shocking case of the shamed psychologist who will be free to work again even though found guilty of sexual misconduct against a client (Psychologist in affair with client can still practise, October 26). A moment's thought, however, shows it is futile to regulate just one section of the talking therapies. What would otherwise stop a miscreant psychologist from turning up again as a psychotherapist?
fields.body:
We are all disturbed by the shocking case of the shamed psychologist who will be free to work again even though found guilty of sexual misconduct against a client (Psychologist in affair with client can still practise, October 26). A moment's thought, however, shows it is futile to regulate just one section of the talking therapies. What would otherwise stop a miscreant psychologist from turning up again as a psychotherapist?

The government must regulate the entire field - mainstream counselling, psychology, psychotherapy, psychoanalysis - for public protection. We have been asking for this for a long time and it is basically the prime minister's responsibility. When will that be, Mr Blair?

Phillip Hodson
Fellow, British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy

fields.headline: I warned about BSE
fields.trailText: On February 15 1989, a fortnight before the Southwood report about BSE was published (Scathing BSE report, October 25), the Guardian printed my letter warning that there was a human risk from this new disease. On the day that report was published (February 27 1989), I appeared on the TV news, warning that the infected tissues of our cattle - the brains - were going into our foods and must immediately be banned. I even uttered the words "some of us may be incubating it already".
fields.body:
On February 15 1989, a fortnight before the Southwood report about BSE was published (Scathing BSE report, October 25), the Guardian printed my letter warning that there was a human risk from this new disease. On the day that report was published (February 27 1989), I appeared on the TV news, warning that the infected tissues of our cattle - the brains - were going into our foods and must immediately be banned. I even uttered the words "some of us may be incubating it already".

On March 2 1989, the Guardian printed another warning letter from me. And although the Ministry of Agriculture had protected cattle from catching the disease by banning their infective feed in July 1988, they failed to do the same for humans for more than another year - November 9 1989. If the ministry had banned cattle brains from our meat pies at the beginning of 1989, there would have been fewer tragic victims of vCJD.

I was a very senior, just retired and therefore independent, neuropathologist. I was familiar with CJD both at the bedside and in the laboratory and had read the all-important scientific work done on the sheep disease, scrapie, which had now got into our cattle. I knew that whereas sheep's brains were left inside the skulls and finished up in cattle rations, cattle brains were always removed in the abattoirs to be added to human foods. They should have listened. Why did they not?
Helen Grant
London

Amid the apologies, I seem to have missed any expression of regret to those honourable scientists who were so shamefully rubbished.
Simon Gardner
Leighton Buzzard, Beds

fields.headline: Where does Blair really stand on the environment?
fields.trailText: One element missing from the prime minister's speech on the environment was a failure to understand that the huge majority of the natural environment in the UK is on land managed by farmers (Blair calls for joint action on green issues, October 25).
fields.body:
One element missing from the prime minister's speech on the environment was a failure to understand that the huge majority of the natural environment in the UK is on land managed by farmers (Blair calls for joint action on green issues, October 25).

Whilst the captains of industry can ensure that their businesses act to reduce the negative impacts of their activities, there is little that they can do to provide seriously large environmental gains.

But there are a few industries, notably farming and to a lesser extent forestry and aggregate extraction, whose activities can provide major positive environmental gains. Given that agriculture has been in the news recently for other reasons and bearing in mind the prime minister's emphasis in his speech on the need to create partnerships, could he not address these two very real and urgent countryside problems - environmental and economic?
Philip Merricks
Farming & Wildlife Advisory Group

Mr Blair is once again blowing in the wind of perceived public opinion, and government policy now seems to be driven more by the muddled thinking of a few non-scientific minority pressure groups than by the views of the public as a whole or, indeed, by the considered opinion of the scientific community. Doubling the tax burden - as the government has done via various stealth taxes like the aggregates tax - on industry will have a negligible effect on a global problem. And the exploitation of the public's concern for the environment is outrageous opportunism.
Robert Durward
British Aggregates Association

Tony Grayling's call for cuts in road tax as opposed to cuts in fuel duty is a sensible one (More mileage, October 24). Much steeper cuts are needed in road tax for the most efficient cars, paid for by increases in road tax for the least efficient "gas guzzlers". As the article rightly states, this would leave most motorists far better off, especially those in rural areas. The Conservatives' policy of a 3p cut in fuel duty would leave the average motorist just 59p a week better off.

And Liberal Democrats have also called for sizeable cuts in hauliers' VED paid for from the introduction of a "vignette" system whereby hauliers pay according to how long they use certain roads. This would mean non-UK hauliers paying for using UK roads for the first time and would help to counter arguments about competition.
Don Foster MP

The rich can manipulate and change their surroundings. This usually results in the degradation of the surroundings of the poor. The poor are trapped in that depleted environment. An example is the current policy of supermarkets, like Safeways, offering customers cheap petrol if they spend over £40 in their store. Why is there no bus or train subsidy to help poor people who have no car?
Dr Colin Guthrie
Glasgow

webTitle: Letters: RTS management should be investigated

fields.headline: Media bosses in the dock
fields.trailText: The crime committed against journalists and media workers during the Nato air campaign against Yugoslavia last year had two distinct elements (The ultimate sacrifice, Media, October 23). First, was the decision to bomb Radio Television Serbia, a civilian installation, on April 23. Nato's action, in which 16 people died, flouted Geneva Convention protocols protecting civilians and also broke a written undertaking to journalists only days earlier that Nato had no intention of attacking media targets.
fields.body:
The crime committed against journalists and media workers during the Nato air campaign against Yugoslavia last year had two distinct elements (The ultimate sacrifice, Media, October 23). First, was the decision to bomb Radio Television Serbia, a civilian installation, on April 23. Nato's action, in which 16 people died, flouted Geneva Convention protocols protecting civilians and also broke a written undertaking to journalists only days earlier that Nato had no intention of attacking media targets.

The second element, as reported by Jonathan Steele, concerns the decision by RTS management to keep people working knowing that an attack was due. Foreign news crews using the technical facilities at the RTS building the evening before the attack were tipped off. As they packed their bags and left, panic spread among the RTS staff still on duty. They were told to stay at their posts. They were the only civilians working in a targeted area during the conflict forced to keep working or face dismissal. The new political administration in Belgrade should clear the air by carrying out a full investigation into this incident.

The people in charge at the time should be held accountable. Dragoljub Milanovic, RTS general manager, and Milorad Komrakov, the editorial director, should particularly be questioned. Komrakov until recently, was the president of the Press Association of Serbia. These men may have been guilty of sacrificing the lives of junior colleagues to score a propaganda point for Milosevic. At the least, their actions were reckless with scandalous disregard for the safety of their workforce.
Aidan White
International Federation of Journalists

fields.headline: What the Michigan papers say
fields.standfirst: Michigan was solidly Democrat in the last two presidential elections, but it's a toss-up this time around. Derek Brown looks over what the state papers are saying
fields.trailText: Michigan was solidly Democrat in the last two presidential elections, but it's a toss-up this time around. Derek Brown looks over what the state papers are saying.
fields.body:
Michigan is not the biggest prize, in terms of electoral college votes, but in this neck-and neck race it offers riches beyond count. In the last two presidential contests, it was solid for the Democrats, but this time it is called a toss-up state, with all the polls suggesting the race is too close to call.

Little wonder, then, that George W Bush is campaigning hard in the state, while campaign workers for Al Gore have launched a so-called phone blitz of Michigan voters, bombarding them with recorded messages.

The phone campaign could, in fact, backfire. Republicans, who are hopping mad about them, hope they will antagonise voters.

In one of the calls, Charlotte Cherry of Houston, Texas, says that "Governor Bush has accepted $1.3m (£0.9m) from corporate polluters, and he's allowed them to keep polluting while my kids suffer." Another Texas caller says Bush signed legislation weakening nursing home regulations.

Actor Ed Asner, a strong Gore supporters, has also recorded calls criticising Bush. He warns listeners that "George W Bush has a proposal that would undermine Social Security, even scuttling current benefits."

So far, there is little evidence that the phone campaign has swayed voters either way. The Detroit Free Press today reports that in the state senatorial contest, the Democrat candidate has come from 10% behind two weeks ago, and is now running neck and neck with the Republican incumbent.

There is better news for Bush in a fun little news-in-brief about the sales of Halloween masks, which are said to mirror the Presidential election results back to 1972. This year Bush masks are outselling Gore ones, 58% to 42%.

The Detroit News also runs a poll showing Gore on level pegging with Bush at 42%, with 13% still undecided. But in Detroit itself, it says, Gore is leading by a whopping 80% to 7%.

Outside the city, Michigan state is much more equally divided. The Daily Telegram of Lenawee County eschews all mention of the Presidential race, but devotes a long editorial in praise of the local Republican candidate for re-election to the House of Representatives.

The Holland Sentinel has already decided who will next inhabit the White House. It features a syndicated column by Cal Thomas, which starts: "President George Bush had it in 1992. Bob Dole had it in 1996. Now Al Gore seems to be getting it. It is the political death pall that comes over a presidential candidate when he realizes he probably will lose the election."

But the bias is not all one way. The Michigan Daily, based in Ann Arbor, highlights the state senatorial contest. It suggests that the steady improvement in the poll fortunes of the Democrat candidate could be good news for Al Gore.

The Macomb Daily focuses on the state legislature elections, endorsing five Democrat candidates and three Republicans.
